title: Replication Study: Federated Text-Driven Prompt Generation for Vision-Language Models
summary: Vision-language models like CLIP have demonstrated remarkable zero-shot capabilities, yet their adaptation to federated learning scenarios presents significant challenges, particularly regarding generalization to unseen classes. The original FedTPG paper \cite{Qiu2024} addresses this limitation by introducing a text driven prompt generation network that dynamically creates prompts conditioned on class names, enabling better cross-class generalization in federated settings. In this work, we present a faithful replication study of FedTPG, evaluating the pre-trained model on six diverse vision datasets: Caltech101, Oxford Flowers, FGVC Aircraft, Oxford Pets, Food-101, and DTD. Our evaluation achieves results within 0.2\% of the original paper's reported accuracies, with an average accuracy of 74.58\% on seen (base) classes and 76.00\% on unseen (new) classes, demonstrating a +1.43 percentage point improvement in generalization. These results validate the original paper's core claims: (1) text-driven prompt generation enables superior generalization to unseen classes compared to static prompt learning methods, and (2) federated training of prompt generators maintains high performance across diverse visual domains without sharing private data. Our successful replication confirms the robustness and reproducibility of the FedTPG approach.

AI.tldr: A replication study of FedTPG confirms that text-driven prompt generation in federated CLIP-style models reliably improves generalization to unseen classes, reproducing the original results across six datasets with comparable accuracy.
AI.motivation: Adaptation of vision-language models like CLIP to federated learning is challenging, especially for generalizing to unseen classes while preserving privacy. Prior static prompt methods underperform on cross-class generalization; this study aims to verify FedTPG’s claimed advantages and reproducibility.
AI.method: Faithfully replicate and evaluate the FedTPG pre-trained text-driven prompt generation model across six diverse datasets (Caltech101, Oxford Flowers, FGVC Aircraft, Oxford Pets, Food-101, DTD), measuring performance on seen (base) versus unseen (new) classes and comparing with the original paper’s reported accuracies.
AI.result: Replication achieves accuracies within 0.2% of the original; average accuracy is 74.58% on seen classes and 76.00% on unseen classes, yielding a +1.43 percentage point improvement for unseen generalization.
AI.conclusion: The replication validates FedTPG’s core claims: (1) text-driven prompt generation outperforms static prompt learning for unseen-class generalization, and (2) federated training of prompt generators preserves strong cross-domain performance without sharing private data, demonstrating robustness and reproducibility.

title: A Patient-Specific Digital Twin for Adaptive Radiotherapy of Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
summary: Radiotherapy continues to become more precise and data dense, with current treatment regimens generating high frequency imaging and dosimetry streams ideally suited for AI driven temporal modeling to characterize how normal tissues evolve with time. Each fraction in biologically guided radiotherapy(BGRT) treated non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients records new metabolic, anatomical, and dose information. However, clinical decision making is largely informed by static, population based NTCP models which overlook the dynamic, unique biological trajectories encoded in sequential data. We developed COMPASS (Comprehensive Personalized Assessment System) for safe radiotherapy, functioning as a temporal digital twin architecture utilizing per fraction PET, CT, dosiomics, radiomics, and cumulative biologically equivalent dose (BED) kinetics to model normal tissue biology as a dynamic time series process. A GRU autoencoder was employed to learn organ specific latent trajectories, which were classified via logistic regression to predict eventual CTCAE grade 1 or higher toxicity. Eight NSCLC patients undergoing BGRT contributed to the 99 organ fraction observations covering 24 organ trajectories (spinal cord, heart, and esophagus). Despite the small cohort, intensive temporal phenotyping allowed for comprehensive analysis of individual dose response dynamics. Our findings revealed a viable AI driven early warning window, as increasing risk ratings occurred from several fractions before clinical toxicity. The dense BED driven representation revealed biologically relevant spatial dose texture characteristics that occur before toxicity and are averaged out with traditional volume based dosimetry. COMPASS establishes a proof of concept for AI enabled adaptive radiotherapy, where treatment is guided by a continually updated digital twin that tracks each patients evolving biological response.

AI.tldr: Proof-of-concept digital twin (COMPASS) uses per‑fraction PET/CT, radiomics/dosiomics, and BED kinetics with a GRU‑autoencoder + logistic regression to model organ trajectories in BGRT NSCLC and predict CTCAE≥1 toxicity several fractions before onset, revealing spatial dose‑texture signals missed by volume dosimetry.
AI.motivation: Radiotherapy now produces rich, high‑frequency imaging and dose streams, yet decisions rely on static, population NTCP models that ignore patient‑specific temporal biology. There is a need to exploit sequential data to anticipate normal‑tissue toxicity and enable adaptive treatment.
AI.method: Developed COMPASS, a temporal digital twin integrating per‑fraction PET, CT, radiomics, dosiomics, and cumulative BED kinetics. A GRU autoencoder learned organ‑specific latent trajectories (spinal cord, heart, esophagus), which were classified via logistic regression to predict eventual CTCAE grade ≥1 toxicity. Dataset: 8 NSCLC BGRT patients, 99 organ‑fraction observations, 24 organ trajectories.
AI.result: Risk scores increased several fractions before clinical toxicity, defining an early warning window. BED‑driven latent features captured biologically relevant spatial dose‑texture patterns predictive of toxicity that are averaged out by volume‑based dosimetry. Despite a very small cohort, intensive temporal phenotyping enabled analysis of individualized dose‑response dynamics.
AI.conclusion: COMPASS provides a feasibility demonstration that a continually updated, patient‑specific digital twin can anticipate normal‑tissue injury and support AI‑enabled adaptive radiotherapy. Findings motivate larger, multi‑site validation, calibration for clinical use, and prospective testing to assess impact on treatment adaptation and outcomes.

title: Scaling Ultrasound Volumetric Reconstruction via Mobile Augmented Reality
summary: Accurate volumetric characterization of lesions is essential for oncologic diagnosis, risk stratification, and treatment planning. While imaging modalities such as Computed Tomography provide high-quality 3D data, 2D ultrasound (2D-US) remains the preferred first-line modality for breast and thyroid imaging due to cost, portability, and safety factors. However, volume estimates derived from 2D-US suffer from high inter-user variability even among experienced clinicians. Existing 3D ultrasound (3D-US) solutions use specialized probes or external tracking hardware, but such configurations increase costs and diminish portability, constraining widespread clinical use. To address these limitations, we present Mobile Augmented Reality Volumetric Ultrasound (MARVUS), a resource-efficient system designed to increase accessibility to accurate and reproducible volumetric assessment. MARVUS is interoperable with conventional ultrasound (US) systems, using a foundation model to enhance cross-specialty generalization while minimizing hardware requirements relative to current 3D-US solutions. In a user study involving experienced clinicians performing measurements on breast phantoms, MARVUS yielded a substantial improvement in volume estimation accuracy (mean difference: 0.469 cm3) with reduced inter-user variability (mean difference: 0.417 cm3). Additionally, we prove that augmented reality (AR) visualizations enhance objective performance metrics and clinician-reported usability. Collectively, our findings suggests that MARVUS can enhance US-based cancer screening, diagnostic workflows, and treatment planning in a scalable, cost-conscious, and resource-efficient manner. Usage video demonstration available (https://youtu.be/m4llYcZpqmM).

AI.tldr: MARVUS is a mobile AR–assisted system that enables accurate, reproducible 3D volumetric assessment from conventional 2D ultrasound, improving accuracy and reducing inter-user variability in phantom studies without specialized 3D probes or tracking hardware.
AI.motivation: 2D ultrasound is the first-line modality for breast/thyroid due to cost and portability, but volumetric estimates are inconsistent across users. Existing 3D-US solutions need specialized probes or external tracking, raising costs and limiting scalability. There is a need for low-cost, portable, and reliable volumetric measurement.
AI.method: Develop Mobile Augmented Reality Volumetric Ultrasound (MARVUS), interoperable with standard US systems. It uses a foundation model to support cross-specialty generalization and mobile AR for spatial guidance/visualization, aiming to reconstruct or estimate volumes from freehand 2D sweeps with minimal hardware. Evaluated via a user study with experienced clinicians on breast phantoms, comparing accuracy, inter-user variability, and usability with/without AR.
AI.result: MARVUS improved volume estimation accuracy (mean difference 0.469 cm³) and reduced inter-user variability (mean difference 0.417 cm³). AR visualizations further improved objective metrics and clinician-reported usability.
AI.conclusion: MARVUS can make accurate volumetric assessment more accessible and consistent in US-based cancer screening, diagnosis, and treatment planning, offering a scalable and cost-conscious alternative to traditional 3D-US solutions.

title: ReportLogic: Evaluating Logical Quality in Deep Research Reports
summary: Users increasingly rely on Large Language Models (LLMs) for Deep Research, using them to synthesize diverse sources into structured reports that support understanding and action. In this context, the practical reliability of such reports hinges on logical quality: whether the report's claims and arguments are explicitly supported and can be trusted as a basis for downstream use, rather than merely appearing fluent or informative. However, current evaluation frameworks largely overlook this requirement. To bridge this gap, we introduce ReportLogic, a benchmark that quantifies report-level logical quality through a reader-centric lens of auditability. Specifically, ReportLogic adopts a hierarchical taxonomy that evaluates whether readers can (1) trace an on-topic report structure with a unified analytical arc (Macro-Logic), (2) understand the progression with necessary context (Expositional-Logic), and (3) verify conclusions via explicit claim--support (Structural-Logic). Based on this taxonomy, we construct a human-annotated rubric-guided dataset and train an open-source LogicJudge for scalable evaluation. We further evaluate judge robustness via adversarial attacks, showing that off-the-shelf LLM judges are frequently influenced by superficial cues (e.g., verbosity), and reasoning modes can mask broken support relations. Overall, our results provide actionable guidance for building more robust logic evaluators and improving the logical reliability of LLM-generated reports.

AI.tldr: ReportLogic is a benchmark and evaluator (LogicJudge) for measuring the logical quality of LLM-generated research reports via a reader-centric notion of auditability across structure, exposition, and claim–support links.
AI.motivation: LLM-written reports can sound fluent yet lack trustworthy, explicitly supported reasoning. Existing evaluations miss whether readers can trace arguments, understand context, and verify claims, which undermines downstream use in “deep research.”
AI.method: Define a hierarchical taxonomy of report logic—Macro-Logic (on-topic, unified analytical arc), Expositional-Logic (coherent progression and necessary context), and Structural-Logic (explicit claim–evidence links). Build a human-annotated, rubric-guided dataset aligned to this taxonomy and train an open-source judge (LogicJudge) for scalable scoring. Probe judge robustness with adversarial attacks and confounds (e.g., verbosity, reasoning mode).
AI.result: Off-the-shelf LLM judges are vulnerable to superficial cues and can be misled by chain-of-thought style reasoning that masks broken support relations. The rubric-trained LogicJudge better resists such attacks and provides more reliable logic assessments. The benchmark reveals common failure modes and provides diagnostics for evaluators.
AI.conclusion: Auditable, taxonomy-grounded evaluation improves the reliability of judging logical quality in LLM-generated reports. ReportLogic and LogicJudge offer practical tools and insights for building more robust logic evaluators and, ultimately, for improving the logical reliability of LLM-produced analyses.

title: Mitigating Shortcut Learning via Feature Disentanglement in Medical Imaging: A Benchmark Study
summary: Although deep learning models in medical imaging often achieve excellent classification performance, they can rely on shortcut learning, exploiting spurious correlations or confounding factors that are not causally related to the target task. This poses risks in clinical settings, where models must generalize across institutions, populations, and acquisition conditions. Feature disentanglement is a promising approach to mitigate shortcut learning by separating task-relevant information from confounder-related features in latent representations. In this study, we systematically evaluated feature disentanglement methods for mitigating shortcuts in medical imaging, including adversarial learning and latent space splitting based on dependence minimization. We assessed classification performance and disentanglement quality using latent space analyses across one artificial and two medical datasets with natural and synthetic confounders. We also examined robustness under varying levels of confounding and compared computational efficiency across methods. We found that shortcut mitigation methods improved classification performance under strong spurious correlations during training. Latent space analyses revealed differences in representation quality not captured by classification metrics, highlighting the strengths and limitations of each method. Model reliance on shortcuts depended on the degree of confounding in the training data. The best-performing models combine data-centric rebalancing with model-centric disentanglement, achieving stronger and more robust shortcut mitigation than rebalancing alone while maintaining similar computational efficiency.

AI.tldr: Systematic evaluation shows that feature disentanglement (adversarial and dependence-minimization latent splitting) mitigates shortcut learning in medical imaging, especially under strong spurious correlations, with best robustness when combined with data rebalancing and without notable extra compute.
AI.motivation: Deep medical-imaging models often exploit spurious, non-causal correlations (shortcuts) that fail to generalize across sites, populations, and acquisition settings, creating clinical risk. Separating task-relevant from confounder-related features (feature disentanglement) is a candidate remedy that needs systematic assessment.
AI.method: Benchmark adversarial learning and dependence-minimization latent-space splitting for disentanglement. Evaluate on one artificial and two medical datasets containing natural and synthetic confounders. Measure both classification performance and disentanglement quality via latent-space analyses. Vary confounding strength and compare computational efficiency across methods.
AI.result: Disentanglement methods improved classification when training data had strong spurious correlations. Latent-space analyses exposed representation differences not visible in standard accuracy metrics. Model reliance on shortcuts scaled with confounding strength. The strongest, most robust mitigation came from combining data-centric rebalancing with model-centric disentanglement, achieving gains comparable in compute to rebalancing alone.
AI.conclusion: Feature disentanglement is effective for shortcut mitigation but must be paired with data rebalancing for consistent robustness. Sole reliance on accuracy is inadequate; representation-level diagnostics are necessary. The combined approach yields robust performance without significant computational overhead and is sensitive to confounding levels in training data.

title: ConfSpec: Efficient Step-Level Speculative Reasoning via Confidence-Gated Verification
summary: Chain-of-Thought reasoning significantly improves the performance of large language models on complex tasks, but incurs high inference latency due to long generation traces. Step-level speculative reasoning aims to mitigate this cost, yet existing approaches face a long-standing trade-off among accuracy, inference speed, and resource efficiency. We propose ConfSpec, a confidence-gated cascaded verification framework that resolves this trade-off. Our key insight is an asymmetry between generation and verification: while generating a correct reasoning step requires substantial model capacity, step-level verification is a constrained discriminative task for which small draft models are well-calibrated within their competence range, enabling high-confidence draft decisions to be accepted directly while selectively escalating uncertain cases to the large target model. Evaluation across diverse workloads shows that ConfSpec achieves up to 2.24$\times$ end-to-end speedups while matching target-model accuracy. Our method requires no external judge models and is orthogonal to token-level speculative decoding, enabling further multiplicative acceleration.

AI.tldr: ConfSpec is a confidence-gated, cascaded step verification framework that uses small, well-calibrated draft models to accept high-confidence reasoning steps and escalates uncertain ones to a large model, yielding up to 2.24× end-to-end speedups while matching target-model accuracy and remaining compatible with token-level speculative decoding.
AI.motivation: Chain-of-Thought improves performance but causes long latencies. Existing step-level speculative methods struggle to balance accuracy, speed, and resource use. The authors exploit an asymmetry: generating correct steps needs high capacity, but verifying a step is a simpler discriminative task that smaller models can do reliably within their competence.
AI.method: Use a cascade where a small verifier (draft model) assesses confidence on each reasoning step. If confidence is high, the step is accepted; otherwise, the case is escalated to the large target model. The approach relies on calibration of the small model’s confidence, requires no separate external judge, and can be composed with token-level speculative decoding for multiplicative gains.
AI.result: Across diverse workloads, ConfSpec matches the large target model’s accuracy while delivering up to 2.24× end-to-end speedups. It reduces reliance on additional judge models and improves resource efficiency, while remaining orthogonal to token-level speculative decoding.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging generation–verification asymmetry with confidence gating resolves the speed–accuracy–efficiency trade-off in step-level speculative reasoning, enabling faster Chain-of-Thought inference without accuracy degradation and stacking with other acceleration methods.

title: On the Dynamics of Observation and Semantics
summary: A dominant paradigm in visual intelligence treats semantics as a static property of latent representations, assuming that meaning can be discovered through geometric proximity in high dimensional embedding spaces. In this work, we argue that this view is physically incomplete. We propose that intelligence is not a passive mirror of reality but a property of a physically realizable agent, a system bounded by finite memory, finite compute, and finite energy interacting with a high entropy environment. We formalize this interaction through the kinematic structure of an Observation Semantics Fiber Bundle, where raw sensory observation data (the fiber) is projected onto a low entropy causal semantic manifold (the base). We prove that for any bounded agent, the thermodynamic cost of information processing (Landauer's Principle) imposes a strict limit on the complexity of internal state transitions. We term this limit the Semantic Constant B. From these physical constraints, we derive the necessity of symbolic structure. We show that to model a combinatorial world within the bound B, the semantic manifold must undergo a phase transition, it must crystallize into a discrete, compositional, and factorized form. Thus, language and logic are not cultural artifacts but ontological necessities the solid state of information required to prevent thermal collapse. We conclude that understanding is not the recovery of a hidden latent variable, but the construction of a causal quotient that renders the world algorithmically compressible and causally predictable.

AI.tldr: Argues that physical limits on computation force semantics to crystallize into discrete, symbolic structures; proposes a fiber-bundle formalism, defines a semantic complexity bound B from Landauer’s principle, and claims a phase transition from continuous observations to a discrete, compositional causal manifold that enables compression and prediction.
AI.motivation: The prevailing view that semantic meaning is recoverable from geometric proximity in high-dimensional continuous embeddings ignores physical constraints of real agents (finite energy, memory, compute) operating in high-entropy environments. A physically grounded account is needed to explain why symbolic structure persists and succeeds.
AI.method: Provides a theoretical framework: (1) models perception as an Observation Semantics Fiber Bundle, projecting high-entropy sensory data (fiber) onto a low-entropy causal semantic manifold (base); (2) invokes Landauer’s principle to bound computation, defining a Semantic Constant B that limits internal state transition complexity; (3) derives, via thermodynamic and combinatorial arguments, that efficient modeling under B requires discrete, factorized, compositional representations—i.e., symbols.
AI.result: Claims a proof that bounded agents face a strict limit B on semantic processing complexity. From this, shows that representing a combinatorial world within B requires a phase transition in the semantic manifold to a discrete, modular code. Concludes that language/logic are necessary, not contingent cultural choices, for maintaining computational viability (“preventing thermal collapse”).
AI.conclusion: Understanding is reframed as constructing a causal quotient—coarse-grained, algorithmically compressible, and causally predictive structure—rather than uncovering static latent variables in continuous spaces. Hence, symbolic semantics emerge as an ontological requirement from physical and causal constraints.

title: A Computer Vision Framework for Multi-Class Detection and Tracking in Soccer Broadcast Footage
comment: Presented at the Robyn Rafferty Mathias Reseaerch Conference. Additional Information available at: https://DGT-International.com
summary: Clubs with access to expensive multi-camera setups or GPS tracking systems gain a competitive advantage through detailed data, whereas lower-budget teams are often unable to collect similar information. This paper examines whether such data can instead be extracted directly from standard broadcast footage using a single-camera computer vision pipeline. This project develops an end-to-end system that combines a YOLO object detector with the ByteTrack tracking algorithm to identify and track players, referees, goalkeepers, and the ball throughout a match. Experimental results show that the pipeline achieves high performance in detecting and tracking players and officials, with strong precision, recall, and mAP50 scores, while ball detection remains the primary challenge. Despite this limitation, our findings demonstrate that AI can extract meaningful player-level spatial information from a single broadcast camera. By reducing reliance on specialized hardware, the proposed approach enables colleges, academies, and amateur clubs to adopt scalable, data-driven analysis methods previously accessible only to professional teams, highlighting the potential for affordable computer vision-based soccer analytics.

AI.tldr: A single-camera pipeline (YOLO + ByteTrack) can reliably detect and track players and officials from broadcast soccer video, offering a low-cost alternative to multi-camera/GPS systems, though ball detection remains challenging.
AI.motivation: Expensive multi-camera or GPS tracking systems create data inequities between well-funded and lower-budget teams; the work seeks to democratize soccer analytics by extracting similar insights from standard broadcast footage.
AI.method: Build an end-to-end computer vision system that applies a YOLO detector and ByteTrack tracker to identify and track players, referees, goalkeepers, and the ball across a match; evaluate with precision, recall, and mAP50 metrics.
AI.result: High detection and tracking performance for players and officials (strong precision, recall, and mAP50). Ball detection is notably less reliable and is the main limitation.
AI.conclusion: Meaningful player-level spatial information can be obtained from a single broadcast camera, reducing reliance on specialized hardware and enabling scalable, affordable analytics for colleges, academies, and amateur clubs.

title: INSURE-Dial: A Phase-Aware Conversational Dataset \& Benchmark for Compliance Verification and Phase Detection
comment: Accepted to the 19th Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics (EACL 2026)
summary: Administrative phone tasks drain roughly 1 trillion USD annually from U.S. healthcare, with over 500 million insurance-benefit verification calls manually handled in 2024. We introduce INSURE-Dial, to our knowledge the first public benchmark for developing and assessing compliance-aware voice agents for phase-aware call auditing with span-based compliance verification. The corpus includes 50 de-identified, AI-initiated calls with live insurance representatives (mean 71 turns/call) and 1,000 synthetically generated calls that mirror the same workflow. All calls are annotated with a phase-structured JSON schema covering IVR navigation, patient identification, coverage status, medication checks (up to two drugs), and agent identification (CRN), and each phase is labeled for Information and Procedural compliance under explicit ask/answer logic. We define two novel evaluation tasks: (1) Phase Boundary Detection (span segmentation under phase-specific acceptance rules) and (2) Compliance Verification (IC/PC decisions given fixed spans). Per-phase scores are strong across small, low-latency baselines, but end-to-end reliability is constrained by span-boundary errors. On real calls, full-call exact segmentation is low, showing a gap between conversational fluency and audit-grade evidence.

AI.tldr: INSURE-Dial is a new public benchmark and corpus for auditing insurance-benefit verification calls, with phase-structured annotations enabling span-based compliance checks. It defines tasks for phase boundary detection and compliance verification; small, low-latency baselines do well per phase but falter end-to-end due to segmentation errors, revealing a gap between conversational fluency and audit-grade evidence.
AI.motivation: U.S. healthcare loses vast resources to administrative phone work (≈$1T/year; >500M verification calls in 2024). There is no public, standardized way to develop and evaluate voice agents that must both converse and produce verifiable, compliance-grade evidence across multi-step call workflows.
AI.method: Construct a corpus of 50 de-identified, AI-initiated real calls with insurers (avg. 71 turns) plus 1,000 synthetic calls reflecting the same workflow. Annotate each call using a phase-structured JSON schema (IVR navigation, patient ID, coverage status, medication checks up to two drugs, and agent ID/CRN). For each phase, mark Information and Procedural compliance via explicit ask/answer logic. Define two evaluation tasks: (1) Phase Boundary Detection (span segmentation under phase-specific acceptance rules) and (2) Compliance Verification (IC/PC decisions given fixed spans). Evaluate small, low-latency baseline systems.
AI.result: Baselines achieve strong per-phase performance but show low full-call exact segmentation on real calls. End-to-end reliability is primarily limited by span-boundary (segmentation) errors, which hinder production of audit-grade evidence even when conversational quality appears adequate.
AI.conclusion: INSURE-Dial provides a needed benchmark for compliance-aware voice agents in healthcare insurance verification. Current systems are bottlenecked by precise phase segmentation; improving boundary detection and robust evidence extraction is critical. Results also suggest a realism gap between synthetic and real calls and highlight the challenge of turning fluent conversation into verifiable compliance artifacts.

title: Hierarchical Reward Design from Language: Enhancing Alignment of Agent Behavior with Human Specifications
comment: Extended version of an identically-titled paper accepted at AAMAS 2026
summary: When training artificial intelligence (AI) to perform tasks, humans often care not only about whether a task is completed but also how it is performed. As AI agents tackle increasingly complex tasks, aligning their behavior with human-provided specifications becomes critical for responsible AI deployment. Reward design provides a direct channel for such alignment by translating human expectations into reward functions that guide reinforcement learning (RL). However, existing methods are often too limited to capture nuanced human preferences that arise in long-horizon tasks. Hence, we introduce Hierarchical Reward Design from Language (HRDL): a problem formulation that extends classical reward design to encode richer behavioral specifications for hierarchical RL agents. We further propose Language to Hierarchical Rewards (L2HR) as a solution to HRDL. Experiments show that AI agents trained with rewards designed via L2HR not only complete tasks effectively but also better adhere to human specifications. Together, HRDL and L2HR advance the research on human-aligned AI agents.

AI.tldr: Proposes a language-driven framework (HRDL) and method (L2HR) that translate natural-language specifications into hierarchical reward functions, enabling RL agents to both complete tasks and follow nuanced human-preferred behaviors more closely.
AI.motivation: As AI tackles long-horizon, complex tasks, stakeholders care about how tasks are accomplished, not just completion. Classical reward design struggles to encode nuanced, process-oriented human preferences, creating a need for richer, structured alignment mechanisms.
AI.method: Define Hierarchical Reward Design from Language (HRDL), extending classical reward design to hierarchical RL settings. Introduce Language to Hierarchical Rewards (L2HR), which maps natural-language behavioral specifications into reward functions distributed across hierarchy levels to guide both high-level plans and low-level actions.
AI.result: Experiments indicate that agents trained with L2HR-derived rewards effectively complete tasks and more faithfully adhere to human-provided specifications than with standard approaches.
AI.conclusion: Encoding human intent via language into hierarchical rewards improves alignment in complex, long-horizon RL, suggesting a practical path toward more controllable, human-aligned AI agents.

title: Suppression or Deletion: A Restoration-Based Representation-Level Analysis of Machine Unlearning
summary: As pretrained models are increasingly shared on the web, ensuring that models can forget or delete sensitive, copyrighted, or private information upon request has become crucial. Machine unlearning has been proposed to address this challenge. However, current evaluations for unlearning methods rely on output-based metrics, which cannot verify whether information is completely deleted or merely suppressed at the representation level, where suppression is insufficient for true unlearning. To address this gap, we propose a novel restoration-based analysis framework that uses Sparse Autoencoders to identify class-specific expert features in intermediate layers and applies inference-time steering to quantitatively distinguish between suppression and deletion. Applying our framework to 12 major unlearning methods in image classification tasks, we find that most methods achieve high restoration rates of unlearned information, indicating that they only suppress information at the decision-boundary level, while preserving semantic features in intermediate representations. Notably, even retraining from pretrained checkpoints shows high restoration, revealing that robust semantic features inherited from pretraining are not removed by retraining. These results demonstrate that representation-level retention poses significant risks overlooked by output-based metrics, highlighting the need for new unlearning evaluation criteria. We propose new evaluation guidelines that prioritize representation-level verification, especially for privacy-critical applications in the era of pre-trained models.

AI.tldr: They introduce a restoration-based evaluation that probes intermediate representations with Sparse Autoencoders and inference-time steering to tell whether “unlearned” information is actually deleted or merely suppressed. Across 12 image-classification unlearning methods (including retraining from pretrained checkpoints), most information is easily restored, implying suppression at the decision boundary rather than true deletion. They propose representation-level verification as a new evaluation standard.
AI.motivation: Pretrained models are widely shared and may contain sensitive, copyrighted, or private information. Existing unlearning evaluations rely on outputs, which can be gamed by suppressing signals at the classifier head while retaining sensitive features internally. This creates security and privacy risks that output metrics cannot detect.
AI.method: Use Sparse Autoencoders to discover class-specific expert features in intermediate layers, then apply inference-time steering along these features to attempt to restore behavior on data the model is supposed to have forgotten. Quantify restoration to distinguish suppression (high restoration) from deletion (low/no restoration). Evaluate this framework on 12 prominent unlearning methods for image classification, including retraining from pretrained checkpoints.
AI.result: Most evaluated unlearning methods show high restoration rates: the model’s internal semantic features for the unlearned classes persist and can be reactivated, indicating suppression near the decision boundary rather than removal. Even full retraining from pretrained checkpoints retains robust semantic features, which can be restored.
AI.conclusion: Output-based unlearning metrics are insufficient. Representation-level retention is prevalent and risky, so evaluation should prioritize verifying deletion at the feature level, especially for privacy-critical deployments of pretrained models. New guidelines are proposed to center representation-level tests.

title: Prompt Optimization Via Diffusion Language Models
summary: We propose a diffusion-based framework for prompt optimization that leverages Diffusion Language Models (DLMs) to iteratively refine system prompts through masked denoising. By conditioning on interaction traces, including user queries, model responses, and optional feedback, our method enables flexible, span-level prompt updates without requiring gradient access or modifying the downstream language model. Across diverse benchmarks (e.g., $τ$-bench, SST-2, SST-5), DLM-optimized prompts consistently improve the performance of a frozen target LLM (e.g., GPT-4o-mini). We further show that moderate diffusion step counts provide the best balance between refinement quality and stability. These results highlight diffusion-based prompt optimization as a general, model-agnostic, and scalable approach for enhancing LLM performance through iterative prompt refinement.

AI.tldr: Use a Diffusion Language Model to iteratively denoise and refine system prompts based on interaction traces, yielding consistent gains on a frozen target LLM; moderate diffusion steps work best.
AI.motivation: Prompt quality drives LLM performance, but current optimization methods often need gradients, RL, or manual engineering. A model-agnostic, stable, and scalable approach that exploits readily available interaction traces is needed to improve downstream results without changing the target LLM.
AI.method: Formulate prompt optimization as masked denoising with a Diffusion Language Model conditioned on interaction traces (queries, responses, optional feedback). Iteratively apply diffusion steps to update spans of the system prompt, requiring no gradient access or architectural changes to the target model.
AI.result: Across τ-bench, SST-2, and SST-5, the DLM-refined prompts improve the accuracy/performance of a frozen LLM (e.g., GPT-4o-mini). Empirically, a moderate number of diffusion steps yields the best trade-off between refinement quality and stability.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion-based prompt optimization offers a general, model-agnostic, and scalable way to enhance LLM performance via iterative span-level prompt refinement from interaction traces. Properly tuning the number of diffusion steps is key to achieving robust gains.

title: Feedback-based Automated Verification in Vibe Coding of CAS Adaptation Built on Constraint Logic
summary:
In CAS adaptation, a challenge is to define the dynamic architecture of the system and changes in its behavior. Implementation-wise, this is projected into an adaptation mechanism, typically realized as an Adaptation Manager (AM). With the advances of generative LLMs, generating AM code based on system specification and desired AM behavior (partially in natural language) is a tempting opportunity. The recent introduction of vibe coding suggests a way to target the problem of the correctness of generated code by iterative testing and vibe coding feedback loops instead of direct code inspection.
  In this paper, we show that generating an AM via vibe coding feedback loops is a viable option when the verification of the generated AM is based on a very precise formulation of the functional requirements. We specify these as constraints in a novel temporal logic FCL that allows us to express the behavior of traces with much finer granularity than classical LTL enables.
  Furthermore, we show that by combining the adaptation and vibe coding feedback loops where the FCL constraints are evaluated for the current system state, we achieved good results in the experiments with generating AMs for two example systems from the CAS domain. Typically, just a few feedback loop iterations were necessary, each feeding the LLM with reports describing detailed violations of the constraints. This AM testing was combined with high run path coverage achieved by different initial settings.

AI.tldr: They propose using LLM-driven “vibe coding” feedback loops, guided by a new fine-grained temporal logic (FCL), to automatically synthesize and verify Adaptation Managers (AMs) for complex adaptive systems, showing promising results on two case studies with few iterations needed.
AI.motivation: Defining and ensuring correct dynamic architectures and behavioral changes in complex adaptive systems is hard; generating AM code with LLMs is attractive but correctness is challenging, and traditional LTL may be too coarse to precisely capture required behaviors without heavy manual inspection.
AI.method: Specify AM functional requirements as constraints in a newly introduced temporal logic (FCL) offering finer-grained trace expressivity than LTL; run iterative vibe-coding loops where the LLM generates AM code, tests evaluate FCL constraints on current states, and detailed violation reports are fed back to the LLM; improve test path coverage via varied initial settings; demonstrate on two CAS exemplars.
AI.result: In both example systems, the approach generated working AMs with only a few feedback iterations; FCL-based evaluations provided actionable, detailed violation reports; high run-path coverage was achieved through diverse initializations.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based synthesis of AMs is viable when paired with precisely formulated requirements in FCL and a combined adaptation-plus-vibe-coding feedback loop; FCL’s finer granularity than LTL and targeted violation feedback enable efficient, test-driven verification and correction of generated AMs.

title: Depth from Defocus via Direct Optimization
summary: Though there exists a reasonable forward model for blur based on optical physics, recovering depth from a collection of defocused images remains a computationally challenging optimization problem. In this paper, we show that with contemporary optimization methods and reasonable computing resources, a global optimization approach to depth from defocus is feasible. Our approach rests on alternating minimization. When holding the depth map fixed, the forward model is linear with respect to the all-in-focus image. When holding the all-in-focus image fixed, the depth at each pixel can be computed independently, enabling embarrassingly parallel computation. We show that alternating between convex optimization and parallel grid search can effectively solve the depth-from-defocus problem at higher resolutions than current deep learning methods. We demonstrate our approach on benchmark datasets with synthetic and real defocus blur and show promising results compared to prior approaches. Our code is available at github.com/hollyjackson/dfd.

AI.tldr: Global, optimization-based depth-from-defocus using alternating minimization: convex recovery of the all-in-focus image given depth, and embarrassingly parallel per-pixel depth search given the image. Scales to higher resolutions than current deep learning and shows strong results on synthetic and real blur; code released.
AI.motivation: Recovering depth from multiple defocused images is hard despite good physical blur models; modern deep nets struggle at high resolutions and may not fully leverage the physical forward model. The authors aim to show that with contemporary optimization and compute, a principled global approach is practical and competitive.
AI.method: Alternate between two subproblems: (1) fix depth and solve a convex, linear inverse problem for the all-in-focus image under the optical blur forward model; (2) fix the all-in-focus image and estimate each pixel’s depth independently via parallel grid search over discrete depth candidates. Iterate to convergence, exploiting embarrassingly parallel computation.
AI.result: On benchmark datasets with synthetic and real defocus blur, the method delivers promising performance versus prior work and handles higher-resolution images than leading deep learning baselines. Empirical evidence suggests effective convergence and scalability; implementation is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: A physically grounded, alternating optimization framework can feasibly and effectively solve depth-from-defocus with reasonable resources, offering strong accuracy and scalability to high resolution, and serving as a competitive alternative to deep learning approaches.

title: Asymptotic Semantic Collapse in Hierarchical Optimization
comment: 23 pages, 2 figures. Includes a dataset-free benchmark with full metric reporting
summary: Multi-agent language systems can exhibit a failure mode where a shared dominant context progressively absorbs individual semantics, yielding near-uniform behavior across agents. We study this effect under the name Asymptotic Semantic Collapse in Hierarchical Optimization. In a closed linguistic setting with a Dominant Anchor Node whose semantic state has effectively infinite inertia, we show that repeated interactions with Peripheral Agent Nodes drive an asymptotic alignment that minimizes a global loss. We model semantic states as points on a Riemannian manifold and analyze the induced projection dynamics. Two consequences follow. First, the limiting semantic configuration is insensitive to the optimization history: both smooth gradient-style updates and stochastic noisy updates converge to the same topological endpoint, establishing path independence at convergence. Second, the degree of context dependence controls information content: moving from atomic (independent) representations to fully entangled (context-bound) representations forces the node entropy, interpreted as available degrees of freedom, to vanish in the limit. The theory connects information-theoretic quantities with differential-geometric structure and suggests an interpretation as an immutable consensus rule that constrains agents to a shared semantic grammar. A lightweight dataset-free benchmark on an RWKV-7 13B GGUF checkpoint complements the analysis, reporting zero hash collisions, mean compliance of 0.50 under greedy decoding and 0.531 under stochastic decoding, and final Jaccard-to-anchor similarity values of 0.295 and 0.224, respectively.

AI.tldr: Formalizes and analyzes a failure mode in multi‑agent language systems where a dominant shared context drives all agents to near‑uniform semantics; proves path‑independent convergence and vanishing informational degrees of freedom as context dependence grows, with a small empirical check on an RWKV-7 13B model.
AI.motivation: Multi-agent LLM setups often drift toward uniform behavior under strong shared context. The paper aims to characterize and explain this “semantic collapse,” relate it to optimization structure, and connect information loss with geometric constraints, to understand and potentially control consensus effects in hierarchical systems.
AI.method: Model a closed system with a Dominant Anchor Node (infinite inertia) and Peripheral Agent Nodes. Represent each node’s semantic state as a point on a Riemannian manifold. Analyze interaction-induced projection dynamics and their optimization properties under both smooth (gradient-like) and stochastic update regimes. Provide a lightweight, dataset-free empirical probe using an RWKV-7 13B GGUF checkpoint, measuring compliance and Jaccard similarity to the anchor.
AI.result: Theoretically: (1) repeated interactions yield convergence to the same topological endpoint regardless of update path (path independence at convergence); (2) increasing context entanglement reduces node entropy, which vanishes asymptotically, implying loss of independent degrees of freedom. Interpreted as an immutable consensus rule linking information-theoretic quantities with manifold geometry. Empirically: zero hash collisions, mean compliance 0.50 (greedy) and 0.531 (stochastic), final Jaccard-to-anchor similarity 0.295 and 0.224.
AI.conclusion: Dominant shared context enforces an inevitable consensus that collapses agent diversity in the limit. The geometric–informational theory explains and predicts this behavior; preliminary measurements on one model are directionally consistent. Implications: designers must manage anchor strength/context coupling to preserve semantic diversity; further validation across models and settings is needed.

title: Decoding ML Decision: An Agentic Reasoning Framework for Large-Scale Ranking System
summary: Modern large-scale ranking systems operate within a sophisticated landscape of competing objectives, operational constraints, and evolving product requirements. Progress in this domain is increasingly bottlenecked by the engineering context constraint: the arduous process of translating ambiguous product intent into reasonable, executable, verifiable hypotheses, rather than by modeling techniques alone. We present GEARS (Generative Engine for Agentic Ranking Systems), a framework that reframes ranking optimization as an autonomous discovery process within a programmable experimentation environment. Rather than treating optimization as static model selection, GEARS leverages Specialized Agent Skills to encapsulate ranking expert knowledge into reusable reasoning capabilities, enabling operators to steer systems via high-level intent vibe personalization. Furthermore, to ensure production reliability, the framework incorporates validation hooks to enforce statistical robustness and filter out brittle policies that overfit short-term signals. Experimental validation across diverse product surfaces demonstrates that GEARS consistently identifies superior, near-Pareto-efficient policies by synergizing algorithmic signals with deep ranking context while maintaining rigorous deployment stability.

AI.tldr: GEARS is a framework that turns ranking optimization into an autonomous, agent-driven discovery process, encoding expert heuristics as reusable skills and enforcing statistical validation to find near-Pareto-efficient, deployable policies across products.
AI.motivation: In large-scale ranking, progress is limited less by model capacity and more by the engineering burden of converting ambiguous product intent into clear, testable hypotheses under many objectives and constraints. The authors aim to reduce this “engineering context constraint.”
AI.method: They build GEARS: a programmable experimentation environment where autonomous agents use Specialized Agent Skills (encapsulated expert ranking knowledge and reasoning) to search policy space. Operators guide the system via high-level intent ("vibe" personalization). Built-in validation hooks enforce statistical robustness and filter policies that overfit short-term signals, aiming for reliable deployment.
AI.result: Across multiple product surfaces, GEARS discovers superior, near-Pareto-efficient ranking policies by combining algorithmic signals with deep context, while maintaining deployment stability (robustness against overfitting and brittle behaviors).
AI.conclusion: Agentic, skill-based optimization plus rigorous validation can reliably translate high-level intent into robust ranking policies, improving effectiveness under real-world constraints and generalizing across different product contexts.

title: Sketch2Feedback: Grammar-in-the-Loop Framework for Rubric-Aligned Feedback on Student STEM Diagrams
summary: Providing timely, rubric-aligned feedback on student-drawn diagrams is a persistent challenge in STEM education. While large multimodal models (LMMs) can jointly parse images and generate explanations, their tendency to hallucinate undermines trust in classroom deployments. We present Sketch2Feedback, a grammar-in-the-loop framework that decomposes the problem into four stages -- hybrid perception, symbolic graph construction, constraint checking, and constrained VLM feedback -- so that the language model verbalizes only violations verified by an upstream rule engine. We evaluate on two synthetic micro-benchmarks, FBD-10 (free-body diagrams) and Circuit-10 (circuit schematics), each with 500 images spanning standard and hard noise augmentation tiers, comparing our pipeline against end-to-end LMMs (LLaVA-1.5-7B, Qwen2-VL-7B), a vision-only detector, a YOLOv8-nano learned detector, and an ensemble oracle. On n=100 test samples per benchmark with 95% bootstrap CIs, results are mixed and instructive: Qwen2-VL-7B achieves the highest micro-F1 on both FBDs (0.570) and circuits (0.528), but with extreme hallucination rates (0.78, 0.98). An ensemble oracle that selects the best prediction per sample reaches F1=0.556 with hallucination 0.320 on FBDs, demonstrating exploitable complementarity between grammar and end-to-end approaches. Confidence thresholding at tau=0.7 reduces circuit hallucination from 0.970 to 0.880 with no F1 loss. Hard noise augmentation reveals domain-dependent robustness: FBD detection is resilient while circuit detection degrades sharply. An LLM-as-judge evaluation confirms that the grammar pipeline produces more actionable circuit feedback (4.85/5) than the end-to-end LMM (3.11/5). We release all code, datasets, and evaluation scripts.

AI.tldr: Sketch2Feedback is a grammar-in-the-loop pipeline that detects and structures student-drawn STEM diagrams, checks rule-based constraints, and has a constrained VLM verbalize only verified errors. It reduces hallucinations and yields more actionable feedback than end-to-end LMMs, though some LMMs still attain higher raw F1; results suggest complementary strengths and sensitivity to domain noise.
AI.motivation: Automated, rubric-aligned feedback for hand-drawn STEM diagrams is needed at scale, but end-to-end LMMs hallucinate, undermining trust and classroom deployment. A method that verifies claims before verbalization can provide reliable, actionable feedback.
AI.method: Decompose diagram feedback into four stages: (1) hybrid perception to detect primitives, (2) build a symbolic graph, (3) rule-engine constraint checking against rubrics, and (4) constrained VLM that only verbalizes violations confirmed upstream. Evaluate on two synthetic micro-benchmarks (FBD-10, Circuit-10; standard and hard-noise tiers) against LLaVA-1.5-7B, Qwen2-VL-7B, a vision-only detector, YOLOv8-nano, and an ensemble oracle; also test confidence thresholding and LLM-as-judge for feedback quality.
AI.result: On n=100 test images per benchmark: Qwen2-VL-7B attains highest micro-F1 (FBD 0.570, Circuit 0.528) but with very high hallucination (0.78, 0.98). An ensemble oracle achieves F1=0.556 with hallucination 0.320 on FBDs, indicating complementarity. Thresholding at τ=0.7 cuts circuit hallucination from 0.970 to 0.880 without F1 loss. Hard-noise robustness is domain-dependent: FBD resilient; circuit detection degrades. LLM-as-judge rates grammar pipeline’s circuit feedback as more actionable (4.85/5 vs 3.11/5).
AI.conclusion: Grammar-in-the-loop verification can constrain hallucinations and improve the usefulness of feedback even if raw detection F1 may lag top LMMs. Combining grammar with end-to-end models and simple calibration can balance precision and coverage. Robustness varies by domain, and public releases support further research and real-world validation.

title: The Million-Label NER: Breaking Scale Barriers with GLiNER bi-encoder
summary: This paper introduces GLiNER-bi-Encoder, a novel architecture for Named Entity Recognition (NER) that harmonizes zero-shot flexibility with industrial-scale efficiency. While the original GLiNER framework offers strong generalization, its joint-encoding approach suffers from quadratic complexity as the number of entity labels increases. Our proposed bi-encoder design decouples the process into a dedicated label encoder and a context encoder, effectively removing the context-window bottleneck. This architecture enables the simultaneous recognition of thousands, and potentially millions, of entity types with minimal overhead. Experimental results demonstrate state-of-the-art zero-shot performance, achieving 61.5 percent Micro-F1 on the CrossNER benchmark. Crucially, by leveraging pre-computed label embeddings, GLiNER-bi-Encoder achieves up to a 130 times throughput improvement at 1024 labels compared to its uni-encoder predecessors. Furthermore, we introduce GLiNKER, a modular framework that leverages this architecture for high-performance entity linking across massive knowledge bases such as Wikidata.

AI.tldr: GLiNER-bi-Encoder is a bi-encoder NER architecture that decouples label and context encoding, enabling precomputed label embeddings to scale zero-shot NER to thousands–millions of types with large speedups and SOTA zero-shot accuracy; it also powers GLiNKER for large-scale entity linking.
AI.motivation: Existing GLiNER’s joint (uni-)encoding has quadratic cost in number of labels and is constrained by context-window limits, preventing efficient scaling to large label sets while maintaining zero-shot flexibility.
AI.method: Replace joint encoding with a bi-encoder: a dedicated label encoder and a context encoder produce embeddings separately; labels can be precomputed and matched to contextual spans, removing the context-window bottleneck and reducing complexity. Build GLiNKER atop this for modular, high-throughput entity linking to massive KBs (e.g., Wikidata).
AI.result: State-of-the-art zero-shot performance with 61.5% Micro-F1 on CrossNER; up to 130× throughput improvement at 1024 labels versus uni-encoder baselines; supports simultaneous recognition of thousands to potentially millions of entity types with minimal overhead.
AI.conclusion: Decoupled bi-encoding preserves zero-shot generalization while delivering industrial-scale efficiency, making large-label NER and entity linking practical; GLiNKER showcases its applicability to massive KBs.

title: Spilled Energy in Large Language Models
summary: We reinterpret the final Large Language Model (LLM) softmax classifier as an Energy-Based Model (EBM), decomposing the sequence-to-sequence probability chain into multiple interacting EBMs at inference. This principled approach allows us to track "energy spills" during decoding, which we empirically show correlate with factual errors, biases, and failures. Similar to Orgad et al. (2025), our method localizes the exact answer token and subsequently tests for hallucinations. Crucially, however, we achieve this without requiring trained probe classifiers or activation ablations. Instead, we introduce two completely training-free metrics derived directly from output logits: spilled energy, which captures the discrepancy between energy values across consecutive generation steps that should theoretically match, and marginalized energy, which is measurable at a single step. Evaluated on nine benchmarks across state-of-the-art LLMs (including LLaMA, Mistral, and Gemma) and on synthetic algebraic operations (Qwen3), our approach demonstrates robust, competitive hallucination detection and cross-task generalization. Notably, these results hold for both pretrained and instruction-tuned variants without introducing any training overhead.

AI.tldr: Reframes the LLM softmax as an interacting set of energy-based models to derive two training-free, logit-only energy metrics (spilled and marginalized) that flag hallucinations and other failures during decoding, achieving competitive, cross-model generalization without probes or added training.
AI.motivation: Reliably detecting hallucinations and generation failures across diverse LLMs and tasks typically requires trained probes, ablations, or extra models. The authors seek a principled, training-free, and broadly applicable signal—available directly from logits—that can monitor token-level reliability and identify when the model’s internal dynamics become inconsistent.
AI.method: Treat the final softmax classifier as an EBM and decompose the sequence probability into interacting EBMs over generation steps. Define two logit-derived metrics: (1) spilled energy—the discrepancy between theoretically matching energy quantities across consecutive steps; (2) marginalized energy—an at-a-single-step measurement. Track these during decoding, localize the answer token (à la Orgad et al., 2025), and test for hallucinations without probes or activation ablations. Evaluate on nine benchmarks and multiple LLM families (LLaMA, Mistral, Gemma) and synthetic algebra (Qwen3).
AI.result: Energy spill magnitudes correlate with factual errors, biases, and failures. The two metrics provide robust, competitive hallucination detection that generalizes across tasks and models, including both pretrained and instruction-tuned variants, with zero training overhead.
AI.conclusion: Casting decoding as interacting EBMs yields simple, plug-and-play, training-free logit metrics for monitoring LLM reliability. These signals detect hallucinations competitively across models and tasks, offering a principled alternative to probe-based approaches and suggesting practical deployment for safety and quality control.

title: Do Generative Metrics Predict YOLO Performance? An Evaluation Across Models, Augmentation Ratios, and Dataset Complexity
summary: Synthetic images are increasingly used to augment object-detection training sets, but reliably evaluating a synthetic dataset before training remains difficult: standard global generative metrics (e.g., FID) often do not predict downstream detection mAP. We present a controlled evaluation of synthetic augmentation for YOLOv11 across three single-class detection regimes -- Traffic Signs (sparse/near-saturated), Cityscapes Pedestrian (dense/occlusion-heavy), and COCO PottedPlant (multi-instance/high-variability). We benchmark six GAN-, diffusion-, and hybrid-based generators over augmentation ratios from 10% to 150% of the real training split, and train YOLOv11 both from scratch and with COCO-pretrained initialization, evaluating on held-out real test splits (mAP@0.50:0.95). For each dataset-generator-augmentation configuration, we compute pre-training dataset metrics under a matched-size bootstrap protocol, including (i) global feature-space metrics in both Inception-v3 and DINOv2 embeddings and (ii) object-centric distribution distances over bounding-box statistics. Synthetic augmentation yields substantial gains in the more challenging regimes (up to +7.6% and +30.6% relative mAP in Pedestrian and PottedPlant, respectively) but is marginal in Traffic Signs and under pretrained fine-tuning. To separate metric signal from augmentation quantity, we report both raw and augmentation-controlled (residualized) correlations with multiple-testing correction, showing that metric-performance alignment is strongly regime-dependent and that many apparent raw associations weaken after controlling for augmentation level.

AI.tldr: Synthetic data can substantially boost YOLOv11 detection in hard, under-specified regimes but has little effect in saturated or pretrained settings; common generative metrics (e.g., FID) are weak predictors of downstream mAP unless you control for augmentation amount and task regime.
AI.motivation: Practitioners increasingly rely on synthetic images to augment detectors yet lack reliable, pre-training indicators of whether a given synthetic set will improve mAP. Widely used global metrics (like FID) often misalign with detection performance. The work aims to quantify when synthetic augmentation helps and which pre-training dataset metrics, if any, predict those gains.
AI.method: Run a controlled benchmark for YOLOv11 across three single-class regimes: Traffic Signs (sparse/near-saturated), Cityscapes Pedestrian (dense/occluded), and COCO PottedPlant (multi-instance/high-variability). Compare six generators (GAN, diffusion, hybrid) at augmentation ratios from 10% to 150% of the real training split. Train detectors from scratch and with COCO-pretrained weights; evaluate on real held-out test splits using mAP@0.50:0.95. Before training, compute dataset metrics with a matched-size bootstrap: (i) global feature-space distances in Inception-v3 and DINOv2 embeddings, (ii) object-centric distribution distances over bounding-box statistics. Analyze raw and augmentation-controlled (residualized) correlations with multiple-testing correction to decouple metric signal from augmentation quantity.
AI.result: Synthetic augmentation yields notable relative mAP gains in challenging regimes: up to +7.6% (Pedestrian) and +30.6% (PottedPlant). Gains are marginal for Traffic Signs and when fine-tuning from COCO-pretrained weights. Metric–performance alignment is strongly regime-dependent; many promising raw correlations weaken or vanish after controlling for augmentation level.
AI.conclusion: Synthetic data is most beneficial where tasks are complex or under-specified and least helpful in near-saturated or pretrained scenarios. Global generative metrics are not universally predictive of detection gains; evaluation should account for task regime and control for augmentation quantity (e.g., via residualization). Object-centric and feature-embedding metrics can be informative but only in certain regimes, cautioning against one-size-fits-all selection of synthetic datasets.

title: Luna-2: Scalable Single-Token Evaluation with Small Language Models
summary:
Real-time guardrails require evaluation that is accurate, cheap, and fast - yet today's default, LLM-as-a-judge (LLMAJ), is slow, expensive, and operationally non-deterministic due to multi-token generation. We present Luna-2, a novel architecture that leverages decoder-only small language models (SLMs) into a deterministic evaluation model to reliably compute complex task-specific LLMAJ metrics (e.g. toxicity, hallucination, tool selection quality, etc.) at an accuracy at par or higher than LLMAJ using frontier LLMs while drastically reducing the cost and latency of computation. Each metric is implemented as a lightweight LoRA/PEFT head on top of a shared SLM backbone, enabling hundreds of specialized metrics to run concurrently on a single GPU, deployable locally next to AI systems in a privacy-preserving and latency optimizing manner. Across content safety and hallucination benchmarks, Luna-2 matches the accuracy of state-of-the-art LLM-based evaluators while reducing inference cost by over 80x and latency by over 20x.
  In this paper, we outline the model architecture, training methodology and report real-world empirical results on accuracy, latency, and throughput results. In production, Luna-2 is protecting 100M+ AI sessions and processing over 100B tokens per month for our customers with eval cost savings of over $30M annually.

AI.tldr: Luna-2 is a deterministic, small-LM–based evaluator that uses LoRA/PEFT heads to deliver many guardrail metrics (e.g., toxicity, hallucination, tool choice) concurrently, matching or beating frontier LLM-as-judge accuracy while cutting cost >80× and latency >20× for real-time deployment.
AI.motivation: Real-time AI guardrails need accurate, cheap, and fast evaluation. The prevailing LLM-as-a-judge approach is slow, expensive, and non-deterministic due to multi-token generation, making it ill-suited for production latency, cost, and reliability constraints.
AI.method: Build a deterministic evaluation model on a shared decoder-only small language model backbone. Attach lightweight, task-specific LoRA/PEFT heads—one per metric—to compute complex LLMAJ-style scores. Run hundreds of metric heads concurrently on a single GPU; deploy locally for privacy and latency. Train the system to replicate/approximate LLMAJ metrics (toxicity, hallucination, tool selection quality, etc.).
AI.result: On content safety and hallucination benchmarks, Luna-2 matches state-of-the-art LLM-based evaluators’ accuracy while reducing inference cost by >80× and latency by >20×. In production, it protects 100M+ AI sessions, processes 100B+ tokens/month, and yields >$30M/year in evaluation cost savings.
AI.conclusion: A practical, scalable alternative to LLM-as-judge: deterministic, low-latency, low-cost, and privacy-preserving multi-metric evaluation suitable for large-scale, real-time guardrails, with a modular architecture that extends to many specialized metrics.

title: Many AI Analysts, One Dataset: Navigating the Agentic Data Science Multiverse
summary: The conclusions of empirical research depend not only on data but on a sequence of analytic decisions that published results seldom make explicit. Past ``many-analyst" studies have demonstrated this: independent teams testing the same hypothesis on the same dataset regularly reach conflicting conclusions. But such studies require months of coordination among dozens of research groups and are therefore rarely conducted. In this work, we show that fully autonomous AI analysts built on large language models (LLMs) can reproduce a similar structured analytic diversity cheaply and at scale. We task these AI analysts with testing a pre-specified hypothesis on a fixed dataset, varying the underlying model and prompt framing across replicate runs. Each AI analyst independently constructs and executes a full analysis pipeline; an AI auditor then screens each run for methodological validity. Across three datasets spanning experimental and observational designs, AI analyst-produced analyses display wide dispersion in effect sizes, $p$-values, and binary decisions on supporting the hypothesis or not, frequently reversing whether a hypothesis is judged supported. This dispersion is structured: recognizable analytic choices in preprocessing, model specification, and inference differ systematically across LLM and persona conditions. Critically, the effects are \emph{steerable}: reassigning the analyst persona or LLM shifts the distribution of outcomes even after excluding methodologically deficient runs.

AI.tldr: Autonomous LLM-based “AI analysts” can replicate the wide, structured variability seen in human many-analyst studies—yielding divergent effect sizes, p-values, and conclusions—while being cheap, scalable, and steerable by changing model or persona prompts.
AI.motivation: Empirical conclusions hinge on hidden analytic choices, but human many-analyst studies that expose this variability are costly and rare. The authors seek a scalable way to generate, observe, and control analytic diversity to understand how much results depend on analysts’ decisions.
AI.method: Deploy fully autonomous LLM analysts tasked with testing a pre-registered hypothesis on fixed datasets. Vary the underlying LLM and prompt persona across many independent runs. Each agent designs and executes a complete analysis pipeline (preprocessing, modeling, inference). A separate AI auditor filters out methodologically invalid runs. Apply this across three datasets (experimental and observational) and examine dispersion in effect sizes, p-values, and support/non-support decisions; relate dispersion to identifiable analytic choices and to LLM/persona conditions.
AI.result: Analyses produced by AI analysts show large dispersion in estimates, p-values, and binary conclusions, often reversing whether a hypothesis is judged supported. The dispersion is structured: different preprocessing, model specifications, and inference choices systematically vary by LLM and persona. These outcome distributions are steerable—switching the analyst persona or LLM shifts results even after excluding invalid pipelines.
AI.conclusion: LLM-driven analysts can reproduce and control the structured analytic variability previously observed only via costly human collaborations. This enables scalable many-analyst investigations but underscores the fragility and steerability of empirical conclusions, motivating stronger transparency, robustness checks, and safeguards against cherry-picking.

title: JAEGER: Joint 3D Audio-Visual Grounding and Reasoning in Simulated Physical Environments
summary: Current audio-visual large language models (AV-LLMs) are predominantly restricted to 2D perception, relying on RGB video and monaural audio. This design choice introduces a fundamental dimensionality mismatch that precludes reliable source localization and spatial reasoning in complex 3D environments. We address this limitation by presenting JAEGER, a framework that extends AV-LLMs to 3D space, to enable joint spatial grounding and reasoning through the integration of RGB-D observations and multi-channel first-order ambisonics. A core contribution of our work is the neural intensity vector (Neural IV), a learned spatial audio representation that encodes robust directional cues to enhance direction-of-arrival estimation, even in adverse acoustic scenarios with overlapping sources. To facilitate large-scale training and systematic evaluation, we propose SpatialSceneQA, a benchmark of 61k instruction-tuning samples curated from simulated physical environments. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach consistently surpasses 2D-centric baselines across diverse spatial perception and reasoning tasks, underscoring the necessity of explicit 3D modelling for advancing AI in physical environments. Our source code, pre-trained model checkpoints and datasets will be released upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: JAEGER augments audio‑visual LLMs with explicit 3D sensing (RGB‑D and ambisonics) and a learned Neural Intensity Vector for robust sound direction cues, enabling superior spatial grounding and reasoning; it’s trained/evaluated with a new 61k-sample SpatialSceneQA benchmark and consistently beats 2D baselines.
AI.motivation: Current AV‑LLMs rely on 2D RGB and mono audio, creating a dimensionality mismatch that hampers reliable source localization and spatial reasoning in real 3D environments. The field needs models that natively perceive and reason in 3D space.
AI.method: Introduce JAEGER, an AV‑LLM framework that integrates RGB‑D observations with multi‑channel first‑order ambisonics for joint spatial grounding and reasoning. Propose Neural Intensity Vector (Neural IV), a learned spatial audio representation capturing robust directional cues for direction‑of‑arrival, even under overlapping sources. Create SpatialSceneQA, a 61k instruction‑tuning dataset from simulated environments for large‑scale training and evaluation.
AI.result: Across diverse spatial perception and reasoning tasks, JAEGER consistently outperforms 2D‑centric baselines. Neural IV improves direction‑of‑arrival estimation in challenging acoustic conditions. The new benchmark supports systematic evaluation at scale.
AI.conclusion: Explicit 3D modeling and learned spatial audio cues are essential for advancing AV‑LLMs in physical environments. JAEGER demonstrates clear benefits over 2D approaches, and the community can build on released code, checkpoints, and datasets.

title: DP-RFT: Learning to Generate Synthetic Text via Differentially Private Reinforcement Fine-Tuning
summary: Differentially private (DP) synthetic data generation plays a pivotal role in developing large language models (LLMs) on private data, where data owners cannot provide eyes-on access to individual examples. Generating DP synthetic data typically involves a difficult trade-off. On one hand, DP finetuning methods train an LLM as a synthetic data generator with formal privacy guarantees, yet it still requires the raw content of private examples for model training. However, methods that avoid direct exposure to private data are bounded by an off-the-shelf, un-finetuned model, whose outputs often lack domain fidelity. Can we train an LLM to generate high-quality synthetic text without eyes-on access to individual private examples? In this work, we introduce Differentially Private Reinforcement Fine-Tuning (DP-RFT), an online reinforcement learning algorithm for synthetic data generation with LLMs. DP-RFT leverages DP-protected nearest-neighbor votes from an eyes-off private corpus as a reward signal for on-policy synthetic samples generated by an LLM. The LLM iteratively learns to generate synthetic data to maximize the expected DP votes through Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). We evaluate DP-RFT for long-form and domain-specific synthetic data generation, such as news articles, meeting transcripts, and medical article abstracts. Our experiments show that DP-RFT closes the gap between private evolution and DP finetuning methods in terms of the fidelity and downstream utility of the generated synthetic data, while respecting the private data boundary.

AI.tldr: Proposes DP-RFT, an online RL fine-tuning approach that uses differentially private nearest-neighbor votes from a private corpus as rewards to train an LLM (via PPO) to generate high-fidelity synthetic text without direct access to individual private examples, matching or approaching DP finetuning utility while preserving eyes-off constraints.
AI.motivation: High-quality synthetic data is needed to leverage private corpora for LLM development. Standard DP finetuning offers formal privacy but still requires eyes-on access to raw data; avoiding eyes-on access typically relies on un-finetuned models with poor domain fidelity. The goal is to achieve both strong privacy boundaries and high domain fidelity/utility.
AI.method: An LLM generates on-policy synthetic samples. A DP-protected k-nearest-neighbor voting mechanism, run against an eyes-off private corpus, scores each sample; these noisy votes constitute the reward signal. The LLM is optimized with Proximal Policy Optimization to maximize expected DP votes, iteratively improving synthetic generation while maintaining DP guarantees through the voting mechanism.
AI.result: Across long-form, domain-specific tasks (news, meeting transcripts, medical abstracts), DP-RFT substantially improves fidelity and downstream utility of synthetic data compared to using an off-the-shelf model and narrows the gap to conventional DP finetuning, all while keeping private texts unseen by model trainers.
AI.conclusion: DP-RFT demonstrates that online RL with DP-protected feedback can train LLMs to produce useful, domain-faithful synthetic text under strict eyes-off privacy constraints, offering a practical path between privacy preservation and data utility for synthetic data generation.

title: Task-Aware Exploration via a Predictive Bisimulation Metric
summary: Accelerating exploration in visual reinforcement learning under sparse rewards remains challenging due to the substantial task-irrelevant variations. Despite advances in intrinsic exploration, many methods either assume access to low-dimensional states or lack task-aware exploration strategies, thereby rendering them fragile in visual domains. To bridge this gap, we present TEB, a Task-aware Exploration approach that tightly couples task-relevant representations with exploration through a predictive Bisimulation metric. Specifically, TEB leverages the metric not only to learn behaviorally grounded task representations but also to measure behaviorally intrinsic novelty over the learned latent space. To realize this, we first theoretically mitigate the representation collapse of degenerate bisimulation metrics under sparse rewards by internally introducing a simple but effective predicted reward differential. Building on this robust metric, we design potential-based exploration bonuses, which measure the relative novelty of adjacent observations over the latent space. Extensive experiments on MetaWorld and Maze2D show that TEB achieves superior exploration ability and outperforms recent baselines.

AI.tldr: TEB is a task-aware exploration method for visual RL that learns a predictive bisimulation-based latent space and uses potential-based bonuses over this space; a predicted reward differential prevents representation collapse under sparse rewards, yielding superior exploration on MetaWorld and Maze2D.
AI.motivation: Exploration in visual RL is hard with sparse rewards because observations contain task-irrelevant variation.
