Many intrinsic-motivation methods either require low-dimensional states or are not task-aware, making them brittle in visual domains. The authors aim to align representation learning with exploration so novelty is measured in terms relevant to the task’s behavior.
AI.method: They build a predictive bisimulation metric to learn behaviorally grounded latent representations and to compute intrinsic novelty directly in that latent space. To avoid degenerate/collapsed bisimulation under sparse rewards, they introduce a simple predicted reward differential as an internal signal. On top of this robust metric, they define potential-based exploration bonuses that measure relative novelty between adjacent observations in the latent space, encouraging exploration consistent with task-relevant behavioral differences.
AI.result: Across MetaWorld and Maze2D benchmarks, TEB shows stronger exploration and outperforms recent baselines (details such as sample efficiency and exact gains are not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Coupling task-aware representation learning with intrinsic exploration via a stabilized bisimulation metric improves exploration in visual RL under sparse rewards. The approach appears robust and effective across different visual control tasks.

title: Image-Based Classification of Olive Varieties Native to Turkiye Using Multiple Deep Learning Architectures: Analysis of Performance, Complexity, and Generalization
summary: This study compares multiple deep learning architectures for the automated, image-based classification of five locally cultivated black table olive varieties in Turkey: Gemlik, Ayvalik, Uslu, Erkence, and Celebi. Using a dataset of 2500 images, ten architectures - MobileNetV2, EfficientNetB0, EfficientNetV2-S, ResNet50, ResNet101, DenseNet121, InceptionV3, ConvNeXt-Tiny, ViT-B16, and Swin-T - were trained using transfer learning. Model performance was evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), Cohen's Kappa, ROC-AUC, number of parameters, FLOPs, inference time, and generalization gap. EfficientNetV2-S achieved the highest classification accuracy (95.8%), while EfficientNetB0 provided the best trade-off between accuracy and computational complexity. Overall, the results indicate that under limited data conditions, parametric efficiency plays a more critical role than model depth alone.

AI.tldr: Compared 10 transfer-learned CNN/Transformer models on 2,500 images to classify five Turkish black olive varieties; EfficientNetV2-S reached 95.8% accuracy, while EfficientNetB0 delivered the best accuracy–efficiency balance, highlighting that parameter efficiency matters more than depth with limited data.
AI.motivation: Enable reliable, fast, and scalable varietal identification of locally cultivated black table olives, reducing reliance on manual inspection and supporting agricultural quality control and supply-chain needs under practical data and compute constraints.
AI.method: Built a five-class image dataset (2,500 samples) and trained ten modern architectures (MobileNetV2, EfficientNetB0, EfficientNetV2-S, ResNet50/101, DenseNet121, InceptionV3, ConvNeXt-Tiny, ViT-B16, Swin-T) via transfer learning. Assessed performance with a comprehensive set of metrics (accuracy, precision, recall, F1, MCC, Cohen’s Kappa, ROC-AUC) alongside efficiency indicators (parameter count, FLOPs, inference time) and generalization gap.
AI.result: EfficientNetV2-S achieved the top accuracy (95.8%). EfficientNetB0 offered the best trade-off between accuracy and computational cost. Results suggest lighter, parameter-efficient CNNs outperform deeper/heavier models and Transformers in this low-data, fine-grained setting.
AI.conclusion: In small, domain-specific image datasets, prioritize parameter-efficient CNNs for strong accuracy and practical deployment. Model depth alone is not predictive of performance; balancing inductive bias, capacity, and compute is key. Scaling data or stronger regularization might be needed before larger or Transformer-based models pay off.

title: PolyFrame at MWE-2026 AdMIRe 2: When Words Are Not Enough: Multimodal Idiom Disambiguation
comment: Accepted at AdMIRe 2 shared task (Advancing Multimodal Idiomaticity Representation) colocated with 22nd Workshop on Multiword Expressions (MWE 2026) @EACL2026
summary: Multimodal models struggle with idiomatic expressions due to their non-compositional meanings, a challenge amplified in multilingual settings. We introduced PolyFrame, our system for the MWE-2026 AdMIRe2 shared task on multimodal idiom disambiguation, featuring a unified pipeline for both image+text ranking (Subtask A) and text-only caption ranking (Subtask B). All model variants retain frozen CLIP-style vision--language encoders and the multilingual BGE M3 encoder, training only lightweight modules: a logistic regression and LLM-based sentence-type predictor, idiom synonym substitution, distractor-aware scoring, and Borda rank fusion. Starting from a CLIP baseline (26.7% Top-1 on English dev, 6.7% on English test), adding idiom-aware paraphrasing and explicit sentence-type classification increased performance to 60.0% Top-1 on English and 60.0% Top-1 (0.822 NDCG@5) in zero-shot transfer to Portuguese. On the multilingual blind test, our systems achieved average Top-1/NDCG scores of 0.35/0.73 for Subtask A and 0.32/0.71 for Subtask B across 15 languages. Ablation results highlight idiom-aware rewriting as the main contributor to performance, while sentence-type prediction and multimodal fusion enhance robustness. These findings suggest that effective idiom disambiguation is feasible without fine-tuning large multimodal encoders.

AI.tldr: PolyFrame tackles multimodal idiom disambiguation by keeping vision–language encoders frozen and adding lightweight, idiom-aware components, yielding large gains and strong multilingual zero-shot performance without heavy fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Idioms are non-compositional, so standard multimodal models that rely on surface-level alignment of words and visuals often fail—especially across languages. The work aims to make idiom disambiguation practical and multilingual without costly fine-tuning of large encoders.
AI.method: Unified pipeline for two ranking subtasks (image+text; text-only). Keep CLIP-style vision–language and multilingual BGE M3 encoders frozen. Train only small modules: (1) LLM-based and logistic-regression sentence-type predictor; (2) idiom synonym substitution/paraphrasing to make meanings explicit; (3) distractor-aware scoring; (4) Borda rank fusion across signals. Apply idiom-aware rewriting and sentence-type conditioning before scoring and fusion.
AI.result: From a CLIP baseline (26.7% Top-1 EN dev; 6.7% EN test), adding idiom-aware paraphrasing and sentence-type prediction reaches 60.0% Top-1 on English, and 60.0% Top-1 with 0.822 NDCG@5 in zero-shot Portuguese. On the multilingual blind test (15 languages): Subtask A avg Top-1/NDCG = 0.35/0.73; Subtask B = 0.32/0.71. Ablations show idiom-aware rewriting is the primary gain driver; sentence-type prediction and multimodal fusion add robustness.
AI.conclusion: Effective multimodal idiom disambiguation is achievable without fine-tuning large encoders by injecting targeted, lightweight, idiom-aware processing. Rewriting idioms is the key lever, and modest classification plus fusion further stabilizes performance across languages and modalities.

title: Beyond Description: A Multimodal Agent Framework for Insightful Chart Summarization
summary: Chart summarization is crucial for enhancing data accessibility and the efficient consumption of information. However, existing methods, including those with Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs), primarily focus on low-level data descriptions and often fail to capture the deeper insights which are the fundamental purpose of data visualization. To address this challenge, we propose Chart Insight Agent Flow, a plan-and-execute multi-agent framework effectively leveraging the perceptual and reasoning capabilities of MLLMs to uncover profound insights directly from chart images. Furthermore, to overcome the lack of suitable benchmarks, we introduce ChartSummInsights, a new dataset featuring a diverse collection of real-world charts paired with high-quality, insightful summaries authored by human data analysis experts. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly improves the performance of MLLMs on the chart summarization task, producing summaries with deep and diverse insights.

AI.tldr: They propose a multi-agent, plan-and-execute framework that uses MLLMs to derive higher-level insights from chart images and release a new expert-annotated dataset; experiments show improved, more insightful chart summaries.
AI.motivation: Current chart summarization methods (including MLLMs) mostly produce low-level descriptions and miss the deeper insights that visualizations are meant to convey. There is also a lack of suitable benchmarks with expert, insight-focused summaries.
AI.method: Chart Insight Agent Flow: a multi-agent system that plans and executes analysis steps, combining perception and reasoning capabilities of MLLMs to extract high-level insights directly from chart images. Additionally, they curate ChartSummInsights, a dataset of real-world charts paired with expert-authored insightful summaries.
AI.result: On chart summarization tasks, their framework substantially improves MLLM performance, yielding summaries that are deeper and more diverse compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: Planning-based multi-agent orchestration of MLLMs can move chart summarization beyond surface-level descriptions toward expert-like insights, and the new dataset enables more rigorous training and evaluation.

title: VLANeXt: Recipes for Building Strong VLA Models
summary: Following the rise of large foundation models, Vision-Language-Action models (VLAs) emerged, leveraging strong visual and language understanding for general-purpose policy learning. Yet, the current VLA landscape remains fragmented and exploratory. Although many groups have proposed their own VLA models, inconsistencies in training protocols and evaluation settings make it difficult to identify which design choices truly matter. To bring structure to this evolving space, we reexamine the VLA design space under a unified framework and evaluation setup. Starting from a simple VLA baseline similar to RT-2 and OpenVLA, we systematically dissect design choices along three dimensions: foundational components, perception essentials, and action modelling perspectives. From this study, we distill 12 key findings that together form a practical recipe for building strong VLA models. The outcome of this exploration is a simple yet effective model, VLANeXt. VLANeXt outperforms prior state-of-the-art methods on the LIBERO and LIBERO-plus benchmarks and demonstrates strong generalization in real-world experiments. We will release a unified, easy-to-use codebase that serves as a common platform for the community to reproduce our findings, explore the design space, and build new VLA variants on top of a shared foundation.

AI.tldr: They unify and benchmark design choices for Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models, distill 12 practical lessons, and introduce VLANeXt—a simple, strong baseline that achieves SOTA on LIBERO/LIBERO-plus and shows real-world generalization, alongside releasing a unified codebase.
AI.motivation: The VLA field is fragmented: disparate training protocols and evaluation setups obscure which architectural and training choices matter. The paper aims to bring structure, comparability, and actionable guidance to building effective VLA policies.
AI.method: Begin with a simple RT-2/OpenVLA-like baseline. Under a single framework and evaluation setup, systematically ablate and analyze choices across three axes: (1) foundational components, (2) perception essentials, and (3) action modeling perspectives. From the study, synthesize 12 key findings and instantiate them in a refined model, VLANeXt.
AI.result: The distilled recipe yields VLANeXt, which surpasses prior state-of-the-art on LIBERO and LIBERO-plus benchmarks and exhibits strong real-world generalization. The authors also provide a unified, easy-to-use codebase to reproduce results and explore variants.
AI.conclusion: A principled, unified analysis reveals a simple recipe that reliably strengthens VLA models. VLANeXt validates the recipe with SOTA performance and practical generalization, and the released codebase offers a common platform to standardize, reproduce, and extend VLA research.

title: From Trial by Fire To Sleep Like a Baby: A Lexicon of Anxiety Associations for 20k English Multiword Expressions
summary: Anxiety is the unease about a possible future negative outcome. In recent years, there has been growing interest in understanding how anxiety relates to our health, well-being, body, mind, and behaviour. This includes work on lexical resources for word-anxiety association. However, there is very little anxiety-related work on larger units of text such as multiword expressions (MWE). Here, we introduce the first large-scale lexicon capturing descriptive norms of anxiety associations for more than 20k English MWEs. We show that the anxiety associations are highly reliable. We use the lexicon to study prevalence of different types of anxiety- and calmness-associated MWEs; and how that varies across two-, three-, and four-word sequences. We also study the extent to which the anxiety association of MWEs is compositional (due to its constituent words). The lexicon enables a wide variety of anxiety-related research in psychology, NLP, public health, and social sciences. The lexicon is freely available: https://saifmohammad.com/worrylex.html

AI.tldr: Introduces and validates a large lexicon of anxiety/calmness associations for 20k+ English multiword expressions, analyzes prevalence across n-gram lengths and tests compositionality, enabling downstream research in NLP and social sciences.
AI.motivation: Existing anxiety resources largely focus on single words; little is known about anxiety associations of multiword expressions despite their importance for meaning, behavior analysis, and mental-health–related inference.
AI.method: Construct a large-scale lexicon assigning anxiety/calmness association scores to 20k+ English MWEs; assess reliability; analyze distribution across bigrams, trigrams, and four-grams; and quantify how much MWE anxiety is explained by constituent-word associations (compositionality).
AI.result: The lexicon’s ratings are highly reliable; distinct prevalence patterns emerge across 2-, 3-, and 4-word sequences; and MWE anxiety associations are only partly compositional, indicating additional phrase-level effects.
AI.conclusion: A publicly available MWE anxiety lexicon fills a key gap beyond word-level resources, supports robust analysis of anxiety language, and opens applications across psychology, NLP, public health, and social sciences.

title: Federated Reasoning Distillation Framework with Model Learnability-Aware Data Allocation
summary: Data allocation plays a critical role in federated large language model (LLM) and small language models (SLMs) reasoning collaboration. Nevertheless, existing data allocation methods fail to address an under-explored challenge in collaboration: bidirectional model learnability gap, where client-side SLMs cannot identify high-reward samples matching their learnability constraints for effective knowledge transfer from LLMs, while LLMs struggle to select samples contributing novel knowledge beyond their existing data. Furthermore, these collaboration frameworks face another key challenge: domain-agnostic reasoning transfer, where existing reasoning transfer methods fail to flexibly adapt to the local domain data, preventing SLMs from effectively acquiring step-by-step reasoning abilities within from general LLM. To address these challenges, we propose LaDa, a federated reasoning distillation framework with model learnability-aware data allocation. It introduces a model learnability-aware data filter that adaptively allocates high-reward samples based on the learnability gap between each SLM and LLM pair, effectively facilitating bidirectional knowledge transfer. We further design a domain adaptive reasoning distillation method that aligns joint probabilities of reasoning paths on filtered high-reward samples through contrastive distillation learning between SLM and LLM, enabling SLM to capture underlying reasoning patterns under local data distribution. LaDa operates as a plug-in module for existing collaboration frameworks, adapting knowledge transfer based on model learnability gaps.

AI.tldr: LaDa is a plug-in federated reasoning distillation framework that allocates data by model learnability and transfers domain-adaptive reasoning from LLMs to SLMs, addressing bidirectional learnability gaps and domain mismatch.
AI.motivation: Federated LLM–SLM collaboration suffers from two overlooked issues: (1) a bidirectional learnability gap—SLMs cannot find high-reward, learnable samples for effective guidance while LLMs cannot identify samples that bring novel information; and (2) domain-agnostic reasoning transfer—current methods fail to adapt step-by-step reasoning to each client’s local domain distribution.
AI.method: LaDa introduces a learnability-aware data filter that adaptively allocates high-reward samples according to the learnability gap for each LLM–SLM pair, enabling mutual knowledge transfer. It further employs domain-adaptive reasoning distillation by aligning joint probabilities of reasoning paths on the filtered samples via contrastive distillation between LLM and SLM, helping SLMs internalize local reasoning patterns. The framework is designed as a plug-in to existing collaboration pipelines.
AI.result: The framework is claimed to facilitate bidirectional knowledge transfer, improve selection of informative samples for both LLMs and SLMs, and enable SLMs to better acquire domain-specific, step-by-step reasoning abilities; quantitative evidence is not provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: By coupling learnability-aware data allocation with domain-adaptive reasoning distillation, LaDa addresses core bottlenecks in federated LLM–SLM collaboration and can be integrated into existing systems to enhance reasoning transfer under heterogeneous client domains.

title: Morphological Addressing of Identity Basins in Text-to-Image Diffusion Models
summary: We demonstrate that morphological pressure creates navigable gradients at multiple levels of the text-to-image generative pipeline. In Study~1, identity basins in Stable Diffusion 1.5 can be navigated using morphological descriptors -- constituent features like platinum blonde,'' beauty mark,'' and 1950s glamour'' -- without the target's name or photographs. A self-distillation loop (generating synthetic images from descriptor prompts, then training a LoRA on those outputs) achieves consistent convergence toward a specific identity as measured by ArcFace similarity. The trained LoRA creates a local coordinate system shaping not only the target identity but also its inverse: maximal away-conditioning produces eldritch'' structural breakdown in base SD1.5, while the LoRA-equipped model produces ``uncanny valley'' outputs -- coherent but precisely wrong. In Study~2, we extend this to prompt-level morphology. Drawing on phonestheme theory, we generate 200 novel nonsense words from English sound-symbolic clusters (e.g., \emph{cr-}, \emph{sn-}, \emph{-oid}, \emph{-ax}) and find that phonestheme-bearing candidates produce significantly more visually coherent outputs than random controls (mean Purity@1 = 0.371 vs.\ 0.209, p<0.00001p < 0.00001 p<0.00001, Cohen's d=0.55d = 0.55 d=0.55). Three candidates -- \emph{snudgeoid}, \emph{crashax}, and \emph{broomix} -- achieve perfect visual consistency (Purity@1 = 1.0) with zero training data contamination, each generating a distinct, coherent visual identity from phonesthetic structure alone. Together, these studies establish that morphological structure -- whether in feature descriptors or prompt-level phonological form -- creates systematic navigational gradients through diffusion model latent spaces. We document phase transitions in identity basins, CFG-invariant identity stability, and novel visual concepts emerging from sub-lexical sound patterns.

AI.tldr: Morphological structure in prompts—both semantic descriptors and phonological “phonesthemes”—creates reliable navigational gradients in Stable Diffusion 1.5, enabling convergence to specific identities and the emergence of new, coherent visual concepts without names or training images.
AI.motivation: To test whether sub-lexical structure in language (feature descriptors and sound-symbolic clusters) systematically shapes diffusion-model latent spaces, allowing identity control and novel concept formation beyond memorized names/images, and to probe the geometry of identity basins and model controllability.
AI.method: Study 1: Use compositional morphological descriptors (e.g., “platinum blonde,” “beauty mark,” “1950s glamour”) to synthesize images with SD1.5; train a LoRA on these synthetic outputs in a self-distillation loop; evaluate convergence to a specific identity via ArcFace similarity; probe the local coordinate system by conditioning toward/away from the learned identity, comparing base vs LoRA-equipped SD1.5. Study 2: Construct 200 nonce prompts from English phonestheme clusters (e.g., cr-, sn-, -oid, -ax); compare against random controls; assess visual coherence via Purity@1; verify no training-data contamination; identify candidates yielding highly consistent imagery.
AI.result: Study 1: Self-distillation + LoRA reliably converges to a distinct identity from descriptors alone; the LoRA defines a local coordinate system whose away-conditioning yields “uncanny valley” outputs (vs eldritch breakdown in base SD1.5). Study 2: Phonestheme-bearing nonce words produce significantly more coherent images than controls (Purity@1 = 0.371 vs 0.209, p < 1e-5, Cohen’s d = 0.55); three words—snudgeoid, crashax, broomix—achieve perfect consistency (Purity@1 = 1.0) without contamination, each forming a stable visual identity.
AI.conclusion: Morphological pressure, in both semantic feature composition and phonological form, imposes smooth, navigable gradients in diffusion latent spaces. This yields phase transitions within identity basins, CFG-invariant identity stability, and coherent novel concepts emerging from sub-lexical patterns, highlighting new avenues for prompt engineering, controllability, and model interpretability beyond data memorization.

title: Contradiction to Consensus: Dual Perspective, Multi Source Retrieval Based Claim Verification with Source Level Disagreement using LLM
summary: The spread of misinformation across digital platforms can pose significant societal risks. Claim verification, a.k.a. fact-checking, systems can help identify potential misinformation. However, their efficacy is limited by the knowledge sources that they rely on. Most automated claim verification systems depend on a single knowledge source and utilize the supporting evidence from that source; they ignore the disagreement of their source with others. This limits their knowledge coverage and transparency. To address these limitations, we present a novel system for open-domain claim verification (ODCV) that leverages large language models (LLMs), multi-perspective evidence retrieval, and cross-source disagreement analysis. Our approach introduces a novel retrieval strategy that collects evidence for both the original and the negated forms of a claim, enabling the system to capture supporting and contradicting information from diverse sources: Wikipedia, PubMed, and Google. These evidence sets are filtered, deduplicated, and aggregated across sources to form a unified and enriched knowledge base that better reflects the complexity of real-world information. This aggregated evidence is then used for claim verification using LLMs. We further enhance interpretability by analyzing model confidence scores to quantify and visualize inter-source disagreement. Through extensive evaluation on four benchmark datasets with five LLMs, we show that knowledge aggregation not only improves claim verification but also reveals differences in source-specific reasoning. Our findings underscore the importance of embracing diversity, contradiction, and aggregation in evidence for building reliable and transparent claim verification systems

AI.tldr: They propose an open-domain fact-checking system that retrieves both supporting and contradicting evidence for a claim from multiple sources (Wikipedia, PubMed, Google), aggregates it, verifies with LLMs, and quantifies cross-source disagreement—yielding better accuracy and transparency on benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Single-source automated fact-checkers have limited knowledge coverage and obscure disagreements between sources, which hinders reliable detection of misinformation and reduces transparency.
AI.method: Introduce multi-perspective retrieval that gathers evidence for both the original and negated claim from diverse sources; filter, deduplicate, and aggregate evidence into a unified knowledge set; use LLMs for final claim verification; analyze model confidence to quantify and visualize inter-source disagreement.
AI.result: Across four benchmark datasets and five LLMs, aggregated multi-source evidence improves claim verification performance and exposes differences in how sources support or contradict claims, indicating source-specific reasoning patterns.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging diverse, even contradictory, evidence and aggregating across sources leads to more reliable and interpretable claim verification; explicitly modeling cross-source disagreement enhances transparency and trustworthiness of fact-checking systems.

title: The Convergence of Schema-Guided Dialogue Systems and the Model Context Protocol
comment: 18 sections, 4 figures, 7 tables, 38 references. Original research presenting: (1) formal framework mapping Schema-Guided Dialogue principles to Model Context Protocol concepts, (2) five foundational design principles for LLM-native schema authoring, (3) architectural patterns for secure, scalable agent orchestration. Research supported by SBB (Swiss Federal Railways)
summary: This paper establishes a fundamental convergence: Schema-Guided Dialogue (SGD) and the Model Context Protocol (MCP) represent two manifestations of a unified paradigm for deterministic, auditable LLM-agent interaction. SGD, designed for dialogue-based API discovery (2019), and MCP, now the de facto standard for LLM-tool integration, share the same core insight -- that schemas can encode not just tool signatures but operational constraints and reasoning guidance. By analyzing this convergence, we extract five foundational principles for schema design: (1) Semantic Completeness over Syntactic Precision, (2) Explicit Action Boundaries, (3) Failure Mode Documentation, (4) Progressive Disclosure Compatibility, and (5) Inter-Tool Relationship Declaration. These principles reveal three novel insights: first, SGD's original design was fundamentally sound and should be inherited by MCP; second, both frameworks leave failure modes and inter-tool relationships unexploited -- gaps we identify and resolve; third, progressive disclosure emerges as a critical production-scaling insight under real-world token constraints. We provide concrete design patterns for each principle. These principles position schema-driven governance as a scalable mechanism for AI system oversight without requiring proprietary system inspection -- central to Software 3.0.

AI.tldr: SGD and MCP are unified under a schema-driven approach to deterministic, auditable LLM–tool interaction; the paper distills five schema principles, identifies gaps (failure modes, tool relationships), elevates progressive disclosure for token efficiency, and offers concrete design patterns to enable scalable governance without proprietary access.
AI.motivation: Ensure reliable, auditable LLM-agent behavior at scale; reconcile historical (SGD) and current (MCP) practices into a single paradigm; address real-world constraints (token limits) while enabling oversight without needing access to closed-source systems.
AI.method: Conceptual/architectural analysis comparing SGD and MCP. From this comparison, the authors derive five foundational schema-design principles and propose actionable design patterns to address observed gaps (failure documentation and inter-tool relationships).
AI.result: Five principles: (1) prioritize semantic completeness over mere syntax, (2) define explicit action boundaries, (3) document failure modes, (4) ensure compatibility with progressive disclosure, and (5) declare inter-tool relationships. Three insights: SGD’s sound design should inform MCP; both frameworks under-specify failures and tool relationships (which the paper addresses); progressive disclosure is essential for production scaling under token constraints. Concrete patterns are provided for each principle.
AI.conclusion: A schema-first approach can govern LLM-agent behavior deterministically and audibly, serving as a scalable oversight mechanism central to Software 3.0. MCP should inherit SGD’s strengths, and systems should explicitly encode failures, boundaries, and tool interrelations while supporting progressive disclosure.

title: Rodent-Bench
summary: We present Rodent-Bench, a novel benchmark designed to evaluate the ability of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) to annotate rodent behaviour footage. We evaluate state-of-the-art MLLMs, including Gemini-2.5-Pro, Gemini-2.5-Flash and Qwen-VL-Max, using this benchmark and find that none of these models perform strongly enough to be used as an assistant for this task. Our benchmark encompasses diverse datasets spanning multiple behavioral paradigms including social interactions, grooming, scratching, and freezing behaviors, with videos ranging from 10 minutes to 35 minutes in length. We provide two benchmark versions to accommodate varying model capabilities and establish standardized evaluation metrics including second-wise accuracy, macro F1, mean average precision, mutual information, and Matthew's correlation coefficient. While some models show modest performance on certain datasets (notably grooming detection), overall results reveal significant challenges in temporal segmentation, handling extended video sequences, and distinguishing subtle behavioral states. Our analysis identifies key limitations in current MLLMs for scientific video annotation and provides insights for future model development. Rodent-Bench serves as a foundation for tracking progress toward reliable automated behavioral annotation in neuroscience research.

AI.tldr: Rodent-Bench is a new evaluation suite for testing multimodal LLMs on long, fine-grained rodent behavior annotation; current leading models (Gemini-2.5 variants, Qwen-VL-Max) underperform—especially on temporal segmentation and subtle state discrimination—though grooming is a partial bright spot.
AI.motivation: Neuroscience needs reliable, scalable, and standardized automated annotation of rodent behaviors in long videos. Existing MLLMs are promising but unproven for this domain and lack a domain-specific, rigorous benchmark to assess fine-grained, temporally precise behavior labeling.
AI.method: Construct a benchmark spanning multiple behavioral paradigms (social interactions, grooming, scratching, freezing) with 10–35 minute videos. Provide two benchmark variants to match different model capabilities. Define standardized metrics (second-wise accuracy, macro F1, mean average precision, mutual information, Matthew’s correlation coefficient). Evaluate state-of-the-art MLLMs (Gemini-2.5-Pro, Gemini-2.5-Flash, Qwen-VL-Max).
AI.result: Across datasets, no model achieves performance sufficient for practical assistant use. Some modest success appears on grooming detection, but models struggle with temporal segmentation, long-duration sequences, and distinguishing subtle behavioral states. Metrics consistently reflect subpar performance across tasks.
AI.conclusion: Current MLLMs are not yet reliable for scientific video annotation of rodent behavior. Rodent-Bench offers a standardized way to measure progress, highlights key failure modes (temporal reasoning over long videos, subtle state discrimination), and provides direction for future model development toward dependable automated annotation in neuroscience.

title: Semantic Substrate Theory: An Operator-Theoretic Framework for Geometric Semantic Drift
summary: Most semantic drift studies report multiple signals e.g., embedding displacement, neighbor changes, distributional divergence, and recursive trajectory instability, without a shared explanatory theory that relates them. This paper proposes a formalization of these signals in one time-indexed substrate, $S_t=(X,d_t,P_t)$, combining embedding geometry with local diffusion. Within this substrate, node-level neighborhood drift measures changes in local conditional distributions, coarse Ricci curvature measures local contractivity of semantic diffusion, and recursive drift probes stability of iterated semantic operators. This manuscript specifies the formal model, assumptions, and tests that can refute the model. Herein, the paper introduces bridge mass, a node-level aggregate of incident negative curvature, as a predictor of future neighborhood rewiring. This paper provides the theory and test contracts; empirical performance is deferred to subsequent studies.

AI.tldr: Unifies disparate semantic-drift signals in a single time-indexed geometric–diffusive framework S_t=(X,d_t,P_t); formalizes neighborhood drift, curvature-based contractivity, and recursive stability; introduces bridge mass as a predictor of future neighborhood rewiring; supplies falsifiable tests; defers empirical validation.
AI.motivation: Current drift studies report multiple signals (embedding shifts, neighbor swaps, distributional divergences, recursive instability) without a theory that relates them or explains agreement/disagreement. A principled, falsifiable framework is needed to connect these signals and to identify local predictors of upcoming semantic reconfiguration.
AI.method: Define a time-indexed substrate S_t=(X,d_t,P_t) where X are nodes (e.g., terms), d_t is a time-varying geometric metric from embeddings, and P_t is a local diffusion/Markov kernel. Within this substrate: (i) neighborhood drift measures changes in local conditional distributions under P_t; (ii) coarse Ricci curvature quantifies local contractivity/expansivity of semantic diffusion; (iii) recursive drift probes stability of iterated semantic operators. Introduce bridge mass: a node-level aggregate of incident negative curvature. State model assumptions and provide refutation tests (“test contracts”).
AI.result: A unified formal model relating standard drift signals; precise definitions connecting geometry and diffusion; the bridge mass quantity posited to predict future neighborhood rewiring; and a set of falsifiable test contracts. No empirical performance results are reported; contributions are theoretical/specification-level.
AI.conclusion: The paper offers a coherent, testable theory linking common drift measures and proposes bridge mass as a local predictor of future structural change. It sets up assumptions and refutation criteria, inviting subsequent empirical studies to validate or falsify the framework.

title: LAMMI-Pathology: A Tool-Centric Bottom-Up LVLM-Agent Framework for Molecularly Informed Medical Intelligence in Pathology
summary: The emergence of tool-calling-based agent systems introduces a more evidence-driven paradigm for pathology image analysis in contrast to the coarse-grained text-image diagnostic approaches. With the recent large-scale experimental adoption of spatial transcriptomics technologies, molecularly validated pathological diagnosis is becoming increasingly open and accessible. In this work, we propose LAMMI-Pathology (LVLM-Agent System for Molecularly Informed Medical Intelligence in Pathology), a scalable agent framework for domain-specific agent tool-calling. LAMMI-Pathology adopts a tool-centric, bottom-up architecture in which customized domain-adaptive tools serve as the foundation. These tools are clustered by domain style to form component agents, which are then coordinated through a top-level planner hierarchically, avoiding excessively long context lengths that could induce task drift. Based on that, we introduce a novel trajectory construction mechanism based on Atomic Execution Nodes (AENs), which serve as reliable and composable units for building semi-simulated reasoning trajectories that capture credible agent-tool interactions. Building on this foundation, we develop a trajectory-aware fine-tuning strategy that aligns the planner's decision-making process with these multi-step reasoning trajectories, thereby enhancing inference robustness in pathology understanding and its adaptive use of the customized toolset.

AI.tldr: LAMMI-Pathology is a hierarchical, tool-centric LVLM agent framework that clusters customized pathology tools into component agents, coordinates them with a top-level planner, and uses Atomic Execution Node–based trajectories plus trajectory-aware fine-tuning to deliver more robust, molecularly informed pathology analysis leveraging spatial transcriptomics.
AI.motivation: Move beyond coarse text-image pathology systems toward evidence-driven, tool-using agents, capitalizing on the growing availability of spatial transcriptomics for molecularly validated diagnosis while mitigating long-context task drift in complex multi-step reasoning.
AI.method: 1) Build a bottom-up, tool-centric stack of customized domain-adaptive tools. 2) Cluster tools by domain style into component agents. 3) Use a hierarchical top-level planner to orchestrate agents, reducing context length and task drift. 4) Construct semi-simulated reasoning trajectories from Atomic Execution Nodes (AENs) that encode reliable, composable agent–tool interactions. 5) Apply trajectory-aware fine-tuning to align the planner’s decisions with these multi-step trajectories for robust inference and adaptive tool use.
AI.result: Qualitatively, the framework improves inference robustness in pathology understanding, better aligns planning with credible multi-step tool interactions, adapts effectively to customized toolsets, and avoids performance degradation from overly long contexts. (No quantitative metrics are reported in the abstract.)
AI.conclusion: A hierarchical, AEN-trajectory–guided, tool-centric agent architecture can scalably deliver molecularly informed pathology intelligence, integrating spatial transcriptomics and improving reliability of agent-tool interactions; it provides a practical path toward robust, evidence-driven diagnostic agents.

title: BloomNet: Exploring Single vs. Multiple Object Annotation for Flower Recognition Using YOLO Variants
comment: Accepted for publication in 7th International Conference on Trends in Computational and Cognitive Engineering (TCCE-2025)
summary: Precise localization and recognition of flowers are crucial for advancing automated agriculture, particularly in plant phenotyping, crop estimation, and yield monitoring. This paper benchmarks several YOLO architectures such as YOLOv5s, YOLOv8n/s/m, and YOLOv12n for flower object detection under two annotation regimes: single-image single-bounding box (SISBB) and single-image multiple-bounding box (SIMBB). The FloralSix dataset, comprising 2,816 high-resolution photos of six different flower species, is also introduced. It is annotated for both dense (clustered) and sparse (isolated) scenarios. The models were evaluated using Precision, Recall, and Mean Average Precision (mAP) at IoU thresholds of 0.5 (mAP@0.5) and 0.5-0.95 (mAP@0.5:0.95). In SISBB, YOLOv8m (SGD) achieved the best results with Precision 0.956, Recall 0.951, mAP@0.5 0.978, and mAP@0.5:0.95 0.865, illustrating strong accuracy in detecting isolated flowers. With mAP@0.5 0.934 and mAP@0.5:0.95 0.752, YOLOv12n (SGD) outperformed the more complicated SIMBB scenario, proving robustness in dense, multi-object detection. Results show how annotation density, IoU thresholds, and model size interact: recall-optimized models perform better in crowded environments, whereas precision-oriented models perform best in sparse scenarios. In both cases, the Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) optimizer consistently performed better than alternatives. These density-sensitive sensors are helpful for non-destructive crop analysis, growth tracking, robotic pollination, and stress evaluation.

AI.tldr: They introduce the FloralSix dataset and benchmark multiple YOLO variants across sparse (SISBB) and dense (SIMBB) flower-detection settings. YOLOv8m with SGD excels on isolated flowers, while YOLOv12n with SGD leads in crowded, multi-object scenes. SGD consistently outperforms other optimizers, and precision/recall trade-offs depend on object density and IoU thresholds.
AI.motivation: Accurate flower localization underpins automated agriculture tasks—phenotyping, crop estimation, yield monitoring—and lacks tailored benchmarks spanning sparse and dense floral scenes.
AI.method: Create the FloralSix dataset (2,816 high-resolution images, six species) with annotations for sparse and clustered cases. Benchmark YOLOv5s, YOLOv8n/s/m, and YOLOv12n under two regimes: SISBB (single box per image) and SIMBB (multiple boxes per image). Train with different optimizers (notably SGD) and evaluate with Precision, Recall, mAP@0.5, and mAP@0.5:0.95. Analyze interactions among annotation density, IoU thresholds, and model size.
AI.result: SISBB: YOLOv8m (SGD) achieves Precision 0.956, Recall 0.951, mAP@0.5 0.978, mAP@0.5:0.95 0.865, indicating strong isolated-flower detection. SIMBB: YOLOv12n (SGD) attains mAP@0.5 0.934 and mAP@0.5:0.95 0.752, showing robustness in dense scenes. Models favoring recall perform better in crowded settings; precision-leaning models excel in sparse ones. Across settings, SGD consistently outperforms alternative optimizers.
AI.conclusion: Model and training choices should be density-aware: use recall-optimized (e.g., lighter) models for clustered flowers and precision-optimized (often larger) models for isolated flowers; prefer SGD. The proposed dataset and benchmarks support applications in non-destructive crop monitoring, growth tracking, robotic pollination, and stress assessment.

title: ReHear: Iterative Pseudo-Label Refinement for Semi-Supervised Speech Recognition via Audio Large Language Models
summary: Semi-supervised learning in automatic speech recognition (ASR) typically relies on pseudo-labeling, which often suffers from confirmation bias and error accumulation due to noisy supervision. To address this limitation, we propose ReHear, a framework for iterative pseudo-label refinement that integrates an instruction-tuned, audio-aware large language model (LLM) into the self-training loop. Unlike conventional text-based correctors, our approach conditions the LLM on both the ASR hypothesis and the source audio, allowing it to recover phonetically accurate transcripts even from severe recognition errors. These refined pseudo-labels serve as high-fidelity targets for fine-tuning the ASR model in an iterative cycle. Experimental results across diverse benchmarks demonstrate that ReHear effectively mitigates error propagation, consistently outperforming both supervised and pseudo-labeling baselines.

AI.tldr: ReHear is an iterative semi-supervised ASR framework that uses an instruction-tuned, audio-aware LLM to refine pseudo-labels by conditioning on both the ASR hypothesis and the source audio, reducing error propagation and outperforming standard supervised and pseudo-labeling baselines.
AI.motivation: Conventional pseudo-labeling in semi-supervised ASR suffers from noisy supervision that causes confirmation bias and error accumulation. Text-only correctors cannot leverage acoustic cues to fix phonetically driven errors. There is a need for a mechanism that directly references the audio to improve pseudo-label fidelity.
AI.method: Integrate an instruction-tuned, audio-aware LLM into the self-training loop. For each unlabeled utterance, feed the ASR hypothesis together with the corresponding audio into the LLM to generate a refined transcript. Use these refined pseudo-labels as targets to fine-tune the ASR model, and iterate this process over multiple rounds.
AI.result: On multiple benchmarks, the approach mitigates error propagation and consistently surpasses both fully supervised baselines and conventional pseudo-labeling methods. The abstract does not report exact numbers but claims consistent gains.
AI.conclusion: Audio-conditioned LLM-based pseudo-label refinement yields phonetically accurate targets that enhance semi-supervised ASR through iterative self-training. The method reduces reliance on noisy labels and improves performance over standard baselines.

title: GenPlanner: From Noise to Plans -- Emergent Reasoning in Flow Matching and Diffusion Models
summary: Path planning in complex environments is one of the key problems of artificial intelligence because it requires simultaneous understanding of the geometry of space and the global structure of the problem. In this paper, we explore the potential of using generative models as planning and reasoning mechanisms. We propose GenPlanner, an approach based on diffusion models and flow matching, along with two variants: DiffPlanner and FlowPlanner. We demonstrate the application of generative models to find and generate correct paths in mazes. A multi-channel condition describing the structure of the environment, including an obstacle map and information about the starting and destination points, is used to condition trajectory generation. Unlike standard methods, our models generate trajectories iteratively, starting with random noise and gradually transforming it into a correct solution. Experiments conducted show that the proposed approach significantly outperforms the baseline CNN model. In particular, FlowPlanner demonstrates high performance even with a limited number of generation steps.

AI.tldr: GenPlanner treats path planning as conditional trajectory generation using diffusion and flow-matching models conditioned on obstacle maps and endpoints, producing feasible maze paths that beat a CNN baseline; FlowPlanner remains strong even with few denoising steps.
AI.motivation: Path planning in complex spaces needs both local geometric reasoning and global structure understanding. Conventional planners or discriminative predictors can struggle to capture the distribution of feasible trajectories. The paper investigates whether modern generative models can directly sample valid paths when conditioned on environment structure.
AI.method: Introduce GenPlanner, instantiated as DiffPlanner (diffusion) and FlowPlanner (flow matching). The environment is encoded as multi-channel inputs (obstacle map, start, goal). Training aligns iterative denoising/flow trajectories from noise to ground-truth paths; at inference, the model iteratively transforms noise into a valid path, enforcing feasibility via conditioning.
AI.result: On maze benchmarks, both variants significantly outperform a CNN baseline. FlowPlanner achieves high accuracy with relatively few generation steps, indicating better sampling efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Conditional generative models are effective planning mechanisms for discrete maze navigation; the flow-matching variant provides strong performance with reduced iteration counts, highlighting efficiency. This supports generative planning as a promising alternative to standard approaches.

title: Effect of Patch Size on Fine-Tuning Vision Transformers in Two-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional Medical Image Classification
summary:
Vision Transformers (ViTs) and their variants have become state-of-the-art in many computer vision tasks and are widely used as backbones in large-scale vision and vision-language foundation models. While substantial research has focused on architectural improvements, the impact of patch size, a crucial initial design choice in ViTs, remains underexplored, particularly in medical domains where both two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) imaging modalities exist.
  In this study, using 12 medical imaging datasets from various imaging modalities (including seven 2D and five 3D datasets), we conduct a thorough evaluation of how different patch sizes affect ViT classification performance. Using a single graphical processing unit (GPU) and a range of patch sizes (1, 2, 4, 7, 14, 28), we fine-tune ViT models and observe consistent improvements in classification performance with smaller patch sizes (1, 2, and 4), which achieve the best results across nearly all datasets. More specifically, our results indicate improvements in balanced accuracy of up to 12.78% for 2D datasets (patch size 2 vs. 28) and up to 23.78% for 3D datasets (patch size 1 vs. 14), at the cost of increased computational expense. Moreover, by applying a straightforward ensemble strategy that fuses the predictions of the models trained with patch sizes 1, 2, and 4, we demonstrate a further boost in performance in most cases, especially for the 2D datasets. Our implementation is publicly available on GitHub: https://github.com/HealMaDe/MedViT

AI.tldr: Across 12 medical imaging datasets (2D and 3D), smaller ViT patch sizes (1–4) consistently yield higher classification accuracy than larger patches, though at higher compute; ensembling small-patch models boosts performance further.
AI.motivation: Despite many architectural advances in ViTs, the foundational design choice of patch size is under-studied, especially in medical imaging that spans both 2D and 3D modalities where spatial granularity and context may trade off differently.
AI.method: Fine-tune ViT models on 12 datasets (7×2D, 5×3D) using a single GPU across patch sizes {1,2,4,7,14,28}; compare classification performance (balanced accuracy). Additionally, apply a simple prediction-fusion ensemble of models trained with patch sizes 1, 2, and 4.
AI.result: Smaller patches (1,2,4) consistently outperform larger ones across nearly all datasets. Reported gains in balanced accuracy reach up to +12.78% on 2D (patch size 2 vs 28) and up to +23.78% on 3D (patch size 1 vs 14). Ensembling small-patch models further improves results, especially on 2D, but increases computational cost.
AI.conclusion: For medical image classification with ViTs, favor small patch sizes to maximize performance, accepting higher computation, and consider ensembling multiple small-patch models for additional gains; public code is provided for reproducibility.

title: Rethinking Retrieval-Augmented Generation as a Cooperative Decision-Making Problem
summary: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) has demonstrated strong effectiveness in knowledge-intensive tasks by grounding language generation in external evidence. Despite its success, many existing RAG systems are built based on a ranking-centric, asymmetric dependency paradigm, where the generation quality of the generator is highly dependent on reranking results of the reranker. To overcome this limitation, we reformulate RAG as a cooperative multi-agent decision-making problem and propose Cooperative Retrieval-Augmented Generation (CoRAG), a framework in which the reranker and the generator act as peer decision-makers rather than being connected through an asymmetric dependency pipeline. By jointly optimizing their behaviors toward a shared task objective, the reranker and generator are encouraged to cooperate, ensuring that document reranking and generation work in concert to improve the final response. Experimental results demonstrate good generalization and improved generation stability of CoRAG, even when the model is trained on only around 10K PopQA samples. Our model released in https://anonymous.4open.science/r/CoRAG-D63F

AI.tldr: CoRAG reframes RAG as a cooperative multi-agent problem where reranker and generator are jointly optimized as peers, reducing asymmetric dependency on reranking and yielding more stable, generalizable generation with limited training data (~10K PopQA).
AI.motivation: Standard RAG pipelines are ranking-centric: the generator’s quality is tightly coupled to the reranker, creating an asymmetric dependency that can propagate reranking errors and hurt robustness. A more coordinated approach could improve faithfulness, stability, and generalization.
AI.method: Treat reranker and generator as cooperative decision-makers optimized toward a shared objective. Replace the unidirectional pipeline with joint optimization that encourages the reranker’s document ordering and the generator’s use of evidence to align, effectively implementing cooperative behavior within RAG. Trained on ~10K PopQA samples; code is released.
AI.result: Experiments show improved response stability and good generalization compared to standard RAG, despite training on a relatively small dataset. The approach appears to maintain or improve answer quality while reducing sensitivity to reranking errors.
AI.conclusion: CoRAG mitigates the pipeline’s asymmetric dependency by fostering cooperation between reranking and generation, producing more stable, generalizable outputs. The framework suggests a promising direction for RAG systems and is supported by a public implementation.

title: ABD: Default Exception Abduction in Finite First Order Worlds
summary: We introduce ABD, a benchmark for default-exception abduction over finite first-order worlds. Given a background theory with an abnormality predicate and a set of relational structures, a model must output a first-order formula that defines exceptions, restoring satisfiability while keeping exceptions sparse. We formalize three observation regimes (closed-world, existential completion, universal completion) with exact SMT verification. Evaluating ten frontier LLMs on 600 instances, the best models achieve high validity but parsimony gaps remain, and holdout evaluation reveals distinct generalization failure modes across regimes.

AI.tldr: ABD is a rigorously verified benchmark for inferring sparse exception rules that restore consistency in finite first‑order worlds; it defines three observation regimes and shows LLMs can fix validity but overgenerate exceptions and generalize unreliably across regimes.
AI.motivation: Default reasoning needs systematic tests that require proposing minimal, explicit exception rules to reconcile a background theory with observed structures. Existing evaluations lack formal, exact verification and do not probe observability assumptions that shape abduction difficulty.
AI.method: Define a task: given a background first‑order theory with an abnormality predicate and a set of finite relational structures, output a first‑order formula characterizing exceptions so the theory becomes satisfiable while keeping exceptions sparse. Formalize three observation regimes (closed‑world, existential completion, universal completion). Use exact SMT checking to verify satisfiability and quantify parsimony. Construct 600 instances and evaluate 10 frontier LLMs.
AI.result: Best models often restore satisfiability (high validity) but select too many exceptions (parsimony gaps). Holdout tests reveal distinct generalization failure modes that differ by observation regime.
AI.conclusion: ABD establishes a precise, SMT‑checked benchmark for exception abduction. Current LLMs can achieve validity but lack parsimony and reliable cross‑regime generalization, indicating a need for methods that explicitly optimize minimal exception sets and improve robustness to observability shifts.

title: Narrating For You: Prompt-guided Audio-visual Narrating Face Generation Employing Multi-entangled Latent Space
comment: To appear in the Proceedings of the IEEE/CVF Winter Conference on Applications of Computer Vision (WACV) 2026. Presented at Poster Session 1
summary: We present a novel approach for generating realistic speaking and talking faces by synthesizing a person's voice and facial movements from a static image, a voice profile, and a target text. The model encodes the prompt/driving text, the driving image, and the voice profile of an individual and then combines them to pass them to the multi-entangled latent space to foster key-value pairs and queries for the audio and video modality generation pipeline. The multi-entangled latent space is responsible for establishing the spatiotemporal person-specific features between the modalities. Further, entangled features are passed to the respective decoder of each modality for output audio and video generation.

AI.tldr: A multimodal system jointly synthesizes a person’s speech and matching talking‑head video from a single face image, a voice profile, and target text by learning a shared, multi‑entangled latent space and decoding synchronized audio and video.
AI.motivation: Enable realistic, synchronized talking‑head generation from minimal inputs while preserving identity and voice consistency; overcome desynchronization and identity drift seen when audio and video are modeled separately.
AI.method: Encode the prompt text (linguistic content), a driving/static face image (visual identity), and a voice profile (speaker timbre). Fuse them in a multi‑entangled latent space that forms key–value pairs and queries to capture cross‑modal, person‑specific spatiotemporal features. Feed these entangled features into modality‑specific decoders to generate the speech audio and the lip‑synced video.
AI.result: Qualitatively, the approach yields realistic speaking faces with synchronized audio–video and preserved person‑specific characteristics. The abstract does not report quantitative benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: A shared, entangled latent representation effectively binds audio and video for person‑specific talking‑head synthesis from minimal prompts. This joint modeling improves cross‑modal coherence and suggests a path for controllable, identity‑preserving avatar generation; future work should add thorough evaluations and address ethical safeguards.

title: ArabicNumBench: Evaluating Arabic Number Reading in Large Language Models
summary: We present ArabicNumBench, a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating large language models on Arabic number reading tasks across Eastern Arabic-Indic numerals (0-9 in Arabic script) and Western Arabic numerals (0-9). We evaluate 71 models from 10 providers using four prompting strategies (zero-shot, zero-shot CoT, few-shot, few-shot CoT) on 210 number reading tasks spanning six contextual categories: pure numerals, addresses, dates, quantities, and prices. Our evaluation comprises 59,010 individual test cases and tracks extraction methods to measure structured output generation. Evaluation reveals substantial performance variation, with accuracy ranging from 14.29\% to 99.05\% across models and strategies. Few-shot Chain-of-Thought prompting achieves 2.8x higher accuracy than zero-shot approaches (80.06\% vs 28.76\%). A striking finding emerges: models achieving elite accuracy (98-99\%) often produce predominantly unstructured output, with most responses lacking Arabic CoT markers. Only 6 models consistently generate structured output across all test cases, while the majority require fallback extraction methods despite high numerical accuracy. Comprehensive evaluation of 281 model-strategy combinations demonstrates that numerical accuracy and instruction-following represent distinct capabilities, establishing baselines for Arabic number comprehension and providing actionable guidance for model selection in production Arabic NLP systems.

AI.tldr: ArabicNumBench is a large benchmark assessing LLMs’ ability to read and structure Arabic numbers (Eastern Arabic-Indic and Western) across real-world contexts, revealing wide accuracy variance, strong gains from few-shot CoT, and a disconnect between numerical correctness and structured output compliance.
AI.motivation: Arabic number reading is critical for production NLP (e.g., addresses, dates, prices), yet current evaluations underrepresent Arabic scripts, mixed numeral systems, and the requirement for reliably structured outputs. Practitioners need guidance on model/prompt choices that balance accuracy with instruction-following for extraction. This work aims to establish clear baselines and expose capability gaps specific to Arabic numeracy and formatting.
AI.method: They build a benchmark of 210 tasks spanning six contextual categories (e.g., pure numerals, addresses, dates, quantities, prices), covering both Eastern Arabic-Indic and Western numerals. They evaluate 71 models from 10 providers under four prompting regimes: zero-shot, zero-shot CoT, few-shot, and few-shot CoT. The test suite comprises 59,010 cases and tracks extraction methods to quantify structured output generation, yielding 281 model–strategy combinations.
AI.result: Accuracy ranges from 14.29% to 99.05% across models/strategies. Few-shot CoT achieves 80.06% vs 28.76% for zero-shot (≈2.8× improvement). Models with elite accuracy (98–99%) often return unstructured outputs and lack Arabic CoT markers; only 6 models consistently produce structured outputs across all cases. Most systems require fallback extraction despite high numeric accuracy, showing numerical correctness and instruction-following are distinct capabilities.
AI.conclusion: ArabicNumBench sets strong baselines for Arabic number comprehension and highlights that prompt design and structured-output reliability are as crucial as raw accuracy. The findings provide actionable guidance for selecting models and prompting strategies in production Arabic NLP, while underscoring the need to improve structured generation alongside numerical reasoning.

title: TPRU: Advancing Temporal and Procedural Understanding in Large Multimodal Models
comment: Accepted to ICLR 2026. 17 pages. Code, data, and models are available at: https://github.com/Stephen-gzk/TPRU
summary: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs), particularly smaller, deployable variants, exhibit a critical deficiency in understanding temporal and procedural visual data, a bottleneck hindering their application in real-world embodied AI. This gap is largely caused by a systemic failure in training paradigms, which lack large-scale, procedurally coherent data. To address this problem, we introduce TPRU, a large-scale dataset sourced from diverse embodied scenarios such as robotic manipulation and GUI navigation. TPRU is systematically designed to cultivate temporal reasoning through three complementary tasks: Temporal Reordering, Next-Frame Prediction, and Previous-Frame Review. A key feature is the inclusion of challenging negative samples, compelling models to transition from passive observation to active, cross-modal validation. We leverage TPRU with a reinforcement learning (RL) fine-tuning methodology, specifically targeting the enhancement of resource-efficient models. Experiments show our approach yields dramatic gains: on our manually curated TPRU-Test, the accuracy of TPRU-7B soars from 50.33\% to 75.70\%, a state-of-the-art result that significantly outperforms vastly larger baselines, including GPT-4o. Crucially, these capabilities generalize effectively, demonstrating substantial improvements on established benchmarks. The codebase is available at https://github.com/Stephen-gzk/TPRU/ .

AI.tldr: They introduce TPRU, a large-scale multimodal dataset and RL fine-tuning recipe to teach small MLLMs temporal/procedural visual reasoning, yielding large gains (e.g., 50.33%→75.70% on TPRU-Test) and reported generalization that surpasses larger models like GPT-4o.
AI.motivation: Smaller, deployable MLLMs underperform on temporal and procedural understanding, largely due to training regimes lacking large-scale, temporally coherent, procedurally grounded data for embodied settings.
AI.method: Create TPRU from diverse embodied scenarios (robotic manipulation, GUI navigation). Design three complementary tasks—Temporal Reordering, Next-Frame Prediction, and Previous-Frame Review—with hard negative samples to force active, cross-modal validation. Apply a reinforcement learning fine-tuning pipeline targeted at resource-efficient models to improve temporal reasoning.
AI.result: On a curated TPRU-Test set, their 7B model’s accuracy improves from 50.33% to 75.70%, achieving state-of-the-art and outperforming larger baselines including GPT-4o, with additional gains reported on established benchmarks beyond TPRU.
AI.conclusion: Combining procedurally coherent temporal data with RL fine-tuning substantially strengthens temporal reasoning in compact MLLMs, with benefits that transfer to external benchmarks. The dataset and code are released for reproducibility and further research.

title: Deep LoRA-Unfolding Networks for Image Restoration
comment: Accepted by IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
summary: Deep unfolding networks (DUNs), combining conventional iterative optimization algorithms and deep neural networks into a multi-stage framework, have achieved remarkable accomplishments in Image Restoration (IR), such as spectral imaging reconstruction, compressive sensing and super-resolution.It unfolds the iterative optimization steps into a stack of sequentially linked blocks.Each block consists of a Gradient Descent Module (GDM) and a Proximal Mapping Module (PMM) which is equivalent to a denoiser from a Bayesian perspective, operating on Gaussian noise with a known level.However, existing DUNs suffer from two critical limitations: (i) their PMMs share identical architectures and denoising objectives across stages, ignoring the need for stage-specific adaptation to varying noise levels; and (ii) their chain of structurally repetitive blocks results in severe parameter redundancy and high memory consumption, hindering deployment in large-scale or resource-constrained scenarios.To address these challenges, we introduce generalized Deep Low-rank Adaptation (LoRA) Unfolding Networks for image restoration, named LoRun, harmonizing denoising objectives and adapting different denoising levels between stages with compressed memory usage for more efficient DUN.LoRun introduces a novel paradigm where a single pretrained base denoiser is shared across all stages, while lightweight, stage-specific LoRA adapters are injected into the PMMs to dynamically modulate denoising behavior according to the noise level at each unfolding step.This design decouples the core restoration capability from task-specific adaptation, enabling precise control over denoising intensity without duplicating full network parameters and achieving up to $N$ times parameter reduction for an $N$-stage DUN with on-par or better performance.Extensive experiments conducted on three IR tasks validate the efficiency of our method.

AI.tldr: LoRun is a deep unfolding network for image restoration that shares one pretrained base denoiser across stages and injects lightweight, stage-specific LoRA adapters into the proximal mapping modules to tune denoising per noise level, cutting parameters by up to N× for an N-stage DUN while matching or improving accuracy.
AI.motivation: Existing DUNs reuse identical proximal modules across stages, ignoring stage-specific noise-level variation, and replicate full block parameters, creating redundancy and high memory usage that hinder scaling and deployment.
AI.method: Unfold iterative optimization into stages with gradient descent and proximal mapping. Keep a single shared base denoiser for all stages; add stage-specific low-rank (LoRA) adapters inside each PMM to dynamically modulate denoising intensity/objective according to per-stage noise. This decouples core restoration capability from adaptation, harmonizes denoising objectives across stages, and compresses parameters.
AI.result: Across three image restoration tasks (e.g., spectral imaging reconstruction, compressive sensing, super-resolution), LoRun achieves on-par or better performance than standard DUNs while reducing parameters by up to N× for an N-stage network, with lower memory consumption.
AI.conclusion: Stage-adaptive LoRA adapters over a shared denoiser make DUNs both more flexible (noise-level aware) and significantly more parameter/memory efficient, facilitating deployment in large-scale or resource-constrained settings without sacrificing quality.

title: BURMESE-SAN: Burmese NLP Benchmark for Evaluating Large Language Models
summary: We introduce BURMESE-SAN, the first holistic benchmark that systematically evaluates large language models (LLMs) for Burmese across three core NLP competencies: understanding (NLU), reasoning (NLR), and generation (NLG). BURMESE-SAN consolidates seven subtasks spanning these competencies, including Question Answering, Sentiment Analysis, Toxicity Detection, Causal Reasoning, Natural Language Inference, Abstractive Summarization, and Machine Translation, several of which were previously unavailable for Burmese. The benchmark is constructed through a rigorous native-speaker-driven process to ensure linguistic naturalness, fluency, and cultural authenticity while minimizing translation-induced artifacts. We conduct a large-scale evaluation of both open-weight and commercial LLMs to examine challenges in Burmese modeling arising from limited pretraining coverage, rich morphology, and syntactic variation. Our results show that Burmese performance depends more on architectural design, language representation, and instruction tuning than on model scale alone. In particular, Southeast Asia regional fine-tuning and newer model generations yield substantial gains. Finally, we release BURMESE-SAN as a public leaderboard to support systematic evaluation and sustained progress in Burmese and other low-resource languages. https://leaderboard.sea-lion.ai/detailed/MY

AI.tldr: BURMESE-SAN introduces the first comprehensive Burmese benchmark spanning NLU, reasoning, and generation with seven subtasks, built by native speakers to avoid translation artifacts, and shows that architecture, language representation, and instruction tuning—especially SEA-focused fine-tuning—matter more than sheer model size. A public leaderboard is released to drive ongoing progress.
AI.motivation: Burmese is severely underrepresented in LLM evaluation, and existing resources are piecemeal or translation-heavy, which distorts performance. There is a need for a culturally authentic, task-diverse benchmark to diagnose modeling challenges in a morphologically rich, syntactically varied, low-resource language and to guide development for Southeast Asian languages.
AI.method: Construct a multi-competency benchmark (NLU, NLR, NLG) covering QA, Sentiment, Toxicity, Causal Reasoning, NLI, Abstractive Summarization, and MT. Use native-speaker-driven data creation to ensure naturalness and minimize translation artifacts. Evaluate a wide range of open and commercial LLMs, analyzing effects of pretraining coverage, morphology/syntax, architecture, language representation, instruction tuning, model scale, and regional (SEA) fine-tuning.
AI.result: Models’ Burmese performance correlates more with architecture choices, linguistic representation quality, and instruction tuning than with parameter count. Newer model generations and Southeast Asia regional fine-tuning yield notable gains across tasks. Several Burmese tasks are introduced for the first time and included in a public leaderboard.
AI.conclusion: BURMESE-SAN provides a standardized, culturally grounded evaluation framework for Burmese, highlighting that targeted design and tuning outperform naive scaling. The released leaderboard supports transparent, sustained benchmarking and can generalize lessons to other low-resource languages.

title: Early Evidence of Vibe-Proving with Consumer LLMs: A Case Study on Spectral Region Characterization with ChatGPT-5.2 (Thinking)
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly used as scientific copilots, but evidence on their role in research-level mathematics remains limited, especially for workflows accessible to individual researchers. We present early evidence for vibe-proving with a consumer subscription LLM through an auditable case study that resolves Conjecture 20 of Ran and Teng (2024) on the exact nonreal spectral region of a 4-cycle row-stochastic nonnegative matrix family. We analyze seven shareable ChatGPT-5.2 (Thinking) threads and four versioned proof drafts, documenting an iterative pipeline of generate, referee, and repair. The model is most useful for high-level proof search, while human experts remain essential for correctness-critical closure. The final theorem provides necessary and sufficient region conditions and explicit boundary attainment constructions. Beyond the mathematical result, we contribute a process-level characterization of where LLM assistance materially helps and where verification bottlenecks persist, with implications for evaluation of AI-assisted research workflows and for designing human-in-the-loop theorem proving systems.

AI.tldr: Audited case study shows a consumer LLM can materially aid research‑level math by guiding high‑level proof search to resolve a concrete open conjecture on the nonreal spectrum of a 4‑cycle row‑stochastic nonnegative matrix family; humans remain essential for verification and final correctness. The work yields a sharp theorem (necessary/sufficient region + boundary constructions) and maps where LLM help is most/least effective for human‑in‑the‑loop theorem proving.
AI.motivation: Evidence for LLMs as practical scientific copilots in rigorous mathematics is sparse, especially in workflows accessible to solo researchers. The authors both test this premise and target a specific open problem—Conjecture 20 of Ran & Teng (2024)—to assess where LLM assistance is valuable and where verification bottlenecks arise.
AI.method: An auditable, iterative generate–referee–repair pipeline using a consumer subscription LLM (ChatGPT‑5.2, Thinking). The authors analyze seven shareable model interaction threads and four versioned proof drafts, focusing on process tracing (“vibe‑proving”) to evaluate how LLM suggestions integrate with expert human verification.
AI.result: They resolve Conjecture 20 by proving necessary and sufficient conditions for the exact nonreal spectral region of the specified matrix family and provide explicit constructions attaining the boundary. Process analysis shows the LLM excels at high‑level proof search and idea generation, while humans are required for correctness‑critical closure and verification.
AI.conclusion: Consumer LLMs can accelerate discovery and structure proof search in research mathematics, but cannot replace human rigor. Transparent, auditable workflows and tools that target verification and closure are key. The findings inform evaluation criteria and design principles for human‑in‑the‑loop theorem‑proving systems.

title: Think with Grounding: Curriculum Reinforced Reasoning with Video Grounding for Long Video Understanding
summary: Long video understanding is challenging due to rich and complicated multimodal clues in long temporal range.Current methods adopt reasoning to improve the model's ability to analyze complex video clues in long videos via text-form reasoning.However,the existing literature suffers from the fact that the text-only reasoning under fixed video context may exacerbate hallucinations since detailed crucial clues are often ignored under limited video context length due to the temporal redundancy of long videos.To address this gap,we propose Video-TwG,a curriculum reinforced framework that employs a novel Think-with-Grounding paradigm,enabling video LLMs to actively decide when to perform on-demand grounding during interleaved text-video reasoning, selectively zooming into question-relevant clips only when necessary.Video-TwG can be trained end-to-end in a straightforward manner, without relying on complex auxiliary modules or heavily annotated reasoning tracesIn detail,we design a Two-stage Reinforced Curriculum Strategy, where the model first learns think-with-grounding behavior on a small short-video GQA dataset with grounding labels,and then scales to diverse general QA data with videos of diverse domains to encourage generalization. Further, to handle complex think-with-grounding reasoning for various kinds of data,we propose TwG-GRPO algorithm which features the fine-grained grounding reward, self-confirmed pseudo reward and accuracy-gated mechanism.Finally,we propose to construct a new TwG-51K dataset that facilitates training. Experiments on Video-MME, LongVideoBench, and MLVU show that Video-TwG consistently outperforms strong LVU baselines.Further ablation validates the necessity of our Two-stage Reinforced Curriculum Strategy and shows our TwG-GRPO better leverages diverse unlabeled data to improve grounding quality and reduce redundant groundings without sacrificing QA performance.

AI.tldr: Video-TwG is a curriculum-RL framework that interleaves language reasoning with on-demand visual grounding, letting a video LLM decide when to zoom into relevant clips. Trained in two stages with a new TwG-51K dataset and a TwG-GRPO algorithm, it reduces hallucinations and redundant groundings and outperforms prior long-video understanding baselines on multiple benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Text-only reasoning over long videos is prone to hallucination because fixed-length video contexts miss crucial details amid temporal redundancy. The field needs a scalable way for models to ground reasoning in the right clips only when necessary, without heavy annotations or complex modules.
AI.method: Introduce Video-TwG with a Think-with-Grounding paradigm: the model dynamically triggers visual grounding during interleaved text–video reasoning to selectively inspect question-relevant segments. Train end-to-end via a Two-stage Reinforced Curriculum Strategy—(1) learn grounding behavior on a small short-video GQA set with grounding labels, then (2) generalize on diverse video QA data. Propose TwG-GRPO with (i) fine-grained grounding rewards, (ii) self-confirmed pseudo rewards, and (iii) an accuracy-gated mechanism. Construct the TwG-51K dataset to support training.
AI.result: On Video-MME, LongVideoBench, and MLVU, Video-TwG consistently surpasses strong long-video understanding baselines. Ablations show the two-stage curriculum is necessary and TwG-GRPO better exploits unlabeled data to improve grounding quality and cut redundant grounding without hurting QA accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Coupling interleaved reasoning with on-demand grounding via curriculum RL provides a simple, annotation-light, end-to-end approach for long-video QA that mitigates hallucinations, improves grounding efficiency, and achieves strong results across benchmarks.

title: Think$^{2}$: Grounded Metacognitive Reasoning in Large Language Models
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate strong reasoning performance, yet their ability to reliably monitor, diagnose, and correct their own errors remains limited.
