We introduce a psychologically grounded metacognitive framework that operationalizes Ann Brown's regulatory cycle (Planning, Monitoring, and Evaluation) as a structured prompting architecture, and study its integration within a lightweight dual-process MetaController for adaptive effort allocation. Across diverse reasoning and diagnostic benchmarks (GSM8K, CRUXEval, MBPP, AIME, CorrectBench, and TruthfulQA) using Llama-3 and Qwen-3 (8B), explicit regulatory structuring substantially improves error diagnosis and yields a threefold increase in successful self-correction. Blinded human evaluations over 580 query pairs show an 84% aggregate preference for trustworthiness and metacognitive self-awareness over standard and Chain-of-Thought baselines. Grounding LLM reasoning in established cognitive theory offers a principled path toward more transparent and diagnostically robust AI systems.

AI.tldr: They map Ann Brown’s metacognitive cycle—Planning, Monitoring, Evaluation—into a structured prompting scheme and add a lightweight dual‑process MetaController to adapt effort. On multiple benchmarks with 8B Llama‑3 and Qwen‑3, this substantially improves error diagnosis, triples successful self‑correction, and wins 84% human preference for trustworthiness vs. standard/CoT baselines.
AI.motivation: LLMs can reason but struggle to reliably detect, explain, and fix their own mistakes. A principled, psychologically grounded form of metacognitive regulation could make them more trustworthy and self-correcting.
AI.method: Operationalize Brown’s regulatory cycle as an explicit prompt scaffold (Planning → Monitoring → Evaluation). Add a dual‑process MetaController to allocate/adjust reasoning effort. Evaluate on GSM8K, CRUXEval, MBPP, AIME, CorrectBench, TruthfulQA with Llama‑3 and Qwen‑3 (8B). Include blinded human comparisons against standard and Chain‑of‑Thought baselines.
AI.result: Explicit regulatory structure yields substantially better error diagnosis and ~3× more successful self‑corrections. In 580 blinded comparisons, raters prefer outputs for trustworthiness/metacognitive self‑awareness 84% of the time over baselines.
AI.conclusion: Grounding prompting in cognitive theory improves transparency and diagnostic robustness of LLM reasoning; metacognitive regulation is an effective, lightweight path to more reliable self‑correction across tasks.

title: DREAM: Deep Research Evaluation with Agentic Metrics
summary: Deep Research Agents generate analyst-grade reports, yet evaluating them remains challenging due to the absence of a single ground truth and the multidimensional nature of research quality. Recent benchmarks propose distinct methodologies, yet they suffer from the Mirage of Synthesis, where strong surface-level fluency and citation alignment can obscure underlying factual and reasoning defects. We characterize this gap by introducing a taxonomy across four verticals that exposes a critical capability mismatch: static evaluators inherently lack the tool-use capabilities required to assess temporal validity and factual correctness. To address this, we propose DREAM (Deep Research Evaluation with Agentic Metrics), a framework that instantiates the principle of capability parity by making evaluation itself agentic. DREAM structures assessment through an evaluation protocol combining query-agnostic metrics with adaptive metrics generated by a tool-calling agent, enabling temporally aware coverage, grounded verification, and systematic reasoning probes. Controlled evaluations demonstrate DREAM is significantly more sensitive to factual and temporal decay than existing benchmarks, offering a scalable, reference-free evaluation paradigm.

AI.tldr: Introduces DREAM, an agentic, tool-using evaluation framework for deep research agents that pairs static, query-agnostic metrics with adaptive, tool-driven probes to detect factual and temporal errors; controlled tests show higher sensitivity than prior static benchmarks, enabling scalable, reference-free assessment.
AI.motivation: Evaluating long-form research agents is hard because there is no single ground truth and quality is multidimensional. Existing static benchmarks overvalue fluency and citation alignment—the “Mirage of Synthesis”—and miss factual/reasoning defects and temporal decay. The authors argue evaluators need capability parity with research agents, including tool-use, to check time-sensitive validity and correctness.
AI.method: (1) Characterize the evaluation gap with a taxonomy across four verticals showing that static evaluators lack tool-use needed for temporal and factual assessment. (2) Propose DREAM, which makes evaluation itself agentic: an evaluator agent uses tools to generate adaptive metrics alongside query-agnostic ones. (3) The protocol enables temporally aware coverage checks, grounded verification against sources, and systematic reasoning probes. (4) Validate with controlled experiments comparing sensitivity to factual and temporal decay vs existing benchmarks.
AI.result: DREAM is significantly more sensitive to factual errors and temporal decay than prior benchmarks in controlled evaluations, while remaining scalable and reference-free.
AI.conclusion: Agentic, tool-using evaluators achieve capability parity and better reveal hidden reasoning and factual defects, mitigating the Mirage of Synthesis. DREAM offers a practical path for temporally aware, grounded, and scalable evaluation of research agents without relying on fixed references.

title: IRIS-SLAM: Unified Geo-Instance Representations for Robust Semantic Localization and Mapping
summary: Geometry foundation models have significantly advanced dense geometric SLAM, yet existing systems often lack deep semantic understanding and robust loop closure capabilities. Meanwhile, contemporary semantic mapping approaches are frequently hindered by decoupled architectures and fragile data association. We propose IRIS-SLAM, a novel RGB semantic SLAM system that leverages unified geometric-instance representations derived from an instance-extended foundation model. By extending a geometry foundation model to concurrently predict dense geometry and cross-view consistent instance embeddings, we enable a semantic-synergized association mechanism and instance-guided loop closure detection. Our approach effectively utilizes viewpoint-agnostic semantic anchors to bridge the gap between geometric reconstruction and open-vocabulary mapping. Experimental results demonstrate that IRIS-SLAM significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly in map consistency and wide-baseline loop closure reliability.

AI.tldr: IRIS-SLAM extends a geometry foundation model to jointly predict dense geometry and cross-view consistent instance embeddings from RGB, creating unified geometric–instance representations that strengthen data association, semantic mapping, and loop closure; it reports SOTA gains in map consistency and wide-baseline loop closures.
AI.motivation: Dense geometric SLAM lacks deep semantic understanding and robust loop closure, while contemporary semantic mapping often uses decoupled pipelines with brittle data association. There is a need to unify geometry and semantics with viewpoint-agnostic anchors to support open-vocabulary mapping and reliable loop closure.
AI.method: Extend a geometry foundation model to output both dense geometry and cross-view consistent instance embeddings. Use these unified geometric–instance representations to (1) perform semantic-synergized data association across frames and (2) drive instance-guided loop closure detection. Leverage viewpoint-agnostic semantic anchors to connect reconstruction with open-vocabulary mapping.
AI.result: Experiments show significant improvements over state-of-the-art baselines, particularly in overall map consistency and the reliability of wide-baseline loop closure detection.
AI.conclusion: A unified geometric–instance foundation-model-based RGB SLAM framework effectively bridges geometric reconstruction with semantic/open-vocabulary mapping, yielding more robust association and loop closure and leading to superior mapping quality.

title: EvalSense: A Framework for Domain-Specific LLM (Meta-)Evaluation
summary: Robust and comprehensive evaluation of large language models (LLMs) is essential for identifying effective LLM system configurations and mitigating risks associated with deploying LLMs in sensitive domains. However, traditional statistical metrics are poorly suited to open-ended generation tasks, leading to growing reliance on LLM-based evaluation methods. These methods, while often more flexible, introduce additional complexity: they depend on carefully chosen models, prompts, parameters, and evaluation strategies, making the evaluation process prone to misconfiguration and bias. In this work, we present EvalSense, a flexible, extensible framework for constructing domain-specific evaluation suites for LLMs. EvalSense provides out-of-the-box support for a broad range of model providers and evaluation strategies, and assists users in selecting and deploying suitable evaluation methods for their specific use-cases. This is achieved through two unique components: (1) an interactive guide aiding users in evaluation method selection and (2) automated meta-evaluation tools that assess the reliability of different evaluation approaches using perturbed data. We demonstrate the effectiveness of EvalSense in a case study involving the generation of clinical notes from unstructured doctor-patient dialogues, using a popular open dataset. All code, documentation, and assets associated with EvalSense are open-source and publicly available at https://github.com/nhsengland/evalsense.

AI.tldr: EvalSense is an open-source framework that helps teams design domain-specific LLM evaluation suites by guiding method selection and automatically stress-testing evaluators via data perturbations; demonstrated on clinical note generation.
AI.motivation: Open-ended LLM outputs are hard to score with traditional metrics, pushing practitioners to LLM-as-judge methods that are sensitive to model/prompt/parameter choices and can be biased. Practitioners need principled guidance and reliability checks when configuring evaluations.
AI.method: Provide a flexible framework with broad model/evaluator support, two key components: (1) an interactive guide to select appropriate evaluation strategies for a given task/domain, (2) automated meta-evaluation that perturbs inputs/outputs to test evaluator robustness and reliability. Validate via a case study on clinical note generation from dialogue using a public dataset.
AI.result: EvalSense integrates multiple providers and strategies out-of-the-box and, in a clinical note generation case study, demonstrates practical effectiveness for selecting and validating evaluation approaches; meta-evaluation surfaces reliability differences across evaluators. Specific quantitative gains are not detailed in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: A practical, extensible approach to reduce misconfiguration and bias in LLM evaluation for open-ended tasks. By pairing guided selection with automated reliability checks, EvalSense can make evaluations more trustworthy, especially in sensitive domains; resources are openly available for adoption.

title: High Dimensional Procedural Content Generation
summary: Procedural content generation (PCG) has made substantial progress in shaping static 2D/3D geometry, while most methods treat gameplay mechanics as auxiliary and optimize only over space. We argue that this limits controllability and expressivity, and formally introduce High-Dimensional PCG (HDPCG): a framework that elevates non-geometric gameplay dimensions to first-class coordinates of a joint state space. We instantiate HDPCG along two concrete directions. Direction-Space augments geometry with a discrete layer dimension and validates reachability in 4D (x,y,z,l), enabling unified treatment of 2.5D/3.5D mechanics such as gravity inversion and parallel-world switching. Direction-Time augments geometry with temporal dynamics via time-expanded graphs, capturing action semantics and conflict rules. For each direction, we present three general, practicable algorithms with a shared pipeline of abstract skeleton generation, controlled grounding, high-dimensional validation, and multi-metric evaluation. Large-scale experiments across diverse settings validate the integrity of our problem formulation and the effectiveness of our methods on playability, structure, style, robustness, and efficiency. Beyond quantitative results, Unity-based case studies recreate playable scenarios that accord with our metrics. We hope HDPCG encourages a shift in PCG toward general representations and the generation of gameplay-relevant dimensions beyond geometry, paving the way for controllable, verifiable, and extensible level generation.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes High-Dimensional PCG (HDPCG), a framework that treats gameplay mechanics (e.g., layers/directions and time) as first-class coordinates alongside geometry, and provides general algorithms and validations showing improved controllability, playability, and robustness across diverse settings.
AI.motivation: Most PCG focuses on spatial geometry and treats gameplay mechanics as auxiliary, limiting control, expressivity, and verifiability of generated levels. The authors aim to unify geometry with non-geometric gameplay dimensions to enable controllable and semantically valid content generation.
AI.method: Formally define HDPCG as a joint state space including geometry and gameplay dimensions. Two instantiations: (1) Direction-Space adds a discrete layer coordinate l to 3D space (x,y,z,l) to model 2.5D/3.5D mechanics like gravity inversion and parallel-world switching via 4D reachability; (2) Direction-Time uses time-expanded graphs to encode temporal dynamics, actions, and conflict constraints. For each, they present three general algorithms following a shared pipeline: abstract skeleton generation, controlled grounding, high-dimensional validation, and multi-metric evaluation.
AI.result: Large-scale experiments across varied settings show the framework and methods produce playable, structured, stylistically controlled, robust, and efficient levels. Unity case studies demonstrate playable scenarios that align with the quantitative metrics.
AI.conclusion: HDPCG encourages a shift from geometry-only PCG toward general representations that include gameplay-relevant dimensions, enabling controllable, verifiable, and extensible level generation.

title: HIME: Mitigating Object Hallucinations in LVLMs via Hallucination Insensitivity Model Editing
summary: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have demonstrated impressive multimodal understanding capabilities, yet they remain prone to object hallucination, where models describe non-existent objects or attribute incorrect factual information, raising serious concerns for reliable real-world deployment. While fine-tuning is a commonly adopted mitigation strategy, its high computational cost and practical difficulty motivate the need for training-free alternatives, among which model editing has recently emerged as a promising direction. However, indiscriminate editing risks disrupting the rich implicit knowledge encoded in pre-trained LVLMs, leading to a fundamental question: how much intervention is necessary at each layer to suppress hallucinations while preserving pre-trained knowledge? To address this question, we present a systematic analysis of LVLM decoders built on three widely used large language model backbones-Qwen, LLaMA, and Vicuna-revealing clear layer-wise differences in susceptibility to object hallucination. Building on these insights, we introduce the Hallucination Insensitivity Score (HIS), a principled metric that quantifies each layer's sensitivity to hallucination and provides guidance for targeted intervention. Leveraging HIS, we propose Hallucination Insensitivity Model Editing (HIME), a simple yet effective layer-adaptive weight editing approach that selectively modifies latent features to suppress hallucinations while preserving pre-trained knowledge. Extensive experiments demonstrate that HIME reduces hallucinations by an average of 61.8% across open-ended generation benchmarks, including CHAIR, MME, and GPT-4V-aided evaluation, without introducing additional parameters, inference-time latency, or computational overhead.

AI.tldr: They propose HIME, a training‑free, layer‑adaptive model editing method guided by a new Hallucination Insensitivity Score (HIS) to reduce object hallucinations in LVLMs, achieving ~61.8% average reduction on CHAIR, MME, and GPT‑4V‑aided benchmarks without added parameters or latency.
AI.motivation: LVLMs often hallucinate objects or attributes, undermining reliability. Fine‑tuning mitigates this but is costly and cumbersome. Naïve model editing can harm useful pre‑trained knowledge. The key question: how much and where to intervene in the model to suppress hallucinations while preserving knowledge?
AI.method: They first conduct a layer‑wise analysis of LVLM decoders built on Qwen, LLaMA, and Vicuna to reveal differences in hallucination susceptibility across layers. They introduce the Hallucination Insensitivity Score (HIS) to quantify each layer’s sensitivity to hallucination. Using HIS, they design HIME, a layer‑adaptive weight editing technique that selectively modifies latent features in more susceptible layers to curb hallucinations while keeping other knowledge intact. The approach is training‑free and adds no parameters or inference overhead.
AI.result: Across open‑ended generation benchmarks (CHAIR, MME, GPT‑4V‑aided evaluation), HIME cuts hallucinations by an average of 61.8% without increasing inference‑time latency or compute.
AI.conclusion: Targeted, layer‑aware editing guided by HIS effectively suppresses object hallucinations in LVLMs while preserving pre‑trained knowledge, offering a practical alternative to fine‑tuning and highlighting the importance of selective intervention across layers.

title: DeepInnovator: Triggering the Innovative Capabilities of LLMs
summary: The application of Large Language Models (LLMs) in accelerating scientific discovery has garnered increasing attention, with a key focus on constructing research agents endowed with innovative capability, i.e., the ability to autonomously generate novel and significant research ideas. Existing approaches predominantly rely on sophisticated prompt engineering and lack a systematic training paradigm. To address this, we propose DeepInnovator, a training framework designed to trigger the innovative capability of LLMs. Our approach comprises two core components. (1) ``Standing on the shoulders of giants''. We construct an automated data extraction pipeline to extract and organize structured research knowledge from a vast corpus of unlabeled scientific literature. (2) ``Conjectures and refutations''. We introduce a ``Next Idea Prediction'' training paradigm, which models the generation of research ideas as an iterative process of continuously predicting, evaluating, and refining plausible and novel next idea. Both automatic and expert evaluations demonstrate that our DeepInnovator-14B significantly outperforms untrained baselines, achieving win rates of 80.53\%-93.81\%, and attains performance comparable to that of current leading LLMs. This work provides a scalable training pathway toward building research agents with genuine, originative innovative capability, and will open-source the dataset to foster community advancement. Source code and data are available at: https://github.com/HKUDS/DeepInnovator.

AI.tldr: DeepInnovator is a training framework that equips LLMs to generate novel research ideas by mining structured knowledge from scientific literature and training via an iterative “Next Idea Prediction” (conjecture–refutation) process, achieving strong wins over untrained baselines and performance on par with leading LLMs; code/data released.
AI.motivation: Existing “research agents” mostly depend on prompt engineering and lack a principled training paradigm to endow LLMs with genuine innovative capability—specifically, autonomously producing novel, meaningful research ideas from vast, unlabeled scientific corpora.
AI.method: Two components: (1) An automated pipeline that extracts and organizes structured research knowledge from large-scale, unlabeled scientific literature (“standing on the shoulders of giants”). (2) A “Next Idea Prediction” training paradigm that models ideation as an iterative loop of predicting, evaluating, and refining plausible, novel next ideas (“conjectures and refutations”). They instantiate this in a 14B-parameter model (DeepInnovator-14B).
AI.result: On both automatic and expert evaluations, DeepInnovator-14B significantly outperforms untrained baselines with win rates of 80.53%–93.81%, and achieves performance comparable to current leading LLMs.
AI.conclusion: DeepInnovator offers a scalable training pathway for building LLM research agents with authentic innovative capability; the dataset and code are open-sourced to catalyze further research.

title: (Perlin) Noise as AI coordinator
summary: Large scale control of nonplayer agents is central to modern games, while production systems still struggle to balance several competing goals: locally smooth, natural behavior, and globally coordinated variety across space and time. Prior approaches rely on handcrafted rules or purely stochastic triggers, which either converge to mechanical synchrony or devolve into uncorrelated noise that is hard to tune. Continuous noise signals such as Perlin noise are well suited to this gap because they provide spatially and temporally coherent randomness, and they are already widely used for terrain, biomes, and other procedural assets. We adapt these signals for the first time to large scale AI control and present a general framework that treats continuous noise fields as an AI coordinator. The framework combines three layers of control: behavior parameterization for movement at the agent level, action time scheduling for when behaviors start and stop, and spawn or event type and feature generation for what appears and where. We instantiate the framework reproducibly and evaluate Perlin noise as a representative coordinator across multiple maps, scales, and seeds against random, filtered, deterministic, neighborhood constrained, and physics inspired baselines. Experiments show that coordinated noise fields provide stable activation statistics without lockstep, strong spatial coverage and regional balance, better diversity with controllable polarization, and competitive runtime. We hope this work motivates a broader exploration of coordinated noise in game AI as a practical path to combine efficiency, controllability, and quality.

AI.tldr: Use continuous noise fields (e.g., Perlin noise) as a global coordinator to control large numbers of NPCs, yielding coherent yet diverse behaviors, strong spatial balance, and stable activation without lockstep, with competitive runtime vs several baselines.
AI.motivation: Game productions need NPC swarms that look natural locally while staying varied and coordinated globally. Handcrafted rules tend to synchronize agents mechanically; purely random triggers create untunable, uncorrelated noise. Continuous noise is already used in procedural assets and offers spatial-temporal coherence, suggesting it as a control signal for AI.
AI.method: Introduce a general framework that treats continuous noise fields as an AI coordinator across three layers: (1) behavior parameterization at the agent level (movement traits), (2) action time scheduling (when behaviors start/stop), and (3) spawn/event type and feature generation (what appears and where). Instantiate with Perlin noise and evaluate across maps, scales, and seeds against random, filtered, deterministic, neighborhood-constrained, and physics-inspired baselines.
AI.result: Coordinated noise fields produce stable activation statistics without lockstep, strong spatial coverage and regional balance, improved diversity with controllable polarization, and competitive runtime across tested maps/scales/seeds versus listed baselines.
AI.conclusion: Coordinated noise is a practical, controllable, and efficient approach for large-scale game AI, meriting broader exploration as a bridge between handcrafted determinism and untuned randomness.

title: NeXt2Former-CD: Efficient Remote Sensing Change Detection with Modern Vision Architectures
comment: Code will be released at https://github.com/VimsLab/NeXt2Former-CD
summary: State Space Models (SSMs) have recently gained traction in remote sensing change detection (CD) for their favorable scaling properties. In this paper, we explore the potential of modern convolutional and attention-based architectures as a competitive alternative. We propose NeXt2Former-CD, an end-to-end framework that integrates a Siamese ConvNeXt encoder initialized with DINOv3 weights, a deformable attention-based temporal fusion module, and a Mask2Former decoder. This design is intended to better tolerate residual co-registration noise and small object-level spatial shifts, as well as semantic ambiguity in bi-temporal imagery. Experiments on LEVIR-CD, WHU-CD, and CDD datasets show that our method achieves the best results among the evaluated methods, improving over recent Mamba-based baselines in both F1 score and IoU. Furthermore, despite a larger parameter count, our model maintains inference latency comparable to SSM-based approaches, suggesting it is practical for high-resolution change detection tasks.

AI.tldr: NeXt2Former-CD is a conv/attention-based change detection model that combines a DINOv3-initialized Siamese ConvNeXt encoder, deformable attention temporal fusion, and a Mask2Former decoder to outperform recent SSM/Mamba baselines on LEVIR-CD, WHU-CD, and CDD in F1/IoU, while keeping inference latency comparable to SSMs.
AI.motivation: Challenge the emerging dominance of state space models in remote sensing change detection by offering an alternative that better tolerates residual co-registration noise, small spatial shifts, and semantic ambiguity, without sacrificing practicality for high-resolution imagery.
AI.method: An end-to-end framework with: (1) a Siamese ConvNeXt encoder initialized with DINOv3 self-supervised weights; (2) a deformable attention-based temporal fusion module to align and integrate bi-temporal features; and (3) a Mask2Former decoder for precise change mask segmentation. Evaluated on LEVIR-CD, WHU-CD, and CDD with F1/IoU and latency comparisons to SSM/Mamba baselines.
AI.result: Achieves the best scores among evaluated methods, surpassing recent Mamba-based SSM baselines in F1 and IoU on three benchmarks. Despite having more parameters, its inference latency is comparable to SSM-based approaches, indicating practical deployment feasibility for high-resolution CD tasks.
AI.conclusion: Modern convolutional and attention architectures remain highly competitive for change detection when paired with strong pretraining, deformable temporal fusion, and a Mask2Former decoder. The approach improves robustness to misregistration and semantic ambiguity and offers a favorable accuracy–latency tradeoff, suggesting SSMs are not strictly required for state-of-the-art performance.

title: Why Agent Caching Fails and How to Fix It: Structured Intent Canonicalization with Few-Shot Learning
summary:
Personal AI agents incur substantial cost via repeated LLM calls. We show existing caching methods fail: GPTCache achieves 37.9% accuracy on real benchmarks; APC achieves 0-12%. The root cause is optimizing for the wrong property -- cache effectiveness requires key consistency and precision,
  not classification accuracy. We observe cache-key evaluation reduces to clustering evaluation and apply V-measure decomposition to separate these on n=8,682 points across MASSIVE, BANKING77, CLINC150, and NyayaBench v2, our new 8,514-entry multilingual agentic dataset (528 intents, 20 W5H2 classes, 63 languages). We introduce W5H2, a structured intent decomposition framework. Using SetFit with 8 examples per class, W5H2 achieves 91.1%+/-1.7% on MASSIVE in ~2ms -- vs 37.9% for
  GPTCache and 68.8% for a 20B-parameter LLM at 3,447ms. On NyayaBench v2 (20 classes), SetFit achieves 55.3%, with cross-lingual transfer across 30 languages. Our five-tier cascade handles 85% of interactions locally, projecting 97.5% cost reduction. We provide risk-controlled selective prediction guarantees via RCPS with nine bound families.

AI.tldr: Caching for LLM-based personal agents underperforms because cache keys are judged with the wrong metric. Reframing key quality as a clustering problem (using V-measure) and using a structured intent schema (W5H2) with lightweight SetFit yields large accuracy, latency, and cost gains; a five-tier cascade handles most requests locally with risk-controlled guarantees and strong multilingual generalization.
AI.motivation: Personal AI agents are expensive due to repeated LLM calls. Existing cache keying (e.g., GPTCache, APC) is inaccurate in practice because it optimizes for classification accuracy rather than the properties a cache needs: key consistency and precision. There is also a need for multilingual, structured intent handling and principled uncertainty/risk guarantees.
AI.method: 1) Recast cache-key evaluation as clustering evaluation; use V-measure decomposition to separate consistency (completeness) and precision (homogeneity). 2) Introduce W5H2, a structured intent decomposition for keys. 3) Train SetFit with 8 shots per class for fast, local inference. 4) Build NyayaBench v2 (8,514 samples, 528 intents, 20 W5H2 classes, 63 languages) for multilingual agentic evaluation. 5) Deploy a five-tier cascade that resolves most requests locally. 6) Provide risk-controlled selective prediction (RCPS) guarantees with nine bound families.
AI.result:
- Existing caches: GPTCache 37.9% on real benchmarks; APC 0–12%.
- MASSIVE: W5H2+SetFit 91.1% ±1.7% in ~2 ms; 20B LLM achieves 68.8% in 3,447 ms.
- NyayaBench v2 (20 classes): SetFit 55.3% with cross-lingual transfer across 30 languages.
- Cascade serves 85% of interactions locally; projected 97.5% cost reduction.
- Evaluated on n=8,682 across MASSIVE, BANKING77, CLINC150; NyayaBench v2 released.
AI.conclusion: Cache effectiveness hinges on clustering-style key quality (consistency and precision), not plain accuracy. A structured intent schema (W5H2) plus few-shot SetFit and cascaded serving can replace many LLM calls, delivering major speed and cost savings while enabling multilingual coverage and formal risk control. The approach suggests rethinking evaluation and design of agent caches toward clustering metrics and structured representations.

title: INDUCTION: Finite-Structure Concept Synthesis in First-Order Logic
summary: We introduce INDUCTION, a benchmark for finite structure concept synthesis in first order logic. Given small finite relational worlds with extensionally labeled target predicates, models must output a single first order logical formula that explains the target uniformly across worlds, with correctness verified via exact model checking. The benchmark includes three regimes, FullObs, CI (contrastive), and EC (existential completion), nd penalizes formula bloat. We find sharp difficulty gradients, persistent hard structural families, and observe that low bloat formulas generalize far better on held out worlds. Elite recent models show qualitatively different behaviors across tasks and performance metrics, hinting to their different strategies of concept generalization.

AI.tldr: INDUCTION is a benchmark for learning first‑order logic concepts from small finite relational worlds. Systems must synthesize a single FOL formula that generalizes across worlds, with exact model checking, under three observation regimes; results reveal difficulty gradients, persistent hard families, and that simpler (low‑bloat) formulas generalize better.
AI.motivation: Evaluate and compare models’ ability to induce symbolic concepts that generalize across structurally varied finite worlds—a capability underrepresented in current benchmarks—and to study how simplicity/complexity of learned formulas affects generalization.
AI.method: Construct small finite relational structures with extensionally labeled target predicates. Task: output one first‑order logical formula explaining targets uniformly across training worlds; verify correctness via exact model checking. Provide three regimes—FullObs, Contrastive Inference (CI), and Existential Completion (EC)—and penalize formula bloat. Assess recent high‑performing models across tasks and metrics.
AI.result: Observed sharp difficulty gradients across tasks and structures; identified persistent hard structural families; found strong correlation where low‑bloat formulas generalize substantially better to held‑out worlds. Different elite models show qualitatively distinct patterns across tasks and metrics, implying diverse generalization strategies.
AI.conclusion: INDUCTION offers a rigorous testbed for symbolic concept synthesis and highlights the importance of parsimony for out‑of‑distribution generalization. It exposes structural challenges and divergent model strategies, motivating methods that produce compact formulas and handle hard structural families under varied observation regimes.

title: Subtle Motion Blur Detection and Segmentation from Static Image Artworks
comment: InProceedings of the Winter Conference on Applications of Computer Vision 2026
summary: Streaming services serve hundreds of millions of viewers worldwide, where visual assets such as thumbnails, box art, and cover images are critical for engagement. Subtle motion blur remains a pervasive quality issue, reducing visual clarity and negatively affecting user trust and click-through rates. However, motion blur detection from static images is underexplored, as existing methods and datasets focus on severe blur and lack fine-grained pixel-level annotations needed for quality-critical applications. Benchmarks such as GOPRO and NFS are dominated by strong synthetic blur and often contain residual blur in their sharp references, leading to ambiguous supervision. We propose SMBlurDetect, a unified framework combining high-quality motion blur specific dataset generation with an end-to-end detector capable of zero-shot detection at multiple granularities. Our pipeline synthesizes realistic motion blur from super high resolution aesthetic images using controllable camera and object motion simulations over SAM segmented regions, enhanced with alpha-aware compositing and balanced sampling to generate subtle, spatially localized blur with precise ground truth masks. We train a U-Net based detector with ImageNet pretrained encoders using a hybrid mask and image centric strategy incorporating curriculum learning, hard negatives, focal loss, blur frequency channels, and resolution aware augmentation.Our method achieves strong zero-shot generalization, reaching 89.68% accuracy on GoPro (vs 66.50% baseline) and 59.77% Mean IoU on CUHK (vs 9.00% baseline), demonstrating 6.6x improvement in segmentation. Qualitative results show accurate localization of subtle blur artifacts, enabling automated filtering of low quality frames and precise region of interest extraction for intelligent cropping.

AI.tldr: SMBlurDetect introduces a data-generation pipeline and a U‑Net–based detector to identify subtle, spatially localized motion blur in static images, achieving strong zero‑shot generalization and large gains over baselines on GoPro and CUHK.
AI.motivation: Subtle motion blur in thumbnails and cover images degrades perceived quality, trust, and CTR in streaming platforms. Existing blur datasets emphasize strong/synthetic blur and lack precise, pixel‑level labels; some even include residual blur in references, complicating supervision. A fine‑grained, realism‑focused approach is needed for quality‑critical applications.
AI.method: Build a realistic subtle-blur dataset by simulating controllable camera/object motion over SAM-segmented regions of high‑resolution aesthetic images, using alpha‑aware compositing and balanced sampling to produce localized blur with accurate masks. Train a U‑Net detector with ImageNet encoders via a hybrid mask‑ and image‑centric curriculum, hard negatives, focal loss, blur‑frequency channels, and resolution‑aware augmentation. The model supports multi‑granularity, zero‑shot detection.
AI.result: Zero‑shot results: 89.68% accuracy on GoPro (vs 66.50% baseline) and 59.77% mIoU on CUHK (vs 9.00%), a reported 6.6× segmentation improvement. Qualitative examples show precise localization of subtle blur artifacts.
AI.conclusion: Combining high‑fidelity synthetic subtle-blur data with tailored training yields a detector that localizes motion blur robustly across datasets, enabling automated frame filtering and region‑of‑interest extraction for better cropping and asset quality control.

title: Yor-Sarc: A gold-standard dataset for sarcasm detection in a low-resource African language
summary: Sarcasm detection poses a fundamental challenge in computational semantics, requiring models to resolve disparities between literal and intended meaning. The challenge is amplified in low-resource languages where annotated datasets are scarce or nonexistent. We present \textbf{Yor-Sarc}, the first gold-standard dataset for sarcasm detection in Yorùbá, a tonal Niger-Congo language spoken by over $50$ million people. The dataset comprises 436 instances annotated by three native speakers from diverse dialectal backgrounds using an annotation protocol specifically designed for Yorùbá sarcasm by taking culture into account. This protocol incorporates context-sensitive interpretation and community-informed guidelines and is accompanied by a comprehensive analysis of inter-annotator agreement to support replication in other African languages. Substantial to almost perfect agreement was achieved (Fleiss' $κ= 0.7660$; pairwise Cohen's $κ= 0.6732$--$0.8743$), with $83.3\%$ unanimous consensus. One annotator pair achieved almost perfect agreement ($κ= 0.8743$; $93.8\%$ raw agreement), exceeding a number of reported benchmarks for English sarcasm research works. The remaining $16.7\%$ majority-agreement cases are preserved as soft labels for uncertainty-aware modelling. Yor-Sarc\footnote{https://github.com/toheebadura/yor-sarc} is expected to facilitate research on semantic interpretation and culturally informed NLP for low-resource African languages.

AI.tldr: Yor-Sarc introduces the first gold-standard Yorùbá sarcasm dataset (436 items) with a culture-aware, context-sensitive annotation protocol, achieving high inter-annotator agreement and providing soft labels for uncertainty-aware modeling.
AI.motivation: Sarcasm detection needs reconciling literal vs. intended meanings and suffers in low-resource languages due to lack of annotated data. Yorùbá, a major African language, lacks such resources and requires culturally grounded annotation to capture sarcasm reliably.
AI.method: Construct a 436-instance Yorùbá dataset annotated by three native speakers from diverse dialects using a protocol tailored to Yorùbá sarcasm that integrates cultural context, community-informed guidelines, and context-sensitive interpretation. Measure inter-annotator agreement and retain majority-agreement cases as soft labels.
AI.result: Substantial to almost perfect agreement: Fleiss’ κ=0.7660; pairwise Cohen’s κ=0.6732–0.8743; 83.3% unanimous consensus. One annotator pair achieved κ=0.8743 with 93.8% raw agreement, exceeding some English benchmarks. 16.7% non-unanimous cases are preserved as soft labels.
AI.conclusion: Yor-Sarc provides the first high-quality Yorùbá sarcasm resource and a replicable, culturally informed annotation protocol, enabling research on sarcasm detection, semantic interpretation, and uncertainty-aware NLP for low-resource African languages.

title: Modularity is the Bedrock of Natural and Artificial Intelligence
summary: The remarkable performance of modern AI systems has been driven by unprecedented scales of data, computation, and energy -- far exceeding the resources required by human intelligence. This disparity highlights the need for new guiding principles and motivates drawing inspiration from the fundamental organizational principles of brain computation. Among these principles, modularity has been shown to be critical for supporting the efficient learning and strong generalization abilities consistently exhibited by humans. Furthermore, modularity aligns well with the No Free Lunch Theorem, which highlights the need for problem-specific inductive biases and motivates architectures composed of specialized components that solve subproblems. However, despite its fundamental role in natural intelligence and its demonstrated benefits across a range of seemingly disparate AI subfields, modularity remains relatively underappreciated in mainstream AI research. In this work, we review several research threads in artificial intelligence and neuroscience through a conceptual framework that highlights the central role of modularity in supporting both artificial and natural intelligence. In particular, we examine what computational advantages modularity provides, how it has emerged as a solution across several AI research areas, which modularity principles the brain exploits, and how modularity can help bridge the gap between natural and artificial intelligence.

AI.tldr: A conceptual review arguing that modularity is a core organizing principle linking brains and AI, offering efficiency and generalization benefits and suggesting modular architectures to bridge natural and artificial intelligence.
AI.motivation: Modern AI’s gains rely on massive data/compute/energy, unlike the brain’s efficiency. To close this gap and in line with the No Free Lunch Theorem, the authors seek principled, problem-specific inductive biases—highlighting modularity as underused yet central in natural intelligence.
AI.method: A cross-disciplinary conceptual framework and literature review spanning AI subfields and neuroscience. The paper analyzes where and how modularity appears, what computational advantages it yields, which modular principles the brain uses, and how these insights can inform AI design.
AI.result: Synthesis showing that modularity repeatedly emerges as a solution across disparate AI areas; identifies advantages such as efficient learning, stronger generalization, specialization via subproblem decomposition, and alignment with inductive biases observed in the brain. It maps brain-inspired modular principles to AI architectures.
AI.conclusion: Modularity is foundational for intelligence and should be elevated in mainstream AI research. Embracing modular, specialized components can improve efficiency and generalization and help narrow the gap between natural and artificial intelligence.

title: WiCompass: Oracle-driven Data Scaling for mmWave Human Pose Estimation
comment: This paper has been accepted by The 32nd Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking (MobiCom'26)
summary: Millimeter-wave Human Pose Estimation (mmWave HPE) promises privacy but suffers from poor generalization under distribution shifts. We demonstrate that brute-force data scaling is ineffective for out-of-distribution (OOD) robustness; efficiency and coverage are the true bottlenecks. To address this, we introduce WiCompass, a coverage-aware data-collection framework. WiCompass leverages large-scale motion-capture corpora to build a universal pose space ``oracle'' that quantifies dataset redundancy and identifies underrepresented motions. Guided by this oracle, WiCompass employs a closed-loop policy to prioritize collecting informative missing samples. Experiments show that WiCompass consistently improves OOD accuracy at matched budgets and exhibits superior scaling behavior compared to conventional collection strategies. By shifting focus from brute-force scaling to coverage-aware data acquisition, this work offers a practical path toward robust mmWave sensing.

AI.tldr: WiCompass is a coverage-aware data collection framework for mmWave human pose estimation that uses a motion-capture–derived pose-space oracle to prioritize missing, informative motions, yielding better OOD robustness than brute-force scaling at the same budget.
AI.motivation: mmWave HPE is privacy-preserving but struggles to generalize under distribution shifts; naive data scaling fails to deliver OOD robustness due to inefficiency and poor coverage of pose/motion space.
AI.method: Construct a universal pose-space oracle from large MoCap corpora to quantify redundancy and detect underrepresented motions; use a closed-loop, coverage-aware policy to guide targeted data acquisition of informative, missing samples for mmWave training.
AI.result: Across experiments, WiCompass consistently improves out-of-distribution accuracy at matched data-collection budgets and shows better scaling behavior than conventional (e.g., random or brute-force) collection strategies.
AI.conclusion: Prioritizing coverage-aware, oracle-guided data acquisition—rather than indiscriminate scaling—provides a practical path to robust mmWave sensing and improved generalization in HPE.

title: Whisper: Courtside Edition Enhancing ASR Performance Through LLM-Driven Context Generation
summary: Domain-specific speech remains a persistent challenge for automatic speech recognition (ASR), even for state-of-the-art systems like OpenAI's Whisper. We introduce Whisper: Courtside Edition, a novel multi-agent large language model (LLM) pipeline that enhances Whisper transcriptions without retraining. The pipeline intercepts Whisper's initial transcript, applies specialized LLM agents for domain context identification, named entity recognition, and jargon detection, and generates compact prompts that guide Whisper's decoder. Evaluated on 421 NBA basketball commentary segments (a domain characterized by dense proper nouns and technical terminology) our best pipeline achieves a statistically significant 17.0% relative reduction in word error rate (WER; from 0.217 to 0.180, p<0.001). Improvements are observed in 40.1% of segments with degradation in only 7.1%, substantially outperforming direct transcript post-editing. These results demonstrate that prompt-based augmentation can deliver scalable domain adaptation for ASR, offering a practical alternative to costly model fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: They propose a multi-agent LLM pipeline that injects compact, domain-informed prompts back into Whisper’s decoding to improve domain-specific ASR, achieving a 17% relative WER reduction on NBA commentary without retraining.
AI.motivation: State-of-the-art ASR (e.g., Whisper) struggles with domains rich in proper nouns and jargon; retraining/fine-tuning is costly and cumbersome. The authors seek a scalable, retraining-free way to adapt ASR to specialized domains.
AI.method: Intercept Whisper’s initial transcript; use specialized LLM agents for domain context identification, named entity recognition, and jargon detection; synthesize concise prompts from these signals; guide Whisper’s decoder with these prompts. Compare against direct LLM post-editing of transcripts.
AI.result: On 421 NBA commentary segments, WER drops from 0.217 to 0.180 (17.0% relative; p<0.001). 40.1% of segments improve while 7.1% degrade, and the approach outperforms direct transcript post-editing.
AI.conclusion: Prompt-based augmentation offers practical, scalable domain adaptation for ASR at inference time, serving as an alternative to expensive fine-tuning.

title: Robust and Efficient Tool Orchestration via Layered Execution Structures with Reflective Correction
summary: Tool invocation is a core capability of agentic systems, yet failures often arise not from individual tool calls but from how multiple tools are organized and executed together. Existing approaches tightly couple tool execution with stepwise language reasoning or explicit planning, leading to brittle behavior and high execution overhead. To overcome these limitations, we revisit tool invocation from the perspective of tool orchestration. Our key insight is that effective orchestration does not require precise dependency graphs or fine-grained planning. Instead, a coarse-grained layer structure suffices to provide global guidance, while execution-time errors can be corrected locally. Specifically, we model tool orchestration as learning a layered execution structure that captures high-level tool dependencies, inducing layer-wise execution through context constraints. To handle execution-time failures, we introduce a schema-aware reflective correction mechanism that detects and repairs errors locally. This design confines errors to individual tool calls and avoids re-planning entire execution trajectories. This structured execution paradigm enables a lightweight and reusable orchestration component for agentic systems. Experimental results show that our approach achieves robust tool execution while reducing execution complexity and overhead. Code will be made publicly available.

AI.tldr: They propose a lightweight, layered orchestration scheme for multi-tool agents that guides execution at a coarse level and fixes failures locally, yielding more robust, lower-overhead tool use.
AI.motivation: Multi-tool agent failures often stem from brittle coupling between tool calls and detailed plans (e.g., stepwise reasoning or explicit dependency graphs), which raises execution cost and fragility. The authors aim to decouple orchestration from fine-grained planning to improve robustness and efficiency.
AI.method: Learn a coarse, layered execution structure capturing high-level tool dependencies; enforce layer-wise execution via context constraints. Add a schema-aware reflective correction mechanism that detects and repairs errors locally during execution, confining issues to individual tool calls without re-planning whole trajectories.
AI.result: Experiments indicate improved robustness of tool execution and reduced execution complexity/overhead compared to tightly coupled, plan-heavy baselines. (Abstract does not provide quantitative metrics.)
AI.conclusion: A structured, reusable orchestration layer—coarse-grained layering plus local reflective repairs—can replace brittle fine-grained planning, delivering robust, efficient tool invocation for agentic systems. Code to be released.

title: MiSCHiEF: A Benchmark in Minimal-Pairs of Safety and Culture for Holistic Evaluation of Fine-Grained Image-Caption Alignment
summary: Fine-grained image-caption alignment is crucial for vision-language models (VLMs), especially in socially critical contexts such as identifying real-world risk scenarios or distinguishing cultural proxies, where correct interpretation hinges on subtle visual or linguistic clues and where minor misinterpretations can lead to significant real-world consequences. We present MiSCHiEF, a set of two benchmarking datasets based on a contrastive pair design in the domains of safety (MiS) and culture (MiC), and evaluate four VLMs on tasks requiring fine-grained differentiation of paired images and captions. In both datasets, each sample contains two minimally differing captions and corresponding minimally differing images. In MiS, the image-caption pairs depict a safe and an unsafe scenario, while in MiC, they depict cultural proxies in two distinct cultural contexts. We find that models generally perform better at confirming the correct image-caption pair than rejecting incorrect ones. Additionally, models achieve higher accuracy when selecting the correct caption from two highly similar captions for a given image, compared to the converse task. The results, overall, highlight persistent modality misalignment challenges in current VLMs, underscoring the difficulty of precise cross-modal grounding required for applications with subtle semantic and visual distinctions.

AI.tldr: MiSCHiEF introduces contrastive, fine-grained benchmarks in safety (MiS) and culture (MiC) to test VLMs’ cross-modal grounding. Across four models, systems are better at confirming correct matches and selecting captions for images than the reverse, exposing persistent modality misalignment in subtle, high-stakes scenarios.
AI.motivation: Fine-grained image–caption alignment is critical in sensitive applications (e.g., identifying unsafe scenarios or correctly interpreting cultural proxies) where small visual/linguistic differences matter and mistakes have real-world consequences. Existing evaluations under-stress such subtle distinctions.
AI.method: Construct two benchmarking datasets—MiS (safe vs. unsafe) and MiC (cultural proxies across contexts)—using minimally differing image and caption pairs in a contrastive design. Evaluate four VLMs on tasks: (1) confirm a correct image–caption pairing vs. reject an incorrect one; (2) choose the correct caption for a given image; (3) choose the correct image for a given caption. Analyze performance asymmetries and fine-grained grounding ability.
AI.result: Models generally perform better at (a) confirming correct image–caption pairs than rejecting mismatches, and (b) selecting the correct caption for an image than selecting the correct image for a caption. These outcomes indicate asymmetric cross-modal reasoning and difficulty with subtle negative discrimination.
AI.conclusion: Current VLMs exhibit modality misalignment on fine-grained, high-stakes distinctions. MiSCHiEF exposes weaknesses in rejecting near-miss pairs and in image selection given captions, underscoring the need for improved cross-modal grounding and alignment methods for safety- and culture-sensitive applications.

title: Capable but Unreliable: Canonical Path Deviation as a Causal Mechanism of Agent Failure in Long-Horizon Tasks
summary: Why do language agents fail on tasks they are capable of solving? We argue that many such failures are reliability failures caused by stochastic drift from a task's latent solution structure, not capability failures. Every well-defined tool-use task imposes a canonical solution path (i.e., a convergent set of tool invocations shared across successful runs) and agent success depends critically on whether a trajectory stays within this path's operating envelope. We establish this causally using a natural experiment that holds model capability and task difficulty fixed by construction. We analyze trajectories from the Toolathlon benchmark: 22 frontier models each attempt 108 real-world tool-use tasks across 3 independent runs, yielding 515 model$\times$task units where the same model succeeds on some runs and fails on others due to LLM sampling stochasticity alone. Within these units, successful runs adhere significantly more closely to the canonical solution path than failed runs ($+$0.060 Jaccard, $p<0.0001$, $n=488$ units, 95% CI [+0.043, +0.077]). This result survives six robustness checks including cross-model-family leave-one-out validation. Critically, the causal mechanism is gradual and self-reinforcing: the adherence gap is statistically indistinguishable from zero through the first 50% of the trajectory, ruling out early-branching selection bias, and each off-canonical tool call raises the probability that the next call is also off-canonical by 22.7 percentage points ($\hatβ=+0.227$, $p<0.0001$), more than doubling the baseline rate. These findings imply that agent reliability cannot be improved by capability scaling alone, but offer a highly actionable intervention: a simple monitor that restarts the bottom tercile of runs based on mid-trajectory canonical adherence lifts success rates by $+$8.8 percentage points among intervened runs.

AI.tldr: Many LLM agent failures in tool-use are reliability failures driven by stochastic drift away from a task’s canonical solution path, not lack of capability; adherence to the canonical path predicts success and a simple mid-trajectory adherence monitor with restarts improves outcomes.
AI.motivation: Despite sufficient capability, language agents often fail inconsistently across runs. The authors hypothesize that such failures come from stochastic deviations from a latent, task-imposed canonical solution path. They aim to causally distinguish reliability from capability and to find actionable interventions.
AI.method: Natural experiment on Toolathlon: 22 frontier models × 108 real-world tool-use tasks with 3 independent runs each. Identify model×task units where the same model both succeeds and fails across runs, holding capability and task difficulty fixed. Define a canonical solution path from successful runs and measure each trajectory’s adherence (Jaccard overlap of tool calls). Compare adherence between successes and failures; analyze temporal dynamics (first 50% of steps), path-drift contagion via regression (effect of an off-canonical call on the next), and perform six robustness checks including cross-model-family leave-one-out. Evaluate an intervention: restart runs in the bottom tercile of mid-trajectory adherence.
AI.result: Successful runs adhere more to the canonical path than failed runs by +0.060 Jaccard (p<0.0001; n=488; 95% CI [+0.043, +0.077]). The adherence gap is indistinguishable from zero in the first half of trajectories, countering early-branching bias. Each off-canonical call increases the probability the next call is off-canonical by 22.7 percentage points (β̂=+0.227, p<0.0001), more than doubling baseline. A simple adherence-based monitor that restarts the bottom tercile of runs raises success by +8.8 percentage points among intervened runs. Findings are robust across six checks, including leave-one-out by model family.
AI.conclusion: Agent failures in tool-use often arise from gradual, self-reinforcing drift off a canonical solution path, implying that scaling capability alone won’t solve reliability. Monitoring canonical adherence mid-trajectory and restarting low-adherence runs is an effective, low-cost intervention; more generally, trajectory-aware control is key to improving agent reliability.

title: When Do LLM Preferences Predict Downstream Behavior?
summary: Preference-driven behavior in LLMs may be a necessary precondition for AI misalignment such as sandbagging: models cannot strategically pursue misaligned goals unless their behavior is influenced by their preferences. Yet prior work has typically prompted models explicitly to act in specific ways, leaving unclear whether observed behaviors reflect instruction-following capabilities vs underlying model preferences. Here we test whether this precondition for misalignment is present. Using entity preferences as a behavioral probe, we measure whether stated preferences predict downstream behavior in five frontier LLMs across three domains: donation advice, refusal behavior, and task performance. Conceptually replicating prior work, we first confirm that all five models show highly consistent preferences across two independent measurement methods. We then test behavioral consequences in a simulated user environment. We find that all five models give preference-aligned donation advice. All five models also show preference-correlated refusal patterns when asked to recommend donations, refusing more often for less-preferred entities. All preference-related behaviors that we observe here emerge without instructions to act on preferences. Results for task performance are mixed: on a question-answering benchmark (BoolQ), two models show small but significant accuracy differences favoring preferred entities; one model shows the opposite pattern; and two models show no significant relationship. On complex agentic tasks, we find no evidence of preference-driven performance differences. While LLMs have consistent preferences that reliably predict advice-giving behavior, these preferences do not consistently translate into downstream task performance.

AI.tldr: Across five frontier LLMs, stable, self-consistent entity preferences reliably shape advice-giving and refusals even without instructions, but only weakly and inconsistently affect downstream task performance.
AI.motivation: Preference-driven behavior is a necessary precondition for strategic misalignment (e.g., sandbagging). Prior demonstrations often rely on explicit prompts, confounding instruction-following with intrinsic preferences. The paper asks whether LLMs’ stated preferences exist consistently and whether they causally predict behavior absent instructions to act on them.
AI.method: Use entity preferences as a behavioral probe. Measure preferences with two independent methods, verify internal consistency, then test behavioral consequences in a simulated user environment across three domains: (1) donation advice, (2) refusal behavior in donation recommendations, and (3) task performance (BoolQ QA and complex agentic tasks). Evaluate five frontier LLMs without instructing them to use preferences.
AI.result: All five models show highly consistent preferences across measurement methods. In the simulation, all models give donation advice aligned with their preferences and refuse more often for less‑preferred entities—without being told to use preferences. For task performance, effects are mixed: on BoolQ, two models show small but significant accuracy boosts for preferred entities, one shows the reverse, and two show no effect; on complex agentic tasks, no preference‑driven performance differences are found.
AI.conclusion: LLMs harbor stable preferences that reliably influence advice and refusals even without explicit instructions, satisfying a precondition for certain misalignment risks. However, these preferences do not robustly translate into performance differences on factual or complex tasks. The risk surface appears greatest in recommendation-like behaviors, while accuracy-oriented task execution shows limited, inconsistent preference influence.

title: LaS-Comp: Zero-shot 3D Completion with Latent-Spatial Consistency
summary: This paper introduces LaS-Comp, a zero-shot and category-agnostic approach that leverages the rich geometric priors of 3D foundation models to enable 3D shape completion across diverse types of partial observations. Our contributions are threefold: First, \ourname{} harnesses these powerful generative priors for completion through a complementary two-stage design: (i) an explicit replacement stage that preserves the partial observation geometry to ensure faithful completion; and (ii) an implicit refinement stage ensures seamless boundaries between the observed and synthesized regions. Second, our framework is training-free and compatible with different 3D foundation models. Third, we introduce Omni-Comp, a comprehensive benchmark combining real-world and synthetic data with diverse and challenging partial patterns, enabling a more thorough and realistic evaluation. Both quantitative and qualitative experiments demonstrate that our approach outperforms previous state-of-the-art approaches. Our code and data will be available at \href{https://github.com/DavidYan2001/LaS-Comp}{LaS-Comp}.

AI.tldr: LaS-Comp is a training-free, zero-shot, category-agnostic 3D shape completion method that leverages 3D foundation model priors via a two-stage (explicit replacement + implicit refinement) pipeline, and introduces Omni-Comp, a challenging real+synthetic benchmark, achieving state-of-the-art performance.
AI.motivation: 3D shape completion must handle highly diverse and incomplete inputs across object categories and sensing patterns. Existing methods often need training, struggle to preserve observed geometry, and may leave artifacts at boundaries. The authors aim to exploit the powerful geometric priors of 3D foundation models without additional training and to provide a more realistic benchmark for evaluation.
AI.method: A complementary two-stage, training-free design compatible with multiple 3D foundation models: (1) Explicit replacement stage that keeps the partial observation’s geometry intact to ensure fidelity; (2) Implicit refinement stage that uses generative priors to blend and smooth transitions between observed and synthesized regions, producing seamless completions.
AI.result: Across quantitative and qualitative evaluations—including the new Omni-Comp benchmark with diverse real and synthetic partial patterns—LaS-Comp consistently outperforms prior state-of-the-art approaches in completion quality.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging 3D foundation model priors with a two-stage replacement-and-refinement pipeline enables robust, zero-shot, category-agnostic 3D shape completion. The introduced Omni-Comp benchmark supports thorough, realistic assessment, and experiments validate superior performance; code and data are released.

title: Uncovering Context Reliance in Unstructured Knowledge Editing
summary: Editing Large language models (LLMs) with real-world, unstructured knowledge is essential for correcting and updating their internal parametric knowledge. In this work, we revisit the fundamental next-token prediction (NTP) as a candidate paradigm for unstructured editing. We identify Context Reliance as a critical failure mode of NTP-based approaches, where knowledge acquired from edited text becomes highly dependent on its preceding context, leading to recall failures when that context is absent during inference. This hypothesis is supported by our empirical validation that prepending context during inference recovers knowledge recall. We further theoretically demonstrate that Context Reliance is an inherent consequence of gradient-based optimization, which tends to bind acquired knowledge to a specific aggregated contextual representation. To address this, we propose a simple yet effective COntext-INdependent editing framework (COIN), encouraging model to focus on knowledge within local scope rather than memorizing contextual patterns. Evaluations show that COIN reduces Context Reliance by 45.2% and outperforms strong baselines by 23.6% in editing success rate, highlighting the vital role of mitigating Context Reliance for robust editing.

AI.tldr: NTP-based editing of LLMs often binds new knowledge to its surrounding prompt context, causing recall failures without that context; the paper diagnoses this “Context Reliance,” explains it theoretically as a byproduct of gradient descent, and introduces COIN to make edits context-independent, substantially improving recall and edit success.
AI.motivation: LLMs need timely correction/update of internal knowledge using unstructured data. Existing next-token prediction (NTP) editing works but often fails to recall edits unless the training context is reproduced at inference, limiting practical reliability.
AI.method: 1) Empirically reveal Context Reliance by showing that prepending the original editing context at inference restores recall. 2) Provide a theoretical account: gradient-based optimization ties learned updates to an aggregated contextual representation. 3) Propose COIN, a training/editing framework that emphasizes local knowledge signals over broader contextual patterns to decouple edits from specific contexts.
AI.result: COIN reduces Context Reliance by 45.2% and improves editing success rate by 23.6% over strong baselines; experiments also confirm that adding back the edit-time context revives recall in NTP edits, supporting the diagnosis.
AI.conclusion: Context Reliance is intrinsic to gradient-based NTP edits and must be mitigated for robust knowledge editing. COIN effectively promotes context-independent recall of edited facts, yielding more reliable model updates.

title: How Far Can We Go with Pixels Alone? A Pilot Study on Screen-Only Navigation in Commercial 3D ARPGs
summary: Modern 3D game levels rely heavily on visual guidance, yet the navigability of level layouts remains difficult to quantify. Prior work either simulates play in simplified environments or analyzes static screenshots for visual affordances, but neither setting faithfully captures how players explore complex, real-world game levels. In this paper, we build on an existing open-source visual affordance detector and instantiate a screen-only exploration and navigation agent that operates purely from visual affordances. Our agent consumes live game frames, identifies salient interest points, and drives a simple finite-state controller over a minimal action space to explore Dark Souls-style linear levels and attempt to reach expected goal regions. Pilot experiments show that the agent can traverse most required segments and exhibits meaningful visual navigation behavior, but also highlight that limitations of the underlying visual model prevent truly comprehensive and reliable auto-navigation. We argue that this system provides a concrete, shared baseline and evaluation protocol for visual navigation in complex games, and we call for more attention to this necessary task. Our results suggest that purely vision-based sense-making models, with discrete single-modality inputs and without explicit reasoning, can effectively support navigation and environment understanding in idealized settings, but are unlikely to be a general solution on their own.

AI.tldr: They build a screen-only agent that navigates Dark Souls–style levels using a visual affordance detector and a simple finite-state controller; it often reaches goals and shows sensible behavior but is constrained by the visual model, so it’s proposed as a shared baseline rather than a complete solution.
AI.motivation: Quantifying and benchmarking navigability of real, complex 3D game levels is hard. Existing approaches either simulate simplified play or analyze static screenshots—neither captures how players actually explore rich environments. The field lacks a faithful, reproducible baseline and protocol for visual navigation in complex games.
AI.method: Extend an open-source visual affordance detector to drive a screen-only exploration/navigation agent. The agent consumes live frames, detects salient interest points, and selects actions via a simple finite-state controller over a minimal action set to explore Dark Souls–style linear levels and head toward expected goal regions. Evaluation is via pilot experiments on these levels.
AI.result: The agent can traverse most required segments and displays meaningful visual navigation, but limitations of the underlying visual affordance model prevent comprehensive and reliable autonomous navigation across all cases.
AI.conclusion: The system offers a concrete, shared baseline and evaluation protocol for visual navigation in complex games. Purely vision-based, single-modality, non-reasoning models can support navigation and environment understanding in idealized settings but are unlikely to suffice as a general solution without additional modalities or explicit reasoning.

title: Synthesizing Multimodal Geometry Datasets from Scratch and Enabling Visual Alignment via Plotting Code
summary: Multimodal geometry reasoning requires models to jointly understand visual diagrams and perform structured symbolic inference, yet current vision--language models struggle with complex geometric constructions due to limited training data and weak visual--symbolic alignment. We propose a pipeline for synthesizing complex multimodal geometry problems from scratch and construct a dataset named \textbf{GeoCode}, which decouples problem generation into symbolic seed construction, grounded instantiation with verification, and code-based diagram rendering, ensuring consistency across structure, text, reasoning, and images. Leveraging the plotting code provided in GeoCode, we further introduce code prediction as an explicit alignment objective, transforming visual understanding into a supervised structured prediction task. GeoCode exhibits substantially higher structural complexity and reasoning difficulty than existing benchmarks, while maintaining mathematical correctness through multi-stage validation. Extensive experiments show that models trained on GeoCode achieve consistent improvements on multiple geometry benchmarks, demonstrating both the effectiveness of the dataset and the proposed alignment strategy. The code will be available at https://github.com/would1920/GeoCode.

AI.tldr: They introduce GeoCode, a pipeline and dataset that synthesize complex multimodal geometry problems with code-rendered diagrams and use code prediction to better align visual understanding with symbolic structure, yielding consistent gains on geometry benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current vision–language models underperform on complex geometric constructions due to scarce, weakly aligned training data and poor coupling between visual diagrams and symbolic reasoning.
AI.method: Construct problems from scratch via a three-stage pipeline: (1) symbolic seed construction, (2) grounded instantiation with verification, and (3) code-based diagram rendering to ensure consistency across structure, text, reasoning, and images. Leverage the plotting code to add an explicit supervised alignment objective by training models to predict the rendering code from the visual input.
AI.result: GeoCode provides higher structural complexity and reasoning difficulty than prior benchmarks while maintaining mathematical correctness via multi-stage validation. Models trained with GeoCode and the code-prediction objective show consistent improvements across multiple geometry benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Synthesizing verified, code-rendered geometry problems and supervising models with code prediction effectively strengthens visual–symbolic alignment and improves multimodal geometry reasoning; resources will be released for broader use.

title: IAPO: Information-Aware Policy Optimization for Token-Efficient Reasoning
summary: Large language models increasingly rely on long chains of thought to improve accuracy, yet such gains come with substantial inference-time costs. We revisit token-efficient post-training and argue that existing sequence-level reward-shaping methods offer limited control over how reasoning effort is allocated across tokens. To bridge the gap, we propose IAPO, an information-theoretic post-training framework that assigns token-wise advantages based on each token's conditional mutual information (MI) with the final answer. This yields an explicit, principled mechanism for identifying informative reasoning steps and suppressing low-utility exploration. We provide a theoretical analysis showing that our IAPO can induce monotonic reductions in reasoning verbosity without harming correctness. Empirically, IAPO consistently improves reasoning accuracy while reducing reasoning length by up to 36%, outperforming existing token-efficient RL methods across various reasoning datasets. Extensive empirical evaluations demonstrate that information-aware advantage shaping is a powerful and general direction for token-efficient post-training. The code is available at https://github.com/YinhanHe123/IAPO.

AI.tldr: IAPO is an information-theoretic post-training method that allocates token-level credit based on each token’s conditional mutual information with the final answer, reducing verbose reasoning while maintaining or improving accuracy and outperforming prior token-efficient RL by cutting reasoning length up to 36%.
AI.motivation: Long chains-of-thought improve LLM accuracy but impose high inference-time costs; existing sequence-level reward shaping provides coarse control and cannot selectively encourage informative tokens while suppressing low-utility exploration.
AI.method: Information-Aware Policy Optimization (IAPO): during post-training, compute token-wise advantages proportional to each token’s conditional mutual information with the final answer. This per-token advantage shaping explicitly rewards informative reasoning steps and penalizes uninformative ones. Theoretical analysis argues monotonic reductions in reasoning verbosity without hurting correctness.
AI.result: Across multiple reasoning datasets, IAPO reduces reasoning length by up to 36% while improving accuracy and surpassing existing token-efficient RL baselines. Extensive experiments substantiate consistent gains; code is released publicly.
AI.conclusion: Token-wise, information-aware advantage shaping is a principled and effective approach for token-efficient post-training, enabling shorter chains-of-thought without sacrificing correctness and offering a general avenue for improving reasoning efficiency.

title: InfEngine: A Self-Verifying and Self-Optimizing Intelligent Engine for Infrared Radiation Computing
summary: Infrared radiation computing underpins advances in climate science, remote sensing and spectroscopy but remains constrained by manual workflows. We introduce InfEngine, an autonomous intelligent computational engine designed to drive a paradigm shift from human-led orchestration to collaborative automation. It integrates four specialized agents through two core innovations: self-verification, enabled by joint solver-evaluator debugging, improves functional correctness and scientific plausibility; self-optimization, realized via evolutionary algorithms with self-discovered fitness functions, facilitates autonomous performance optimization. Evaluated on InfBench with 200 infrared-specific tasks and powered by InfTools with 270 curated tools, InfEngine achieves a 92.7% pass rate and delivers workflows 21x faster than manual expert effort. More fundamentally, it illustrates how researchers can transition from manual coding to collaborating with self-verifying, self-optimizing computational partners. By generating reusable, verified and optimized code, InfEngine transforms computational workflows into persistent scientific assets, accelerating the cycle of scientific discovery. Code: https://github.com/kding1225/infengine

AI.tldr: InfEngine is an autonomous, multi‑agent system for infrared radiation computing that combines self‑verification and evolutionary self‑optimization to generate reusable, verified code, reporting 92.7% task pass rate and 21× speedups over manual workflows on a domain benchmark.
AI.motivation: Infrared radiation computing for climate science, remote sensing, and spectroscopy is bottlenecked by manual, expert‑driven coding and orchestration, slowing iteration and limiting scalability and reproducibility.
AI.method: Integrates four specialized agents and a large toolset (InfTools, 270 tools). Two core innovations: (1) self‑verification via joint solver–evaluator debugging to improve functional correctness and scientific plausibility; (2) self‑optimization via evolutionary algorithms with self‑discovered fitness functions to autonomously improve performance. Evaluated on InfBench comprising 200 infrared‑specific tasks.
AI.result: On InfBench, InfEngine attains a 92.7% pass rate and produces workflows 21× faster than manual expert baselines.
AI.conclusion: Autonomous, self‑verifying and self‑optimizing agents can shift scientific computing from manual scripting to collaborative automation, yielding reusable, validated, and optimized code assets that accelerate discovery; InfEngine demonstrates this potential within infrared computing.

title: MIRROR: Multimodal Iterative Reasoning via Reflection on Visual Regions
summary: In the era of Vision-Language Models (VLMs), enhancing multimodal reasoning capabilities remains a critical challenge, particularly in handling ambiguous or complex visual inputs, where initial inferences often lead to hallucinations or logic errors.
