Existing VLMs often produce plausible yet ungrounded answers, and even when prompted to "reflect", their corrections may remain detached from the image evidence. To address this, we propose the MIRROR framework for Multimodal Iterative Reasoning via Reflection On visual Regions. By embedding visual reflection as a core mechanism, MIRROR is formulated as a closed-loop process comprising draft, critique, region-based verification, and revision, which are repeated until the output is visually grounded. To facilitate training of this model, we construct **ReflectV**, a visual reflective dataset for multi-turn supervision that explicitly contains reflection triggers, region-based verification actions, and answer revision grounded in visual evidence. Experiments on both general vision-language benchmarks and representative vision-language reasoning benchmarks show that MIRROR improves correctness and reduces visual hallucinations, demonstrating the value of training reflection as an evidence-seeking, region-aware verification process rather than a purely textual revision step.

AI.tldr: MIRROR is an iterative, region-aware reflection framework and dataset (ReflectV) for VLMs that grounds multi-turn reasoning in explicit visual evidence, cutting hallucinations and improving accuracy.
AI.motivation: VLMs often produce plausible but ungrounded answers, and even reflective prompts tend to revise textually without checking image evidence. The work aims to make reflection evidence-seeking and visually grounded, especially for ambiguous/complex scenes.
AI.method: Closed-loop pipeline: (1) draft answer; (2) critique; (3) region-based verification by pointing to/inspecting image regions; (4) revision. Loop repeats until responses are visually grounded. Training uses ReflectV, a multi-turn dataset with reflection triggers, explicit region verification actions, and evidence-grounded revisions.
AI.result: Across general VL and reasoning benchmarks, MIRROR reduces visual hallucinations and increases correctness versus standard VLMs and text-only reflection approaches.
AI.conclusion: Embedding region-aware visual verification into the reflection loop yields more reliable, grounded multimodal reasoning than purely textual reflection, highlighting the value of training evidence-seeking behaviors.

title: Do LLMs and VLMs Share Neurons for Inference? Evidence and Mechanisms of Cross-Modal Transfer
summary:
Large vision-language models (LVLMs) have rapidly advanced across various domains, yet they still lag behind strong text-only large language models (LLMs) on tasks that require multi-step inference and compositional decision-making. Motivated by their shared transformer architectures, we investigate whether the two model families rely on common internal computation for such inference. At the neuron level, we uncover a surprisingly large overlap: more than half of the top-activated units during multi-step inference are shared between representative LLMs and LVLMs, revealing a modality-invariant inference subspace.
  Through causal probing via activation amplification, we further show that these shared neurons encode consistent and interpretable concept-level effects, demonstrating their functional contribution to inference. Building on this insight, we propose Shared Neuron Low-Rank Fusion (SNRF), a parameter-efficient framework that transfers mature inference circuitry from LLMs to LVLMs. SNRF profiles cross-model activations to identify shared neurons, computes a low-rank approximation of inter-model weight differences, and injects these updates selectively within the shared-neuron subspace. This mechanism strengthens multimodal inference performance with minimal parameter changes and requires no large-scale multimodal fine-tuning.
  Across diverse mathematics and perception benchmarks, SNRF consistently enhances LVLM inference performance while preserving perceptual capabilities. Our results demonstrate that shared neurons form an interpretable bridge between LLMs and LVLMs, enabling low-cost transfer of inference ability into multimodal models. Our code is available at [https://github.com/chenhangcuisg-code/Do-LLMs-VLMs-Share-Neurons](https://github.com/chenhangcuisg-code/Do-LLMs-VLMs-Share-Neurons).

AI.tldr: They find a large, causally meaningful overlap in inference-related neurons between text-only LLMs and LVLMs, and exploit it with a low-rank, shared-neuron fusion (SNRF) to transfer LLM reasoning into LVLMs, improving multi-step inference without heavy multimodal retraining.
AI.motivation: LVLMs underperform strong LLMs on multi-step reasoning and compositional decision-making. Given both use transformers, the authors ask whether they share internal inference machinery that can be identified, verified causally, and leveraged to boost LVLM reasoning efficiently.
AI.method: 1) Identify top-activated neurons during multi-step inference in representative LLMs and LVLMs and quantify cross-model overlap; 2) Use causal probing via activation amplification to test whether these shared units have consistent, interpretable concept effects; 3) Propose SNRF: profile cross-model activations to select shared neurons, compute a low-rank approximation of inter-model weight differences, and inject updates only within the shared-neuron subspace. No large-scale multimodal fine-tuning is required.
AI.result: Over half of the top-activated units during multi-step inference are shared between LLMs and LVLMs, indicating a modality-invariant inference subspace. Causal interventions show these neurons carry consistent, interpretable effects. SNRF delivers consistent gains on mathematics and perception benchmarks for LVLMs while preserving perceptual capabilities, using minimal parameter updates.
AI.conclusion: A shared, interpretable neuron subspace bridges LLMs and LVLMs. Targeted low-rank fusion within this subspace effectively transfers mature reasoning circuitry from LLMs to LVLMs, yielding low-cost, parameter-efficient improvements in multimodal inference without degrading perception.

title: Quantifying Automation Risk in High-Automation AI Systems: A Bayesian Framework for Failure Propagation and Optimal Oversight
summary: Organizations across finance, healthcare, transportation, content moderation, and critical infrastructure are rapidly deploying highly automated AI systems, yet they lack principled methods to quantify how increasing automation amplifies harm when failures occur. We propose a parsimonious Bayesian risk decomposition expressing expected loss as the product of three terms: the probability of system failure, the conditional probability that a failure propagates into harm given the automation level, and the expected severity of harm. This framework isolates a critical quantity -- the conditional probability that failures propagate into harm -- which captures execution and oversight risk rather than model accuracy alone. We develop complete theoretical foundations: formal proofs of the decomposition, a harm propagation equivalence theorem linking the harm propagation probability to observable execution controls, risk elasticity measures, efficient frontier analysis for automation policy, and optimal resource allocation principles with second-order conditions. We motivate the framework with an illustrative case study of the 2012 Knight Capital incident ($440M loss) as one instantiation of a broadly applicable failure pattern, and characterize the research design required to empirically validate the framework at scale across deployment domains. This work provides the theoretical foundations for a new class of deployment-focused risk governance tools for agentic and automated AI systems.

AI.tldr: Introduces a parsimonious Bayesian decomposition of expected loss for automated/agentic AI—failure probability × harm-propagation probability (conditioned on automation) × expected harm severity—yielding theory, policy tools, and a validation path; illustrated via the Knight Capital incident.
AI.motivation: Highly automated AI is being deployed in high-stakes domains without principled ways to quantify how greater automation can amplify harm; prevailing metrics emphasize model accuracy and overlook execution/oversight risk.
AI.method: Formally define a Bayesian risk decomposition; prove the decomposition; develop a harm propagation equivalence theorem linking the conditional harm-propagation probability to observable execution controls; derive risk elasticities; conduct efficient-frontier analysis for automation policy; establish optimal resource-allocation rules with second-order conditions; motivate with a Knight Capital case study; outline research design for large-scale empirical validation across domains.
AI.result: Provides complete theoretical underpinnings and policy-relevant constructs: (1) a separable expression for expected loss, (2) an equivalence connecting harm propagation to measurable controls, (3) elasticity measures to quantify sensitivity of loss to components, (4) efficient frontiers to trade off automation vs. risk, and (5) optimal allocation principles; demonstrates applicability through a major real-world failure pattern and specifies how to validate empirically.
AI.conclusion: Shifts governance focus from model accuracy to controlling harm propagation via execution and oversight; supplies a foundation for deployment-focused risk tools and principled automation-level and investment decisions for agentic/automated AI systems.

title: Benchmarking Computational Pathology Foundation Models For Semantic Segmentation
summary: In recent years, foundation models such as CLIP, DINO,and CONCH have demonstrated remarkable domain generalization and unsupervised feature extraction capabilities across diverse imaging tasks. However, systematic and independent evaluations of these models for pixel-level semantic segmentation in histopathology remain scarce. In this study, we propose a robust benchmarking approach to asses 10 foundational models on four histopathological datasets covering both morphological tissue-region and cellular/nuclear segmentation tasks. Our method leverages attention maps of foundation models as pixel-wise features, which are then classified using a machine learning algorithm, XGBoost, enabling fast, interpretable, and model-agnostic evaluation without finetuning. We show that the vision language foundation model, CONCH performed the best across datasets when compared to vision-only foundation models, with PathDino as close second. Further analysis shows that models trained on distinct histopathology cohorts capture complementary morphological representations, and concatenating their features yields superior segmentation performance. Concatenating features from CONCH, PathDino and CellViT outperformed individual models across all the datasets by 7.95% (averaged across the datasets), suggesting that ensembles of foundation models can better generalize to diverse histopathological segmentation tasks.

AI.tldr: They benchmark 10 foundation models for pixel-level histopathology segmentation by turning model attention maps into pixel features classified with XGBoost (no finetuning). CONCH performs best overall, PathDino is close second, and concatenating features from CONCH+PathDino+CellViT boosts performance by ~7.95% on average, indicating ensembles generalize better.
AI.motivation: Despite strong generalization of foundation models, there is little independent, systematic evaluation for pixel-level (tissue/cell) segmentation in histopathology and a need for a fast, interpretable, model-agnostic assessment without finetuning.
AI.method: Use attention maps from each foundation model as pixel-wise feature representations and train an XGBoost classifier on these features to produce semantic segmentations. Benchmark 10 models across four histopathology datasets spanning tissue-region and cellular/nuclear tasks; analyze complementarity by concatenating features across models.
AI.result: CONCH (vision–language) achieves the best segmentation performance across datasets, with PathDino a close second among vision-only models. Models trained on different histopathology cohorts encode complementary morphology; concatenating features improves segmentation. A CONCH+PathDino+CellViT feature ensemble outperforms any single model across all datasets by an average of 7.95%.
AI.conclusion: A simple, finetuning-free, attention-feature-plus-XGBoost pipeline enables fair, fast benchmarking of foundation models for histopathology segmentation. Vision–language and vision-only models capture complementary cues, and feature-level ensembles provide superior generalization across diverse histopathological segmentation tasks.

title: TriTopic: Tri-Modal Graph-Based Topic Modeling with Iterative Refinement and Archetypes
summary:
Topic modeling extracts latent themes from large text collections, but leading approaches like BERTopic face critical limitations: stochastic instability, loss of lexical precision ("Embedding Blur"), and reliance on a single data perspective.
  We present TriTopic, a framework that addresses these weaknesses through a tri-modal graph fusing semantic embeddings, TF-IDF, and metadata. Three core innovations drive its performance: hybrid graph construction via Mutual kNN and Shared Nearest Neighbors to eliminate noise and combat the curse of dimensionality; Consensus Leiden Clustering for reproducible, stable partitions; and Iterative Refinement that sharpens embeddings through dynamic centroid-pulling. TriTopic also replaces the "average document" concept with archetype-based topic representations defined by boundary cases rather than centers alone.
  In benchmarks across 20 Newsgroups, BBC News, AG News, and Arxiv, TriTopic achieves the highest NMI on every dataset (mean NMI 0.575 vs. 0.513 for BERTopic, 0.416 for NMF, 0.299 for LDA), guarantees 100% corpus coverage with 0% outliers, and is available as an open-source PyPI library.

AI.tldr: TriTopic is a tri‑modal, graph‑based topic modeling framework that fuses semantic embeddings, TF‑IDF, and metadata; it uses a hybrid Mutual kNN + Shared Nearest Neighbors graph, Consensus Leiden clustering for stability, iterative embedding refinement via centroid‑pulling, and archetype‑based topic representations. It outperforms BERTopic, NMF, and LDA in NMI across several benchmarks while assigning every document to a topic (0% outliers).
AI.motivation: Prevailing topic models (e.g., BERTopic) can be unstable, blur lexical specificity due to heavy reliance on embeddings, and depend on a single data view. The goal is to obtain more stable, precise, and multi‑perspective topics with full corpus coverage.
AI.method: Construct a tri‑modal graph that integrates semantic embeddings, TF‑IDF features, and metadata. Denoise and structure it using a hybrid of Mutual kNN and Shared Nearest Neighbors to mitigate high‑dimensional noise. Partition with Consensus Leiden Clustering for reproducibility and stability. Apply Iterative Refinement that sharpens embeddings through dynamic centroid‑pulling. Represent topics not by average documents but by archetypes defined by boundary cases.
AI.result: On 20 Newsgroups, BBC News, AG News, and Arxiv, TriTopic achieves the best NMI on all datasets (mean NMI 0.575 vs. 0.513 for BERTopic, 0.416 for NMF, 0.299 for LDA), guarantees 100% corpus coverage with 0% outliers, and is released as an open‑source PyPI library.
AI.conclusion: TriTopic addresses instability, embedding blur, and single‑view limitations of existing methods, yielding more stable, higher‑NMI topics with full coverage and archetype‑based interpretability, and is positioned as a practical, reproducible alternative to BERTopic and classical topic models.

title: Benchmark Test-Time Scaling of General LLM Agents
summary: LLM agents are increasingly expected to function as general-purpose systems capable of resolving open-ended user requests. While existing benchmarks focus on domain-aware environments for developing specialized agents, evaluating general-purpose agents requires more realistic settings that challenge them to operate across multiple skills and tools within a unified environment. We introduce General AgentBench, a benchmark that provides such a unified framework for evaluating general LLM agents across search, coding, reasoning, and tool-use domains. Using General AgentBench, we systematically study test-time scaling behaviors under sequential scaling (iterative interaction) and parallel scaling (sampling multiple trajectories). Evaluation of ten leading LLM agents reveals a substantial performance degradation when moving from domain-specific evaluations to this general-agent setting. Moreover, we find that neither scaling methodology yields effective performance improvements in practice, due to two fundamental limitations: context ceiling in sequential scaling and verification gap in parallel scaling. Code is publicly available at https://github.com/cxcscmu/General-AgentBench.

AI.tldr: Introduces General AgentBench, a unified and realistic benchmark for evaluating general-purpose LLM agents across search, coding, reasoning, and tool use; shows that 10 leading agents drop markedly in performance versus domain-specific settings, and that test-time scaling via sequential or parallel strategies fails due to context ceilings and verification gaps.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks mostly test specialized, domain-aware agents. Real-world use demands general-purpose agents that can operate across multiple skills and tools in one environment. The authors aim to provide a realistic evaluation setting and to understand whether test-time scaling can recover performance.
AI.method: Build General AgentBench, a single framework spanning search, coding, reasoning, and tool-use tasks. Evaluate ten state-of-the-art LLM agents. Analyze test-time scaling via (1) sequential scaling: longer/iterative interactions that expand context, and (2) parallel scaling: sampling multiple trajectories and selecting among them.
AI.result: Agents that perform well in domain-specific benchmarks suffer substantial drops in the unified, general-agent setting. Increasing steps/context (sequential scaling) and sampling many trajectories (parallel scaling) do not yield reliable improvements. Two core bottlenecks are identified: a context ceiling that limits gains from longer interactions, and a verification gap that prevents effective selection among parallel samples.
AI.conclusion: Today’s LLM agents are not yet robust general-purpose problem solvers in unified environments. Naive test-time scaling strategies are inadequate; progress likely requires overcoming context limitations and building stronger verification/selection mechanisms. The benchmark and code are released to catalyze further research.

title: Optimizing ID Consistency in Multimodal Large Models: Facial Restoration via Alignment, Entanglement, and Disentanglement
summary: Multimodal editing large models have demonstrated powerful editing capabilities across diverse tasks. However, a persistent and long-standing limitation is the decline in facial identity (ID) consistency during realistic portrait editing. Due to the human eye's high sensitivity to facial features, such inconsistency significantly hinders the practical deployment of these models. Current facial ID preservation methods struggle to achieve consistent restoration of both facial identity and edited element IP due to Cross-source Distribution Bias and Cross-source Feature Contamination. To address these issues, we propose EditedID, an Alignment-Disentanglement-Entanglement framework for robust identity-specific facial restoration. By systematically analyzing diffusion trajectories, sampler behaviors, and attention properties, we introduce three key components: 1) Adaptive mixing strategy that aligns cross-source latent representations throughout the diffusion process. 2) Hybrid solver that disentangles source-specific identity attributes and details. 3) Attentional gating mechanism that selectively entangles visual elements. Extensive experiments show that EditedID achieves state-of-the-art performance in preserving original facial ID and edited element IP consistency. As a training-free and plug-and-play solution, it establishes a new benchmark for practical and reliable single/multi-person facial identity restoration in open-world settings, paving the way for the deployment of multimodal editing large models in real-person editing scenarios. The code is available at https://github.com/NDYBSNDY/EditedID.

AI.tldr: EditedID is a training‑free, plug‑and‑play framework that preserves facial identity during realistic portrait edits by aligning, disentangling, and selectively re‑entangling cross‑source features in diffusion models, achieving state‑of‑the‑art ID and edit consistency for single/multi‑person cases in the wild.
AI.motivation: Multimodal editing models often degrade facial identity, which is highly perceptible to humans. Existing solutions fail to jointly maintain the person’s identity and the intended edit due to Cross‑source Distribution Bias and Cross‑source Feature Contamination when mixing information from original and edited sources. A robust, deployable, retraining‑free method is needed.
AI.method: An Alignment‑Disentanglement‑Entanglement pipeline: (1) Adaptive mixing to align latent representations from different sources throughout the diffusion trajectory; (2) A hybrid solver to disentangle source‑specific identity attributes and fine details; (3) An attentional gating mechanism to selectively re‑entangle visual elements, guided by analyses of diffusion trajectories, sampler behavior, and attention properties. The approach is training‑free and plug‑and‑play.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, EditedID attains state‑of‑the‑art preservation of original facial identity while keeping edited element IP consistent, demonstrating robustness in open‑world, single‑ and multi‑person settings. Code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: By mitigating cross‑source bias and contamination, EditedID provides a practical, reliable path for real‑person portrait editing with multimodal editing models, setting a new benchmark for identity‑specific restoration without additional training.

title: Value Entanglement: Conflation Between Different Kinds of Good In (Some) Large Language Models
summary: Value alignment of Large Language Models (LLMs) requires us to empirically measure these models' actual, acquired representation of value. Among the characteristics of value representation in humans is that they distinguish among value of different kinds. We investigate whether LLMs likewise distinguish three different kinds of good: moral, grammatical, and economic. By probing model behavior, embeddings, and residual stream activations, we report pervasive cases of value entanglement: a conflation between these distinct representations of value. Specifically, both grammatical and economic valuation was found to be overly influenced by moral value, relative to human norms. This conflation was repaired by selective ablation of the activation vectors associated with morality.

AI.tldr: LLMs conflate different kinds of “good”: moral judgments bleed into grammatical and economic evaluations, but this entanglement can be reduced by ablating morality-associated activation directions.
AI.motivation: For robust value alignment, we must empirically characterize what kinds of value LLMs actually represent. Humans distinguish moral, grammatical, and economic value; the study asks whether LLMs similarly separate these value kinds or mix them.
AI.method: Probe model behavior, embedding structure, and residual stream activations to diagnose overlaps among value dimensions. Identify activation vectors associated with morality and perform selective ablation to test whether removing them disentangles valuations.
AI.result: Pervasive value entanglement observed: grammatical and economic valuations are overly influenced by moral value relative to human baselines. Selective ablation of morality-associated activations reduced the conflation, suggesting a causal role of these directions.
AI.conclusion: LLMs do not natively keep moral, grammatical, and economic value representations separate. Mechanistic edits can partially repair this, with implications for alignment, interpretability, and control—but raise questions about reliability, side effects, and how to define the human-normative baseline.

title: MagicAgent: Towards Generalized Agent Planning
summary: The evolution of Large Language Models (LLMs) from passive text processors to autonomous agents has established planning as a core component of modern intelligence. However, achieving generalized planning remains elusive, not only by the scarcity of high-quality interaction data but also by inherent conflicts across heterogeneous planning tasks. These challenges result in models that excel at isolated tasks yet struggle to generalize, while existing multi-task training attempts suffer from gradient interference. In this paper, we present \textbf{MagicAgent}, a series of foundation models specifically designed for generalized agent planning. We introduce a lightweight and scalable synthetic data framework that generates high-quality trajectories across diverse planning tasks, including hierarchical task decomposition, tool-augmented planning, multi-constraint scheduling, procedural logic orchestration, and long-horizon tool execution. To mitigate training conflicts, we propose a two-stage training paradigm comprising supervised fine-tuning followed by multi-objective reinforcement learning over both static datasets and dynamic environments. Empirical results demonstrate that MagicAgent-32B and MagicAgent-30B-A3B deliver superior performance, achieving accuracies of $75.1\%$ on Worfbench, $55.9\%$ on NaturalPlan, $57.5\%$ on $τ^2$-Bench, $86.9\%$ on BFCL-v3, and $81.2\%$ on ACEBench, as well as strong results on our in-house MagicEval benchmarks. These results substantially outperform existing sub-100B models and even surpass leading closed-source models.

AI.tldr: MagicAgent is a family of mid-size (≈30B) foundation models for generalized agent planning, trained on scalable synthetic multi-task planning data and a two-stage SFT + multi-objective RL pipeline, achieving state-of-the-art results across diverse planning benchmarks—often surpassing larger and closed-source systems.
AI.motivation: LLM agents need robust, transferable planning skills, but current models overfit to single tasks due to scarce high-quality interaction data and gradient interference when jointly training heterogeneous planning abilities. The goal is to build a unified planner that generalizes across task types and horizons.
AI.method: (1) A lightweight, scalable synthetic data framework generating high-quality trajectories for varied planning tasks: hierarchical decomposition, tool-augmented planning, multi-constraint scheduling, procedural logic orchestration, and long-horizon tool execution. (2) A two-stage training paradigm: supervised fine-tuning on synthetic/static data, followed by multi-objective reinforcement learning over both static datasets and dynamic environments to mitigate cross-task conflicts and gradient interference.
AI.result: MagicAgent-32B and MagicAgent-30B-A3B achieve 75.1% on Worfbench, 55.9% on NaturalPlan, 57.5% on τ^2-Bench, 86.9% on BFCL-v3, and 81.2% on ACEBench, plus strong in-house MagicEval scores—substantially outperforming sub-100B models and even surpassing leading closed-source models on these benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Combining scalable synthetic planning trajectories with a staged SFT + multi-objective RL regimen yields broad, transferable planning competence in LLM agents while reducing task interference. MagicAgent sets a new state-of-the-art for generalized planning in sub-100B models.

title: Driving with A Thousand Faces: A Benchmark for Closed-Loop Personalized End-to-End Autonomous Driving
summary: Human driving behavior is inherently diverse, yet most end-to-end autonomous driving (E2E-AD) systems learn a single average driving style, neglecting individual differences. Achieving personalized E2E-AD faces challenges across three levels: limited real-world datasets with individual-level annotations, a lack of quantitative metrics for evaluating personal driving styles, and the absence of algorithms that can learn stylized representations from users' trajectories. To address these gaps, we propose Person2Drive, a comprehensive personalized E2E-AD platform and benchmark. It includes an open-source, flexible data collection system that simulates realistic scenarios to generate scalable and diverse personalized driving datasets; style vector-based evaluation metrics with Maximum Mean Discrepancy and KL divergence to comprehensively quantify individual driving behaviors; and a personalized E2E-AD framework with a style reward model that efficiently adapts E2E models for safe and individualized driving. Extensive experiments demonstrate that Person2Drive enables fine-grained analysis, reproducible evaluation, and effective personalization in end-to-end autonomous driving. Our dataset and code will be released after acceptance.

AI.tldr: Person2Drive proposes a full-stack platform and benchmark for personalized end-to-end autonomous driving, featuring (1) an open-source data collection system for scalable, user-specific driving data, (2) style-vector metrics using MMD and KL to quantify driving styles, and (3) a personalization framework with a style reward model to adapt E2E policies. Experiments show improved, reproducible personalization without sacrificing safety.
AI.motivation: Human drivers exhibit diverse styles, but most E2E-AD models learn an averaged policy. Progress is hindered by three gaps: scarce individual-annotated data, no standard quantitative style metrics, and no algorithms to learn or condition on user-specific style from trajectories.
AI.method: Build a flexible simulator-based data collection pipeline to gather stylized, user-conditioned trajectories; define style vectors and evaluate inter-/intra-driver differences via MMD and KL divergence; introduce a personalized E2E-AD framework that leverages a style reward model to adapt base E2E policies toward each user's style while maintaining safety.
AI.result: On extensive experiments, the platform supports fine-grained style analysis, reproducible benchmarking, and effective personalization of E2E-AD policies, demonstrating safe, individualized behavior according to the proposed metrics.
AI.conclusion: Person2Drive closes critical gaps for personalized E2E-AD by unifying data, metrics, and an adaptable learning framework. It enables rigorous style-aware evaluation and practical personalization; dataset and code will be released upon acceptance.

title: Astra: Activation-Space Tail-Eigenvector Low-Rank Adaptation of Large Language Models
summary: Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) methods, especially LoRA, are widely used for adapting pre-trained models to downstream tasks due to their computational and storage efficiency. However, in the context of LoRA and its variants, the potential of activation subspaces corresponding to tail eigenvectors remains substantially under-exploited, which may lead to suboptimal fine-tuning performance. In this work, we propose Astra (Activation-Space Tail-Eigenvector Low-Rank Adaptation), a novel PEFT method that leverages the tail eigenvectors of the model output activations-estimated from a small task-specific calibration set-to construct task-adaptive low-rank adapters. By constraining updates to the subspace spanned by these tail eigenvectors, Astra achieves faster convergence and improved downstream performance with a significantly reduced parameter budget. Extensive experiments across natural language understanding (NLU) and natural language generation (NLG) tasks demonstrate that Astra consistently outperforms existing PEFT baselines across 16 benchmarks and even surpasses full fine-tuning (FFT) in certain scenarios.

AI.tldr: Astra is a PEFT approach that builds task-adaptive low‑rank adapters by constraining updates to the tail eigenvector subspace of model output activations (estimated from a small calibration set), achieving faster convergence and better performance than LoRA variants, and sometimes even full fine-tuning, across 16 NLU/NLG benchmarks with fewer trainable parameters.
AI.motivation: Standard PEFT (e.g., LoRA) underutilizes informative low-variance activation directions, potentially limiting adaptation quality. The authors aim to exploit these tail activation subspaces to improve fine-tuning efficiency and downstream performance under tight parameter budgets.
AI.method: Estimate the eigenspectrum of model output activations on a small task-specific calibration set; select tail eigenvectors (smallest eigenvalues) and constrain adapter updates to their span. Construct low-rank, task-adaptive adapters aligned with these tail directions, thereby focusing learning on under-exploited activation subspaces while keeping parameter count low.
AI.result: On 16 NLU and NLG benchmarks, Astra consistently outperforms existing PEFT baselines, converges faster, and in some cases surpasses full fine-tuning, all with a significantly reduced parameter budget.
AI.conclusion: Tail activation subspaces are valuable for adaptation. Projecting LoRA-style updates onto these subspaces yields superior accuracy–efficiency trade-offs versus standard PEFT and can even exceed full fine-tuning in some settings.

title: Evaluating Large Language Models on Quantum Mechanics: A Comparative Study Across Diverse Models and Tasks
summary: We present a systematic evaluation of large language models on quantum mechanics problem-solving. Our study evaluates 15 models from five providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Alibaba, DeepSeek) spanning three capability tiers on 20 tasks covering derivations, creative problems, non-standard concepts, and numerical computation, comprising 900 baseline and 75 tool-augmented assessments. Results reveal clear tier stratification: flagship models achieve 81\% average accuracy, outperforming mid-tier (77\%) and fast models (67\%) by 4pp and 14pp respectively. Task difficulty patterns emerge distinctly: derivations show highest performance (92\% average, 100\% for flagship models), while numerical computation remains most challenging (42\%). Tool augmentation on numerical tasks yields task-dependent effects: modest overall improvement (+4.4pp) at 3x token cost masks dramatic heterogeneity ranging from +29pp gains to -16pp degradation. Reproducibility analysis across three runs quantifies 6.3pp average variance, with flagship models demonstrating exceptional stability (GPT-5 achieves zero variance) while specialized models require multi-run evaluation. This work contributes: (i) a benchmark for quantum mechanics with automatic verification, (ii) systematic evaluation quantifying tier-based performance hierarchies, (iii) empirical analysis of tool augmentation trade-offs, and (iv) reproducibility characterization. All tasks, verifiers, and results are publicly released.

AI.tldr: They benchmark 15 LLMs on 20 quantum-mechanics tasks with automatic verification, finding clear tier stratification (flagships best), derivations easy and numerics hard, mixed benefits from tool augmentation, measurable run-to-run variance, and they release the full benchmark and results.
AI.motivation: To rigorously quantify how well different capability tiers of LLMs solve quantum mechanics problems, identify task-type strengths/weaknesses, understand the trade-offs of tool augmentation, and assess reproducibility—while providing a public, automatically verifiable benchmark.
AI.method: Evaluate 15 models from five providers across three tiers on 20 QM tasks (derivations, creative, non-standard, numerical). Conduct 900 baseline evaluations plus 75 tool-augmented (for numerics), use automatic verifiers for correctness, and perform a three-run reproducibility analysis to measure variance.
AI.result: Flagships average 81% accuracy, mid-tier 77% (−4pp), fast 67% (−14pp). Derivations are highest-performing (92% avg; 100% for flagships), numerics lowest (42%). Tool augmentation on numerical tasks yields a modest +4.4pp average gain at ~3× token cost, with wide heterogeneity from +29pp to −16pp. Reproducibility shows ~6.3pp average variance; flagship models are very stable (GPT-5: zero variance), while specialized models require multi-run evaluation.
AI.conclusion: The work delivers a public, auto-graded QM benchmark and shows clear performance hierarchies, task-dependent difficulty, and nuanced, cost-sensitive benefits of tool use. Flagship models are both more accurate and more stable; numerics remain a key weakness; and multi-run evaluation is advisable for specialized models.

title: TAG: Thinking with Action Unit Grounding for Facial Expression Recognition
summary: Facial Expression Recognition (FER) is a fine-grained visual understanding task where reliable predictions require reasoning over localized and meaningful facial cues. Recent vision--language models (VLMs) enable natural language explanations for FER, but their reasoning is often ungrounded, producing fluent yet unverifiable rationales that are weakly tied to visual evidence and prone to hallucination, leading to poor robustness across different datasets. We propose TAG (Thinking with Action Unit Grounding), a vision--language framework that explicitly constrains multimodal reasoning to be supported by facial Action Units (AUs). TAG requires intermediate reasoning steps to be grounded in AU-related facial regions, yielding predictions accompanied by verifiable visual evidence. The model is trained via supervised fine-tuning on AU-grounded reasoning traces followed by reinforcement learning with an AU-aware reward that aligns predicted regions with external AU detectors. Evaluated on RAF-DB, FERPlus, and AffectNet, TAG consistently outperforms strong open-source and closed-source VLM baselines while simultaneously improving visual faithfulness. Ablation and preference studies further show that AU-grounded rewards stabilize reasoning and mitigate hallucination, demonstrating the importance of structured grounded intermediate representations for trustworthy multimodal reasoning in FER. The code will be available at https://github.com/would1920/FER_TAG .

AI.tldr: TAG grounds FER reasoning in Facial Action Units (AUs), training VLMs with AU-grounded traces and an AU-aware RL reward to produce verifiable, region-aligned explanations that boost accuracy and faithfulness on RAF-DB, FERPlus, and AffectNet versus strong baselines.
AI.motivation: VLM-generated explanations for FER are often ungrounded and hallucinated, weakening robustness and trust because they are not tied to concrete, verifiable facial cues. Facial Action Units provide semantically meaningful, localized evidence that can anchor reasoning.
AI.method: Introduce TAG, a vision–language framework that constrains intermediate reasoning to AU-related facial regions. Train with supervised fine-tuning on AU-grounded reasoning traces, then apply reinforcement learning using an AU-aware reward that aligns predicted regions with external AU detectors, yielding predictions plus localized visual evidence.
AI.result: Across RAF-DB, FERPlus, and AffectNet, TAG outperforms strong open- and closed-source VLM baselines while improving visual faithfulness. Ablations and preference studies indicate AU-grounded rewards stabilize reasoning and reduce hallucinations.
AI.conclusion: Structured, AU-grounded intermediate representations yield more robust and trustworthy multimodal FER by coupling explanations with verifiable visual evidence; code will be released for reproducibility.

title: How Do LLMs Encode Scientific Quality? An Empirical Study Using Monosemantic Features from Sparse Autoencoders
comment: Presented at SESAME 2025: Smarter Extraction of ScholArly MEtadata using Knowledge Graphs and Language Models, @ JCDL 2025
summary: In recent years, there has been a growing use of generative AI, and large language models (LLMs) in particular, to support both the assessment and generation of scientific work. Although some studies have shown that LLMs can, to a certain extent, evaluate research according to perceived quality, our understanding of the internal mechanisms that enable this capability remains limited. This paper presents the first study that investigates how LLMs encode the concept of scientific quality through relevant monosemantic features extracted using sparse autoencoders. We derive such features under different experimental settings and assess their ability to serve as predictors across three tasks related to research quality: predicting citation count, journal SJR, and journal h-index. The results indicate that LLMs encode features associated with multiple dimensions of scientific quality. In particular, we identify four recurring types of features that capture key aspects of how research quality is represented: 1) features reflecting research methodologies; 2) features related to publication type, with literature reviews typically exhibiting higher impact; 3) features associated with high-impact research fields and technologies; and 4) features corresponding to specific scientific jargons. These findings represent an important step toward understanding how LLMs encapsulate concepts related to research quality.

AI.tldr: They use sparse autoencoders to expose monosemantic features inside LLMs that correlate with proxies of scientific quality (citations, journal SJR, h-index). These features cluster into four recurring types—methodology, publication type, high-impact fields/technologies, and domain-specific jargon—showing LLMs encode multi-dimensional cues of research quality.
AI.motivation: LLMs can approximate judgments of scientific quality, but it is unclear what internal representations enable this. The work aims to identify interpretable, mechanistic features tied to research quality and test whether such features meaningfully predict impact-related outcomes.
AI.method: Apply sparse autoencoders to LLM activations to extract monosemantic features under varied settings. Use these features as predictors on three tasks: forecasting citation counts, journal SJR, and journal h-index. Inspect recurring and semantically coherent feature types that relate to perceived scientific quality.
AI.result: The learned features predict citation counts and journal-level metrics, implying that LLMs encode multiple dimensions of research quality. Four consistent feature families emerge: (1) research-methodology markers; (2) publication-type signals (e.g., literature reviews often higher impact); (3) indicators of high-impact fields/technologies; (4) specific scientific jargon features.
AI.conclusion: LLMs house interpretable features that encapsulate aspects of scientific quality. Making these features explicit is a step toward mechanistic understanding and could support more transparent evaluation and generation of scientific text, though broader validation beyond the tested proxies is needed.

title: Agentic Problem Frames: A Systematic Approach to Engineering Reliable Domain Agents
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are evolving into autonomous agents, yet current "frameless" development--relying on ambiguous natural language without engineering blueprints--leads to critical risks such as scope creep and open-loop failures. To ensure industrial-grade reliability, this study proposes Agentic Problem Frames (APF), a systematic engineering framework that shifts focus from internal model intelligence to the structured interaction between the agent and its environment.
  The APF establishes a dynamic specification paradigm where intent is concretized at runtime through domain knowledge injection. At its core, the Act-Verify-Refine (AVR) loop functions as a closed-loop control system that transforms execution results into verified knowledge assets, driving system behavior toward asymptotic convergence to mission requirements (R). To operationalize this, this study introduces the Agentic Job Description (AJD), a formal specification tool that defines jurisdictional boundaries, operational contexts, and epistemic evaluation criteria.
  The efficacy of this framework is validated through two contrasting case studies: a delegated proxy model for business travel and an autonomous supervisor model for industrial equipment management. By applying AJD-based specification and APF modeling to these scenarios, the analysis demonstrates how operational scenarios are systematically controlled within defined boundaries. These cases provide a conceptual proof that agent reliability stems not from a model's internal reasoning alone, but from the rigorous engineering structures that anchor stochastic AI within deterministic business processes, thereby enabling the development of verifiable and dependable domain agents.

AI.tldr: Introduces an engineering framework—Agentic Problem Frames (APF) with an Act‑Verify‑Refine (AVR) closed loop and a formal Agentic Job Description (AJD)—to make LLM agents reliable by constraining and verifying their behavior via runtime domain knowledge; supported by two case studies (business travel proxy, industrial equipment supervisor).
AI.motivation: ‘Frameless’ prompt-driven agents suffer scope creep and open-loop failures, unsuitable for industrial reliability. The paper aims to provide deterministic, auditable boundaries and verification for agent behavior.
AI.method: Shift focus from model internals to agent–environment interaction using APF; dynamically instantiate intent at runtime through domain knowledge injection; run an AVR loop that converts execution outcomes into verified knowledge assets guiding convergence to requirements (R); operationalize with AJD specifying jurisdiction, context, and epistemic evaluation criteria.
AI.result: In two contrasting scenarios (business travel delegation and industrial equipment supervision), APF+AJD purportedly keeps operations within defined bounds and turns results into verifiable artifacts, illustrating controlled, closed-loop behavior toward mission requirements.
AI.conclusion: Agent dependability arises from rigorous engineering structures (APF/AJD and closed-loop verification) rather than model reasoning alone, enabling verifiable, domain-specific agents that integrate with deterministic business processes.

title: A high-resolution nationwide urban village mapping product for 342 Chinese cities based on foundation models
comment: Submitted to Earth System Science Data
summary: Urban Villages (UVs) represent a distinctive form of high-density informal settlement embedded within China's rapidly urbanizing cities. Accurate identification of UVs is critical for urban governance, renewal, and sustainable development. But due to the pronounced heterogeneity and diversity of UVs across China's vast territory, a consistent and reliable nationwide dataset has been lacking. In this work, we present GeoLink-UV, a high-resolution nationwide UV mapping product that clearly delineates the locations and boundaries of UVs in 342 Chinese cities. The dataset is derived from multisource geospatial data, including optical remote sensing images and geo-vector data, and is generated through a foundation model-driven mapping framework designed to address the generalization issues and improve the product quality. A geographically stratified accuracy assessment based on independent samples from 28 cities confirms the reliability and scientific credibility of the nationwide dataset across heterogeneous urban contexts. Based on this nationwide product, we reveal substantial interregional disparities in UV prevalence and spatial configuration. On average, UV areas account for 8 % of built-up land, with marked clustering in central and south China. Building-level analysis further confirms a consistent low-rise, high-density development pattern of UVs nationwide, while highlighting regionally differentiated morphological characteristics. The GeoLink-UV dataset provides an open and systematically validated geospatial foundation for urban studies, informal settlement monitoring, and evidence-based urban renewal planning, and contributes directly to large-scale assessments aligned with Sustainable Development Goal 11. The GeoLink-UV dataset introduced in this article is freely available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.18688062.

AI.tldr: GeoLink-UV is a nationwide, high-resolution map of urban villages across 342 Chinese cities, built with a foundation-model framework from multisource geospatial data and independently validated; it reveals UVs average ~8% of built-up land, cluster in central/southern China, and are characteristically low-rise, high-density.
AI.motivation: China lacks a consistent, reliable, and nation-scale dataset of urban villages (UVs) because UVs are heterogeneous and diverse across regions; this gap hampers governance, renewal, monitoring, and SDG-aligned planning.
AI.method: Construct a foundation model-driven mapping framework that fuses optical remote sensing imagery and geo-vector data to delineate UV locations and boundaries nationwide. Address generalization challenges via the foundation model, and conduct a geographically stratified accuracy assessment with independent samples from 28 cities.
AI.result: Produced GeoLink-UV, a high-resolution UV dataset covering 342 cities. Validation confirms reliability across heterogeneous urban contexts. Empirically, UVs comprise ~8% of built-up land, with strong clustering in central and southern China. Building-level metrics show a consistent low-rise, high-density form, with regional morphological differences. Dataset is openly available (DOI provided).
AI.conclusion: GeoLink-UV offers a rigorously validated, open geospatial foundation for urban research, monitoring of informal settlements, and evidence-based renewal, directly supporting large-scale assessments aligned with SDG 11 and enabling cross-regional comparisons of UV prevalence and morphology.

title: AgenticRAGTracer: A Hop-Aware Benchmark for Diagnosing Multi-Step Retrieval Reasoning in Agentic RAG
summary: With the rapid advancement of agent-based methods in recent years, Agentic RAG has undoubtedly become an important research direction. Multi-hop reasoning, which requires models to engage in deliberate thinking and multi-step interaction, serves as a critical testbed for assessing such capabilities. However, existing benchmarks typically provide only final questions and answers, while lacking the intermediate hop-level questions that gradually connect atomic questions to the final multi-hop query. This limitation prevents researchers from analyzing at which step an agent fails and restricts more fine-grained evaluation of model capabilities. Moreover, most current benchmarks are manually constructed, which is both time-consuming and labor-intensive, while also limiting scalability and generalization. To address these challenges, we introduce AgenticRAGTracer, the first Agentic RAG benchmark that is primarily constructed automatically by large language models and designed to support step-by-step validation. Our benchmark spans multiple domains, contains 1,305 data points, and has no overlap with existing mainstream benchmarks. Extensive experiments demonstrate that even the best large language models perform poorly on our dataset. For instance, GPT-5 attains merely 22.6\% EM accuracy on the hardest portion of our dataset. Hop-aware diagnosis reveals that failures are primarily driven by distorted reasoning chains -- either collapsing prematurely or wandering into over-extension. This highlights a critical inability to allocate steps consistent with the task's logical structure, providing a diagnostic dimension missing in traditional evaluations. We believe our work will facilitate research in Agentic RAG and inspire further meaningful progress in this area. Our code and data are available at https://github.com/YqjMartin/AgenticRAGTracer.

AI.tldr: AgenticRAGTracer is a new, largely LLM-constructed benchmark for Agentic RAG that adds hop-level questions to enable step-by-step evaluation and diagnosis; state-of-the-art LLMs perform poorly on it, revealing failures in allocating and maintaining coherent reasoning steps.
AI.motivation: Current multi-hop benchmarks typically provide only final Q/A pairs, preventing diagnosis of which intermediate step fails. Manual dataset construction is costly, slow, and limits scale and generalization. The field needs an agent-focused, hop-aware benchmark that can be built and scaled efficiently.
AI.method: Automatically generate a multi-domain benchmark via large language models that includes intermediate hop-level questions linking atomic facts to the final multi-hop query. Provide step-by-step validation for fine-grained evaluation. Ensure non-overlap with mainstream benchmarks. Evaluate leading LLMs and analyze errors with hop-aware diagnostics.
AI.result: Across the 1,305-example dataset, top LLMs underperform; for example, GPT-5 yields only 22.6% exact match on the hardest split. Error analysis shows distorted reasoning chains, either collapsing early or over-extending beyond necessary steps, indicating poor alignment between step allocation and task logic.
AI.conclusion: AgenticRAGTracer exposes key weaknesses in Agentic RAG multi-hop reasoning and adds a missing diagnostic dimension via hop-aware evaluation. The benchmark and tools aim to drive progress; resources are released publicly for replication and further research.

title: Asking the Right Questions: Improving Reasoning with Generated Stepping Stones
summary: Recent years have witnessed tremendous progress in enabling LLMs to solve complex reasoning tasks such as math and coding. As we start to apply LLMs to harder tasks that they may not be able to solve in one shot, it is worth paying attention to their ability to construct intermediate stepping stones that prepare them to better solve the tasks. Examples of stepping stones include simplifications, alternative framings, or subproblems. We study properties and benefits of stepping stones in the context of modern reasoning LLMs via ARQ (\textbf{A}king the \textbf{R}ight \textbf{Q}uestions), our simple framework which introduces a question generator to the default reasoning pipeline. We first show that good stepping stone questions exist and are transferrable, meaning that good questions can be generated, and they substantially help LLMs of various capabilities in solving the target tasks. We next frame stepping stone generation as a post-training task and show that we can fine-tune LLMs to generate more useful stepping stones by SFT and RL on synthetic data.

AI.tldr: ARQ adds a question-generation stage to LLM reasoning so the model first proposes “stepping-stone” questions (simplifications, reframings, subproblems). Such questions exist, transfer across models, and measurably boost task performance; fine-tuning with SFT and RL on synthetic data further improves question quality and downstream results.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle on harder tasks when forced into one-shot solutions. Introducing intermediate reasoning aids—explicit questions that decompose or reframe problems—may systematically improve their ability to solve complex math/coding-style tasks.
AI.method: Propose ARQ (Asking the Right Questions): insert a question generator into the standard reasoning pipeline to produce stepping-stone questions before solving. Study (1) existence and transferability of helpful questions, and (2) post-training for question generation via supervised fine-tuning and reinforcement learning on synthetic data.
AI.result: Show that high-quality stepping-stone questions can be generated, generalize across models of varying capability, and substantially increase success on target tasks. Post-training (SFT and RL) on synthetic data yields better question generation and further boosts performance.
AI.conclusion: Equipping LLMs to generate targeted intermediate questions is an effective, trainable lever for improving complex reasoning. Stepping-stone generation should be an explicit post-training objective to enhance LLM problem-solving across tasks and models.

title: Initialization matters in few-shot adaptation of vision-language models for histopathological image classification
comment: Accepted as oral presentation at CASEIB 2024 held in Sevilla, Spain
summary: Vision language models (VLM) pre-trained on datasets of histopathological image-caption pairs enabled zero-shot slide-level classification. The ability of VLM image encoders to extract discriminative features also opens the door for supervised fine-tuning for whole-slide image (WSI) classification, ideally using few labeled samples. Slide-level prediction frameworks require the incorporation of multiple instance learning (MIL) due to the gigapixel size of the WSI. Following patch-level feature extraction and aggregation, MIL frameworks rely on linear classifiers trained on top of the slide-level aggregated features. Classifier weight initialization has a large influence on Linear Probing performance in efficient transfer learning (ETL) approaches based on few-shot learning. In this work, we propose Zero-Shot Multiple-Instance Learning (ZS-MIL) to address the limitations of random classifier initialization that underperform zero-shot prediction in MIL problems. ZS-MIL uses the class-level embeddings of the VLM text encoder as the classification layer's starting point to compute each sample's bag-level probabilities. Through multiple experiments, we demonstrate the robustness of ZS-MIL compared to well-known weight initialization techniques both in terms of performance and variability in an ETL few-shot scenario for subtyping prediction.

AI.tldr: Proposes Zero-Shot Multiple-Instance Learning (ZS-MIL), which initializes the MIL slide-level classifier with class text embeddings from a vision–language model to outperform and stabilize few-shot WSI subtyping versus random and other inits, and to avoid underperforming zero-shot baselines.
AI.motivation: In few-shot efficient transfer learning for whole-slide images, slide-level MIL pipelines depend on a linear classifier whose performance is highly sensitive to weight initialization; random starts can even trail zero-shot VLM predictions. A principled, semantically aligned initialization is needed to leverage VLMs’ prior knowledge and reduce variability.
AI.method: Extract patch features with a VLM image encoder, aggregate to slide-level (MIL), and replace random linear head initialization by seeding classifier weights with class-level embeddings from the VLM text encoder; compute bag-level probabilities from this initialized head. Compare against standard initialization schemes in few-shot subtyping tasks.
AI.result: Across multiple experiments, ZS-MIL shows higher accuracy and lower performance variability than common weight-initialization baselines in an efficient transfer learning few-shot setting for subtype prediction; it avoids the degradation relative to zero-shot seen with random inits.
AI.conclusion: Using VLM text embeddings to initialize the MIL classifier provides a robust, semantically grounded starting point that enhances few-shot slide-level classification performance and stability, suggesting a practical path to reliable ETL on WSIs with limited labels.

title: A Dataset for Named Entity Recognition and Relation Extraction from Art-historical Image Descriptions
summary: This paper introduces FRAME (Fine-grained Recognition of Art-historical Metadata and Entities), a manually annotated dataset of art-historical image descriptions for Named Entity Recognition (NER) and Relation Extraction (RE). Descriptions were collected from museum catalogs, auction listings, open-access platforms, and scholarly databases, then filtered to ensure that each text focuses on a single artwork and contains explicit statements about its material, composition, or iconography. FRAME provides stand-off annotations in three layers: a metadata layer for object-level properties, a content layer for depicted subjects and motifs, and a co-reference layer linking repeated mentions. Across layers, entity spans are labeled with 37 types and connected by typed RE links between mentions. Entity types are aligned with Wikidata to support Named Entity Linking (NEL) and downstream knowledge-graph construction. The dataset is released as UIMA XMI Common Analysis Structure (CAS) files with accompanying images and bibliographic metadata, and can be used to benchmark and fine-tune NER and RE systems, including zero- and few-shot setups with Large Language Models (LLMs).

AI.tldr: FRAME is a manually annotated, multi-layer dataset of art-historical descriptions designed for fine-grained NER, relation extraction, and entity linking, aligned to Wikidata and packaged in UIMA XMI, enabling benchmarking and knowledge-graph construction—even in zero/few-shot LLM settings.
AI.motivation: General-purpose NER/RE resources miss the domain-specific entities, relations, and co-reference patterns found in art-historical texts (materials, composition, iconography). The field needs a standardized, fine-grained, and linkable dataset to power accurate extraction and knowledge-graph building for artworks.
AI.method: Curate textual descriptions from museums, auctions, open platforms, and scholarly databases; filter to single-artwork focus with explicit material/composition/iconography statements; annotate stand-off in three layers (metadata/object, content/subjects-motifs, co-reference). Label entity spans with 37 types; connect mentions with typed relations; align entity types to Wikidata for NEL. Release as UIMA XMI CAS with associated images and bibliographic metadata to support benchmarking and model fine-tuning, including LLM zero/few-shot.
AI.result: A publicly released dataset (FRAME) comprising three-layer stand-off annotations, 37 entity types, typed relations, Wikidata alignment, and packaged as UIMA XMI CAS with images and bibliographic data. It is suitable for benchmarking and fine-tuning NER/RE systems and for NEL and KG construction, including zero-/few-shot LLM evaluations.
AI.conclusion: FRAME fills a critical gap for art-history NLP by providing standardized, fine-grained, and linkable annotations, facilitating robust NER/RE/NEL and downstream knowledge-graph applications, and offering a reusable benchmark for both traditional models and LLMs.

title: Defining Explainable AI for Requirements Analysis
comment: 7 pages, 1 figure. Originally published as Sheh, R., Monteath, I. Defining Explainable AI for Requirements Analysis. Kunstl Intell 32, 261-266 (2018)
summary:
Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) has become popular in the last few years. The Artificial Intelligence (AI) community in general, and the Machine Learning (ML) community in particular, is coming to the realisation that in many applications, for AI to be trusted, it must not only demonstrate good performance in its decisionmaking, but it also must explain these decisions and convince us that it is making the decisions for the right reasons. However, different applications have different requirements on the information required of the underlying AI system in order to convince us that it is worthy of our trust. How do we define these requirements?
  In this paper, we present three dimensions for categorising the explanatory requirements of different applications. These are Source, Depth and Scope. We focus on the problem of matching up the explanatory requirements of different applications with the capabilities of underlying ML techniques to provide them. We deliberately avoid including aspects of explanation that are already well-covered by the existing literature and we focus our discussion on ML although the principles apply to AI more broadly.

AI.tldr: Proposes a concise framework—Source, Depth, and Scope—to categorize what different applications need from explanations and to align those needs with the explainability capabilities of various ML methods.
AI.motivation: Trust in AI/ML depends not just on performance but on reasons behind decisions. Different applications demand different kinds of explanations, yet the community lacks a clear way to define and compare these requirements.
AI.method: Conceptual analysis introducing three dimensions (Source, Depth, Scope) to classify explanatory requirements, and discussion on mapping these requirements to the capabilities of ML techniques; deliberately excludes already well-trodden XAI aspects and keeps focus on ML while noting broader AI relevance.
AI.result: A taxonomy/organizing framework that characterizes explanation needs across applications along the three dimensions and guidance on how to match them with ML methods’ explanatory offerings.
AI.conclusion: Using Source, Depth, and Scope provides a structured way to specify and evaluate explanation requirements and to select or design ML techniques that can satisfy them; the approach generalizes beyond ML to AI at large.

title: MaskDiME: Adaptive Masked Diffusion for Precise and Efficient Visual Counterfactual Explanations
summary: Visual counterfactual explanations aim to reveal the minimal semantic modifications that can alter a model's prediction, providing causal and interpretable insights into deep neural networks. However, existing diffusion-based counterfactual generation methods are often computationally expensive, slow to sample, and imprecise in localizing the modified regions. To address these limitations, we propose MaskDiME, a simple, fast, and effective diffusion framework that unifies semantic consistency and spatial precision through localized sampling. Our approach adaptively focuses on decision-relevant regions to achieve localized and semantically consistent counterfactual generation while preserving high image fidelity. Our training-free framework, MaskDiME, achieves over 30x faster inference than the baseline method and achieves comparable or state-of-the-art performance across five benchmark datasets spanning diverse visual domains, establishing a practical and generalizable solution for efficient counterfactual explanation.

AI.tldr: MaskDiME is a training‑free, localized diffusion sampling method that produces semantically consistent visual counterfactuals ~30× faster than prior diffusion approaches while matching or surpassing quality across five datasets.
AI.motivation: Current diffusion-based visual counterfactual methods are computationally heavy, slow to sample, and often fail to localize edits, undermining interpretability. The aim is to achieve minimal, spatially precise changes that flip model predictions while preserving semantics and image fidelity.
AI.method: A simple diffusion framework that performs localized sampling, adaptively focusing on decision-relevant regions to unify semantic consistency and spatial precision. The approach is training-free and designed for high-fidelity, localized counterfactual generation.
AI.result: Across five diverse benchmarks, MaskDiME achieves >30× faster inference than a baseline diffusion method, with comparable or state-of-the-art counterfactual quality and strong image fidelity, indicating effective localization and semantic consistency.
AI.conclusion: MaskDiME provides a practical and generalizable solution for efficient visual counterfactual explanations by coupling semantic consistency with precise, localized edits, delivering large speedups without sacrificing quality.

title: Facet-Level Persona Control by Trait-Activated Routing with Contrastive SAE for Role-Playing LLMs
comment: Accepted in PAKDD 2026 special session on Data Science :Foundation and Applications
summary: Personality control in Role-Playing Agents (RPAs) is commonly achieved via training-free methods that inject persona descriptions and memory through prompts or retrieval-augmented generation, or via supervised fine-tuning (SFT) on persona-specific corpora. While SFT can be effective, it requires persona-labeled data and retraining for new roles, limiting flexibility. In contrast, prompt- and RAG-based signals are easy to apply but can be diluted in long dialogues, leading to drifting and sometimes inconsistent persona behavior. To address this, we propose a contrastive Sparse AutoEncoder (SAE) framework that learns facet-level personality control vectors aligned with the Big Five 30-facet model. A new 15,000-sample leakage-controlled corpus is constructed to provide balanced supervision for each facet. The learned vectors are integrated into the model's residual space and dynamically selected by a trait-activated routing module, enabling precise and interpretable personality steering. Experiments on Large Language Models (LLMs) show that the proposed method maintains stable character fidelity and output quality across contextualized settings, outperforming Contrastive Activation Addition (CAA) and prompt-only baselines. The combined SAE+Prompt configuration achieves the best overall performance, confirming that contrastively trained latent vectors can enhance persona control while preserving dialogue coherence.

AI.tldr: Learn facet-level personality control vectors with a contrastive Sparse AutoEncoder aligned to the Big Five; inject them into an LLM’s residual stream with a trait-activated router to stably steer role-play personas. Outperforms prompt-only and CAA; best when combined with prompts.
AI.motivation: Prompt/RAG persona signals dilute over long dialogues, causing drift and inconsistency; SFT needs persona-labeled data and retraining for each role, limiting flexibility. The paper seeks precise, persistent, interpretable persona control without retraining and robust across contexts.
AI.method: 1) Build a 15k-sample, leakage-controlled, balanced corpus for the 30 Big Five facets. 2) Train a contrastive Sparse AutoEncoder to learn disentangled facet-level control vectors. 3) Inject these vectors into the LLM’s residual space; a trait-activated routing module dynamically selects which vectors to apply per context. 4) Optionally combine with persona prompts. 5) Evaluate against Contrastive Activation Addition (CAA) and prompt-only baselines on character fidelity, consistency, and dialogue quality in contextualized/long-dialogue settings.
AI.result: The approach maintains stable persona fidelity and preserves output quality across contexts, outperforming CAA and prompt-only methods. The SAE+Prompt configuration yields the strongest overall results, indicating that contrastively trained latent directions enhance control while keeping coherence.
AI.conclusion: Contrastively learned, facet-aligned control vectors offer precise, interpretable, and modular personality steering for RPAs, mitigating prompt dilution and avoiding SFT retraining. Combining these vectors with prompts provides the best trade-off between control strength and dialogue coherence.

title: Post-Routing Arithmetic in Llama-3: Last-Token Result Writing and Rotation-Structured Digit Directions
summary:
We study three-digit addition in Meta-Llama-3-8B (base) under a one-token readout to characterize how
  arithmetic answers are finalized after cross-token routing becomes causally irrelevant.
  Causal residual patching and cumulative attention ablations localize a sharp boundary near layer~17:
  beyond it, the decoded sum is controlled almost entirely by the last input token and late-layer self-attention
  is largely dispensable.
  In this post-routing regime, digit(-sum) direction dictionaries vary with a next-higher-digit context but are
  well-related by an approximately orthogonal map inside a shared low-rank subspace (low-rank Procrustes alignment).
  Causal digit editing matches this geometry: naive cross-context transfer fails, while rotating directions through the
  learned map restores strict counterfactual edits; negative controls do not recover.

AI.tldr: They find a sharp “post‑routing” boundary (~layer 17) in Meta‑Llama‑3‑8B where the final three‑digit addition result is determined almost entirely by the last token, with late self‑attention largely unnecessary. Across higher‑digit carry contexts, digit(s)-sum directions change but live in a shared low‑rank subspace and are related by near‑orthogonal maps; using these rotations enables precise counterfactual digit edits, whereas naive transfers fail.
AI.motivation: Clarify how LLMs finalize arithmetic answers once cross‑token information flow ceases to matter, and whether late‑stage computation is token‑local and geometrically structured enough to enable reliable edits and mechanistic transfer across contexts.
AI.method: Use causal residual stream patching and cumulative attention ablations to localize layers where attention becomes dispensable; decode digit/sum directions under a one‑token readout; analyze cross‑context geometry with low‑rank Procrustes alignment; validate via causal digit editing and cross‑context transfer (with and without learned rotations), plus negative controls.
AI.result: A sharp boundary around layer 17 marks a post‑routing regime where the last input token controls the decoded sum; late self‑attention contributes little. Digit/sum direction dictionaries vary with the next‑higher‑digit (carry) context but occupy a shared low‑rank subspace and are connected by approximately orthogonal transforms. Naive cross‑context direction transfer fails; rotating via the learned map restores strict counterfactual edits, and negative controls do not.
AI.conclusion: Late‑stage arithmetic in this model is modular and token‑local: answers are consolidated from a low‑rank subspace anchored on the final token, with context‑dependent but near‑orthogonally related frames. This geometry enables principled interventions (rotational edits) and suggests broader interpretability and editing strategies, while emphasizing that attention is not the key actor in late layers for this task.

title: Rethinking Preference Alignment for Diffusion Models with Classifier-Free Guidance
summary: Aligning large-scale text-to-image diffusion models with nuanced human preferences remains challenging. While direct preference optimization (DPO) is simple and effective, large-scale finetuning often shows a generalization gap. We take inspiration from test-time guidance and cast preference alignment as classifier-free guidance (CFG): a finetuned preference model acts as an external control signal during sampling. Building on this view, we propose a simple method that improves alignment without retraining the base model. To further enhance generalization, we decouple preference learning into two modules trained on positive and negative data, respectively, and form a \emph{contrastive guidance} vector at inference by subtracting their predictions (positive minus negative), scaled by a user-chosen strength and added to the base prediction at each step. This yields a sharper and controllable alignment signal. We evaluate on Stable Diffusion 1.5 and Stable Diffusion XL with Pick-a-Pic v2 and HPDv3, showing consistent quantitative and qualitative gains.

AI.tldr: They recast preference alignment for text-to-image diffusion as a sampling-time guidance problem: train two lightweight preference heads on positive and negative data and, at inference, add a contrastive guidance vector (positive minus negative, scaled) to the base model’s prediction each step. This improves alignment without retraining the base model and shows gains on SD1.5/SDXL with Pick-a-Pic v2 and HPDv3.
AI.motivation: Direct preference optimization (DPO) is simple but large-scale finetuning often fails to generalize and is costly. The authors want a controllable, generalizable, and cheap way to infuse nuanced human preferences into powerful base diffusion models without degrading them.
AI.method: Treat preference alignment as classifier-free guidance (CFG). Train two modules: one on positive-labeled data and one on negative-labeled data. At inference, compute their predictions and subtract negative from positive to form a contrastive guidance vector, scale it by a user-set weight, and add it to the base denoiser’s prediction at every diffusion step. This yields a sharper alignment signal and exposes a control knob.
AI.result: On Stable Diffusion 1.5 and SDXL, using Pick-a-Pic v2 and HPDv3 benchmarks, the approach yields consistent quantitative and qualitative gains over baselines. Improvements come without retraining the base model and allow user-controlled strength of alignment.
AI.conclusion: Preference-as-guidance with decoupled positive/negative modules provides a simple, plug-and-play, and controllable way to align diffusion outputs. It mitigates generalization gaps seen in finetuning-centric methods, preserves the base model, and appears broadly applicable; future work can extend to other modalities and analyze trade-offs in diversity and artifacts under strong guidance.

title: TurkicNLP: An NLP Toolkit for Turkic Languages
summary: Natural language processing for the Turkic language family, spoken by over 200 million people across Eurasia, remains fragmented, with most languages lacking unified tooling and resources. We present TurkicNLP, an open-source Python library providing a single, consistent NLP pipeline for Turkic languages across four script families: Latin, Cyrillic, Perso-Arabic, and Old Turkic Runic. The library covers tokenization, morphological analysis, part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing, named entity recognition, bidirectional script transliteration, cross-lingual sentence embeddings, and machine translation through one language-agnostic API. A modular multi-backend architecture integrates rule-based finite-state transducers and neural models transparently, with automatic script detection and routing between script variants. Outputs follow the CoNLL-U standard for full interoperability and extension. Code and documentation are hosted at https://github.com/turkic-nlp/turkicnlp .

AI.tldr: TurkicNLP is an open-source, language-agnostic Python library that unifies core NLP tasks and multi-script handling for Turkic languages via a modular pipeline mixing rule-based FSTs and neural models, outputting CoNLL-U for interoperability.
AI.motivation: Turkic NLP is fragmented: most languages lack consistent tools and resources, and multiple scripts (Latin, Cyrillic, Perso-Arabic, Old Turkic Runic) hinder interoperability and cross-lingual work. A unified pipeline and API are needed to standardize processing and enable research and applications.
AI.method: Build a modular, multi-backend Python library that integrates finite-state transducers and neural models under a single API. Provide automatic script detection and routing across script variants; support tokenization, morphological analysis, POS tagging, dependency parsing, NER, bidirectional transliteration, cross-lingual sentence embeddings, and MT; standardize outputs in CoNLL-U for compatibility.
AI.result: A functioning open-source library (TurkicNLP) that delivers a consistent NLP pipeline across four script families for Turkic languages, with transparent backend selection, multi-script transliteration, cross-lingual embeddings, and MT, and CoNLL-U-compliant outputs. Code and docs are publicly available on GitHub.
AI.conclusion: TurkicNLP consolidates disparate tools into one extensible framework, improving accessibility, interoperability, and future extensibility of NLP for the Turkic language family across scripts and tasks.
