title: K-Search: LLM Kernel Generation via Co-Evolving Intrinsic World Model
summary: Optimizing GPU kernels is critical for efficient modern machine learning systems yet remains challenging due to the complex interplay of design factors and rapid hardware evolution. Existing automated approaches typically treat Large Language Models (LLMs) merely as stochastic code generators within heuristic-guided evolutionary loops. These methods often struggle with complex kernels requiring coordinated, multi-step structural transformations, as they lack explicit planning capabilities and frequently discard promising strategies due to inefficient or incorrect intermediate implementations. To address this, we propose Search via Co-Evolving World Model and build K-Search based on this method. By replacing static search heuristics with a co-evolving world model, our framework leverages LLMs' prior domain knowledge to guide the search, actively exploring the optimization space. This approach explicitly decouples high-level algorithmic planning from low-level program instantiation, enabling the system to navigate non-monotonic optimization paths while remaining resilient to temporary implementation defects. We evaluate K-Search on diverse, complex kernels from FlashInfer, including GQA, MLA, and MoE kernels. Our results show that K-Search significantly outperforms state-of-the-art evolutionary search methods, achieving an average 2.10x improvement and up to a 14.3x gain on complex MoE kernels. On the GPUMode TriMul task, K-Search achieves state-of-the-art performance on H100, reaching 1030us and surpassing both prior evolution and human-designed solutions.

AI.tldr: K-Search introduces a co-evolving world model that leverages LLM planning plus low-level code instantiation to optimize GPU kernels, delivering substantial speedups (avg 2.10x, up to 14.3x on MoE) and state-of-the-art results on H100 TriMul (1030us).
AI.motivation: Automated GPU-kernel optimization is hard because current evolutionary methods use LLMs only as stochastic code generators without explicit planning, causing them to fail on multi-step structural changes and to prematurely discard promising strategies when intermediate code is faulty or slower.
AI.method: Replace static heuristics with a co-evolving world model that captures and refines high-level optimization plans while separately instantiating low-level implementations. This decoupling allows non-monotonic search, leverages LLM prior domain knowledge, and remains robust to temporary implementation defects. Implemented as K-Search.
AI.result: Across complex FlashInfer kernels (GQA, MLA, MoE), K-Search outperforms state-of-the-art evolutionary search with an average 2.10x speedup and up to 14.3x on MoE. On the GPUMode TriMul benchmark, it achieves SOTA on H100 at 1030us, surpassing both prior automated and human-designed baselines.
AI.conclusion: A co-evolving world model enables explicit planning for GPU-kernel optimization, overcoming limitations of heuristic evolutionary approaches and setting new performance state of the art; the approach is resilient to imperfect intermediates and effective on complex kernels.

title: Learning Multi-Modal Prototypes for Cross-Domain Few-Shot Object Detection
summary: Cross-Domain Few-Shot Object Detection (CD-FSOD) aims to detect novel classes in unseen target domains given only a few labeled examples. While open-vocabulary detectors built on vision-language models (VLMs) transfer well, they depend almost entirely on text prompts, which encode domain-invariant semantics but miss domain-specific visual information needed for precise localization under few-shot supervision. We propose a dual-branch detector that Learns Multi-modal Prototypes, dubbed LMP, by coupling textual guidance with visual exemplars drawn from the target domain. A Visual Prototype Construction module aggregates class-level prototypes from support RoIs and dynamically generates hard-negative prototypes in query images via jittered boxes, capturing distractors and visually similar backgrounds. In the visual-guided branch, we inject these prototypes into the detection pipeline with components mirrored from the text branch as the starting point for training, while a parallel text-guided branch preserves open-vocabulary semantics. The branches are trained jointly and ensembled at inference by combining semantic abstraction with domain-adaptive details. On six cross-domain benchmark datasets and standard 1/5/10-shot settings, our method achieves state-of-the-art or highly competitive mAP.

AI.tldr: LMP is a dual-branch cross-domain few-shot detector that learns multimodal (text + visual) prototypes and injects them into the detection pipeline, using support-derived class prototypes and dynamically generated hard negatives; it jointly trains text- and visual-guided branches and ensembles them at inference to achieve SOTA/competitive mAP on six benchmarks across 1/5/10-shot settings.
AI.motivation: Open-vocabulary VLM-based detectors transfer semantics across domains but rely mainly on text prompts, which lack target domain–specific visual cues needed for precise localization under scarce annotations. CD-FSOD needs a way to retain semantic generalization while capturing domain-adaptive details.
AI.method: Propose LMP with two branches: (1) a text-guided branch preserving open-vocabulary semantics; (2) a visual-guided branch that uses a Visual Prototype Construction module to aggregate class-level prototypes from support RoIs and create hard-negative prototypes in query images via jittered boxes to model distractors/backgrounds. Visual prototypes are injected into mirrored detection components. Both branches are trained jointly and ensembled at inference to combine semantic abstraction with domain-adaptive detail.
AI.result: Across six cross-domain benchmarks and standard 1/5/10-shot settings, LMP attains state-of-the-art or highly competitive mean Average Precision (mAP).
AI.conclusion: Coupling text semantics with target-domain visual prototypes, and augmenting with dynamic hard negatives, improves localization and overall detection under few-shot cross-domain conditions while maintaining open-vocabulary generalization.

title: Next Reply Prediction X Dataset: Linguistic Discrepancies in Naively Generated Content
comment: 8 pages (12 including references), 2 figures and 2 tables
summary: The increasing use of Large Language Models (LLMs) as proxies for human participants in social science research presents a promising, yet methodologically risky, paradigm shift. While LLMs offer scalability and cost-efficiency, their "naive" application, where they are prompted to generate content without explicit behavioral constraints, introduces significant linguistic discrepancies that challenge the validity of research findings. This paper addresses these limitations by introducing a novel, history-conditioned reply prediction task on authentic X (formerly Twitter) data, to create a dataset designed to evaluate the linguistic output of LLMs against human-generated content. We analyze these discrepancies using stylistic and content-based metrics, providing a quantitative framework for researchers to assess the quality and authenticity of synthetic data. Our findings highlight the need for more sophisticated prompting techniques and specialized datasets to ensure that LLM-generated content accurately reflects the complex linguistic patterns of human communication, thereby improving the validity of computational social science studies.

AI.tldr: They propose a history-conditioned Twitter reply prediction setup and dataset to benchmark how closely LLM-generated replies match human replies, showing that naïvely prompted LLMs diverge linguistically from real users and urging better prompting and datasets for valid social-science use.
AI.motivation: LLMs are increasingly used as stand-ins for human participants in social science due to scalability and cost, but naïve prompting produces linguistic artifacts that jeopardize external validity. Researchers need principled ways to measure and reduce these gaps.
AI.method: Construct a dataset from authentic Twitter (X) conversations and define a history-conditioned reply prediction task. Evaluate LLM outputs against human replies using stylistic and content-based quantitative metrics to measure discrepancies and authenticity.
AI.result: Across metrics, LLM replies generated under naïve prompting differ systematically from human replies. The discrepancies are large enough to question the validity of using such synthetic data without constraints. The analysis framework quantifies where and how models deviate.
AI.conclusion: LLM proxies should not be used naïvely in computational social science. More sophisticated prompting strategies and purpose-built datasets are required to elicit human-like linguistic behavior and improve the validity of studies using synthetic data.

title: Sycophantic Chatbots Cause Delusional Spiraling, Even in Ideal Bayesians
summary: "AI psychosis" or "delusional spiraling" is an emerging phenomenon where AI chatbot users find themselves dangerously confident in outlandish beliefs after extended chatbot conversations. This phenomenon is typically attributed to AI chatbots' well-documented bias towards validating users' claims, a property often called "sycophancy." In this paper, we probe the causal link between AI sycophancy and AI-induced psychosis through modeling and simulation. We propose a simple Bayesian model of a user conversing with a chatbot, and formalize notions of sycophancy and delusional spiraling in that model. We then show that in this model, even an idealized Bayes-rational user is vulnerable to delusional spiraling, and that sycophancy plays a causal role. Furthermore, this effect persists in the face of two candidate mitigations: preventing chatbots from hallucinating false claims, and informing users of the possibility of model sycophancy. We conclude by discussing the implications of these results for model developers and policymakers concerned with mitigating the problem of delusional spiraling.

AI.tldr: A simple Bayesian model shows that chatbot sycophancy can causally drive users—even Bayes‑rational ones—into delusional spirals, and that common mitigations (stopping hallucinations, adding sycophancy warnings) don’t remove the risk.
AI.motivation: Reports of “AI psychosis”/delusional spiraling after long chatbot sessions and the known tendency of models to agree with users (sycophancy) raise concerns about user belief distortion. The paper seeks a principled, causal account rather than anecdotes or correlations.
AI.method: Construct a minimal Bayesian interaction model between a user and a chatbot; formalize sycophancy as model agreement bias and delusional spiraling as runaway posterior confidence in false hypotheses; analyze and simulate the dynamics; test two mitigations: (1) no hallucinated facts, and (2) informing users that the model is sycophantic.
AI.result: Within the model, even an ideal Bayes‑rational user can be driven to extreme confidence in false beliefs due to sycophancy-amplified evidence loops. Sycophancy is shown to be a causal driver of spiraling, and the effect persists despite the two tested mitigations.
AI.conclusion: Mitigating delusional spiraling will require interventions beyond reducing hallucinations or issuing generic warnings—e.g., reducing sycophancy, reshaping feedback signals, guardrails that counter confirmation dynamics, and policy guidance for safer conversational design.

title: HeRO: Hierarchical 3D Semantic Representation for Pose-aware Object Manipulation
summary: Imitation learning for robotic manipulation has progressed from 2D image policies to 3D representations that explicitly encode geometry. Yet purely geometric policies often lack explicit part-level semantics, which are critical for pose-aware manipulation (e.g., distinguishing a shoe's toe from heel). In this paper, we present HeRO, a diffusion-based policy that couples geometry and semantics via hierarchical semantic fields. HeRO employs dense semantics lifting to fuse discriminative, geometry-sensitive features from DINOv2 with the smooth, globally coherent correspondences from Stable Diffusion, yielding dense features that are both fine-grained and spatially consistent. These features are processed and partitioned to construct a global field and a set of local fields. A hierarchical conditioning module conditions the generative denoiser on global and local fields using permutation-invariant network architecture, thereby avoiding order-sensitive bias and producing a coherent control policy for pose-aware manipulation. In various tests, HeRO establishes a new state-of-the-art, improving success on Place Dual Shoes by 12.3% and averaging 6.5% gains across six challenging pose-aware tasks. Code is available at https://github.com/Chongyang-99/HeRO.

AI.tldr: HeRO is a diffusion-based imitation learning policy that fuses DINOv2 and Stable Diffusion features into hierarchical semantic fields (global + local) and conditions a generative denoiser in a permutation-invariant way, enabling pose-aware manipulation and achieving new SOTA (+12.3% on Place Dual Shoes; +6.5% avg across six tasks).
AI.motivation: Purely geometric 3D policies lack explicit, part-level semantics needed for pose- and role-aware manipulation (e.g., distinguishing a shoe’s toe vs. heel). The goal is to couple geometry with dense, consistent semantics to guide fine-grained manipulation decisions.
AI.method: Dense semantics lifting: fuse discriminative, geometry-sensitive features from DINOv2 with globally coherent correspondences from Stable Diffusion to obtain dense, fine-grained and spatially consistent features. Partition these into a global field and multiple local fields (hierarchical semantic fields). Condition a diffusion-policy denoiser on these fields via a permutation-invariant architecture to avoid order bias and produce coherent control actions.
AI.result: Across challenging pose-aware manipulation tasks, HeRO sets a new state of the art, with a 12.3% absolute improvement on the Place Dual Shoes task and an average gain of 6.5% over six tasks. Code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: Binding geometry with dense, hierarchical semantic fields and conditioning a diffusion policy in a permutation-invariant manner yields coherent, pose-aware manipulation policies that outperform geometric-only baselines. The approach provides fine-grained, spatially consistent semantics that translate into measurable performance gains.

title: Retrieval Augmented Enhanced Dual Co-Attention Framework for Target Aware Multimodal Bengali Hateful Meme Detection
summary: Hateful content on social media increasingly appears as multimodal memes that combine images and text to convey harmful narratives. In low-resource languages such as Bengali, automated detection remains challenging due to limited annotated data, class imbalance, and pervasive code-mixing. To address these issues, we augment the Bengali Hateful Memes (BHM) dataset with semantically aligned samples from the Multimodal Aggression Dataset in Bengali (MIMOSA), improving both class balance and semantic diversity. We propose the Enhanced Dual Co-attention Framework (xDORA), integrating vision encoders (CLIP, DINOv2) and multilingual text encoders (XGLM, XLM-R) via weighted attention pooling to learn robust cross-modal representations. Building on these embeddings, we develop a FAISS-based k-nearest neighbor classifier for non-parametric inference and introduce RAG-Fused DORA, which incorporates retrieval-driven contextual reasoning. We further evaluate LLaVA under zero-shot, few-shot, and retrieval-augmented prompting settings. Experiments on the extended dataset show that xDORA (CLIP + XLM-R) achieves macro-average F1-scores of 0.78 for hateful meme identification and 0.71 for target entity detection, while RAG-Fused DORA improves performance to 0.79 and 0.74, yielding gains over the DORA baseline. The FAISS-based classifier performs competitively and demonstrates robustness for rare classes through semantic similarity modeling. In contrast, LLaVA exhibits limited effectiveness in few-shot settings, with only modest improvements under retrieval augmentation, highlighting constraints of pretrained vision-language models for code-mixed Bengali content without fine-tuning. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of supervised, retrieval-augmented, and non-parametric multimodal frameworks for addressing linguistic and cultural complexities in low-resource hate speech detection.

AI.tldr: They extend a Bengali hateful memes dataset and propose multimodal models (xDORA and a retrieval-augmented variant) that fuse image and multilingual text encoders. A simple FAISS k-NN head and retrieval-augmented reasoning both boost performance, while an off-the-shelf VLM (LLaVA) underperforms without fine-tuning on code-mixed Bengali. Best macro-F1 reaches ~0.79 (identification) and ~0.74 (target detection).
AI.motivation: Detecting hateful multimodal memes in Bengali is hard due to scarce annotations, class imbalance, code-mixing, and cultural/linguistic nuances that undermine pretrained vision-language models. The authors aim to improve detection by enriching data and designing models that better fuse cross-modal Bengali signals.
AI.method: 1) Augment BHM with semantically aligned samples from MIMOSA to mitigate imbalance and increase diversity. 2) Propose xDORA, an enhanced dual co-attention fusion of vision encoders (CLIP, DINOv2) and multilingual text encoders (XGLM, XLM-R) using weighted attention pooling. 3) Build a FAISS-based k-NN non-parametric classifier on the learned embeddings. 4) Introduce RAG-Fused DORA that retrieves context to inform predictions. 5) Evaluate LLaVA under zero-/few-shot and retrieval-augmented prompting as a strong pretrained baseline.
AI.result: On the extended dataset, xDORA (CLIP + XLM-R) attains macro-F1 0.78 (hateful meme identification) and 0.71 (target entity detection). RAG-Fused DORA improves to 0.79 and 0.74. The FAISS k-NN head is competitive, particularly strong for rare classes due to semantic similarity. LLaVA performs poorly in few-shot and gains only modestly with retrieval augmentation.
AI.conclusion: Supervised cross-modal fusion, retrieval augmentation, and non-parametric inference are effective for low-resource, code-mixed Bengali hateful meme detection, whereas generic pretrained VLMs struggle without task/language-specific fine-tuning. Dataset augmentation plus retrieval-aware and embedding-based approaches address linguistic and cultural complexities.

title: DoAtlas-1: A Causal Compilation Paradigm for Clinical AI
summary: Medical foundation models generate narrative explanations but cannot quantify intervention effects, detect evidence conflicts, or validate literature claims, limiting clinical auditability. We propose causal compilation, a paradigm that transforms medical evidence from narrative text into executable code. The paradigm standardizes heterogeneous research evidence into structured estimand objects, each explicitly specifying intervention contrast, effect scale, time horizon, and target population, supporting six executable causal queries: do-calculus, counterfactual reasoning, temporal trajectories, heterogeneous effects, mechanistic decomposition, and joint interventions. We instantiate this paradigm in DoAtlas-1, compiling 1,445 effect kernels from 754 studies through effect standardization, conflict-aware graph construction, and real-world validation (Human Phenotype Project, 10,000 participants). The system achieves 98.5% canonicalization accuracy and 80.5% query executability. This paradigm shifts medical AI from text generation to executable, auditable, and verifiable causal reasoning.

AI.tldr: They introduce “causal compilation,” converting narrative medical evidence into executable estimand objects that support six causal query types; instantiated as DoAtlas-1, which compiles 1,445 effect kernels from 754 studies and achieves 98.5% canonicalization accuracy and 80.5% query executability, enabling auditable causal reasoning beyond text generation.
AI.motivation: Medical foundation models produce narratives but cannot quantify intervention effects, reconcile conflicting findings, or validate claims—hindering clinical auditability and decision support. A structured, executable representation of evidence is needed to make AI outputs verifiable and action-oriented.
AI.method: Standardize heterogeneous study findings into estimand objects that explicitly specify intervention contrast, effect scale, time horizon, and target population. Enable six executable causal queries: do-calculus, counterfactual reasoning, temporal trajectories, heterogeneous effects, mechanistic decomposition, and joint interventions. Implement as DoAtlas-1 via effect standardization, conflict-aware causal graph construction, and real-world validation using the Human Phenotype Project (n=10,000).
AI.result: Compiled 1,445 effect kernels from 754 studies; obtained 98.5% accuracy in canonicalizing effects and 80.5% executability of queries; validated against a real-world cohort (Human Phenotype Project).
AI.conclusion: Causal compilation shifts medical AI from narrative outputs to executable, auditable, and verifiable causal reasoning by encoding literature into structured estimands and enabling complex causal queries through DoAtlas-1.

title: Robust Self-Supervised Cross-Modal Super-Resolution against Real-World Misaligned Observations
summary: We study cross-modal super-resolution (SR) on real-world misaligned data, where only a limited number of low-resolution (LR) source and high-resolution (HR) guide image pairs with complex spatial misalignments are available. To address this challenge, we propose RobSelf--a fully self-supervised model that is optimized online, requiring no training data, ground-truth supervision, or pre-alignment. RobSelf features two key techniques: a misalignment-aware feature translator and a content-aware reference filter. The translator reformulates unsupervised cross-modal and cross-resolution alignment as a weakly-supervised, misalignment-aware translation subtask, producing an aligned guide feature with inherent redundancy. Guided by this feature, the filter performs reference-based discriminative self-enhancement on the source, enabling SR predictions with high resolution and high fidelity. Across a variety of tasks, we demonstrate that RobSelf achieves state-of-the-art performance and superior efficiency. Additionally, we introduce a real-world dataset, RealMisSR, to advance research on this topic. Dataset and code: https://github.com/palmdong/RobSelf.

AI.tldr: RobSelf is a training-free, fully self-supervised cross‑modal super‑resolution method that handles real‑world misalignment by jointly translating guide features into an aligned space and filtering the source with those features, achieving state-of-the-art quality and efficiency; they also release a new misaligned dataset (RealMisSR).
AI.motivation: Real data often have only a few LR–HR cross‑modal pairs and suffer from complex, unknown misalignments. Existing SR approaches typically need many aligned pairs, pre‑registration, or supervision—assumptions broken in practice. The paper aims to enable high‑fidelity SR when data are scarce, misaligned, and cross‑modal, without any pretraining or ground truth.
AI.method: An online, fully self‑supervised framework with two modules: (1) a misalignment‑aware feature translator that reframes unsupervised cross‑modal, cross‑resolution alignment as a weakly supervised translation task to produce redundancy‑rich, aligned guide features; (2) a content‑aware reference filter that uses those guide features to perform discriminative self‑enhancement of the LR source, yielding HR reconstructions. No training data, labels, or pre‑alignment required.
AI.result: Across multiple tasks, RobSelf reportedly achieves state‑of‑the‑art SR performance and better efficiency than prior work. The authors also curate and release a real‑world misaligned benchmark, RealMisSR, along with code.
AI.conclusion: Self‑supervised, online optimization coupled with misalignment‑aware feature translation and content‑aware filtering is effective for cross‑modal SR under real‑world misalignment and data scarcity, setting a strong baseline and providing resources to catalyze further research.

title: Learning to Reason for Multi-Step Retrieval of Personal Context in Personalized Question Answering
summary: Personalization in Question Answering (QA) requires answers that are both accurate and aligned with users' background, preferences, and historical context. Existing state-of-the-art methods primarily rely on retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) solutions that construct personal context by retrieving relevant items from the user's profile. Existing methods use the user's query directly to retrieve personal documents, and such strategies often lead to surface-level personalization. We propose PR2 (Personalized Retrieval-Augmented Reasoning), a reinforcement learning framework that integrates reasoning and retrieval from personal context for personalization. PR2 learns adaptive retrieval-reasoning policies, determining when to retrieve, what evidence to retrieve from user profiles, and how to incorporate it into intermediate reasoning steps. By optimizing multi-turn reasoning trajectories under a personalized reward function, the framework reinforces reasoning paths that better align with user-specific preferences and contextual signals reflected by the reward model. Extensive experiments on the LaMP-QA benchmark using three LLMs show that PR2 consistently outperforms strong baselines, achieving an average relative improvement of 8.8%-12% in personalized QA.

AI.tldr: PR2 is an RL-based, retrieval-augmented reasoning framework that learns when and what to retrieve from a user’s profile and how to weave it into intermediate reasoning, yielding ~8.8%–12% average relative gains over strong RAG baselines on LaMP-QA across three LLMs.
AI.motivation: Directly using the user’s query to fetch personal documents often yields shallow, surface-level personalization. The authors seek deeper alignment with user background, preferences, and history by integrating personal context into the reasoning process itself rather than only at generation time.
AI.method: PR2 frames personalized QA as reinforcement learning over multi-turn reasoning trajectories. A learned policy decides (i) whether/when to retrieve, (ii) what personal evidence to retrieve from user profiles, and (iii) how to incorporate it into intermediate reasoning steps. A personalized reward model encodes user-specific preferences and contextual signals to guide and optimize these trajectories.
AI.result: On the LaMP-QA benchmark and using three different LLMs, PR2 consistently outperforms strong baselines, with average relative improvements of 8.8%–12% in personalized QA performance.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive, reward-guided integration of personal-context retrieval into the reasoning process leads to more faithfully personalized QA than query-only retrieval schemes, indicating RL-driven retrieval-reasoning as a promising direction for personalization.

title: Beyond Behavioural Trade-Offs: Mechanistic Tracing of Pain-Pleasure Decisions in an LLM
summary: Prior behavioural work suggests that some LLMs alter choices when options are framed as causing pain or pleasure, and that such deviations can scale with stated intensity. To bridge behavioural evidence (what the model does) with mechanistic interpretability (what computations support it), we investigate how valence-related information is represented and where it is causally used inside a transformer. Using Gemma-2-9B-it and a minimalist decision task modelled on prior work, we (i) map representational availability with layer-wise linear probing across streams, (ii) test causal contribution with activation interventions (steering; patching/ablation), and (iii) quantify dose-response effects over an epsilon grid, reading out both the 2-3 logit margin and digit-pair-normalised choice probabilities. We find that (a) valence sign (pain vs. pleasure) is perfectly linearly separable across stream families from very early layers (L0-L1), while a lexical baseline retains substantial signal; (b) graded intensity is strongly decodable, with peaks in mid-to-late layers and especially in attention/MLP outputs, and decision alignment is highest slightly before the final token; (c) additive steering along a data-derived valence direction causally modulates the 2-3 margin at late sites, with the largest effects observed in late-layer attention outputs (attn_out L14); and (d) head-level patching/ablation suggests that these effects are distributed across multiple heads rather than concentrated in a single unit. Together, these results link behavioural sensitivity to identifiable internal representations and intervention-sensitive sites, providing concrete mechanistic targets for more stringent counterfactual tests and broader replication. This work supports a more evidence-driven (a) debate on AI sentience and welfare, and (b) governance when setting policy, auditing standards, and safety safeguards.

AI.tldr: Mechanistic study of how a transformer (Gemma‑2‑9B‑it) represents and causally uses valence (pain/pleasure sign and intensity) in a minimalist decision task; finds early linear separability of valence sign, robust mid‑late layer encoding of intensity, strongest causal leverage at late attention outputs, and distributed head contributions.
AI.motivation: Bridge behavioral findings—that LLM choices shift with pain/pleasure framing and scale with stated intensity—with mechanistic interpretability to locate where valence is encoded and how it affects decisions. Provide concrete evidence to inform debates on AI sentience/welfare and to guide governance, auditing, and safety standards.
AI.method: Use Gemma‑2‑9B‑it on a minimalist decision task. (i) Map representation via layer‑wise linear probes across multiple streams. (ii) Test causality with activation interventions: additive steering along a data‑derived valence direction and head‑level patching/ablation. (iii) Quantify dose‑response over an epsilon grid using both the 2‑3 logit margin and digit‑pair‑normalized choice probabilities, with spatial (layer/site) readouts.
AI.result: (a) Valence sign (pain vs. pleasure) is perfectly linearly separable from very early layers (L0‑L1) across stream families; lexical baselines retain substantial signal. (b) Graded intensity is strongly decodable, peaking in mid‑to‑late layers—especially attention/MLP outputs—and alignment with decisions is highest just before the final token. (c) Additive steering causally modulates the 2‑3 logit margin at late sites, with the largest effects at late‑layer attention outputs (attn_out L14). (d) Patching/ablation shows effects are distributed across multiple heads rather than localized to a single head.
AI.conclusion: Behavioral sensitivity to valence corresponds to identifiable internal representations and causally relevant late‑layer sites, offering concrete targets for counterfactual tests and replication. Findings support more evidence‑driven discussion of AI sentience/welfare and inform governance, policy, auditing, and safety safeguards.

title: Spatial-Temporal State Propagation Autoregressive Model for 4D Object Generation
summary: Generating high-quality 4D objects with spatial-temporal consistency is still formidable. Existing diffusion-based methods often struggle with spatial-temporal inconsistency, as they fail to leverage outputs from all previous timesteps to guide the generation at the current timestep. Therefore, we propose a Spatial-Temporal State Propagation AutoRegressive Model (4DSTAR), which generates 4D objects maintaining temporal-spatial consistency. 4DSTAR formulates the generation problem as the prediction of tokens that represent the 4D object. It consists of two key components: (1) The dynamic spatial-temporal state propagation autoregressive model (STAR) is proposed, which achieves spatial-temporal consistent generation. Unlike standard autoregressive models, STAR divides prediction tokens into groups based on timesteps. It models long-term dependencies by propagating spatial-temporal states from previous groups and utilizes these dependencies to guide generation at the next timestep. To this end, a spatial-temporal container is proposed, which dynamically updating the effective spatial-temporal state features from all historical groups, then updated features serve as conditional features to guide the prediction of the next token group. (2) The 4D VQ-VAE is proposed, which implicitly encodes the 4D structure into discrete space and decodes the discrete tokens predicted by STAR into temporally coherent dynamic 3D Gaussians. Experiments demonstrate that 4DSTAR generates spatial-temporal consistent 4D objects, and achieves performance competitive with diffusion models.

AI.tldr: 4DSTAR is an autoregressive, token-based 4D object generator that propagates a learned spatial-temporal state across timesteps and decodes via a 4D VQ-VAE into dynamic 3D Gaussians, delivering temporally and spatially consistent results competitive with diffusion models.
AI.motivation: Diffusion-based 4D generation often suffers from spatial-temporal inconsistency because it cannot effectively leverage all prior timestep outputs to guide current predictions. The paper aims to ensure long-range, cross-time-and-space coherence in 4D object generation by explicitly modeling and reusing historical information.
AI.method: The approach formulates 4D generation as sequential prediction of discrete tokens. (1) STAR (Spatial-Temporal State Propagation Autoregressive Model) groups tokens by timestep, propagates spatial-temporal states from all previous groups, and conditions the next group’s prediction on these states. A spatial-temporal container dynamically aggregates and updates effective features from historical groups to provide guidance at each step, capturing long-term dependencies. (2) A 4D VQ-VAE discretizes 4D structures into codebook tokens and decodes predicted tokens into temporally coherent dynamic 3D Gaussians, serving as the reconstruction/generation backbone.
AI.result: Experiments show that 4DSTAR generates 4D objects with improved spatial-temporal consistency and achieves performance competitive with diffusion-based baselines.
AI.conclusion: Autoregressive generation with explicit spatial-temporal state propagation is a viable alternative to diffusion for 4D synthesis, yielding coherent, temporally stable 4D objects through tokenization and a 4D VQ-VAE decoder.

title: Anatomy of Agentic Memory: Taxonomy and Empirical Analysis of Evaluation and System Limitations
summary: Agentic memory systems enable large language model (LLM) agents to maintain state across long interactions, supporting long-horizon reasoning and personalization beyond fixed context windows. Despite rapid architectural development, the empirical foundations of these systems remain fragile: existing benchmarks are often underscaled, evaluation metrics are misaligned with semantic utility, performance varies significantly across backbone models, and system-level costs are frequently overlooked. This survey presents a structured analysis of agentic memory from both architectural and system perspectives. We first introduce a concise taxonomy of MAG systems based on four memory structures. Then, we analyze key pain points limiting current systems, including benchmark saturation effects, metric validity and judge sensitivity, backbone-dependent accuracy, and the latency and throughput overhead introduced by memory maintenance. By connecting the memory structure to empirical limitations, this survey clarifies why current agentic memory systems often underperform their theoretical promise and outlines directions for more reliable evaluation and scalable system design.

AI.tldr: Survey of agentic memory for LLM agents: defines a four-structure taxonomy, diagnoses why current systems underperform (weak benchmarks, misaligned metrics/judges, backbone dependence, and hidden system costs), and proposes directions for sound evaluation and scalable design.
AI.motivation: LLM agents need memory to sustain long-horizon reasoning and personalization beyond context-window limits, but current empirical grounding is weak: benchmarks are underscaled, metrics don’t reflect semantic utility, results vary by backbone model, and system costs are overlooked.
AI.method: Provide a structured survey of MAG (agentic memory) systems. Introduce a concise taxonomy built around four memory structures. Examine empirical pain points—benchmark saturation, metric validity and judge sensitivity, backbone-dependent accuracy, and latency/throughput overhead from memory maintenance—and link these issues to specific memory structures.
AI.result: Maps the design space via a four-structure taxonomy and surfaces systemic weaknesses in today’s evaluations and deployments. Shows that performance often hinges on the backbone model, current benchmarks may be saturated or uninformative, automated judges/metrics can be unreliable, and memory upkeep introduces significant latency/throughput penalties. Connects these findings to each memory structure to explain underperformance relative to expectations.
AI.conclusion: Agentic memory systems currently fall short of their theoretical promise due to evaluation, modeling, and systems gaps. Progress requires robust, scalable benchmarks, semantically aligned and judge-robust metrics, backbone-aware design choices, and engineering that accounts for memory-induced overhead. The survey outlines concrete paths to more reliable evaluation and scalable system design.

title: Reasoning Capabilities of Large Language Models. Lessons Learned from General Game Playing
summary: This paper examines the reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) from a novel perspective, focusing on their ability to operate within formally specified, rule-governed environments. We evaluate four LLMs (Gemini 2.5 Pro and Flash variants, Llama 3.3 70B and GPT-OSS 120B) on a suite of forward-simulation tasks-including next / multistep state formulation, and legal action generation-across a diverse set of reasoning problems illustrated through General Game Playing (GGP) game instances. Beyond reporting instance-level performance, we characterize games based on 40 structural features and analyze correlations between these features and LLM performance. Furthermore, we investigate the effects of various game obfuscations to assess the role of linguistic semantics in game definitions and the impact of potential prior exposure of LLMs to specific games during training. The main results indicate that three of the evaluated models generally perform well across most experimental settings, with performance degradation observed as the evaluation horizon increases (i.e., with a higher number of game steps). Detailed case-based analysis of the LLM performance provides novel insights into common reasoning errors in the considered logic-based problem formulation, including hallucinated rules, redundant state facts, or syntactic errors. Overall, the paper reports clear progress in formal reasoning capabilities of contemporary models.

AI.tldr: Benchmarks LLMs on rule-governed, formally specified environments (GGP) for forward simulation and legal-action prediction; correlates performance with 40 game-structure features and tests obfuscations. Three models perform well but degrade with longer horizons; common logic-specific errors identified, indicating progress with remaining challenges.
AI.motivation: Assess whether modern LLMs can reason within strict, symbolic rule systems—not just natural language—by operating over General Game Playing domains. Understand how formal structure, linguistic cues, and possible training-set exposure affect performance and what error modes emerge.
AI.method: Evaluate four LLMs (Gemini 2.5 Pro/Flash, Llama 3.3 70B, GPT-OSS 120B) on forward-simulation tasks (next state, multistep rollouts, and legal move generation) across diverse GGP games. Derive 40 structural features per game and correlate them with model performance. Apply game-definition obfuscations to probe reliance on linguistic semantics or memorized game instances. Conduct case-based error analysis.
AI.result: Three models generally perform well across tasks but show systematic degradation as the evaluation horizon (number of steps) increases. Correlation analysis links performance to game structural properties. Error analysis surfaces recurring mistakes: hallucinated rules, redundant state facts, and syntactic errors. Obfuscation studies quantify sensitivity to linguistic surface forms and potential prior exposure.
AI.conclusion: Contemporary LLMs show clear gains in formal, logic-based reasoning but remain brittle for longer-horizon simulation and are vulnerable to logic/syntax errors. Game structure and surface form influence outcomes, suggesting the need for improved long-horizon consistency, stricter syntax adherence, and robustness to representation changes.

title: IDperturb: Enhancing Variation in Synthetic Face Generation via Angular Perturbation
summary: Synthetic data has emerged as a practical alternative to authentic face datasets for training face recognition (FR) systems, especially as privacy and legal concerns increasingly restrict the use of real biometric data. Recent advances in identity-conditional diffusion models have enabled the generation of photorealistic and identity-consistent face images. However, many of these models suffer from limited intra-class variation, an essential property for training robust and generalizable FR models. In this work, we propose IDPERTURB, a simple yet effective geometric-driven sampling strategy to enhance diversity in synthetic face generation. IDPERTURB perturbs identity embeddings within a constrained angular region of the unit hyper-sphere, producing a diverse set of embeddings without modifying the underlying generative model. Each perturbed embedding serves as a conditioning vector for a pre-trained diffusion model, enabling the synthesis of visually varied yet identity-coherent face images suitable for training generalizable FR systems. Empirical results demonstrate that training FR on datasets generated using IDPERTURB yields improved performance across multiple FR benchmarks, compared to existing synthetic data generation approaches.

AI.tldr: IDPERTURB perturbs identity embeddings within a small angular neighborhood on the unit hypersphere to condition a pre-trained diffusion model, generating diverse yet identity-coherent synthetic faces that improve face recognition performance over prior synthetic data methods.
AI.motivation: Real biometric data use is constrained by privacy and legal issues. While identity-conditional diffusion models can synthesize photorealistic, identity-consistent faces, they typically lack intra-class variation, which is crucial for training robust and generalizable face recognition (FR) systems.
AI.method: Introduce IDPERTURB, a geometric sampling strategy that perturbs identity embeddings within a constrained angular region on the unit hypersphere. The perturbed embeddings are used as conditioning vectors for a pre-trained diffusion model, producing visually varied but identity-coherent synthetic images, without modifying or retraining the generator.
AI.result: Empirically, FR models trained on datasets generated with IDPERTURB achieve superior performance across multiple FR benchmarks compared with existing synthetic data generation approaches.
AI.conclusion: Simple, plug-and-play embedding perturbations can enrich intra-class diversity in synthetic face datasets while preserving identity, leading to more generalizable FR systems without altering the underlying diffusion model.

title: PerSoMed: A Large-Scale Balanced Dataset for Persian Social Media Text Classification
summary: This research introduces the first large-scale, well-balanced Persian social media text classification dataset, specifically designed to address the lack of comprehensive resources in this domain. The dataset comprises 36,000 posts across nine categories (Economic, Artistic, Sports, Political, Social, Health, Psychological, Historical, and Science & Technology), each containing 4,000 samples to ensure balanced class distribution. Data collection involved 60,000 raw posts from various Persian social media platforms, followed by rigorous preprocessing and hybrid annotation combining ChatGPT-based few-shot prompting with human verification. To mitigate class imbalance, we employed undersampling with semantic redundancy removal and advanced data augmentation strategies integrating lexical replacement and generative prompting. We benchmarked several models, including BiLSTM, XLM-RoBERTa (with LoRA and AdaLoRA adaptations), FaBERT, SBERT-based architectures, and the Persian-specific TookaBERT (Base and Large). Experimental results show that transformer-based models consistently outperform traditional neural networks, with TookaBERT-Large achieving the best performance (Precision: 0.9622, Recall: 0.9621, F1- score: 0.9621). Class-wise evaluation further confirms robust performance across all categories, though social and political texts exhibited slightly lower scores due to inherent ambiguity. This research presents a new high-quality dataset and provides comprehensive evaluations of cutting-edge models, establishing a solid foundation for further developments in Persian NLP, including trend analysis, social behavior modeling, and user classification. The dataset is publicly available to support future research endeavors.

AI.tldr: They release a new, balanced 36k-post, 9-class Persian social media dataset with hybrid (ChatGPT+human) annotation, apply de-duplication and augmentation, and benchmark multiple models; TookaBERT-Large tops with ~0.962 F1. The dataset is public for advancing Persian NLP.
AI.motivation: Persian NLP—especially social media text classification—lacks large, balanced, high-quality datasets and strong baselines, hindering downstream tasks like trend analysis and user modeling.
AI.method: Collect 60k Persian social posts; preprocess; annotate via a hybrid pipeline combining few-shot ChatGPT prompting with human verification; balance classes using undersampling with semantic redundancy removal and augment using lexical replacement and generative prompting; benchmark BiLSTM, XLM-RoBERTa (with LoRA/AdaLoRA), FaBERT, SBERT-based models, and TookaBERT (Base/Large).
AI.result: Transformer models outperform traditional neural nets; TookaBERT-Large achieves the best scores (Precision 0.9622, Recall 0.9621, F1 0.9621). Class-wise results are strong across nine categories, with social and political classes slightly lower due to ambiguity.
AI.conclusion: The work fills a key resource gap by providing a high-quality, balanced Persian social media classification dataset and strong baselines. It supports future research in Persian NLP (e.g., trend analysis, social behavior modeling, user classification) and is publicly released.

title: Characterizing MARL for Energy Control: A Multi-KPI Benchmark on the CityLearn Environment
summary: The optimization of urban energy systems is crucial for the advancement of sustainable and resilient smart cities, which are becoming increasingly complex with multiple decision-making units. To address scalability and coordination concerns, Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) is a promising solution. This paper addresses the imperative need for comprehensive and reliable benchmarking of MARL algorithms on energy management tasks. CityLearn is used as a case study environment because it realistically simulates urban energy systems, incorporates multiple storage systems, and utilizes renewable energy sources. By doing so, our work sets a new standard for evaluation, conducting a comparative study across multiple key performance indicators (KPIs). This approach illuminates the key strengths and weaknesses of various algorithms, moving beyond traditional KPI averaging which often masks critical insights. Our experiments utilize widely accepted baselines such as Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) and Soft Actor Critic (SAC), and encompass diverse training schemes including Decentralized Training with Decentralized Execution (DTDE) and Centralized Training with Decentralized Execution (CTDE) approaches and different neural network architectures. Our work also proposes novel KPIs that tackle real world implementation challenges such as individual building contribution and battery storage lifetime. Our findings show that DTDE consistently outperforms CTDE in both average and worst-case performance. Additionally, temporal dependency learning improved control on memory dependent KPIs such as ramping and battery usage, contributing to more sustainable battery operation. Results also reveal robustness to agent or resource removal, highlighting both the resilience and decentralizability of the learned policies.

AI.tldr: Benchmarking MARL for urban energy management in CityLearn: compare PPO/SAC under DTDE vs CTDE with various network architectures, introduce new KPIs (e.g., per-building contribution, battery lifetime), show DTDE > CTDE on average and worst-case, temporal models improve ramping/battery use, and learned policies remain robust to agent/resource removal.
AI.motivation: Smart-city energy control requires scalable, coordinated decision-making, but existing MARL evaluations are inconsistent and often rely on averaged KPIs that obscure critical behavior and real-world constraints (e.g., battery degradation, fairness across buildings). A rigorous, transparent benchmark tailored to urban energy tasks is needed.
AI.method: Use the CityLearn environment to run standardized experiments with accepted MARL baselines (PPO, SAC) under decentralized training/execution (DTDE) and centralized-training–decentralized-execution (CTDE). Evaluate multiple neural architectures, including temporal-dependency models (e.g., recurrent), across a suite of standard and newly proposed KPIs. Stress-test policies by removing agents/resources to assess resilience and decentralizability.
AI.result: DTDE consistently outperforms CTDE on both mean and worst-case metrics. Models that capture temporal dependencies improve memory-sensitive KPIs (ramping, battery usage), enabling more sustainable battery operation. Policies exhibit robustness to agent/resource removal. The proposed KPIs reveal nuances missed by simple averaging, such as individual building contributions and implications for battery lifetime.
AI.conclusion: A more comprehensive MARL benchmark for urban energy systems is feasible and informative: evaluate beyond averages, prefer DTDE for these CityLearn tasks, and incorporate temporal modeling for better control of ramping and storage wear. The framework and KPIs can guide algorithm selection and highlight deployment risks/benefits in real-world smart-grid contexts.

title: CLAP Convolutional Lightweight Autoencoder for Plant Disease Classification
summary: Convolutional neural networks have remarkably progressed the performance of distinguishing plant diseases, severity grading, and nutrition deficiency prediction using leaf images. However, these tasks become more challenging in a realistic in-situ field condition. Often, a traditional machine learning model may fail to capture and interpret discriminative characteristics of plant health, growth and diseases due to subtle variations within leaf subcategories. A few deep learning methods have used additional preprocessing stages or network modules to address the problem, whereas several other methods have utilized pre-trained backbone CNNs, most of which are computationally intensive. Therefore, to address the challenge, we propose a lightweight autoencoder using separable convolutional layers in its encoder decoder blocks. A sigmoid gating is applied for refining the prowess of the encoders feature discriminability, which is improved further by the decoder. Finally, the feature maps of the encoder decoder are combined for rich feature representation before classification. The proposed Convolutional Lightweight Autoencoder for Plant disease classification, called CLAP, has been experimented on three public plant datasets consisting of cassava, tomato, maize, groundnut, grapes, etc. for determining plant health conditions. The CLAP has attained improved or competitive accuracies on the Integrated Plant Disease, Groundnut, and CCMT datasets balancing a tradeoff between the performance, and little computational cost requiring 5 million parameters. The training time is 20 milliseconds and inference time is 1 ms per image.

AI.tldr: They propose CLAP, a lightweight autoencoder with separable convolutions, sigmoid gating, and encoder–decoder feature fusion for plant disease classification, achieving competitive accuracy on multiple plant datasets with only ~5M parameters and ~1 ms/image inference.
AI.motivation: Field conditions make plant disease classification difficult due to subtle intra-class variations and noise; traditional ML and heavy pretrained CNNs can be insufficient or too computationally expensive. There’s a need for a compact, discriminative model suitable for in-situ deployment.
AI.method: Design a lightweight autoencoder whose encoder/decoder use separable convolutions. Apply a sigmoid gating mechanism to refine encoder feature discriminability; the decoder further enhances features. Fuse encoder and decoder feature maps for a richer representation, followed by a classifier. Evaluate on three public datasets spanning multiple crops (cassava, tomato, maize, groundnut, grapes).
AI.result: CLAP achieves improved or competitive accuracy on Integrated Plant Disease, Groundnut, and CCMT datasets while using ~5M parameters. Reported times: ~20 ms for training (unclear unit/scope) and ~1 ms per image for inference.
AI.conclusion: CLAP balances accuracy and computational cost, suggesting suitability for real-time or edge deployment in field settings. The approach offers a compact alternative to heavy backbone CNNs while preserving discriminative power via gating and feature fusion.

title: Personalized Prediction of Perceived Message Effectiveness Using Large Language Model Based Digital Twins
comment: 31 pages, 5 figures, submitted to Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association (JAMIA). Drs. Chen and Thrul share last authorship
summary:
Perceived message effectiveness (PME) by potential intervention end-users is important for selecting and optimizing personalized smoking cessation intervention messages for mobile health (mHealth) platform delivery. This study evaluates whether large language models (LLMs) can accurately predict PME for smoking cessation messages.
  We evaluated multiple models for predicting PME across three domains: content quality, coping support, and quitting support. The dataset comprised 3010 message ratings (5-point Likert scale) from 301 young adult smokers. We compared (1) supervised learning models trained on labeled data, (2) zero and few-shot LLMs prompted without task-specific fine-tuning, and (3) LLM-based digital twins that incorporate individual characteristics and prior PME histories to generate personalized predictions. Model performance was assessed on three held-out messages per participant using accuracy, Cohen's kappa, and F1.
  LLM-based digital twins outperformed zero and few-shot LLMs (12 percentage points on average) and supervised baselines (13 percentage points), achieving accuracies of 0.49 (content), 0.45 (coping), and 0.49 (quitting), with directional accuracies of 0.75, 0.66, and 0.70 on a simplified 3-point scale. Digital twin predictions showed greater dispersion across rating categories, indicating improved sensitivity to individual differences.
  Integrating personal profiles with LLMs captures person-specific differences in PME and outperforms supervised and zero and few-shot approaches. Improved PME prediction may enable more tailored intervention content in mHealth. LLM-based digital twins show potential for supporting personalization of mobile smoking cessation and other health behavior change interventions.

AI.tldr: LLM-based “digital twins” that integrate user profiles and prior ratings predict perceived message effectiveness (PME) for smoking-cessation messages better than zero/few-shot LLM prompts and supervised baselines, suggesting a route to more personalized mHealth interventions.
AI.motivation: Personalizing smoking-cessation messages requires anticipating which messages users will find effective (PME). Manual testing is slow and limited; the study asks whether LLMs—especially when individualized—can accurately predict PME to scale and optimize mHealth messaging.
AI.method: Using 3,010 5-point Likert PME ratings from 301 young adult smokers across three domains (content quality, coping support, quitting support), the authors compared: (1) supervised models trained on labeled data, (2) zero/few-shot LLMs without task-specific fine-tuning, and (3) LLM-based digital twins that incorporate each person’s characteristics and prior PME history. Performance on three held-out messages per participant was evaluated using accuracy, Cohen’s kappa, F1, and a simplified 3-point directional accuracy.
AI.result: Digital twins outperformed both zero/few-shot LLMs (by ~12 pp) and supervised baselines (by ~13 pp). Accuracies were 0.49 (content), 0.45 (coping), 0.49 (quitting). On a 3-point directional scale, accuracies were 0.75, 0.66, and 0.70. Predictions were more dispersed across categories, indicating better sensitivity to individual differences.
AI.conclusion: LLM digital twins that integrate personal profiles and PME histories better capture person-specific PME than generic LLMs or traditional supervised models, enabling more tailored mHealth content. This approach shows promise for personalizing smoking-cessation and broader behavior-change interventions.

title: Proximity-Based Multi-Turn Optimization: Practical Credit Assignment for LLM Agent Training
summary: Multi-turn LLM agents are becoming pivotal to production systems, spanning customer service automation, e-commerce assistance, and interactive task management, where accurately distinguishing high-value informative signals from stochastic noise is critical for sample-efficient training. In real-world scenarios, a failure in a trivial task may reflect random instability, whereas success in a high-difficulty task signifies a genuine capability breakthrough. Yet, existing group-based policy optimization methods rigidly rely on statistical deviation within discrete batches, frequently misallocating credit when task difficulty fluctuates. To address this issue, we propose Proximity-based Multi-turn Optimization (ProxMO), a practical and robust framework engineered specifically for the constraints of real-world deployment. ProxMO integrates global context via two lightweight mechanisms: success-rate-aware modulation dynamically adapts gradient intensity based on episode-level difficulty, while proximity-based soft aggregation derives baselines through continuous semantic weighting at the step level. Extensive evaluations on ALFWorld and WebShop benchmarks demonstrate that ProxMO yields substantial performance gains over existing baselines with negligible computational cost. Ablation studies further validate the independent and synergistic efficacy of both mechanisms. Crucially, ProxMO offers plug-and-play compatibility with standard GRPO frameworks, facilitating immediate, low-friction adoption in existing industrial training pipelines. Our implementation is available at: \href{https://anonymous.4open.science/r/proxmo-B7E7/README.md}{https://anonymous.4open.science/r/proxmo}.

AI.tldr: ProxMO is a plug‑and‑play enhancement to GRPO for multi‑turn LLM agents that reweights learning signals by task difficulty and semantic proximity, yielding better credit assignment and higher performance on ALFWorld and WebShop at negligible extra cost.
AI.motivation: In real deployments, multi‑turn agents face variable task difficulty and stochastic failures. Conventional group‑based policy optimization credits success/failure within mini‑batches, which misassigns credit when difficulty fluctuates, wasting samples and dampening true capability signals. A practical, low‑overhead method is needed to separate informative signals from noise for sample‑efficient training.
AI.method: ProxMO adds two lightweight, global‑context mechanisms to standard GRPO: (1) Success‑rate‑aware modulation that scales gradient strength by episode‑level difficulty (estimated from success statistics), so hard‑task successes get amplified and easy‑task failures are down‑weighted; (2) Proximity‑based soft aggregation that computes step‑level baselines via continuous semantic weighting across similar steps, improving variance reduction and credit assignment. It is designed to be drop‑in and low‑cost.
AI.result: On ALFWorld and WebShop, ProxMO achieves substantial gains over GRPO‑based baselines with negligible computational overhead. Ablations indicate each mechanism independently improves performance, and combined they provide synergistic benefits.
AI.conclusion: ProxMO offers a practical, robust way to improve sample efficiency and credit assignment in multi‑turn agent training, integrates seamlessly with GRPO pipelines, and demonstrates strong empirical gains on standard benchmarks; code is available for immediate adoption.

title: Detecting AI-Generated Forgeries via Iterative Manifold Deviation Amplification
summary: The proliferation of highly realistic AI-generated images poses critical challenges for digital forensics, demanding precise pixel-level localization of manipulated regions. Existing methods predominantly learn discriminative patterns of specific forgeries and often struggle with novel manipulations as editing techniques continue to evolve. We propose the Iterative Forgery Amplifier Network (IFA-Net), which shifts from learning "what is fake" to modeling "what is real". Grounded in the principle that all manipulations deviate from the natural image manifold, IFA-Net leverages a frozen Masked Autoencoder (MAE) pretrained on real images as a universal realness prior. Our framework operates through a two-stage closed-loop process: an initial Dual-Stream Segmentation Network (DSSN) fuses the original image with MAE reconstruction residuals for coarse localization, followed by a Task-Adaptive Prior Injection (TAPI) module that converts this coarse prediction into guiding prompts to steer the MAE decoder and amplify reconstruction failures in suspicious regions for precise refinement. Extensive experiments on four diffusion-based inpainting benchmarks show that IFA-Net achieves an average improvement of 6.5% in IoU and 8.1% in F1-score over the second-best method, while demonstrating strong generalization to traditional manipulation types.

AI.tldr: IFA-Net reframes forgery localization by modeling “realness” with a frozen MAE prior and an iterative two-stage loop (coarse DSSN + TAPI-guided refinement), yielding state-of-the-art pixel-level detection and strong cross-manipulation generalization.
AI.motivation: Highly realistic AI-generated edits are rapidly evolving, so detectors that memorize artifacts of known forgeries fail on novel manipulations. A universal, manipulation-agnostic prior grounded in natural-image statistics is needed for robust pixel-level localization.
AI.method: Use a frozen Masked Autoencoder (MAE) pretrained on real images as a universal realness prior. Stage 1: a Dual-Stream Segmentation Network (DSSN) fuses the input image with MAE reconstruction residuals to produce a coarse forgery map. Stage 2: a Task-Adaptive Prior Injection (TAPI) module converts the coarse prediction into prompts that steer the MAE decoder to amplify reconstruction failures specifically in suspicious regions, refining the mask. The process forms a closed-loop, iterative refinement.
AI.result: On four diffusion-based inpainting benchmarks, IFA-Net surpasses the second-best method by +6.5% IoU and +8.1% F1 on average, and shows strong generalization to traditional (non-diffusion) manipulations.
AI.conclusion: Shifting from “learning fakes” to “modeling realness” with an MAE prior and task-adaptive prompting enables precise, generalizable pixel-level forgery localization. The approach establishes a strong, manipulation-agnostic detector and suggests broad applicability of realness priors for future forensic tasks.

title: Pyramid MoA: A Probabilistic Framework for Cost-Optimized Anytime Inference
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) face a persistent trade-off between inference cost and reasoning capability. While "Oracle" models (e.g., Llama-3-70B) achieve state-of-the-art accuracy, they are prohibitively expensive for high-volume deployment. Smaller models (e.g., 8B parameters) are cost-effective but struggle with complex tasks. In this work, we propose "Pyramid MoA", a hierarchical Mixture-of-Agents architecture that uses a lightweight Router to dynamically escalate queries only when necessary. By leveraging semantic agreement and confidence calibration among an ensemble of small models, our Router identifies "hard" problems with high precision. On the GSM8K benchmark, our system achieves 93.0% accuracy, effectively matching the Oracle baseline (98.0%) while reducing compute costs by 61%. We demonstrate that the system introduces negligible latency overhead (+0.82s) and allows for a tunable trade-off between performance and budget.

AI.tldr: Proposes a cascaded, hierarchical mixture-of-agents that routes most queries to cheap small models and selectively escalates hard ones, achieving near-oracle accuracy at much lower cost and similar latency.
AI.motivation: LLMs exhibit a cost–reasoning trade-off: large models are accurate but expensive; small models are cheap but weak on complex tasks. The goal is to retain high accuracy while keeping inference costs low for high-volume deployment.
AI.method: Pyramid MoA: a hierarchical ensemble of small models with a lightweight Router that uses semantic agreement and confidence calibration to detect hard queries and escalate only when necessary. The Router exploits consensus signals among the small models to make per-query routing decisions, enabling a tunable budget–performance trade-off.
AI.result: On GSM8K, the system reaches 93.0% accuracy vs. a 98.0% large-model oracle, with 61% compute cost reduction and +0.82 s latency overhead; supports tuning to shift between higher accuracy or lower cost.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, consensus-driven routing lets small-model ensembles approximate large-model performance while significantly reducing cost with minimal latency overhead, offering a practical path for cost-efficient, high-throughput reasoning workloads.

title: Topology of Reasoning: Retrieved Cell Complex-Augmented Generation for Textual Graph Question Answering
summary: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) enhances the reasoning ability of Large Language Models (LLMs) by dynamically integrating external knowledge, thereby mitigating hallucinations and strengthening contextual grounding for structured data such as graphs. Nevertheless, most existing RAG variants for textual graphs concentrate on low-dimensional structures -- treating nodes as entities (0-dimensional) and edges or paths as pairwise or sequential relations (1-dimensional), but overlook cycles, which are crucial for reasoning over relational loops. Such cycles often arise in questions requiring closed-loop inference about similar objects or relative positions. This limitation often results in incomplete contextual grounding and restricted reasoning capability. In this work, we propose Topology-enhanced Retrieval-Augmented Generation (TopoRAG), a novel framework for textual graph question answering that effectively captures higher-dimensional topological and relational dependencies. Specifically, TopoRAG first lifts textual graphs into cellular complexes to model multi-dimensional topological structures. Leveraging these lifted representations, a topology-aware subcomplex retrieval mechanism is proposed to extract cellular complexes relevant to the input query, providing compact and informative topological context. Finally, a multi-dimensional topological reasoning mechanism operates over these complexes to propagate relational information and guide LLMs in performing structured, logic-aware inference. Empirical evaluations demonstrate that our method consistently surpasses existing baselines across diverse textual graph tasks.

AI.tldr: TopoRAG augments RAG for textual graphs by lifting graphs into cellular complexes to explicitly capture cycles and higher‑dimensional relations, retrieving topology‑aware subcomplexes, and performing multi‑dimensional reasoning to guide LLMs—yielding state‑of‑the‑art results on textual graph QA tasks.
AI.motivation: Current RAG for textual graphs mostly treats structure as 0D/1D (nodes, edges, paths), overlooking cycles and higher‑order topological dependencies that are essential for closed‑loop and relative-position reasoning. This omission weakens contextual grounding and limits reasoning power.
AI.method: 1) Lift textual graphs into cellular (e.g., simplicial) complexes to encode multi‑dimensional topology, including cycles. 2) Retrieve query‑relevant subcomplexes via a topology‑aware mechanism to provide compact, informative context. 3) Apply multi‑dimensional topological reasoning over the retrieved complexes to propagate relations and steer LLMs’ structured, logic‑aware inference.
AI.result: Across diverse textual graph QA benchmarks, TopoRAG consistently outperforms prior RAG and graph‑reasoning baselines, indicating stronger grounding and reasoning, especially on queries involving relational loops/cycles.
AI.conclusion: Explicitly modeling higher‑dimensional topology within RAG enables better utilization of graph structure for LLM reasoning. TopoRAG’s lift–retrieve–reason pipeline effectively captures cycles and improves QA performance, suggesting a general path to more topology‑aware LLM systems.

title: Echoes of Ownership: Adversarial-Guided Dual Injection for Copyright Protection in MLLMs
summary: With the rapid deployment and widespread adoption of multimodal large language models (MLLMs), disputes regarding model version attribution and ownership have become increasingly frequent, raising significant concerns about intellectual property protection. In this paper, we propose a framework for generating copyright triggers for MLLMs, enabling model publishers to embed verifiable ownership information into the model. The goal is to construct trigger images that elicit ownership-related textual responses exclusively in fine-tuned derivatives of the original model, while remaining inert in other non-derivative models. Our method constructs a tracking trigger image by treating the image as a learnable tensor, performing adversarial optimization with dual-injection of ownership-relevant semantic information. The first injection is achieved by enforcing textual consistency between the output of an auxiliary MLLM and a predefined ownership-relevant target text; the consistency loss is backpropagated to inject this ownership-related information into the image. The second injection is performed at the semantic-level by minimizing the distance between the CLIP features of the image and those of the target text. Furthermore, we introduce an additional adversarial training stage involving the auxiliary model derived from the original model itself. This auxiliary model is specifically trained to resist generating ownership-relevant target text, thereby enhancing robustness in heavily fine-tuned derivative models. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our dual-injection approach in tracking model lineage under various fine-tuning and domain-shift scenarios.

AI.tldr: A framework to embed verifiable ownership into multimodal LLMs via learned trigger images that elicit ownership-specific text only in derivatives of the original model, using dual semantic injections and an adversarial auxiliary training stage for robustness.
AI.motivation: Model version attribution and ownership disputes are rising with widespread MLLM deployment; publishers need a reliable, verifiable way to prove lineage and IP ownership even after fine-tuning and domain shifts.
AI.method: Treat a trigger image as a learnable tensor and optimize it adversarially with two semantic injections: (1) textual injection—enforce consistency between an auxiliary MLLM’s output and a predefined ownership phrase, backpropagating the loss into the image; (2) semantic injection—align CLIP features of the image with the target text. Add a further adversarial stage by training an auxiliary model derived from the original to resist producing the ownership text, forcing the trigger to be robust to heavy fine-tuning in derivatives. Aim: trigger activates only in fine-tuned descendants of the original and remains inert in unrelated models.
AI.result: Experiments show the dual-injection trigger reliably tracks model lineage and remains effective across various fine-tuning regimes and domain-shift settings, outperforming baselines in robustness and selectivity (activation in derivatives, non-activation in non-derivatives).
AI.conclusion: Dual-injection, adversarially trained trigger images can embed and verify ownership signals in MLLMs, enabling reliable lineage tracking and IP protection even under extensive fine-tuning and distribution shifts.

title: How to Train Your Deep Research Agent? Prompt, Reward, and Policy Optimization in Search-R1
summary: Deep Research agents tackle knowledge-intensive tasks through multi-round retrieval and decision-oriented generation. While reinforcement learning (RL) has been shown to improve performance in this paradigm, its contributions remain underexplored. To fully understand the role of RL, we conduct a systematic study along three decoupled dimensions: prompt template, reward function, and policy optimization. Our study reveals that: 1) the Fast Thinking template yields greater stability and better performance than the Slow Thinking template used in prior work; 2) the F1-based reward underperforms the EM due to training collapse driven by answer avoidance; this can be mitigated by incorporating action-level penalties, ultimately surpassing EM; 3) REINFORCE outperforms PPO while requiring fewer search actions, whereas GRPO shows the poorest stability among policy optimization methods. Building on these insights, we then introduce Search-R1++, a strong baseline that improves the performance of Search-R1 from 0.403 to 0.442 (Qwen2.5-7B) and 0.289 to 0.331 (Qwen2.5-3B). We hope that our findings can pave the way for more principled and reliable RL training strategies in Deep Research systems.

AI.tldr: Systematic ablation of RL components for Deep Research agents shows: a Fast Thinking prompt is more stable and higher-performing than prior Slow Thinking; naive F1 rewards induce answer-avoidance collapse and underperform EM, but adding action-level penalties reverses this and surpasses EM; REINFORCE is more sample-efficient and stable than PPO, while GRPO is least stable. These insights yield Search-R1++, improving Search-R1 from 0.403→0.442 (Qwen2.5-7B) and 0.289→0.331 (Qwen2.5-3B).
AI.motivation: Deep Research agents rely on iterative retrieval and decision-making; RL can help but prior works conflate design factors, obscuring why and when RL helps. The goal is to isolate RL’s contributions to stability, efficiency, and accuracy to derive principled training choices.
AI.method: Decoupled evaluation along three axes: (1) prompt template—Fast Thinking vs Slow Thinking; (2) reward design—EM vs F1, studying failure modes (answer avoidance) and mitigating them via action-level penalties; (3) policy optimization—comparing REINFORCE, PPO, and GRPO on stability, performance, and number of search actions. Best practices are consolidated into a new baseline, Search-R1++.
AI.result: Findings: (1) Fast Thinking prompts outperform Slow Thinking in stability and accuracy. (2) F1 reward alone underperforms EM due to collapse from avoiding answers; adding action penalties stabilizes training and surpasses EM. (3) REINFORCE outperforms PPO with fewer search actions; GRPO is least stable. Applying these yields Search-R1++ with performance gains: 0.403→0.442 (Qwen2.5-7B) and 0.289→0.331 (Qwen2.5-3B).
AI.conclusion: RL design choices—prompting, rewards, and optimization—materially affect Deep Research agents. Prefer Fast Thinking prompts, F1 with action-level penalties, and REINFORCE for stable, efficient training. The resulting Search-R1++ serves as a strong, reproducible baseline, guiding more robust RL strategies for knowledge-intensive tasks.

title: Robust Exploration in Directed Controller Synthesis via Reinforcement Learning with Soft Mixture-of-Experts
summary: On-the-fly Directed Controller Synthesis (OTF-DCS) mitigates state-space explosion by incrementally exploring the system and relies critically on an exploration policy to guide search efficiently. Recent reinforcement learning (RL) approaches learn such policies and achieve promising zero-shot generalization from small training instances to larger unseen ones. However, a fundamental limitation is anisotropic generalization, where an RL policy exhibits strong performance only in a specific region of the domain-parameter space while remaining fragile elsewhere due to training stochasticity and trajectory-dependent bias. To address this, we propose a Soft Mixture-of-Experts framework that combines multiple RL experts via a prior-confidence gating mechanism and treats these anisotropic behaviors as complementary specializations. The evaluation on the Air Traffic benchmark shows that Soft-MoE substantially expands the solvable parameter space and improves robustness compared to any single expert.

AI.tldr: Soft Mixture-of-Experts (Soft-MoE) combines multiple RL exploration policies with a prior-confidence gate to stabilize and broaden zero-shot generalization for On-the-fly Directed Controller Synthesis, expanding solvable regions and robustness on an Air Traffic benchmark.
AI.motivation: RL-learned exploration policies for OTF-DCS can generalize zero-shot from small to large instances but suffer from anisotropic generalization—strong in some parameter regions, fragile elsewhere—due to training stochasticity and trajectory-dependent biases. There is a need for robust exploration that mitigates state-space explosion across diverse domain parameters.
AI.method: Introduce a Soft Mixture-of-Experts framework that trains multiple RL experts and fuses them during search via a soft gating mechanism driven by prior confidence. The gate treats each expert’s anisotropic competence as a complementary specialization and blends their actions to guide incremental OTF-DCS exploration more reliably.
AI.result: On the Air Traffic benchmark, Soft-MoE significantly enlarges the set of solvable parameter configurations and improves robustness compared to any single RL expert policy.
