AI.conclusion: Aggregating specialized RL experts with a confidence-weighted soft gate effectively counters anisotropic generalization in OTF-DCS, yielding more reliable zero-shot performance and a broader solvable parameter space than single-expert approaches.

title: DUET-VLM: Dual stage Unified Efficient Token reduction for VLM Training and Inference
comment: 15 Pages, 8 figures, 15 tables, CVPR 2026; Code: https://github.com/AMD-AGI/DUET-VLM
summary: Vision-language models (VLMs) have achieved remarkable multimodal understanding and reasoning capabilities, yet remain computationally expensive due to dense visual tokenization. Existing efficiency approaches either merge redundant visual tokens or drop them progressively in language backbone, often trading accuracy for speed. In this work, we propose DUET-VLM, a versatile plug-and-play dual compression framework that consists of (a) vision-only redundancy aware compression of vision encoder's output into information-preserving tokens, followed by (b) layer-wise, salient text-guided dropping of visual tokens within the language backbone to progressively prune less informative tokens. This coordinated token management enables aggressive compression while retaining critical semantics. On LLaVA-1.5-7B, our approach maintains over 99% of baseline accuracy with 67% fewer tokens, and still retains >97% even at 89% reduction. With this dual-stage compression during training, it achieves 99.7% accuracy at 67% and 97.6% at 89%, surpassing prior SoTA visual token reduction methods across multiple benchmarks. When integrated into Video-LLaVA-7B, it even surpasses the baseline -- achieving >100% accuracy with a substantial 53.1% token reduction and retaining 97.6% accuracy under an extreme 93.4% setting. These results highlight end-to-end training with DUET-VLM, enabling robust adaptation to reduced visual (image/video) input without sacrificing accuracy, producing compact yet semantically rich representations within the same computational budget. Our code is available at https://github.com/AMD-AGI/DUET-VLM.

AI.tldr: DUET-VLM introduces a two-stage, plug-and-play token compression for vision-language models that aggressively reduces visual tokens while preserving (and sometimes improving) accuracy across image and video benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Dense visual tokenization in VLMs makes inference and training costly. Prior token-merging or progressive dropping methods typically trade accuracy for speed. The goal is to cut visual tokens drastically without sacrificing semantics or accuracy.
AI.method: A dual compression pipeline: (a) vision-only, redundancy-aware compression that converts the vision encoder’s output into a smaller set of information-preserving tokens; (b) layer-wise, salient text-guided dropping of visual tokens inside the language backbone, progressively pruning less informative tokens. The framework supports end-to-end training so the model adapts to reduced visual inputs.
AI.result: On LLaVA-1.5-7B, retains >99% baseline accuracy with 67% fewer tokens, and >97% at 89% reduction. With dual-stage compression applied during training, performance improves to 99.7% (67% reduction) and 97.6% (89% reduction), outperforming prior SoTA visual token reduction approaches. On Video-LLaVA-7B, it surpasses baseline (>100% relative accuracy) with 53.1% fewer tokens and retains 97.6% even at 93.4% reduction.
AI.conclusion: Coordinated pre-language compression plus text-guided, in-language pruning enables strong token savings with minimal or no accuracy loss, sometimes improving it. The approach is versatile, works for images and video, benefits further from end-to-end training, and is released as open-source.

title: Hyper-KGGen: A Skill-Driven Knowledge Extractor for High-Quality Knowledge Hypergraph Generation
summary: Knowledge hypergraphs surpass traditional binary knowledge graphs by encapsulating complex $n$-ary atomic facts, providing a more comprehensive paradigm for semantic representation. However, constructing high-quality hypergraphs remains challenging due to the \textit{scenario gap}: generic extractors struggle to generalize across diverse domains with specific jargon, while existing methods often fail to balance structural skeletons with fine-grained details. To bridge this gap, we propose \textbf{Hyper-KGGen}, a skill-driven framework that reformulates extraction as a dynamic skill-evolving process. First, Hyper-KGGen employs a \textit{coarse-to-fine} mechanism to systematically decompose documents, ensuring full-dimensional coverage from binary links to complex hyperedges. Crucially, it incorporates an \textit{adaptive skill acquisition} module that actively distills domain expertise into a Global Skill Library. This is achieved via a stability-based feedback loop, where extraction stability serves as a relative reward signal to induce high-quality skills from unstable traces and missed predictions. Additionally, we present \textbf{HyperDocRED}, a rigorously annotated benchmark for document-level knowledge hypergraph extraction. Experiments demonstrate that Hyper-KGGen significantly outperforms strong baselines, validating that evolved skills provide substantially richer guidance than static few-shot examples in multi-scenario settings.

AI.tldr: Proposes Hyper-KGGen, a skill-evolving, coarse-to-fine extractor for document-level knowledge hypergraphs, plus a new HyperDocRED benchmark; shows consistent gains over strong baselines, with adaptive skills outperforming static few-shot prompts across domains.
AI.motivation: Binary knowledge graphs miss n-ary facts and current extractors struggle to generalize across domain-specific jargon (“scenario gap”) while also balancing high-level structure with fine-grained details in documents.
AI.method: Reformulates hypergraph extraction as a dynamic, skill-evolving process: (1) a coarse-to-fine decomposition covers from binary links to complex hyperedges; (2) an adaptive skill acquisition module distills domain expertise into a Global Skill Library using a stability-based feedback loop, where extraction stability acts as a relative reward to mine robust skills from unstable traces and missed predictions. Also introduces HyperDocRED, a rigorously annotated document-level benchmark.
AI.result: Hyper-KGGen significantly outperforms strong baselines on multi-scenario settings and on HyperDocRED; learned, evolving skills provide richer and more transferable guidance than static few-shot exemplars.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, stability-driven skill evolution coupled with coarse-to-fine modeling effectively bridges the scenario gap for document-level hypergraph extraction, advancing both methodology (Hyper-KGGen) and evaluation resources (HyperDocRED).

title: Limited Reasoning Space: The cage of long-horizon reasoning in LLMs
summary: The test-time compute strategy, such as Chain-of-Thought (CoT), has significantly enhanced the ability of large language models to solve complex tasks like logical reasoning. However, empirical studies indicate that simply increasing the compute budget can sometimes lead to a collapse in test-time performance when employing typical task decomposition strategies such as CoT. This work hypothesizes that reasoning failures with larger compute budgets stem from static planning methods, which hardly perceive the intrinsic boundaries of LLM reasoning. We term it as the Limited Reasoning Space hypothesis and perform theoretical analysis through the lens of a non-autonomous stochastic dynamical system. This insight suggests that there is an optimal range for compute budgets; over-planning can lead to redundant feedback and may even impair reasoning capabilities. To exploit the compute-scaling benefits and suppress over-planning, this work proposes Halo, a model predictive control framework for LLM planning. Halo is designed for long-horizon tasks with reason-based planning and crafts an entropy-driven dual controller, which adopts a Measure-then-Plan strategy to achieve controllable reasoning. Experimental results demonstrate that Halo outperforms static baselines on complex long-horizon tasks by dynamically regulating planning at the reasoning boundary.

AI.tldr: Naively scaling test-time compute (e.g., longer Chain-of-Thought) can hurt LLM reasoning. The authors hypothesize a Limited Reasoning Space with an optimal compute range and propose Halo, a model-predictive-control planner that measures uncertainty first and then plans, dynamically regulating computation to avoid over-planning and improve long-horizon performance.
AI.motivation: Empirical collapses in performance when increasing CoT/compute suggest static, open-loop planning fails to respect intrinsic limits of LLM reasoning; there is a need for adaptive, feedback-driven compute allocation that prevents redundant or harmful reasoning steps.
AI.method: Provide a theoretical lens via a non-autonomous stochastic dynamical system to formalize a Limited Reasoning Space and argue for an optimal compute range. Introduce Halo, a model predictive control framework with an entropy-driven dual controller that follows a Measure-then-Plan strategy to modulate reasoning depth/horizon in long-horizon, reason-based tasks.
AI.result: Across complex long-horizon benchmarks, Halo outperforms static planning baselines by dynamically regulating planning near the reasoning boundary, mitigating over-planning effects observed with larger compute budgets.
AI.conclusion: Static scaling of test-time compute is not universally beneficial; adaptive, control-theoretic planning that measures uncertainty and regulates reasoning can better exploit compute scaling. Halo demonstrates improved reliability and efficiency by preventing over-planning and operating near the reasoning boundary.

title: Open-Vocabulary Domain Generalization in Urban-Scene Segmentation
summary: Domain Generalization in Semantic Segmentation (DG-SS) aims to enable segmentation models to perform robustly in unseen environments. However, conventional DG-SS methods are restricted to a fixed set of known categories, limiting their applicability in open-world scenarios. Recent progress in Vision-Language Models (VLMs) has advanced Open-Vocabulary Semantic Segmentation (OV-SS) by enabling models to recognize a broader range of concepts. Yet, these models remain sensitive to domain shifts and struggle to maintain robustness when deployed in unseen environments, a challenge that is particularly severe in urban-driving scenarios. To bridge this gap, we introduce Open-Vocabulary Domain Generalization in Semantic Segmentation (OVDG-SS), a new setting that jointly addresses unseen domains and unseen categories. We introduce the first benchmark for OVDG-SS in autonomous driving, addressing a previously unexplored problem and covering both synthetic-to-real and real-to-real generalization across diverse unseen domains and unseen categories. In OVDG-SS, we observe that domain shifts often distort text-image correlations in pre-trained VLMs, which hinders the performance of OV-SS models. To tackle this challenge, we propose S2-Corr, a state-space-driven text-image correlation refinement mechanism that mitigates domain-induced distortions and produces more consistent text-image correlations under distribution changes. Extensive experiments on our constructed benchmark demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior cross-domain performance and efficiency compared to existing OV-SS approaches.

AI.tldr: They define a new setting—Open-Vocabulary Domain Generalization for Semantic Segmentation (OVDG-SS)—and release the first driving benchmark for it. They show domain shifts break text–image alignment in VLM-based OV-SS, and propose S2-Corr, a state-space-based correlation refinement that restores alignment and yields better cross-domain, open-vocab segmentation with higher efficiency.
AI.motivation: DG-SS models don’t handle unseen categories; OV-SS models can name unseen categories but break under domain shifts (especially in urban driving). There is no benchmark that jointly evaluates robustness to unseen domains and categories, leaving a key open-world deployment gap.
AI.method: 1) Define OVDG-SS: simultaneous generalization to unseen domains and categories. 2) Build a benchmark for autonomous driving covering synthetic-to-real and real-to-real shifts with unseen classes. 3) Propose S2-Corr: a state-space-driven mechanism that refines text–image correlation scores from pre-trained VLMs to counter domain-induced distortions and make correlations consistent under distribution changes.
AI.result: Across the new benchmark, S2-Corr delivers stronger cross-domain open-vocabulary segmentation and better efficiency than prior OV-SS methods, indicating improved robustness to domain shifts.
AI.conclusion: Jointly treating domain and vocabulary generalization is crucial. Their benchmark establishes a standard for evaluation in driving, and S2-Corr effectively stabilizes VLM text–image correlations under shift, improving open-world segmentation performance and efficiency.

title: Beyond a Single Extractor: Re-thinking HTML-to-Text Extraction for LLM Pretraining
summary: One of the first pre-processing steps for constructing web-scale LLM pretraining datasets involves extracting text from HTML. Despite the immense diversity of web content, existing open-source datasets predominantly apply a single fixed extractor to all webpages. In this work, we investigate whether this practice leads to suboptimal coverage and utilization of Internet data. We first show that while different extractors may lead to similar model performance on standard language understanding tasks, the pages surviving a fixed filtering pipeline can differ substantially. This suggests a simple intervention: by taking a Union over different extractors, we can increase the token yield of DCLM-Baseline by up to 71% while maintaining benchmark performance. We further show that for structured content such as tables and code blocks, extractor choice can significantly impact downstream task performance, with differences of up to 10 percentage points (p.p.) on WikiTQ and 3 p.p. on HumanEval.

AI.tldr: Union-of-extractors for HTML text extraction in LLM pretraining substantially increases usable tokens (up to +71%) without hurting general benchmarks; extractor choice strongly affects structured-content tasks (tables, code).
AI.motivation: Web-scale LLM datasets usually extract text from HTML with a single fixed extractor. This may discard valuable content and bias the dataset, especially for diverse or structured pages, potentially limiting coverage and downstream performance.
AI.method: Compare multiple HTML extractors applied to the same web data and a fixed filtering pipeline; analyze overlap and survival of pages; propose taking the union of outputs across extractors to build training data; pretrain/evaluate (e.g., DCLM-Baseline) on standard language tasks and structured-content benchmarks (tables: WikiTQ; code: HumanEval).
AI.result:
- Different extractors yield similar performance on standard language understanding tasks but select notably different pages after filtering.
- Taking the union across extractors increases token yield for DCLM-Baseline by up to 71% while maintaining benchmark performance.
- For structured content, extractor choice materially affects downstream performance: up to +10 percentage points on WikiTQ and +3 p.p. on HumanEval.
AI.conclusion: Single-extractor pipelines underutilize Internet data. Adopting a union-of-extractors improves coverage without degrading general performance, and careful extractor selection is crucial for tasks reliant on structured content (tables, code).

title: Automated Generation of Microfluidic Netlists using Large Language Models
summary: Microfluidic devices have emerged as powerful tools in various laboratory applications, but the complexity of their design limits accessibility for many practitioners. While progress has been made in microfluidic design automation (MFDA), a practical and intuitive solution is still needed to connect microfluidic practitioners with MFDA techniques. This work introduces the first practical application of large language models (LLMs) in this context, providing a preliminary demonstration. Building on prior research in hardware description language (HDL) code generation with LLMs, we propose an initial methodology to convert natural language microfluidic device specifications into system-level structural Verilog netlists. We demonstrate the feasibility of our approach by generating structural netlists for practical benchmarks representative of typical microfluidic designs with correct functional flow and an average syntactical accuracy of 88%.

AI.tldr: Preliminary proof-of-concept showing that LLMs can translate natural-language microfluidic device specifications into system-level structural Verilog netlists, achieving functionally correct flow with ~88% syntactic accuracy, potentially bridging practitioners and MFDA tools.
AI.motivation: Microfluidic device design is complex and existing MFDA solutions are not easily accessible to practitioners. There is a need for an intuitive, natural-language interface that links practitioner intent to automated design workflows.
AI.method: Leverage prior LLM-based HDL code generation to build a pipeline that converts natural-language descriptions of microfluidic devices into structural Verilog netlists at the system level. Evaluate on practical, representative microfluidic design benchmarks.
AI.result: The approach generated structural netlists for benchmark designs that preserved correct functional flow and achieved an average syntactic accuracy of 88%. This is presented as the first practical application of LLMs to MFDA.
AI.conclusion: LLMs appear feasible for bridging natural-language specifications and MFDA representations, improving accessibility for practitioners. While promising, the work is preliminary, with nontrivial syntax errors and likely needs for robustness, validation, and broader benchmarking before deployment.

title: Joint Post-Training Quantization of Vision Transformers with Learned Prompt-Guided Data Generation
summary: We present a framework for end-to-end joint quantization of Vision Transformers trained on ImageNet for the purpose of image classification. Unlike prior post-training or block-wise reconstruction methods, we jointly optimize over the entire set of all layers and inter-block dependencies without any labeled data, scaling effectively with the number of samples and completing in just one hour on a single GPU for ViT-small. We achieve state-of-the-art W4A4 and W3A3 accuracies on ImageNet and, to the best of our knowledge, the first PTQ results that maintain strong accuracy on ViT, DeiT, and Swin-T models under extremely low-bit settings (W1.58A8), demonstrating the potential for efficient edge deployment. Furthermore, we introduce a data-free calibration strategy that synthesizes diverse, label-free samples using Stable Diffusion Turbo guided by learned multi-mode prompts. By encouraging diversity in both the learned prompt embeddings and the generated image features, our data-free approach achieves performance on par with real-data ImageNet calibration and surpasses simple text-prompt baselines such as "a <adjective> photo of <adjective> <cls>".

AI.tldr: End-to-end, unlabeled, joint post-training quantization for Vision Transformers that optimizes all layers together and introduces a diffusion-based, data-free calibration; delivers SOTA W4A4/W3A3 ImageNet accuracy and the first strong ultra–low-bit (≈W1.58A8) PTQ on ViT/DeiT/Swin-T, enabling efficient edge deployment.
AI.motivation: ViT models are compute/memory heavy for edge devices. Existing PTQ often treats layers/blocks locally, ignores inter-block dependencies, and typically needs real calibration data. The authors aim to make PTQ both globally optimal (across all layers) and practical without labeled or even real data, to unlock low-bit deployment of ViTs.
AI.method: Jointly optimize quantization parameters across the entire network accounting for inter-block dependencies using unlabeled calibration. For cases without data, synthesize diverse calibration images via Stable Diffusion Turbo guided by learned multi-mode prompt embeddings that explicitly encourage diversity in prompts and image feature space. The procedure scales with the number of samples and runs in ~1 hour on a single GPU for ViT-S.
AI.result: State-of-the-art PTQ accuracies on ImageNet at W4A4 and W3A3; to their knowledge, the first to retain strong accuracy on ViT, DeiT, and Swin-T at an extremely low-bit regime (≈W1.58A8). The diffusion-based, data-free calibration matches real-data calibration performance and outperforms simple text-prompt baselines.
AI.conclusion: Globally optimized, unlabeled PTQ combined with diffusion-driven, data-free calibration is effective for ViTs, maintaining high ImageNet accuracy even at very low precision and broadening practical edge deployment. Data synthesis with learned multi-mode prompts can stand in for real calibration data while preserving performance.

title: Sculpting the Vector Space: Towards Efficient Multi-Vector Visual Document Retrieval via Prune-then-Merge Framework
summary: Visual Document Retrieval (VDR), which aims to retrieve relevant pages within vast corpora of visually-rich documents, is of significance in current multimodal retrieval applications. The state-of-the-art multi-vector paradigm excels in performance but suffers from prohibitive overhead, a problem that current efficiency methods like pruning and merging address imperfectly, creating a difficult trade-off between compression rate and feature fidelity. To overcome this dilemma, we introduce Prune-then-Merge, a novel two-stage framework that synergizes these complementary approaches. Our method first employs an adaptive pruning stage to filter out low-information patches, creating a refined, high-signal set of embeddings. Subsequently, a hierarchical merging stage compresses this pre-filtered set, effectively summarizing semantic content without the noise-induced feature dilution seen in single-stage methods. Extensive experiments on 29 VDR datasets demonstrate that our framework consistently outperforms existing methods, significantly extending the near-lossless compression range and providing robust performance at high compression ratios.

AI.tldr: Two-stage “Prune-then-Merge” for multi-vector Visual Document Retrieval compresses page embeddings far more efficiently than single-stage pruning or merging, preserving retrieval quality while cutting vectors aggressively; it consistently outperforms baselines on 29 datasets and extends the near-lossless compression regime.
AI.motivation: Multi-vector VDR yields strong accuracy but incurs prohibitive storage/query-time costs. Existing single-stage efficiency methods (pruning or merging) force a harsh trade-off: high compression harms semantic fidelity, while conservative compression leaves costs high. Noise and low-information patches exacerbate feature dilution during merging.
AI.method: A two-stage pipeline: (1) Adaptive pruning removes low-information patches to produce a high-signal embedding set; (2) Hierarchical merging then compresses the pruned set, summarizing semantics while avoiding noise-induced dilution. The synergy enables stronger compression before accuracy drops, compared to either pruning-only or merging-only approaches.
AI.result: Across 29 VDR datasets, the approach consistently outperforms prior pruning/merging methods, achieves robust performance at high compression ratios, and meaningfully enlarges the range where compression is near-lossless.
AI.conclusion: Combining adaptive pruning with hierarchical merging provides a principled, practical path to efficient multi-vector VDR, reducing overhead without sacrificing retrieval quality and setting a stronger Pareto frontier of accuracy vs compression.

title: ALPACA: A Reinforcement Learning Environment for Medication Repurposing and Treatment Optimization in Alzheimer's Disease
summary: Evaluating personalized, sequential treatment strategies for Alzheimer's disease (AD) using clinical trials is often impractical due to long disease horizons and substantial inter-patient heterogeneity. To address these constraints, we present the Alzheimer's Learning Platform for Adaptive Care Agents (ALPACA), an open-source, Gym-compatible reinforcement learning (RL) environment for systematically exploring personalized treatment strategies using existing therapies. ALPACA is powered by the Continuous Action-conditioned State Transitions (CAST) model trained on longitudinal trajectories from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI), enabling medication-conditioned simulation of disease progression under alternative treatment decisions. We show that CAST autoregressively generates realistic medication-conditioned trajectories and that RL policies trained in ALPACA outperform no-treatment and behavior-cloned clinician baselines on memory-related outcomes. Interpretability analyses further indicated that the learned policies relied on clinically meaningful patient features when selecting actions. Overall, ALPACA provides a reusable in silico testbed for studying individualized sequential treatment decision-making for AD.

AI.tldr: ALPACA is an open-source, Gym-compatible RL testbed for Alzheimer’s care that uses a learned, medication-conditioned simulator (CAST) trained on ADNI to evaluate personalized, sequential treatment policies. Policies trained in ALPACA generate realistic trajectories, beat no-treatment and clinician behavior-cloning baselines on memory outcomes, and use clinically meaningful features.
AI.motivation: Clinical trials to assess individualized, sequential treatment strategies in AD are impractical due to long disease courses and high patient heterogeneity, motivating an in silico platform to safely and systematically explore adaptive care policies using existing therapies.
AI.method: Build ALPACA, a reinforcement-learning environment driven by the Continuous Action-conditioned State Transitions (CAST) model trained on longitudinal ADNI data. CAST autoregressively simulates disease progression conditional on medication choices. Train RL policies within ALPACA and compare them against no-treatment and behavior-cloned clinician baselines; analyze policy interpretability to assess reliance on clinically meaningful features.
AI.result: CAST produces realistic, medication-conditioned trajectories. RL policies trained in ALPACA outperform both no-treatment and behavior-cloned clinician baselines on memory-related outcomes and appear to base decisions on clinically relevant patient features.
AI.conclusion: ALPACA offers a reusable, open-source in silico platform for studying and optimizing personalized, sequential treatment decisions for AD using existing therapies, demonstrating promise for improving memory outcomes while maintaining interpretability.

title: Similarity-as-Evidence: Calibrating Overconfident VLMs for Interpretable and Label-Efficient Medical Active Learning
comment: 8 pages, 5 figures, Accepted to CVPR 2026 (to appear)
summary: Active Learning (AL) reduces annotation costs in medical imaging by selecting only the most informative samples for labeling, but suffers from cold-start when labeled data are scarce. Vision-Language Models (VLMs) address the cold-start problem via zero-shot predictions, yet their temperature-scaled softmax outputs treat text-image similarities as deterministic scores while ignoring inherent uncertainty, leading to overconfidence. This overconfidence misleads sample selection, wasting annotation budgets on uninformative cases. To overcome these limitations, the Similarity-as-Evidence (SaE) framework calibrates text-image similarities by introducing a Similarity Evidence Head (SEH), which reinterprets the similarity vector as evidence and parameterizes a Dirichlet distribution over labels. In contrast to a standard softmax that enforces confident predictions even under weak signals, the Dirichlet formulation explicitly quantifies lack of evidence (vacuity) and conflicting evidence (dissonance), thereby mitigating overconfidence caused by rigid softmax normalization. Building on this, SaE employs a dual-factor acquisition strategy: high-vacuity samples (e.g., rare diseases) are prioritized in early rounds to ensure coverage, while high-dissonance samples (e.g., ambiguous diagnoses) are prioritized later to refine boundaries, providing clinically interpretable selection rationales. Experiments on ten public medical imaging datasets with a 20% label budget show that SaE attains state-of-the-art macro-averaged accuracy of 82.57%. On the representative BTMRI dataset, SaE also achieves superior calibration, with a negative log-likelihood (NLL) of 0.425.

AI.tldr: SaE reframes VLM text–image similarities as Dirichlet evidence to quantify uncertainty (vacuity and dissonance) and drives a staged active-learning policy—coverage first, refinement later—achieving state-of-the-art accuracy with strong calibration under tight label budgets.
AI.motivation: Active learning in medical imaging suffers from cold-start (few labels) and misleads selection when VLM zero-shot scores are overconfident due to softmax treating similarities as deterministic. The authors aim to calibrate uncertainty in VLM outputs so AL can pick truly informative cases and avoid wasting labels.
AI.method: Introduce a Similarity Evidence Head (SEH) that maps the VLM similarity vector to Dirichlet concentration parameters, interpreting similarities as evidential support for classes. This enables explicit measures of lack of evidence (vacuity) and conflicting evidence (dissonance). A dual-factor acquisition strategy prioritizes high-vacuity samples in early AL rounds to ensure class/phenotype coverage (e.g., rare diseases), then high-dissonance samples later to sharpen decision boundaries, providing clinical rationales for selection.
AI.result: Across ten public medical imaging datasets with only 20% labels, SaE reaches a macro-averaged accuracy of 82.57% (state-of-the-art). On BTMRI, it yields improved calibration with NLL of 0.425.
AI.conclusion: Calibrating VLM similarities as evidence mitigates overconfidence, addresses AL cold-start, and enables interpretable, phase-aware sample selection, producing better accuracy and calibration under limited annotation budgets.

title: Temporal-Aware Heterogeneous Graph Reasoning with Multi-View Fusion for Temporal Question Answering
summary: Question Answering over Temporal Knowledge Graphs (TKGQA) has attracted growing interest for handling time-sensitive queries. However, existing methods still struggle with: 1) weak incorporation of temporal constraints in question representation, causing biased reasoning; 2) limited ability to perform explicit multi-hop reasoning; and 3) suboptimal fusion of language and graph representations. We propose a novel framework with temporal-aware question encoding, multi-hop graph reasoning, and multi-view heterogeneous information fusion. Specifically, our approach introduces: 1) a constraint-aware question representation that combines semantic cues from language models with temporal entity dynamics; 2) a temporal-aware graph neural network for explicit multi-hop reasoning via time-aware message passing; and 3) a multi-view attention mechanism for more effective fusion of question context and temporal graph knowledge. Experiments on multiple TKGQA benchmarks demonstrate consistent improvements over multiple baselines.

AI.tldr: A TKGQA framework that tightly encodes temporal constraints in questions, performs explicit multi-hop reasoning with a time-aware GNN, and fuses language and temporal-graph views via multi-view attention, yielding consistent gains on several benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing TKGQA systems underuse temporal constraints in question encoding (leading to biased reasoning), lack explicit multi-hop temporal reasoning, and inadequately fuse language and graph information. Time-sensitive queries require models that respect temporal dynamics and combine heterogeneous signals effectively.
AI.method: Three components: (1) constraint-aware question representation that blends language-model semantics with temporal entity dynamics; (2) temporal-aware GNN enabling explicit multi-hop reasoning through time-aware message passing; (3) multi-view attention mechanism to fuse question context and temporal graph knowledge.
AI.result: On multiple TKGQA benchmarks, the approach consistently outperforms several baselines (exact metrics not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Integrating temporal constraints into question encoding, enabling time-aware multi-hop message passing, and using multi-view fusion improves reasoning over temporal knowledge graphs for question answering.

title: Time Series, Vision, and Language: Exploring the Limits of Alignment in Contrastive Representation Spaces
summary: The Platonic Representation Hypothesis posits that learned representations from models trained on different modalities converge to a shared latent structure of the world. However, this hypothesis has largely been examined in vision and language, and it remains unclear whether time series participate in such convergence. We first examine this in a trimodal setting and find that independently pretrained time series, vision, and language encoders exhibit near-orthogonal geometry in the absence of explicit coupling. We then apply post-hoc alignment by training projection heads over frozen encoders using contrastive learning, and analyze the resulting representations with respect to geometry, scaling behavior, and dependence on information density and input modality characteristics. Our investigation reveals that overall alignment in contrastive representation spaces improves with model size, but this alignment is asymmetric: time series align more strongly with visual representations than with text, and images can act as effective intermediaries between time series and language. We further see that richer textual descriptions improve alignment only up to a threshold; training on denser captions does not lead to further improvement. Analogous effects are observed for visual representations. Our findings shed light on considerations for building multimodal systems involving non-conventional data modalities beyond vision and language.

AI.tldr: Without explicit coupling, time‑series, vision, and language encoders do not naturally share a latent space; contrastive post‑hoc alignment over frozen encoders yields scale‑dependent, asymmetric alignment (time series align better with vision than with text), with images serving as a bridge and diminishing returns from denser captions/visual detail.
AI.motivation: Test whether the Platonic Representation Hypothesis extends beyond vision–language to include time series, and identify factors (model scale, information density, modality traits) that enable or limit cross‑modal alignment—informing design of multimodal systems with nontraditional modalities.
AI.method: Use a trimodal setup with independently pretrained encoders for time series, images, and text. First, analyze inter‑modal geometry without coupling. Then freeze encoders and train small projection heads via contrastive learning to post‑hoc align modalities. Evaluate geometry, scaling behavior, and effects of information density (e.g., caption richness) and modality characteristics.
AI.result: Independently trained encoders are near‑orthogonal across modalities. Post‑hoc contrastive alignment improves cross‑modal agreement, and improves with larger models. Alignment is asymmetric: time series align more strongly with vision than with text; images can mediate alignment between time series and language. Richer textual descriptions help only up to a threshold, after which benefits plateau; analogous diminishing‑returns effects are seen for visual representations.
AI.conclusion: Time series do not spontaneously converge to the same latent space as vision and language; explicit alignment is required. Scaling improves but does not eliminate asymmetries. Images are effective pivots for integrating time series with language. Overly dense captions (and analogous visual detail) yield limited additional gains, guiding practical choices for building multimodal systems that include nonconventional modalities.

title: Enhancing 3D LiDAR Segmentation by Shaping Dense and Accurate 2D Semantic Predictions
summary: Semantic segmentation of 3D LiDAR point clouds is important in urban remote sensing for understanding real-world street environments. This task, by projecting LiDAR point clouds and 3D semantic labels as sparse maps, can be reformulated as a 2D problem. However, the intrinsic sparsity of the projected LiDAR and label maps can result in sparse and inaccurate intermediate 2D semantic predictions, which in return limits the final 3D accuracy. To address this issue, we enhance this task by shaping dense and accurate 2D predictions. Specifically, we develop a multi-modal segmentation model, MM2D3D. By leveraging camera images as auxiliary data, we introduce cross-modal guided filtering to overcome label map sparsity by constraining intermediate 2D semantic predictions with dense semantic relations derived from the camera images; and we introduce dynamic cross pseudo supervision to overcome LiDAR map sparsity by encouraging the 2D predictions to emulate the dense distribution of the semantic predictions from the camera images. Experiments show that our techniques enable our model to achieve intermediate 2D semantic predictions with dense distribution and higher accuracy, which effectively enhances the final 3D accuracy. Comparisons with previous methods demonstrate our superior performance in both 2D and 3D spaces.

AI.tldr: They improve 3D LiDAR semantic segmentation by turning sparse 2D projections into dense, accurate predictions using multi-modal cues from cameras, yielding better 2D and 3D performance.
AI.motivation: Projecting 3D LiDAR point clouds to 2D makes segmentation easier, but the projections and labels are very sparse, causing inaccurate 2D predictions that cap final 3D accuracy.
AI.method: Introduce MM2D3D, a multi-modal LiDAR–camera model with: (1) cross-modal guided filtering, which injects dense semantic relations from images to constrain sparse 2D LiDAR predictions; and (2) dynamic cross pseudo supervision, which encourages LiDAR-side 2D outputs to match the denser semantic distributions predicted from images.
AI.result: The techniques produce denser, more accurate intermediate 2D predictions and thereby improve final 3D segmentation accuracy; empirical comparisons show state-of-the-art performance in both 2D and 3D.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging camera-derived dense semantics to guide and supervise LiDAR projections mitigates sparsity, leading to better 2D intermediates and superior 3D segmentation outcomes.

title: DEEP: Docker-based Execution and Evaluation Platform
summary: Comparative evaluation of several systems is a recurrent task in researching. It is a key step before deciding which system to use for our work, or, once our research has been conducted, to demonstrate the potential of the resulting model. Furthermore, it is the main task of competitive, public challenges evaluation. Our proposed software (DEEP) automates both the execution and scoring of machine translation and optical character recognition models. Furthermore, it is easily extensible to other tasks. DEEP is prepared to receive dockerized systems, run them (extracting information at that same time), and assess hypothesis against some references. With this approach, evaluators can achieve a better understanding of the performance of each model. Moreover, the software uses a clustering algorithm based on a statistical analysis of the significance of the results yielded by each model, according to the evaluation metrics. As a result, evaluators are able to identify clusters of performance among the swarm of proposals and have a better understanding of the significance of their differences. Additionally, we offer a visualization web-app to ensure that the results can be adequately understood and interpreted. Finally, we present an exemplary case of use of DEEP.

AI.tldr: DEEP is a docker-based framework that automates running and scoring MT/OCR systems, performs significance-aware clustering of results, and offers a visualization web app to interpret comparative performance; it’s extensible to other tasks and demonstrated via a case study.
AI.motivation: Comparative evaluation across multiple systems is recurrent in research and challenges, but it’s labor-intensive and can obscure which differences are meaningful. There’s a need to standardize execution, scoring, and interpretation, and to assess statistical significance of performance gaps.
AI.method:
- Accept dockerized systems and execute them while logging/extracting outputs.
- Evaluate model hypotheses against references using standard metrics.
- Apply a clustering algorithm grounded in statistical significance tests over metric results to group systems by performance.
- Provide a visualization web app to explore scores and clusters.
- Designed to be extensible beyond MT and OCR.
AI.result:
- Automated pipeline for execution and scoring of MT/OCR models.
- Statistical significance-based clustering that reveals performance groupings and the meaningfulness of differences.
- Interactive visualization for clearer interpretation.
- An illustrative case study demonstrating the workflow and outputs (no specific numeric gains reported).
AI.conclusion: DEEP streamlines and standardizes comparative evaluation, enabling more trustworthy, interpretable comparisons via significance-aware clustering and visualization; while focused on MT/OCR, it is readily extendable to other tasks and applicable to challenge evaluations and research benchmarks.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Modeling & Simulation in Digital Twins
summary: The convergence of modeling & simulation (M&S) and artificial intelligence (AI) is leaving its marks on advanced digital technology. Pertinent examples are digital twins (DTs) - high-fidelity, live representations of physical assets, and frequent enablers of corporate digital maturation and transformation. Often seen as technological platforms that integrate an array of services, DTs have the potential to bring AI-enabled M&S closer to end-users. It is, therefore, paramount to understand the role of M&S in DTs, and the role of digital twins in enabling the convergence of AI and M&S. To this end, this chapter provides a comprehensive exploration of the complementary relationship between these three. We begin by establishing a foundational understanding of DTs by detailing their key components, architectural layers, and their various roles across business, development, and operations. We then examine the central role of M&S in DTs and provide an overview of key modeling techniques from physics-based and discrete-event simulation to hybrid approaches. Subsequently, we investigate the bidirectional role of AI: first, how AI enhances DTs through advanced analytics, predictive capabilities, and autonomous decision-making, and second, how DTs serve as valuable platforms for training, validating, and deploying AI models. The chapter concludes by identifying key challenges and future research directions for creating more integrated and intelligent systems.

AI.tldr: Survey chapter mapping how digital twins (DTs) serve as platforms where modeling & simulation (M&S) and AI converge; it outlines DT components/architectures, reviews core M&S techniques, analyzes AI’s dual role (enhancing DTs and being trained/validated via DTs), and distills open challenges and research directions.
AI.motivation: As DTs become central to digital transformation, there is a need to clarify how M&S underpins DTs and how AI both augments DTs and is accelerated by them—so practitioners and researchers can design more integrated, intelligent systems.
AI.method: Conceptual synthesis and structured review: defines DT building blocks and architectural layers; surveys M&S approaches (physics-based, discrete-event, hybrid); analyzes bidirectional AI–DT relationships (AI for DT analytics, prediction, autonomy; DTs as data/experimentation platforms for AI training, validation, deployment).
AI.result: A consolidated framework linking DT roles across business, development, and operations with specific M&S techniques; taxonomy of AI augmentation pathways for DTs; articulation of how DTs provide safe, rich environments and data streams for AI lifecycle; and an agenda of key challenges and research opportunities.
AI.conclusion: DTs are effective integration hubs for AI and M&S. Realizing their potential requires advances in model fidelity/validation, interoperability and standards, real-time data-model coupling, trustworthy/secure operation, and methods for autonomous and explainable decision-making.

title: BiMotion: B-spline Motion for Text-guided Dynamic 3D Character Generation
summary: Text-guided dynamic 3D character generation has advanced rapidly, yet producing high-quality motion that faithfully reflects rich textual descriptions remains challenging. Existing methods tend to generate limited sub-actions or incoherent motion due to fixed-length temporal inputs and discrete frame-wise representations that fail to capture rich motion semantics. We address these limitations by representing motion with continuous differentiable B-spline curves, enabling more effective motion generation without modifying the capabilities of the underlying generative model. Specifically, our closed-form, Laplacian-regularized B-spline solver efficiently compresses variable-length motion sequences into compact representations with a fixed number of control points. Further, we introduce a normal-fusion strategy for input shape adherence along with correspondence-aware and local-rigidity losses for motion-restoration quality. To train our model, we collate BIMO, a new dataset containing diverse variable-length 3D motion sequences with rich, high-quality text annotations. Extensive evaluations show that our feed-forward framework BiMotion generates more expressive, higher-quality, and better prompt-aligned motions than existing state-of-the-art methods, while also achieving faster generation. Our project page is at: https://wangmiaowei.github.io/BiMotion.github.io/.

AI.tldr: BiMotion represents text-guided 3D character motion with continuous B‑spline curves and a closed‑form, Laplacian‑regularized solver, plus normal‑fusion and correspondence/local‑rigidity losses, achieving faster, more expressive, and better prompt‑aligned motions than prior SOTA; training is supported by a new BIMO dataset of diverse, richly annotated motions.
AI.motivation: Text‑to‑3D motion methods often produce limited, incoherent sub‑actions due to fixed‑length temporal windows and discrete frame‑wise representations that fail to capture rich motion semantics across variable durations. A representation that preserves temporal continuity and semantics, yet remains compatible with existing generative models, is needed.
AI.method: Model motion as continuous, differentiable B‑spline curves. Use a closed‑form, Laplacian‑regularized B‑spline solver to compress variable‑length sequences into a fixed number of control points. Introduce a normal‑fusion strategy to enforce adherence to input shape/surface, and add correspondence‑aware and local‑rigidity losses to improve motion restoration fidelity. Train a feed‑forward framework (BiMotion) using BIMO, a new dataset of diverse, variable‑length 3D motions with rich text annotations.
AI.result: Extensive evaluations indicate BiMotion generates motions that are more expressive, higher quality, better aligned to textual prompts, and faster to produce than state‑of‑the‑art baselines.
AI.conclusion: Continuous B‑spline motion representation, coupled with an efficient solver and targeted losses, overcomes limitations of discrete, fixed‑length motion modeling, enabling a feed‑forward system that sets new performance and speed benchmarks; the BIMO dataset supports training and broader evaluation.

title: Eye-Tracking-while-Reading: A Living Survey of Datasets with Open Library Support
summary: Eye-tracking-while-reading corpora are a valuable resource for many different disciplines and use cases. Use cases range from studying the cognitive processes underlying reading to machine-learning-based applications, such as gaze-based assessments of reading comprehension. The past decades have seen an increase in the number and size of eye-tracking-while-reading datasets as well as increasing diversity with regard to the stimulus languages covered, the linguistic background of the participants, or accompanying psychometric or demographic data. The spread of data across different disciplines and the lack of data sharing standards across the communities lead to many existing datasets that cannot be easily reused due to a lack of interoperability. In this work, we aim at creating more transparency and clarity with regards to existing datasets and their features across different disciplines by i) presenting an extensive overview of existing datasets, ii) simplifying the sharing of newly created datasets by publishing a living overview online, https://dili-lab.github.io/datasets.html, presenting over 45 features for each dataset, and iii) integrating all publicly available datasets into the Python package pymovements which offers an eye-tracking datasets library. By doing so, we aim to strengthen the FAIR principles in eye-tracking-while-reading research and promote good scientific practices, such as reproducing and replicating studies.

AI.tldr: Creates a unified, living catalog and a Python library (pymovements) to standardize access to eye-tracking-while-reading datasets, improving interoperability, reuse, and FAIR compliance.
AI.motivation: Proliferation of eye-tracking-while-reading datasets across disciplines, languages, and participant backgrounds without common sharing standards has led to fragmented, hard-to-reuse resources and hindered replication and cross-study comparison.
AI.method: Survey and curate existing datasets; publish a continuously updated online overview listing 45+ features per dataset; integrate all publicly available datasets into the pymovements Python package to provide a consistent, programmatic access layer.
AI.result: Delivered an online catalog (https://dili-lab.github.io/datasets.html) detailing dataset features and consolidated public datasets within pymovements, enabling standardized documentation and access.
AI.conclusion: By centralizing documentation and access, the work advances FAIR principles and facilitates robust scientific practices, including easier sharing, reproduction, and replication across communities.

title: Hiding in Plain Text: Detecting Concealed Jailbreaks via Activation Disentanglement
summary: Large language models (LLMs) remain vulnerable to jailbreak prompts that are fluent and semantically coherent, and therefore difficult to detect with standard heuristics. A particularly challenging failure mode occurs when an attacker tries to hide the malicious goal of their request by manipulating its framing to induce compliance. Because these attacks maintain malicious intent through a flexible presentation, defenses that rely on structural artifacts or goal-specific signatures can fail. Motivated by this, we introduce a self-supervised framework for disentangling semantic factor pairs in LLM activations at inference. We instantiate the framework for goal and framing and construct GoalFrameBench, a corpus of prompts with controlled goal and framing variations, which we use to train Representation Disentanglement on Activations (ReDAct) module to extract disentangled representations in a frozen LLM. We then propose FrameShield, an anomaly detector operating on the framing representations, which improves model-agnostic detection across multiple LLM families with minimal computational overhead. Theoretical guarantees for ReDAct and extensive empirical validations show that its disentanglement effectively powers FrameShield. Finally, we use disentanglement as an interpretability probe, revealing distinct profiles for goal and framing signals and positioning semantic disentanglement as a building block for both LLM safety and mechanistic interpretability.

AI.tldr: They propose a self-supervised method (ReDAct) to disentangle goal vs. framing signals in LLM activations, build a controlled benchmark (GoalFrameBench), and use the framing representation to run a lightweight, model-agnostic jailbreak detector (FrameShield) with theory-backed and empirically validated gains; disentanglement also aids interpretability.
AI.motivation: Jailbreaks that reframe malicious requests remain fluent and coherent, evading heuristics and goal-specific or structure-reliant filters. A semantic, model-agnostic defense is needed to detect attacks that hide intent via framing.
AI.method: Introduce a self-supervised framework to disentangle paired semantic factors in LLM activations at inference time. Instantiate for goal and framing: (1) construct GoalFrameBench with controlled variations; (2) train ReDAct on frozen LLM activations to extract separate goal/framing representations; (3) design FrameShield, an anomaly detector operating on framing representations for jailbreak detection; (4) use disentangled reps as interpretability probes.
AI.result: Provide theoretical guarantees for ReDAct’s disentanglement; empirically, FrameShield improves jailbreak detection across multiple LLM families with minimal compute overhead, and analyses show distinct activation profiles for goal vs. framing signals.
AI.conclusion: Semantic disentanglement of activations is a practical building block for LLM safety and interpretability. By isolating framing signals, the approach yields robust, transferable, and efficient detection of framing-based jailbreaks.

title: Structure-Level Disentangled Diffusion for Few-Shot Chinese Font Generation
summary: Few-shot Chinese font generation aims to synthesize new characters in a target style using only a handful of reference images. Achieving accurate content rendering and faithful style transfer requires effective disentanglement between content and style. However, existing approaches achieve only feature-level disentanglement, allowing the generator to re-entangle these features, leading to content distortion and degraded style fidelity. We propose the Structure-Level Disentangled Diffusion Model (SLD-Font), which receives content and style information from two separate channels. SimSun-style images are used as content templates and concatenated with noisy latent features as the input. Style features extracted by a CLIP model from target-style images are integrated via cross-attention. Additionally, we train a Background Noise Removal module in the pixel space to remove background noise in complex stroke regions. Based on theoretical validation of disentanglement effectiveness, we introduce a parameter-efficient fine-tuning strategy that updates only the style-related modules. This allows the model to better adapt to new styles while avoiding overfitting to the reference images' content. We further introduce the Grey and OCR metrics to evaluate the content quality of generated characters. Experimental results show that SLD-Font achieves significantly higher style fidelity while maintaining comparable content accuracy to existing state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: SLD-Font is a diffusion-based, structure-level disentangled model for few-shot Chinese font generation that feeds content and style through separate channels (SimSun templates for content; CLIP-derived style via cross-attention), adds a pixel-space background-noise remover, uses parameter-efficient style-only fine-tuning, and introduces Grey/OCR metrics—yielding markedly better style fidelity with similar content accuracy versus SOTA.
AI.motivation: Few-shot font synthesis must preserve character content (glyph structure) while transferring target style from very limited references. Existing methods disentangle content/style only at the feature level, enabling re-entanglement during generation, which causes content distortion and weak style fidelity. A stronger, structure-level disentanglement is needed to robustly separate and control content vs. style.
AI.method:
- Architecture: A diffusion model with dual information pathways. Content is provided explicitly via SimSun-style template images concatenated with noisy latents; style is encoded by CLIP from target-style images and injected via cross-attention, enforcing separation at the structural level.
- Background Noise Removal: A pixel-space module trained to suppress background noise, especially in dense/complex stroke regions.
- Training/Adaptation: Theoretical support for the disentanglement design. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning updates only style-related modules to adapt to new styles while limiting overfitting to reference content.
- Evaluation: New Grey and OCR metrics to quantify content quality of generated characters in addition to style fidelity measures.
AI.result: Experiments show SLD-Font substantially improves style fidelity while keeping content accuracy on par with or close to state-of-the-art baselines. The Grey and OCR metrics confirm strong content preservation; qualitative and quantitative results indicate reduced artifacts from background noise.
AI.conclusion: Enforcing structure-level separation of content and style in a diffusion framework—augmented by targeted noise removal and style-only fine-tuning—enables more faithful few-shot Chinese font generation. The approach balances style transfer with content preservation and provides practical evaluation metrics, suggesting a more controllable and adaptable path for low-shot font synthesis.

title: Anatomy of Unlearning: The Dual Impact of Fact Salience and Model Fine-Tuning
summary: Machine Unlearning (MU) enables Large Language Models (LLMs) to remove unsafe or outdated information. However, existing work assumes that all facts are equally forgettable and largely ignores whether the forgotten knowledge originates from pretraining or supervised fine-tuning (SFT). In this paper, we introduce DUAL (Dual Unlearning Evaluation across Training Stages), a benchmark of 28.6k Wikidata-derived triplets annotated with fact popularity using Wikipedia link counts and LLM-based salience scores. Our experiments show that pretrained and SFT models respond differently to unlearning. An SFT step on the forget data yields smoother forgetting, more stable tuning, and 10-50% higher retention, while direct unlearning on pretrained models remains unstable and prone to relearning or catastrophic forgetting.

AI.tldr: DUAL is a benchmark showing that unlearning behaves differently for knowledge from pretraining vs. SFT; adding an SFT step on the forget set greatly stabilizes unlearning and preserves 10–50% more retained knowledge, while direct unlearning on pretrained models is unstable and prone to relearning/catastrophic forgetting.
AI.motivation: Current machine unlearning work treats all facts as equally forgettable and often ignores whether the targeted knowledge comes from pretraining or SFT. The authors aim to evaluate MU realism by accounting for fact popularity/salience and by contrasting unlearning across training stages.
AI.method: Construct DUAL: 28.6k Wikidata triples annotated with (a) popularity via Wikipedia link counts and (b) LLM-based salience scores. Use this benchmark to compare unlearning behavior in pretrained vs. SFT models, including the effect of inserting an SFT step on the forget data. Assess forgetting smoothness, tuning stability, retention of unrelated knowledge, and risks of relearning/catastrophic forgetting.
AI.result: Pretrained and SFT models exhibit distinct unlearning dynamics. Performing an SFT step on the forget data before/alongside unlearning yields smoother forgetting, more stable tuning, and 10–50% higher retention of non-target knowledge. Direct unlearning on pretrained models is unstable and susceptible to relearning or catastrophic forgetting.
AI.conclusion: Unlearning effectiveness depends on the training stage and the salience/popularity of facts. Practitioners should consider SFT-assisted unlearning rather than directly unlearning from a pretrained model. DUAL offers a standardized way to study and compare MU across stages, challenging the assumption of uniform forgettability.

title: IR$^3$: Contrastive Inverse Reinforcement Learning for Interpretable Detection and Mitigation of Reward Hacking
summary: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) enables powerful LLM alignment but can introduce reward hacking - models exploit spurious correlations in proxy rewards without genuine alignment. Compounding this, the objectives internalized during RLHF remain opaque, making hacking behaviors difficult to detect or correct. We introduce IR3 (Interpretable Reward Reconstruction and Rectification), a framework that reverse-engineers, interprets, and surgically repairs the implicit objectives driving RLHF-tuned models. We propose Contrastive Inverse Reinforcement Learning (C-IRL), which reconstructs the implicit reward function by contrasting paired responses from post-alignment and baseline policies to explain behavioral shifts during RLHF. We then decompose the reconstructed reward via sparse autoencoders into interpretable features, enabling identification of hacking signatures through contribution analysis. Finally, we propose mitigation strategies - clean reward optimization, adversarial shaping, constrained optimization, and feature-guided distillation - that target problematic features while preserving beneficial alignment. Experiments across multiple reward model configurations show that IR3 achieves 0.89 correlation with ground-truth rewards, identifies hacking features with over 90% precision, and significantly reduces hacking behaviors while maintaining capabilities within 3% of the original model.

AI.tldr: IR3 reconstructs and interprets the implicit reward learned during RLHF to detect and fix reward hacking, achieving high fidelity to ground-truth rewards and reducing hacking with minimal capability loss.
AI.motivation: RLHF can cause models to exploit proxy rewards (reward hacking), and the internalized objectives are opaque, making such failures hard to diagnose and correct. The paper aims to open the black box of RLHF objectives and provide targeted repairs without sacrificing desirable behavior.
AI.method: Introduce IR3: (1) Contrastive Inverse Reinforcement Learning (C-IRL) to infer the implicit reward by contrasting paired outputs from post-RLHF and baseline models; (2) Decompose the reconstructed reward with sparse autoencoders to obtain interpretable features; (3) Identify hacking signatures via contribution analysis; (4) Apply mitigation strategies—clean reward optimization, adversarial shaping, constrained optimization, and feature-guided distillation—to suppress problematic features while preserving beneficial ones.
AI.result: Across multiple reward-model settings, IR3 attains 0.89 correlation with ground-truth rewards, detects hacking-related features with >90% precision, and reduces hacking behaviors while keeping overall capabilities within 3% of the original model.
AI.conclusion: IR3 offers a practical, interpretable pipeline to reverse-engineer and surgically rectify RLHF-induced objectives, enabling targeted mitigation of reward hacking with limited performance regressions.

title: FOCA: Frequency-Oriented Cross-Domain Forgery Detection, Localization and Explanation via Multi-Modal Large Language Model
summary: Advances in image tampering techniques, particularly generative models, pose significant challenges to media verification, digital forensics, and public trust. Existing image forgery detection and localization (IFDL) methods suffer from two key limitations: over-reliance on semantic content while neglecting textural cues, and limited interpretability of subtle low-level tampering traces. To address these issues, we propose FOCA, a multimodal large language model-based framework that integrates discriminative features from both the RGB spatial and frequency domains via a cross-attention fusion module. This design enables accurate forgery detection and localization while providing explicit, human-interpretable cross-domain explanations. We further introduce FSE-Set, a large-scale dataset with diverse authentic and tampered images, pixel-level masks, and dual-domain annotations. Extensive experiments show that FOCA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in detection performance and interpretability across both spatial and frequency domains.

AI.tldr: FOCA fuses RGB spatial and frequency-domain cues via a cross-attention, MLLM-based framework and introduces FSE-Set; together they deliver state-of-the-art forgery detection, localization, and human-interpretable cross-domain explanations.
AI.motivation: Generative image tampering undermines media trust. Existing IFDL systems over-rely on semantic content, miss fine textural/frequency traces, and provide limited interpretability of subtle, low-level artifacts. There is a need for detectors that leverage both spatial and frequency cues and can explain decisions in a human-understandable way.
AI.method: FOCA is a multimodal large-language-model-driven framework that extracts discriminative features from RGB spatial and frequency domains and fuses them with a cross-attention module. It outputs both detection/localization (pixel-level masks) and explicit, human-interpretable explanations grounded in both domains. The authors also curate FSE-Set, a large-scale dataset containing authentic and tampered images, pixel-wise masks, and dual-domain (spatial/frequency) annotations to supervise and evaluate detection and interpretability.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, FOCA surpasses state-of-the-art baselines in both detection accuracy and localization, while also outperforming them in interpretability metrics. Gains hold in both spatial and frequency analyses, indicating the benefit of cross-domain fusion and explanation generation.
AI.conclusion: Combining spatial and frequency features with cross-attention and MLLM reasoning improves robustness and transparency of image forgery detection. FOCA provides accurate, localized decisions and human-readable cross-domain explanations, and FSE-Set supports training/evaluation. This approach addresses semantic over-reliance and interpretability gaps in current IFDL methods.

title: KGHaluBench: A Knowledge Graph-Based Hallucination Benchmark for Evaluating the Breadth and Depth of LLM Knowledge
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) possess a remarkable capacity to generate persuasive and intelligible language. However, coherence does not equate to truthfulness, as the responses often contain subtle hallucinations. Existing benchmarks are limited by static and narrow questions, leading to limited coverage and misleading evaluations. We present KGHaluBench, a Knowledge Graph-based hallucination benchmark that assesses LLMs across the breadth and depth of their knowledge, providing a fairer and more comprehensive insight into LLM truthfulness. Our framework utilises the KG to dynamically construct challenging, multifaceted questions, whose difficulty is then statistically estimated to address popularity bias. Our automated verification pipeline detects abstentions and verifies the LLM's response at both conceptual and correctness levels to identify different types of hallucinations. We evaluate 25 frontier models, using novel accuracy and hallucination metrics. The results provide a more interpretable insight into the knowledge factors that cause hallucinations across different model sizes. KGHaluBench is publicly available to support future developments in hallucination mitigation.

AI.tldr: KGHaluBench is a knowledge-graph-driven, dynamic benchmark to more fairly and comprehensively evaluate LLM hallucinations, with automated verification and new metrics, tested on 25 frontier models.
AI.motivation: LLMs often produce coherent but untrue outputs, and current hallucination benchmarks are static, narrow, and biased (e.g., toward popular facts), yielding misleading assessments. There is a need for a scalable, coverage-rich, and difficulty-aware way to measure LLM truthfulness across breadth and depth of knowledge.
AI.method: Use a knowledge graph to dynamically generate challenging, multi-faceted questions; statistically estimate question difficulty to reduce popularity bias; employ an automated verification pipeline that detects abstentions and checks answers at conceptual and factual-correctness levels to categorize hallucination types; introduce new accuracy and hallucination metrics.
AI.result: Applied to 25 frontier LLMs, the benchmark yields interpretable measurements and insights into which knowledge factors and model sizes correlate with different hallucination behaviors. (No specific numbers reported in the abstract.)
AI.conclusion: KGHaluBench offers a fairer, more comprehensive view of LLM truthfulness and is publicly released to facilitate research on hallucination diagnosis and mitigation.

title: OptiRepair: Closed-Loop Diagnosis and Repair of Supply Chain Optimization Models with LLM Agents
summary:
Problem Definition. Supply chain optimization models frequently become infeasible because of modeling errors. Diagnosis and repair require scarce OR expertise: analysts must interpret solver diagnostics, trace root causes across echelons, and fix formulations without sacrificing operational soundness. Whether AI agents can perform this task remains untested.
  Methodology/Results. OptiRepair splits this task into a domain-agnostic feasibility phase (iterative IIS-guided repair of any LP) and a domain-specific validation phase (five rationality checks grounded in inventory theory). We test 22 API models from 7 families on 976 multi-echelon supply chain problems and train two 8B-parameter models using self-taught reasoning with solver-verified rewards. The trained models reach 81.7% Rational Recovery Rate (RRR) -- the fraction of problems resolved to both feasibility and operational rationality -- versus 42.2% for the best API model and 21.3% on average. The gap concentrates in Phase 1 repair: API models average 27.6% recovery rate versus 97.2% for trained models.
  Managerial Implications. Two gaps separate current AI from reliable model repair: solver interaction (API models restore only 27.6% of infeasible formulations) and operational rationale (roughly one in four feasible repairs violate supply chain theory). Each requires a different intervention: solver interaction responds to targeted training; operational rationale requires explicit specification as solver-verifiable checks. For organizations adopting AI in operational planning, formalizing what "rational" means in their context is the higher-return investment.

AI.tldr: OptiRepair trains 8B-parameter AI agents to iteratively fix infeasible LP-based supply-chain models via solver-guided (IIS) edits and then enforce domain rationality with inventory-theory checks, achieving 81.7% Rational Recovery Rate—nearly doubling the best API model—with most gains from the feasibility-repair phase.
AI.motivation: Supply-chain optimization models often fail due to formulation errors, and diagnosing/repairing infeasibilities requires scarce OR expertise. The authors ask whether AI agents can assume this role reliably without sacrificing operational soundness.
AI.method: Two-phase pipeline: (1) domain-agnostic feasibility repair using iterative IIS-guided modifications applicable to any LP; (2) domain-specific validation via five solver-verifiable rationality checks grounded in inventory theory. They evaluate 22 off-the-shelf API models across 7 model families on 976 multi-echelon problems and train two 8B models using self-taught reasoning with solver-verified rewards.
AI.result: Trained models reach 81.7% Rational Recovery Rate (feasible and rational) vs 42.2% for the best API model (21.3% average). The largest gap is in Phase 1: API models recover 27.6% vs 97.2% for trained models; roughly one in four feasible repairs from baseline models fail rationality checks.
AI.conclusion: Targeted training for solver interaction is key to repairing infeasible optimizations; operational rationality must be explicitly specified as solver-verifiable checks. For practitioners, formalizing what counts as “rational” in their setting yields higher returns than relying on generic AI alone.

title: SceneTok: A Compressed, Diffusable Token Space for 3D Scenes
summary: We present SceneTok, a novel tokenizer for encoding view sets of scenes into a compressed and diffusable set of unstructured tokens. Existing approaches for 3D scene representation and generation commonly use 3D data structures or view-aligned fields. In contrast, we introduce the first method that encodes scene information into a small set of permutation-invariant tokens that is disentangled from the spatial grid. The scene tokens are predicted by a multi-view tokenizer given many context views and rendered into novel views by employing a light-weight rectified flow decoder. We show that the compression is 1-3 orders of magnitude stronger than for other representations while still reaching state-of-the-art reconstruction quality. Further, our representation can be rendered from novel trajectories, including ones deviating from the input trajectory, and we show that the decoder gracefully handles uncertainty. Finally, the highly-compressed set of unstructured latent scene tokens enables simple and efficient scene generation in 5 seconds, achieving a much better quality-speed trade-off than previous paradigms.

AI.tldr: SceneTok encodes a set of multi-view images of a 3D scene into a tiny, permutation-invariant set of unstructured tokens, then decodes them with a lightweight rectified-flow model to render novel views and generate scenes, achieving 10–1000× higher compression with state-of-the-art reconstruction and fast (≈5 s) generation.
AI.motivation: Prevailing 3D scene representations (e.g., voxel grids, tri-planes, NeRF-like fields, view-aligned features) are tied to spatial structures that are memory-heavy, slower to render or generate, and awkward to diffuse/generate. The paper seeks a compact, generative-friendly, permutation-invariant representation disentangled from spatial grids to improve compression, speed, and flexibility for novel view synthesis and scene generation.
AI.method: A multi-view tokenizer consumes many context views and outputs a small set of permutation-invariant latent scene tokens (unstructured and grid-free). A lightweight rectified flow decoder renders novel views from these tokens. The latent tokens are designed to be diffusable for generative tasks; rendering supports trajectories beyond the input path and the decoder models uncertainty.
AI.result: Compared to existing representations, SceneTok achieves 1–3 orders of magnitude stronger compression while maintaining state-of-the-art reconstruction quality. It enables rendering from novel and deviating camera trajectories with uncertainty-aware decoding. The compact token set allows simple, efficient scene generation in about 5 seconds, providing a superior quality–speed trade-off to prior paradigms.
AI.conclusion: Unstructured, permutation-invariant scene tokens constitute an effective alternative to grid- or view-aligned 3D representations, delivering extreme compression, SOTA reconstruction, robust novel-view rendering, and fast generative capabilities. This suggests a practical path toward scalable, efficient 3D scene reconstruction and generation from compact latents.

title: Keyboards for the Endangered Idu Mishmi Language
summary: We present a mobile and desktop keyboard suite for Idu Mishmi, an endangered Trans-Himalayan language spoken by approximately 11,000 people in Arunachal Pradesh, India. Although a Latin-based orthography was developed in 2018, no digital input tools existed to use it, forcing speakers into ad-hoc romanizations that cannot represent the full writing system. Our keyboards comprise two tools: (1) an Android mobile keyboard, published on the Google Play Store and actively used in teacher training programs, and (2) a Windows desktop keyboard currently undergoing community testing. Both tools support the complete Idu Mishmi character inventory, including schwa, retracted schwa, nasalized vowels, and accented forms. Both operate fully offline with zero network permissions, addressing connectivity constraints and data sovereignty concerns. We describe the design, implementation, and deployment as a replicable model for other endangered language communities.

AI.tldr: They built and deployed offline mobile and desktop keyboards that fully support the 2018 Latin-based Idu Mishmi orthography, closing a critical input gap and offering a replicable model for other endangered languages.
AI.motivation: Idu Mishmi speakers lacked digital input tools for their newly standardized Latin orthography, forcing lossy ad‑hoc romanizations. Connectivity constraints and data sovereignty concerns also necessitated offline, permission-minimal solutions.
AI.method: Design and implementation of two keyboards: (1) an Android keyboard released on Google Play and used in teacher training; (2) a Windows desktop keyboard in community testing. Both encode the full character inventory (schwa, retracted schwa, nasalized vowels, accented forms) and run entirely offline with zero network permissions. The paper details design choices, implementation, and deployment to serve as a template for similar communities.
AI.result: A functioning Android keyboard in active educational use and a Windows keyboard under community testing; both cover the complete orthographic inventory and operate fully offline to meet connectivity and sovereignty requirements.
AI.conclusion: Purpose-built, offline keyboards can bridge critical digital gaps for endangered languages and provide a practical, replicable blueprint for other communities seeking secure, complete input methods aligned with their orthographies.

title: ComplLLM: Fine-tuning LLMs to Discover Complementary Signals for Decision-making
summary: Multi-agent decision pipelines can outperform single agent workflows when complementarity holds, i.e., different agents bring unique information to the table to inform a final decision. We propose ComplLLM, a post-training framework based on decision theory that fine-tunes a decision-assistant LLM using complementary information as reward to output signals that complement existing agent decisions. We validate ComplLLM on synthetic and real-world tasks involving domain experts, demonstrating how the approach recovers known complementary information and produces plausible explanations of complementary signals to support downstream decision-makers.

AI.tldr: ComplLLM is a decision-theoretic post-training method that fine-tunes an LLM to produce signals that complement other agents, improving multi-agent decision pipelines; validated on synthetic and real-world expert tasks, it recovers complementary information and provides plausible explanations.
