AI.motivation: Single-agent workflows can miss gains available when multiple agents contribute non-overlapping information. Existing LLM assistants may be redundant rather than complementary. The goal is to systematically train an LLM to add unique, decision-relevant signals that improve final decisions in multi-agent settings and support human decision-makers.
AI.method: ComplLLM: a post-training framework grounded in decision theory that uses complementary information as the reward signal to fine-tune a decision-assistant LLM. The model is optimized to output signals that specifically complement existing agent decisions and to produce explanations of those signals.
AI.result: On synthetic and real-world tasks involving domain experts, ComplLLM recovers known complementary information and generates plausible explanations of its contributions, indicating effective complementarity relative to existing agents (no specific metrics reported in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Optimizing LLMs for complementarity can enhance multi-agent decision pipelines. ComplLLM offers a practical way to make an LLM add non-redundant, explainable value alongside other agents, thereby supporting downstream decision-makers.

title: PhysConvex: Physics-Informed 3D Dynamic Convex Radiance Fields for Reconstruction and Simulation
summary: Reconstructing and simulating dynamic 3D scenes with both visual realism and physical consistency remains a fundamental challenge. Existing neural representations, such as NeRFs and 3DGS, excel in appearance reconstruction but struggle to capture complex material deformation and dynamics. We propose PhysConvex, a Physics-informed 3D Dynamic Convex Radiance Field that unifies visual rendering and physical simulation. PhysConvex represents deformable radiance fields using physically grounded convex primitives governed by continuum mechanics. We introduce a boundary-driven dynamic convex representation that models deformation through vertex and surface dynamics, capturing spatially adaptive, non-uniform deformation, and evolving boundaries. To efficiently simulate complex geometries and heterogeneous materials, we further develop a reduced-order convex simulation that advects dynamic convex fields using neural skinning eigenmodes as shape- and material-aware deformation bases with time-varying reduced DOFs under Newtonian dynamics. Convex dynamics also offers compact, gap-free volumetric coverage, enhancing both geometric efficiency and simulation fidelity. Experiments demonstrate that PhysConvex achieves high-fidelity reconstruction of geometry, appearance, and physical properties from videos, outperforming existing methods.

AI.tldr: PhysConvex is a physics-informed dynamic 3D radiance field that represents scenes with deformable convex primitives, enabling joint photo-realistic rendering and physically consistent simulation, and outperforming NeRF/3DGS-style baselines on dynamic, deforming scenes.
AI.motivation: Neural radiance methods reconstruct appearance well but fail to capture complex material deformation, non-uniform dynamics, and evolving boundaries. The goal is to couple visual fidelity with physically grounded behavior to reconstruct not only how a scene looks but how it moves and responds to forces.
AI.method: Represent the scene as a set of physically grounded convex primitives forming a deformable radiance field. Introduce a boundary-driven dynamic convex representation where vertex/surface dynamics capture spatially adaptive, non-uniform deformation and changing topology/boundaries. Develop a reduced-order convex simulation that advects these primitives using neural skinning eigenmodes as material- and shape-aware bases, with time-varying reduced degrees of freedom governed by Newtonian dynamics. Convex coverage ensures compact, gap-free volumetrics, aiding both rendering and simulation.
AI.result: From video input, the method reconstructs geometry, appearance, and physical properties and shows higher fidelity and better physical consistency than prior neural representations (e.g., NeRFs, 3D Gaussian Splatting) on benchmarks and qualitative tests.
AI.conclusion: Coupling convex-primitive radiance fields with reduced-order, continuum-mechanics-based dynamics provides an efficient, physically consistent, and visually accurate representation for dynamic scenes, handling complex deformations and heterogeneous materials better than existing approaches.

title: SAMAS: A Spectrum-Guided Multi-Agent System for Achieving Style Fidelity in Literary Translation
summary: Modern large language models (LLMs) excel at generating fluent and faithful translations. However, they struggle to preserve an author's unique literary style, often producing semantically correct but generic outputs. This limitation stems from the inability of current single-model and static multi-agent systems to perceive and adapt to stylistic variations. To address this, we introduce the Style-Adaptive Multi-Agent System (SAMAS), a novel framework that treats style preservation as a signal processing task. Specifically, our method quantifies literary style into a Stylistic Feature Spectrum (SFS) using the wavelet packet transform. This SFS serves as a control signal to dynamically assemble a tailored workflow of specialized translation agents based on the source text's structural patterns. Extensive experiments on translation benchmarks show that SAMAS achieves competitive semantic accuracy against strong baselines, primarily by leveraging its statistically significant advantage in style fidelity.

AI.tldr: SAMAS is a style-aware translation framework that quantifies literary style via a wavelet-based Stylistic Feature Spectrum and uses it to dynamically orchestrate specialized translation agents, achieving on-par semantic accuracy with significantly better style fidelity than strong baselines.
AI.motivation: LLMs produce semantically correct but stylistically generic translations because single-model and static multi-agent setups cannot perceive or adapt to varied literary styles. The work aims to preserve an author's unique style while maintaining semantic faithfulness.
AI.method: Treat style preservation as a signal processing problem. Derive a Stylistic Feature Spectrum (SFS) from source text using the wavelet packet transform. Use the SFS as a control signal to assemble a task-specific workflow of specialized translation agents that match the source text’s structural and stylistic patterns.
AI.result: On standard translation benchmarks, SAMAS matches strong baselines on semantic accuracy and shows a statistically significant improvement in style fidelity, indicating better preservation of authorial voice.
AI.conclusion: Quantifying style with wavelet-based features and using it to drive a dynamic multi-agent translation pipeline effectively preserves literary style without sacrificing meaning. The approach bridges signal processing with LLM orchestration and offers a promising direction for style-aware machine translation.

title: Human-Guided Agentic AI for Multimodal Clinical Prediction: Lessons from the AgentDS Healthcare Benchmark
comment: Submitted to the Data Challenge track at the 14th IEEE International Conference on Healthcare Informatics (ICHI) 2026
summary: Agentic AI systems are increasingly capable of autonomous data science workflows, yet clinical prediction tasks demand domain expertise that purely automated approaches struggle to provide. We investigate how human guidance of agentic AI can improve multimodal clinical prediction, presenting our approach to all three AgentDS Healthcare benchmark challenges: 30-day hospital readmission prediction (Macro-F1 = 0.8986), emergency department cost forecasting (MAE = $465.13), and discharge readiness assessment (Macro-F1 = 0.7939). Across these tasks, human analysts directed the agentic workflow at key decision points, multimodal feature engineering from clinical notes, scanned PDF billing receipts, and time-series vital signs; task-appropriate model selection; and clinically informed validation strategies. Our approach ranked 5th overall in the healthcare domain, with a 3rd-place finish on the discharge readiness task. Ablation studies reveal that human-guided decisions compounded to a cumulative gain of +0.065 F1 over automated baselines, with multimodal feature extraction contributing the largest single improvement (+0.041 F1). We distill three generalizable lessons: (1) domain-informed feature engineering at each pipeline stage yields compounding gains that outperform extensive automated search; (2) multimodal data integration requires task-specific human judgment that no single extraction strategy generalizes across clinical text, PDFs, and time-series; and (3) deliberate ensemble diversity with clinically motivated model configurations outperforms random hyperparameter search. These findings offer practical guidance for teams deploying agentic AI in healthcare settings where interpretability, reproducibility, and clinical validity are essential.

AI.tldr: Human-guided agentic AI outperforms purely automated approaches on multimodal clinical prediction in the AgentDS Healthcare benchmark, achieving top-5 overall performance and demonstrating cumulative gains (+0.065 F1) from domain-informed decisions—especially multimodal feature extraction (+0.041 F1).
AI.motivation: Purely automated agentic AI lacks the domain expertise and clinical judgment needed for high-stakes prediction tasks that demand interpretability, reproducibility, and clinical validity. The study tests whether structured human guidance can close this gap on real, multimodal clinical data.
AI.method: Human analysts steered an agentic workflow at key decision points: (1) task-specific multimodal feature engineering from clinical notes, scanned PDF billing receipts, and time-series vital signs; (2) clinically informed validation strategies; and (3) model/ensemble selection emphasizing deliberate, clinically motivated diversity. Performance was evaluated on three AgentDS Healthcare tasks, with ablation studies quantifying the contribution of human-guided choices.
AI.result: Performance: 30-day readmission Macro-F1=0.8986; ED cost forecasting MAE=$465.13; discharge readiness Macro-F1=0.7939. Leaderboard: 5th overall, 3rd on discharge readiness. Ablations: human-guided decisions yield +0.065 F1 over automated baselines; multimodal feature extraction provides the largest single gain (+0.041 F1).
AI.conclusion: Human-in-the-loop guidance compounds improvements across the pipeline and outperforms extensive automated search. Effective deployment requires (1) domain-informed feature engineering at each stage, (2) task-specific strategies for integrating text, PDFs, and time-series (no single extractor fits all), and (3) deliberate ensemble diversity with clinically motivated configurations—principles that support interpretable, reproducible, and clinically valid AI in healthcare.

title: SafeDrive: Fine-Grained Safety Reasoning for End-to-End Driving in a Sparse World
summary: The end-to-end (E2E) paradigm, which maps sensor inputs directly to driving decisions, has recently attracted significant attention due to its unified modeling capability and scalability. However, ensuring safety in this unified framework remains one of the most critical challenges. In this work, we propose SafeDrive, an E2E planning framework designed to perform explicit and interpretable safety reasoning through a trajectory-conditioned Sparse World Model. SafeDrive comprises two complementary networks: the Sparse World Network (SWNet) and the Fine-grained Reasoning Network (FRNet). SWNet constructs trajectory-conditioned sparse worlds that simulate the future behaviors of critical dynamic agents and road entities, providing interaction-centric representations for downstream reasoning. FRNet then evaluates agent-specific collision risks and temporal adherence to drivable regions, enabling precise identification of safety-critical events across future timesteps. SafeDrive achieves state-of-the-art performance on both open-loop and closed-loop benchmarks. On NAVSIM, it records a PDMS of 91.6 and an EPDMS of 87.5, with only 61 collisions out of 12,146 scenarios (0.5%). On Bench2Drive, SafeDrive attains a 66.8% driving score.

AI.tldr: SafeDrive is an end-to-end driving planner that adds explicit, interpretable safety reasoning via a trajectory‑conditioned Sparse World Model. It uses SWNet to simulate future, interaction‑centric sparse scenes and FRNet to score collision and drivable‑area risks over time, achieving state‑of‑the‑art results with very low collision rates on NAVSIM and strong closed‑loop performance on Bench2Drive.
AI.motivation: End-to-end (sensor‑to‑decision) driving scales well but struggles to guarantee and explain safety. The paper aims to embed explicit, interpretable safety reasoning within an E2E planner so that safety‑critical interactions are modeled and risks are auditable rather than implicit in a monolithic network.
AI.method: Introduce a trajectory‑conditioned Sparse World Model comprising two networks: (1) SWNet constructs sparse, interaction‑centric world states by predicting future behaviors of critical agents and road entities conditioned on the candidate ego trajectory; (2) FRNet performs fine‑grained reasoning on these sparse worlds to estimate agent‑specific collision risks and temporal adherence to drivable regions across future timesteps, enabling identification of safety‑critical events for planning.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance in both open‑loop and closed‑loop settings. On NAVSIM: PDMS 91.6 and EPDMS 87.5 with 61 collisions in 12,146 scenarios (≈0.5%). On Bench2Drive: 66.8% driving score. The approach outperforms prior E2E baselines per reported metrics.
AI.conclusion: Explicit safety reasoning layered into an E2E planner improves safety and interpretability without sacrificing scalability. SafeDrive’s sparse, trajectory‑conditioned world modeling plus risk evaluation yields low collision rates and strong driving scores, suggesting a practical path toward safer, more auditable E2E autonomy; future work likely targets broader scenarios and real‑world validation.

title: SHIELD: Semantic Heterogeneity Integrated Embedding for Latent Discovery in Clinical Trial Safety Signals
summary: We present SHIELD, a novel methodology for automated and integrated safety signal detection in clinical trials. SHIELD combines disproportionality analysis with semantic clustering of adverse event (AE) terms applied to MedDRA term embeddings. For each AE, the pipeline computes an information-theoretic disproportionality measure (Information Component) with effect size derived via empirical Bayesian shrinkage. A utility matrix is constructed by weighting semantic term-term similarities by signal magnitude, followed by spectral embedding and clustering to identify groups of related AEs. Resulting clusters are annotated with syndrome-level summary labels using large language models, yielding a coherent, data-driven representation of treatment-associated safety profiles in the form of a network graph and hierarchical tree. We implement the SHIELD framework in the context of a single-arm incidence summary, to compare two treatment arms or for the detection of any treatment effect in a multi-arm trial. We illustrate its ability to recover known safety signals and generate interpretable, cluster-based summaries in a real clinical trial example. This work bridges statistical signal detection with modern natural language processing to enhance safety assessment and causal interpretation in clinical trials.

AI.tldr: SHIELD is an automated pipeline that detects and summarizes safety signals in clinical trials by combining empirical‑Bayes disproportionality (Information Component) with semantic clustering of MedDRA‑embedded adverse events, then uses LLMs to label clusters, producing interpretable network and hierarchical summaries that recover known signals across single-, two-, and multi‑arm settings.
AI.motivation: Safety review of adverse events is fragmented and labor‑intensive, with sparse counts, synonymy, and taxonomy granularity obscuring true signals. There is a need to connect statistical signal strength with clinically coherent groupings to improve detection, interpretation, and communication of treatment‑related risks.
AI.method: For each AE, compute an information‑theoretic disproportionality measure (Information Component) with empirical‑Bayes shrinkage. Build a utility matrix by weighting pairwise semantic similarities (from MedDRA term embeddings) by signal magnitude. Apply spectral embedding and clustering to form groups of related AEs. Use large language models to assign concise syndrome‑level labels to clusters. Output treatment‑associated safety profiles as a network graph and hierarchical tree; support single‑arm incidence summaries, arm‑to‑arm comparisons, and multi‑arm trials.
AI.result: In a real clinical trial example, SHIELD recovered known safety signals and generated coherent, interpretable cluster‑based summaries of AEs. The framework demonstrated applicability for different trial designs (single-, two-, and multi‑arm) and produced data‑driven visual representations of safety profiles.
AI.conclusion: By unifying empirical‑Bayes disproportionality statistics with NLP‑based semantic clustering and LLM labeling, SHIELD provides scalable, interpretable, and integrated safety signal detection that can enhance safety assessment workflows and aid causal interpretation in clinical trials.

title: Classroom Final Exam: An Instructor-Tested Reasoning Benchmark
summary: We introduce \CFE{} (\textbf{C}lassroom \textbf{F}inal \textbf{E}xam), a multimodal benchmark for evaluating the reasoning capabilities of large language models across more than 20 STEM domains. \CFE{} is curated from repeatedly used, authentic university homework and exam problems, together with reference solutions provided by course instructors. \CFE{} presents a significant challenge even for frontier models: the newly released Gemini-3.1-pro-preview achieves an overall accuracy of 59.69\%, while the second-best model, Gemini-3-flash-preview, reaches 55.46\%, leaving considerable room for improvement. Beyond leaderboard results, we perform a diagnostic analysis by decomposing reference solutions into reasoning flows. We find that although frontier models can often answer intermediate sub-questions correctly, they struggle to reliably derive and maintain correct intermediate states throughout multi-step solutions. We further observe that model-generated solutions typically have more reasoning steps than those provided by the instructor, indicating suboptimal step efficiency and a higher risk of error accumulation. The data and code are available at https://github.com/Analogy-AI/CFE_Bench.

AI.tldr: CFE is a new multimodal benchmark of authentic university STEM problems showing frontier LLMs still struggle with multi-step reasoning—best model ≈59.7% accuracy—and revealing inefficiencies and instability in maintaining correct intermediate states.
AI.motivation: Provide a rigorous, realistic, and broad evaluation of LLM reasoning across 20+ STEM domains, moving beyond simple QA to diagnose where multi-step reasoning breaks (especially maintenance of intermediate states and step efficiency).
AI.method: Curate repeatedly used, real university homework and exam problems with instructor reference solutions to build a multimodal benchmark; evaluate multiple state-of-the-art models; decompose instructor solutions into reasoning flows to analyze intermediate sub-steps, state maintenance, and step counts; compare model- vs instructor-style solution trajectories.
AI.result: Overall accuracies are modest: Gemini-3.1-pro-preview reaches 59.69%, Gemini-3-flash-preview 55.46%. Models can often answer sub-questions but fail to reliably derive and carry forward correct intermediate states across steps; model solutions typically use more steps than instructors, implying inefficiency and increased error accumulation risk.
AI.conclusion: CFE is a challenging, realistic benchmark that exposes key weaknesses in current LLMs: unstable intermediate-state reasoning and suboptimal step efficiency. There remains substantial headroom for progress; the released data/code enable further research and targeted improvements.

title: Beyond Stationarity: Rethinking Codebook Collapse in Vector Quantization
summary: Vector Quantization (VQ) underpins many modern generative frameworks such as VQ-VAE, VQ-GAN, and latent diffusion models. Yet, it suffers from the persistent problem of codebook collapse, where a large fraction of code vectors remains unused during training. This work provides a new theoretical explanation by identifying the nonstationary nature of encoder updates as the fundamental cause of this phenomenon. We show that as the encoder drifts, unselected code vectors fail to receive updates and gradually become inactive. To address this, we propose two new methods: Non-Stationary Vector Quantization (NSVQ), which propagates encoder drift to non-selected codes through a kernel-based rule, and Transformer-based Vector Quantization (TransVQ), which employs a lightweight mapping to adaptively transform the entire codebook while preserving convergence to the k-means solution. Experiments on the CelebA-HQ dataset demonstrate that both methods achieve near-complete codebook utilization and superior reconstruction quality compared to baseline VQ variants, providing a principled and scalable foundation for future VQ-based generative models. The code is available at: https://github.com/CAIR- LAB- WFUSM/NSVQ-TransVQ.git

AI.tldr: Identifies encoder drift as the root cause of VQ codebook collapse and proposes two fixes—NSVQ (kernel-propagated updates to unused codes) and TransVQ (adaptive codebook transform)—that yield near-complete code usage and better reconstructions on CelebA-HQ.
AI.motivation: VQ-based generative models frequently waste a large portion of their codebooks (codebook collapse), hurting capacity and quality. Prior fixes (e.g., EMA updates, code resets) lack a principled explanation and can still leave many codes unused. The paper aims to explain the collapse mechanistically and design methods that prevent it without sacrificing k-means consistency or scalability.
AI.method: 1) Diagnose the cause: nonstationary encoder updates make assignments drift over training, leaving some codes unselected and thus never updated. 2) NSVQ: when selected codes move due to encoder drift, propagate that drift to nearby unselected codes via a kernel-based rule so they do not stagnate. 3) TransVQ: learn a lightweight mapping (transformer-like) that adaptively transforms the entire codebook in sync with encoder changes while preserving convergence to the k-means solution.
AI.result: On CelebA-HQ, both NSVQ and TransVQ achieve near-complete codebook utilization and improved reconstruction quality over baseline VQ variants.
AI.conclusion: Nonstationarity in the encoder is a fundamental driver of codebook collapse. Propagating encoder drift to all codes (NSVQ) or applying a global adaptive transform to the codebook (TransVQ) mitigates collapse, improves utilization and reconstructions, and offers a scalable, principled path for future VQ-based generative models.

title: Axis Decomposition for ODRL: Resolving Dimensional Ambiguity in Policy Constraints through Interval Semantics
summary:
Every ODRL 2.2 constraint compares a single scalar value: (leftOperand, operator, rightOperand). Five of ODRL's approximately 34 left operands, however, denote multi-dimensional quantities--image dimensions, canvas positions, geographic coordinates--whose specification text explicitly references multiple axes. For these operands, a single scalar constraint admits one interpretation per axis, making policy evaluation non-deterministic.
  We classify ODRL's left operands by value-domain structure (scalar, dimensional, concept-valued), grounded in the ODRL 2.2 specification text, and show that dimensional ambiguity is intrinsic to the constraint syntax.
  We present an axis-decomposition framework that refines each dimensional operand into axis-specific scalar operands and prove four properties: deterministic interpretation, AABB completeness, sound over-approximation under projection, and conservative extension.
  Conflict detection operates in two layers: per-axis verdicts are always decidable; box-level verdicts compose through Strong Kleene conjunction into a three-valued logic (Conflict, Compatible, Unknown). For ODRL's disjunctive (odrl:or) and exclusive-or (odrl:xone) logical constraints, where per-axis decomposition does not apply, the framework encodes coupled multi-axis conjectures directly.
  We instantiate the framework as the ODRL Spatial Axis Profile--15 axis-specific left operands for the five affected base terms--and evaluate it on 117 benchmark problems spanning nine categories across both TPTP FOF (Vampire) and SMT-LIB (Z3) encodings, achieving full concordance between provers. Benchmark scenarios are inspired by constraints arising in cultural heritage dataspaces such as Datenraum Kultur. All meta-theorems are mechanically verified in Isabelle/HOL.

AI.tldr: ODRL 2.2’s scalar constraint form becomes ambiguous for multi-axis operands (e.g., image size, positions, geocoordinates). The paper classifies operand value domains, introduces an axis-decomposition into per-axis scalar operands (ODRL Spatial Axis Profile), proves determinism and related properties, and validates with dual prover encodings and Isabelle/HOL proofs.
AI.motivation: ODRL policies involving inherently multidimensional quantities yield non-deterministic evaluations because the syntax compares only single scalars. This threatens interoperability, decidability, and correctness in real-world dataspaces (e.g., cultural heritage). A principled way to make such constraints deterministic and checkable is needed.
AI.method: 1) Classify ODRL left operands by value-domain (scalar, dimensional, concept-valued) from the spec. 2) Refine each dimensional operand into axis-specific scalar operands (axis decomposition). 3) Prove properties: deterministic interpretation, AABB completeness, sound over-approximation under projection, conservative extension. 4) Design two-layer conflict detection: per-axis decidable checks; compose box-level outcomes via Strong Kleene three-valued logic; directly encode coupled multi-axis conjectures for odrl:or and odrl:xone. 5) Instantiate as ODRL Spatial Axis Profile (15 axis-specific operands for 5 base terms). 6) Validate with 117 benchmarks across 9 categories in both TPTP FOF (Vampire) and SMT-LIB (Z3), and mechanically verify metatheorems in Isabelle/HOL.
AI.result: - Eliminates ambiguity: guarantees deterministic interpretation for dimensional operands. - Demonstrates AABB completeness and conservative extension to ODRL. - Shows sound over-approximation when projecting to axes. - Achieves full concordance between Vampire and Z3 on 117 benchmarks. - Mechanically checks meta-theorems in Isabelle/HOL. - Provides encodings for disjunctive/xor constraints when decomposition is not applicable.
AI.conclusion: Dimensional ambiguity is intrinsic to ODRL’s scalar constraint syntax. Axis-specific scalar operands resolve it while preserving ODRL compatibility and decidability. The Spatial Axis Profile operationalizes the approach and is validated both empirically (benchmarks) and formally (Isabelle). The framework is ready for adoption in domains like cultural heritage dataspaces and suggests a path to standardize multidimensional constraints in ODRL.

title: Ada-RS: Adaptive Rejection Sampling for Selective Thinking
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly being deployed in cost and latency-sensitive settings. While chain-of-thought improves reasoning, it can waste tokens on simple requests. We study selective thinking for tool-using LLMs and introduce Adaptive Rejection Sampling (Ada-RS), an algorithm-agnostic sample filtering framework for learning selective and efficient reasoning. For each given context, Ada-RS scores multiple sampled completions with an adaptive length-penalized reward then applies stochastic rejection sampling to retain only high-reward candidates (or preference pairs) for downstream optimization. We demonstrate how Ada-RS plugs into both preference pair (e.g. DPO) or grouped policy optimization strategies (e.g. DAPO). Using Qwen3-8B with LoRA on a synthetic tool call-oriented e-commerce benchmark, Ada-RS improves the accuracy-efficiency frontier over standard algorithms by reducing average output tokens by up to 80% and reducing thinking rate by up to 95% while maintaining or improving tool call accuracy. These results highlight that training-signal selection is a powerful lever for efficient reasoning in latency-sensitive deployments.

AI.tldr: Ada-RS is a training-time, algorithm-agnostic filtering method that teaches tool-using LLMs to reason selectively—rewarding shorter yet accurate outputs—thereby cutting tokens and latency without sacrificing tool-call correctness.
AI.motivation: Chain-of-thought often over-expends tokens on easy queries, which is costly in latency- and budget-constrained deployments, especially for tool-using LLMs. Existing optimization methods don’t explicitly prefer concise, sufficient reasoning, so models may learn to “overthink.”
AI.method: For each context, sample multiple completions. Score them with an adaptive reward that penalizes length while capturing task success, then apply stochastic rejection sampling to keep only high-reward candidates (or preference pairs). Plug this filtered data into preference learning (e.g., DPO) or grouped policy optimization (e.g., DAPO). Evaluated by finetuning Qwen3-8B (LoRA) on a synthetic e-commerce tool-calling benchmark.
AI.result: Relative to standard algorithms, Ada-RS reduced average output tokens by up to 80% and the fraction of prompts that trigger extended reasoning by up to 95%, while maintaining or improving tool-call accuracy on the benchmark.
AI.conclusion: Selecting training signals via adaptive, length-aware rejection sampling effectively instills selective reasoning, improving the accuracy–efficiency trade-off for latency-sensitive tool-using LLM applications.

title: SCHEMA for Gemini 3 Pro Image: A Structured Methodology for Controlled AI Image Generation on Google's Native Multimodal Model
comment: 24 pages, 8 tables. Based on SCHEMA Method v1.0 (deposited December 11, 2025). Previously published on Zenodo: doi:10.5281/zenodo.18721380
summary: This paper presents SCHEMA (Structured Components for Harmonized Engineered Modular Architecture), a structured prompt engineering methodology specifically developed for Google Gemini 3 Pro Image. Unlike generic prompt guidelines or model-agnostic tips, SCHEMA is an engineered framework built on systematic professional practice encompassing 850 verified API predictions within an estimated corpus of approximately 4,800 generated images, spanning six professional domains: real estate photography, commercial product photography, editorial content, storyboards, commercial campaigns, and information design. The methodology introduces a three-tier progressive system (BASE, MEDIO, AVANZATO) that scales practitioner control from exploratory (approximately 5%) to directive (approximately 95%), a modular label architecture with 7 core and 5 optional structured components, a decision tree with explicit routing rules to alternative tools, and systematically documented model limitations with corresponding workarounds. Key findings include an observed 91% Mandatory compliance rate and 94% Prohibitions compliance rate across 621 structured prompts, a comparative batch consistency test demonstrating substantially higher inter-generation coherence for structured prompts, independent practitioner validation (n=40), and a dedicated Information Design validation demonstrating >95% first-generation compliance for spatial and typographical control across approximately 300 publicly verifiable infographics. Previously published on Zenodo (doi:10.5281/zenodo.18721380).

AI.tldr: SCHEMA is a structured, model-specific prompt-engineering framework for Google Gemini 3 Pro Image that uses a three-tier control system and modular labels to boost compliance, consistency, and layout control across professional visual domains, with high measured compliance and strong results in information design tasks.
AI.motivation: Practitioners need predictable, controllable, and repeatable image generation for professional use cases; generic prompt tips are insufficient. The work aims to engineer a disciplined, model-tailored framework that improves compliance with instructions, inter-generation consistency, and provides workarounds for known model limitations, including guidance on when to route to alternative tools.
AI.method: Design a three-tier progressive control system (BASE, MEDIO, AVANZATO) ranging from exploratory (~5%) to directive (~95%); define a modular label architecture with 7 core and 5 optional components; create a decision tree with routing rules to other tools; catalog model limitations and workarounds. Empirically evaluate using 850 verified API predictions over ~4,800 generated images across six domains; assess 621 structured prompts for Mandatory/Prohibitions compliance; run a batch consistency test; conduct independent practitioner validation (n=40); and perform a dedicated Information Design study (~300 public infographics) for spatial/typographic control.
AI.result: Observed 91% compliance for Mandatory requirements and 94% for Prohibitions across 621 structured prompts; structured prompts yielded substantially higher inter-generation coherence in batch tests; independent practitioner validation (n=40) supported effectiveness; information design validation showed >95% first-generation compliance for spatial and typographic constraints across ~300 public infographics.
AI.conclusion: A model-tailored, structured prompting methodology can significantly improve directive control, compliance, and batch consistency for Gemini 3 Pro Image, particularly in information design. SCHEMA offers a practical, modular workflow and tooling guidance for professional image generation. While results are strong within the tested setup, broader generalizability beyond this model and transparent statistical details would strengthen claims.

title: Denotational Semantics for ODRL: Knowledge-Based Constraint Conflict Detection
comment: 17 pages, 6 tables. Working draft. Supplementary material (154 TPTP/SMT-LIB benchmarks, Isabelle/HOL theory file) will be made available at https://github.com/Daham-Mustaf/odrl-benchmark upon publication
summary: ODRL's six set-based operators -- isA, isPartOf, hasPart, isAnyOf, isAllOf, isNoneOf -- depend on external domain knowledge that the W3C specification leaves unspecified. Without it, every cross-dataspace policy comparison defaults to Unknown. We present a denotational semantics that maps each ODRL constraint to the set of knowledge-base concepts satisfying it. Conflict detection reduces to denotation intersection under a three-valued verdict -- Conflict, Compatible, or Unknown -- that is sound under incomplete knowledge. The framework covers all three ODRL composition modes (and, or, xone) and all three semantic domains arising in practice: taxonomic (class subsumption), mereological (part-whole containment), and nominal (identity). For cross-dataspace interoperability, we define order-preserving alignments between knowledge bases and prove two guarantees: conflicts are preserved across different KB standards, and unmapped concepts degrade gracefully to Unknown -- never to false conflicts. A runtime soundness theorem ensures that design-time verdicts hold for all execution contexts. The encoding stays within the decidable EPR fragment of first-order logic. We validate it with 154 benchmarks across six knowledge base families (GeoNames, ISO 3166, W3C DPV, a GDPR-derived taxonomy, BCP 47, and ISO 639-3) and four structural KBs targeting adversarial edge cases. Both the Vampire theorem prover and the Z3 SMT solver agree on all 154 verdicts. A key finding is that exclusive composition (xone) requires strictly stronger KB axioms than conjunction or disjunction: open-world semantics blocks exclusivity even when positive evidence appears to satisfy exactly one branch.

AI.tldr: Formalizes ODRL’s set-based constraints via denotational semantics grounded in external knowledge bases, enabling sound three-valued conflict detection and cross-dataspace interoperability; encoded in decidable EPR and empirically validated; shows xone needs stronger KB axioms under open-world semantics.
AI.motivation: ODRL relies on domain knowledge the W3C spec leaves unspecified, making cross-dataspace policy comparisons default to Unknown. There is a need for a principled, interoperable, and sound way to evaluate and compare ODRL constraints under incomplete knowledge.
AI.method: Map each ODRL constraint to the denotation (set) of KB concepts that satisfy it; reduce policy conflict detection to denotation intersections with a three-valued verdict (Conflict, Compatible, Unknown). Cover all ODRL composition modes (and/or/xone) and semantic domains (taxonomic, mereological, nominal). Introduce order-preserving alignments between heterogeneous KBs with proofs that conflicts are preserved and unmapped concepts degrade to Unknown. Prove a runtime soundness theorem. Encode the framework within the decidable EPR fragment. Validate on 154 benchmarks across six real KB families and four adversarial structural KBs using Vampire and Z3.
AI.result: Theoretical guarantees: preservation of conflicts across KB standards; unmapped concepts never cause false conflicts; runtime soundness. Practical validation: Vampire and Z3 agree on all 154 verdicts. Key insight: xone requires stronger/disjointness-style axioms; open-world semantics blocks exclusivity even when one branch appears uniquely satisfied.
AI.conclusion: Provides a sound, interoperable, and decidable approach to ODRL constraint comparison that works across heterogeneous KBs. It is practically viable but highlights that exclusivity (xone) demands richer KB axioms to avoid pervasive Unknown outcomes under open-world assumptions.

title: A Multimodal Framework for Aligning Human Linguistic Descriptions with Visual Perceptual Data
summary: Establishing stable mappings between natural language expressions and visual percepts is a foundational problem for both cognitive science and artificial intelligence. Humans routinely ground linguistic reference in noisy, ambiguous perceptual contexts, yet the mechanisms supporting such cross-modal alignment remain poorly understood. In this work, we introduce a computational framework designed to model core aspects of human referential interpretation by integrating linguistic utterances with perceptual representations derived from large-scale, crowd-sourced imagery. The system approximates human perceptual categorization by combining scale-invariant feature transform (SIFT) alignment with the Universal Quality Index (UQI) to quantify similarity in a cognitively plausible feature space, while a set of linguistic preprocessing and query-transformation operations captures pragmatic variability in referring expressions. We evaluate the model on the Stanford Repeated Reference Game corpus (15,000 utterances paired with tangram stimuli), a paradigm explicitly developed to probe human-level perceptual ambiguity and coordination. Our framework achieves robust referential grounding. It requires 65\% fewer utterances than human interlocutors to reach stable mappings and can correctly identify target objects from single referring expressions 41.66\% of the time (versus 20\% for humans).These results suggest that relatively simple perceptual-linguistic alignment mechanisms can yield human-competitive behavior on a classic cognitive benchmark, and offers insights into models of grounded communication, perceptual inference, and cross-modal concept formation. Code is available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/metasequoia-9D13/README.md .

AI.tldr: A simple, cognitively inspired framework grounds natural-language referring expressions in visual percepts by aligning SIFT-based image features with pragmatic linguistic transformations, achieving strong performance on the Stanford Repeated Reference Game with fewer utterances and higher single-shot identification than humans.
AI.motivation: Address the core grounding problem: how to stably map linguistic references to noisy, ambiguous visual percepts, modeling human-like referential interpretation for both cognitive science and AI.
AI.method: Integrate linguistic preprocessing and query-transformation (to capture pragmatic variability) with perceptual similarity computed from large, crowd-sourced imagery. Use SIFT feature alignment plus the Universal Quality Index (UQI) to quantify similarity in a cognitively plausible space. Evaluate on the Stanford Repeated Reference Game corpus (15k utterances with tangram stimuli).
AI.result: Robust referential grounding: reaches stable mappings with 65% fewer utterances than human interlocutors; identifies targets from single referring expressions 41.66% of the time vs 20% for humans on the same paradigm.
AI.conclusion: Relatively simple perceptual–linguistic alignment mechanisms can yield human-competitive behavior on a classic grounding benchmark, offering insights into grounded communication, perceptual inference, and cross-modal concept formation; code is publicly available.

title: Marginalized Bundle Adjustment: Multi-View Camera Pose from Monocular Depth Estimates
summary: Structure-from-Motion (SfM) is a fundamental 3D vision task for recovering camera parameters and scene geometry from multi-view images. While recent deep learning advances enable accurate Monocular Depth Estimation (MDE) from single images without depending on camera motion, integrating MDE into SfM remains a challenge. Unlike conventional triangulated sparse point clouds, MDE produces dense depth maps with significantly higher error variance. Inspired by modern RANSAC estimators, we propose Marginalized Bundle Adjustment (MBA) to mitigate MDE error variance leveraging its density. With MBA, we show that MDE depth maps are sufficiently accurate to yield SoTA or competitive results in SfM and camera relocalization tasks. Through extensive evaluations, we demonstrate consistently robust performance across varying scales, ranging from few-frame setups to large multi-view systems with thousands of images. Our method highlights the significant potential of MDE in multi-view 3D vision.

AI.tldr: Proposes Marginalized Bundle Adjustment (MBA) to robustly integrate dense but noisy monocular depth estimates into SfM, achieving state-of-the-art or competitive performance in SfM and camera relocalization across small to very large scales.
AI.motivation: Monocular Depth Estimation (MDE) can predict dense depths from single images, but these depths have higher variance than triangulated SfM points, making them hard to use directly in bundle adjustment. The goal is to exploit MDE’s density while mitigating its noise to improve multi-view reconstruction and relocalization.
AI.method: Introduce MBA, a RANSAC-inspired robust optimization that leverages dense MDE depth maps while marginalizing or down-weighting high-variance/noisy measurements within bundle adjustment. This integrates MDE as a primary geometric cue for jointly refining camera parameters and scene structure across varying scales.
AI.result: Using only (or primarily) MDE depth maps, the approach attains state-of-the-art or competitive accuracy in SfM and camera relocalization. Experiments show consistent robustness from few-frame scenarios up to systems with thousands of images.
AI.conclusion: Dense MDE, when coupled with MBA, is accurate enough to drive reliable SfM and relocalization, revealing significant untapped potential of MDE in multi-view 3D vision and challenging the reliance on sparse triangulation alone.

title: Janus-Q: End-to-End Event-Driven Trading via Hierarchical-Gated Reward Modeling
summary: Financial market movements are often driven by discrete financial events conveyed through news, whose impacts are heterogeneous, abrupt, and difficult to capture under purely numerical prediction objectives. These limitations have motivated growing interest in using textual information as the primary source of trading signals in learning-based systems. Two key challenges hinder existing approaches: (1) the absence of large-scale, event-centric datasets that jointly model news semantics and statistically grounded market reactions, and (2) the misalignment between language model reasoning and financially valid trading behavior under dynamic market conditions. To address these challenges, we propose Janus-Q, an end-to-end event-driven trading framework that elevates financial news events from auxiliary signals to primary decision units. Janus-Q unifies event-centric data construction and model optimization under a two-stage paradigm. Stage I focuses on event-centric data construction, building a large-scale financial news event dataset comprising 62,400 articles annotated with 10 fine-grained event types, associated stocks, sentiment labels, and event-driven cumulative abnormal return (CAR). Stage II performs decision-oriented fine-tuning, combining supervised learning with reinforcement learning guided by a Hierarchical Gated Reward Model (HGRM), which explicitly captures trade-offs among multiple trading objectives. Extensive experiments demonstrate that Janus-Q achieves more consistent, interpretable, and profitable trading decisions than market indices and LLM baselines, improving the Sharpe Ratio by up to 102.0% while increasing direction accuracy by over 17.5% compared to the strongest competing strategies.

AI.tldr: Janus-Q is an event-driven trading framework that treats news events as primary decision units, builds a large annotated event–market reaction dataset, and fine-tunes with supervised learning plus RL via a hierarchical gated reward model, yielding markedly higher Sharpe and accuracy than indices and LLM baselines.
AI.motivation: Purely numerical objectives struggle to capture heterogeneous, abrupt impacts of discrete news. Existing approaches lack a large-scale event-centric dataset linking news semantics to market reactions and suffer from misalignment between LLM reasoning and financially sound trading under dynamic conditions.
AI.method: Two-stage pipeline: (Stage I) construct a large-scale event-centric dataset of 62,400 news articles with 10 fine-grained event types, mapped stocks, sentiment labels, and event-driven cumulative abnormal return (CAR). (Stage II) perform decision-oriented fine-tuning that mixes supervised learning with reinforcement learning guided by a Hierarchical Gated Reward Model (HGRM) to balance multiple trading objectives and align decisions with financial performance.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, Janus-Q delivers more consistent, interpretable, and profitable trades than market indices and LLM baselines, improving Sharpe Ratio by up to 102% and boosting direction accuracy by over 17.5% versus the strongest competing strategies.
AI.conclusion: Elevating events to first-class decision units and aligning training with multi-objective financial rewards can significantly improve text-driven trading. The event-centric dataset and HGRM-based RL produce decisions that are both interpretable and profitable, suggesting a viable path for robust, news-driven trading systems.

title: Rules or Weights? Comparing User Understanding of Explainable AI Techniques with the Cognitive XAI-Adaptive Model
summary: Rules and Weights are popular XAI techniques for explaining AI decisions. Yet, it remains unclear how to choose between them, lacking a cognitive framework to compare their interpretability. In an elicitation user study on forward and counterfactual decision tasks, we identified 7 reasoning strategies of interpreting three XAI Schemas - weights, rules, and their hybrid. To analyze their capabilities, we propose CoXAM, a Cognitive XAI-Adaptive Model with shared memory representation to encode instance attributes, linear weights, and decision rules. CoXAM employs computational rationality to choose among reasoning processes based on the trade-off in utility and reasoning time, separately for forward or counterfactual decision tasks. In a validation study, CoXAM demonstrated a stronger alignment with human decision-making compared to baseline machine learning proxy models. The model successfully replicated and explained several key empirical findings, including that counterfactual tasks are inherently harder than forward tasks, decision tree rules are harder to recall and apply than linear weights, and the helpfulness of XAI depends on the application data context, alongside identifying which underlying reasoning strategies were most effective. With CoXAM, we contribute a cognitive basis to accelerate debugging and benchmarking disparate XAI techniques.

AI.tldr: Introduces CoXAM, a cognitive model that adaptively chooses between rule-, weight-, and hybrid-based reasoning to explain AI decisions, matching human strategies across forward and counterfactual tasks and outperforming ML proxy baselines in predicting human judgments.
AI.motivation: Practitioners lack a cognitive framework for deciding when to use rules vs. weights (or hybrids) in XAI and how these explanations support forward vs. counterfactual reasoning. The paper seeks to ground XAI choice in human cognition rather than ad hoc preference or aggregate accuracy alone.
AI.method: (1) Elicitation user study to surface seven human reasoning strategies when interpreting three XAI schemas: weights, rules, and hybrid. (2) Proposes CoXAM, which encodes instance attributes, linear weights, and decision rules in a shared memory representation, using computational rationality to select a reasoning process that trades off utility and time—separately for forward and counterfactual tasks. (3) Validation study contrasting CoXAM with ML proxy models on alignment with human decisions.
AI.result: CoXAM exhibits stronger alignment with human decision-making than proxy baselines. It reproduces key empirical observations: counterfactual tasks are harder than forward tasks; decision-tree rules are harder to recall/apply than linear weights; the helpfulness of XAI is data-context dependent. It also reveals which underlying reasoning strategies are most effective under varying conditions.
AI.conclusion: A cognitively grounded, task- and context-aware framework can benchmark and debug disparate XAI techniques. CoXAM provides a principled basis for selecting and improving explanations (rules, weights, hybrids) by predicting when each will aid human reasoning, particularly across forward vs. counterfactual tasks.

title: CRAFT-LoRA: Content-Style Personalization via Rank-Constrained Adaptation and Training-Free Fusion
summary: Personalized image generation requires effectively balancing content fidelity with stylistic consistency when synthesizing images based on text and reference examples. Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) offers an efficient personalization approach, with potential for precise control through combining LoRA weights on different concepts. However, existing combination techniques face persistent challenges: entanglement between content and style representations, insufficient guidance for controlling elements' influence, and unstable weight fusion that often require additional training. We address these limitations through CRAFT-LoRA, with complementary components: (1) rank-constrained backbone fine-tuning that injects low-rank projection residuals to encourage learning decoupled content and style subspaces; (2) a prompt-guided approach featuring an expert encoder with specialized branches that enables semantic extension and precise control through selective adapter aggregation; and (3) a training-free, timestep-dependent classifier-free guidance scheme that enhances generation stability by strategically adjusting noise predictions across diffusion steps. Our method significantly improves content-style disentanglement, enables flexible semantic control over LoRA module combinations, and achieves high-fidelity generation without additional retraining overhead.

AI.tldr: CRAFT-LoRA introduces a controllable, training-free framework to combine LoRA modules for personalized image generation, disentangling content and style while improving stability and fidelity.
AI.motivation: Personalized image generation needs to balance content fidelity with stylistic consistency. While LoRA allows efficient personalization, combining multiple LoRA weights suffers from content–style entanglement, weak control over each component’s influence, and unstable fusion that often requires extra training.
AI.method: CRAFT-LoRA has three parts: (1) Rank-constrained backbone fine-tuning that injects low-rank projection residuals to encourage separate subspaces for content vs. style; (2) A prompt-guided expert encoder with specialized branches enabling semantic extension and precise control via selective aggregation of LoRA adapters; (3) A training-free, timestep-dependent classifier-free guidance scheme that adjusts noise predictions across diffusion steps to stabilize generation.
AI.result: The approach improves content–style disentanglement, offers flexible semantic control over how LoRA modules are combined, and achieves high-fidelity, stable image synthesis without additional retraining overhead.
AI.conclusion: By decoupling content and style, enabling prompt-contingent selective adapter use, and stabilizing diffusion through timestep-aware guidance, CRAFT-LoRA addresses key limitations in LoRA fusion and facilitates precise, scalable personalization with reduced complexity.

title: Assessing Risks of Large Language Models in Mental Health Support: A Framework for Automated Clinical AI Red Teaming
comment: This paper is a condensed version of the first author's Ph.D. dissertation submitted to Northeastern University
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly utilized for mental health support; however, current safety benchmarks often fail to detect the complex, longitudinal risks inherent in therapeutic dialogue. We introduce an evaluation framework that pairs AI psychotherapists with simulated patient agents equipped with dynamic cognitive-affective models and assesses therapy session simulations against a comprehensive quality of care and risk ontology. We apply this framework to a high-impact test case, Alcohol Use Disorder, evaluating six AI agents (including ChatGPT, Gemini, and Character.AI) against a clinically-validated cohort of 15 patient personas representing diverse clinical phenotypes.
  Our large-scale simulation (N=369 sessions) reveals critical safety gaps in the use of AI for mental health support. We identify specific iatrogenic risks, including the validation of patient delusions ("AI Psychosis") and failure to de-escalate suicide risk. Finally, we validate an interactive data visualization dashboard with diverse stakeholders, including AI engineers and red teamers, mental health professionals, and policy experts (N=9), demonstrating that this framework effectively enables stakeholders to audit the "black box" of AI psychotherapy. These findings underscore the critical safety risks of AI-provided mental health support and the necessity of simulation-based clinical red teaming before deployment.

AI.tldr: They propose a simulation-based framework to stress-test AI “therapists” with realistic, dynamically changing patient agents and a rich risk/quality ontology, apply it to Alcohol Use Disorder across six popular LLM-based agents and 15 validated personas (369 sessions), uncover serious safety failures (e.g., validating delusions, poor suicide de-escalation), and show an auditing dashboard useful to diverse stakeholders—arguing for simulation-based clinical red teaming before deployment.
AI.motivation: Existing safety benchmarks miss the longitudinal, contextual, and iatrogenic risks that arise in therapeutic dialogue. Stakeholders need a way to peer into the “black box” of AI psychotherapy to evaluate quality of care and risk over time, not just with static prompts.
AI.method: Create simulated patient agents with dynamic cognitive–affective models and pair them with AI psychotherapist agents. Score session trajectories against a comprehensive quality-of-care and risk ontology. Use Alcohol Use Disorder as the test case. Evaluate six AI systems (e.g., ChatGPT, Gemini, Character.AI) interacting with 15 clinically validated personas, yielding 369 sessions. Validate an interactive visualization dashboard with nine stakeholders (engineers/red teamers, clinicians, policy experts).
AI.result: Across agents and personas, the simulation uncovered critical safety gaps, including iatrogenic harms such as reinforcing delusional thinking (“AI Psychosis”) and failures to properly de-escalate suicide risk. Stakeholders found the dashboard effective for auditing behaviors and risks across sessions.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based mental health support exhibits substantial safety risks that current benchmarks overlook. Simulation-based, clinically grounded red teaming and auditing should be prerequisites to deployment; the presented framework and dashboard can operationalize this process for diverse stakeholders.

title: TAPE: Tool-Guided Adaptive Planning and Constrained Execution in Language Model Agents
summary: Language Model (LM) agents have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in solving tasks that require multiple interactions with the environment. However, they remain vulnerable in environments where a single error often leads to irrecoverable failure, particularly under strict feasibility constraints. We systematically analyze existing agent frameworks, identifying imperfect planning and stochastic execution as the primary causes. To address these challenges, we propose Tool-guided Adaptive Planning with constrained Execution (TAPE). TAPE enhances planning capability by aggregating multiple plans into a graph and employing an external solver to identify a feasible path. During execution, TAPE employs constrained decoding to reduce sampling noise, while adaptively re-planning whenever environmental feedback deviates from the intended state. Experiments across Sokoban, ALFWorld, MuSiQue, and GSM8K-Hard demonstrate that TAPE consistently outperforms existing frameworks, with particularly large gains on hard settings, improving success rates by 21.0 percentage points on hard settings on average, and by 20.0 percentage points for weaker base models on average. Code and data available at here.

AI.tldr: Introduces TAPE, a planning-and-execution framework that aggregates multiple LM-generated plans into a graph, uses an external solver to find a feasible path, and executes with constrained decoding plus adaptive re-planning—yielding large gains on hard, error-intolerant tasks (e.g., +21 pp success on average).
AI.motivation: LM agents often fail in environments where one mistake is irrecoverable due to strict feasibility constraints. The paper identifies two culprits—imperfect planning and stochastic (noisy) execution—and seeks a robust method to mitigate both.
AI.method: Tool-guided Adaptive Planning with constrained Execution (TAPE): (1) generate multiple candidate plans and merge them into a plan graph; (2) use an external solver to select a feasible path through the graph; (3) enforce constrained decoding during action generation to reduce randomness; (4) adaptively re-plan when observed environment states deviate from the intended plan.
AI.result: Across Sokoban, ALFWorld, MuSiQue, and GSM8K-Hard, TAPE consistently outperforms existing agent frameworks, with average +21.0 percentage-point gains on hard settings and +20.0 pp gains for weaker base models.
AI.conclusion: Aggregating plans into a solvable graph and constraining execution—while re-planning on deviations—substantially improves LM agent reliability under strict feasibility constraints. The approach is broadly effective across symbolic planning, embodied tasks, and challenging reasoning benchmarks; code and data are available.

title: Global Commander and Local Operative: A Dual-Agent Framework for Scene Navigation
summary: Vision-and-Language Scene navigation is a fundamental capability for embodied human-AI collaboration, requiring agents to follow natural language instructions to execute coherent action sequences in complex environments. Existing approaches either rely on multiple agents, incurring high coordination and resource costs, or adopt a single-agent paradigm, which overloads the agent with both global planning and local perception, often leading to degraded reasoning and instruction drift in long-horizon settings. To address these issues, we introduce DACo, a planning-grounding decoupled architecture that disentangles global deliberation from local grounding. Concretely, it employs a Global Commander for high-level strategic planning and a Local Operative for egocentric observing and fine-grained execution. By disentangling global reasoning from local action, DACo alleviates cognitive overload and improves long-horizon stability. The framework further integrates dynamic subgoal planning and adaptive replanning to enable structured and resilient navigation. Extensive evaluations on R2R, REVERIE, and R4R demonstrate that DACo achieves 4.9%, 6.5%, 5.4% absolute improvements over the best-performing baselines in zero-shot settings, and generalizes effectively across both closed-source (e.g., GPT-4o) and open-source (e.g., Qwen-VL Series) backbones. DACo provides a principled and extensible paradigm for robust long-horizon navigation. Project page: https://github.com/ChocoWu/DACo

AI.tldr: DACo is a decoupled planning–grounding architecture for vision–language navigation that splits global strategic planning (Global Commander) from local perception and execution (Local Operative), adds dynamic subgoal planning and adaptive replanning, and yields sizable zero-shot gains (4.9–6.5% absolute) on R2R, REVERIE, and R4R across both closed- and open-source backbones.
AI.motivation: Existing VLN systems either use multiple agents with high coordination costs or single agents that must both plan globally and act locally, which causes cognitive overload, degraded reasoning, and instruction drift in long-horizon tasks. A more stable, scalable approach is needed for embodied language-guided navigation.
AI.method: Introduce DACo, a two-module architecture: (1) Global Commander for high-level, instruction-grounded strategic planning, subgoal decomposition, and adaptive replanning; (2) Local Operative for egocentric perception and fine-grained action execution. The framework performs dynamic subgoal generation and can replan when deviations occur. It is backbone-agnostic and works with closed- and open-source VLMs/LLMs.
AI.result: On R2R, REVERIE, and R4R, DACo achieves absolute zero-shot improvements of 4.9%, 6.5%, and 5.4% over strong baselines. It shows better long-horizon stability, reduced instruction drift, and generalization across GPT-4o and Qwen-VL series backbones.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling global deliberation from local grounding alleviates cognitive overload and improves robustness for long-horizon VLN. DACo is a principled, extensible paradigm that generalizes across model families and offers consistent gains in zero-shot settings.

title: Unlocking Multimodal Document Intelligence: From Current Triumphs to Future Frontiers of Visual Document Retrieval
summary: With the rapid proliferation of multimodal information, Visual Document Retrieval (VDR) has emerged as a critical frontier in bridging the gap between unstructured visually rich data and precise information acquisition. Unlike traditional natural image retrieval, visual documents exhibit unique characteristics defined by dense textual content, intricate layouts, and fine-grained semantic dependencies. This paper presents the first comprehensive survey of the VDR landscape, specifically through the lens of the Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM) era. We begin by examining the benchmark landscape, and subsequently dive into the methodological evolution, categorizing approaches into three primary aspects: multimodal embedding models, multimodal reranker models, and the integration of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and Agentic systems for complex document intelligence. Finally, we identify persistent challenges and outline promising future directions, aiming to provide a clear roadmap for future multimodal document intelligence.

AI.tldr: A survey of Visual Document Retrieval (VDR) in the Multimodal LLM era, covering benchmarks, method taxonomy (embeddings, rerankers, RAG/agents), and open challenges, offering a roadmap for future research.
AI.motivation: Multimodal, visually rich documents (dense text, complex layouts, fine-grained semantics) are proliferating, and classic natural image retrieval is ill-suited. There is a need to consolidate knowledge and guidance for VDR, especially given rapid progress with MLLMs.
AI.method: Comprehensive literature survey: (1) review and organize the benchmark landscape; (2) analyze methodological evolution; (3) categorize approaches into multimodal embedding models, multimodal rerankers, and systems integrating Retrieval-Augmented Generation and agentic workflows for complex document intelligence.
AI.result: Establishes the first focused, MLLM-era survey of VDR; presents a structured taxonomy, synthesizes benchmarks and methods, and surfaces persistent challenges, culminating in a consolidated view of the field.
AI.conclusion: VDR is a critical capability for multimodal document intelligence. Organizing the field around MLLM-driven embeddings, reranking, and RAG/agent systems clarifies progress and gaps; the survey charts challenges and proposes future directions as a roadmap for the community.

title: SkillOrchestra: Learning to Route Agents via Skill Transfer
summary: Compound AI systems promise capabilities beyond those of individual models, yet their success depends critically on effective orchestration. Existing routing approaches face two limitations: (1) input-level routers make coarse query-level decisions that ignore evolving task requirements; (2) RL-trained orchestrators are expensive to adapt and often suffer from routing collapse, repeatedly invoking one strong but costly option in multi-turn scenarios. We introduce SkillOrchestra, a framework for skill-aware orchestration. Instead of directly learning a routing policy end-to-end, SkillOrchestra learns fine-grained skills from execution experience and models agent-specific competence and cost under those skills. At deployment, the orchestrator infers the skill demands of the current interaction and selects agents that best satisfy them under an explicit performance-cost trade-off. Extensive experiments across ten benchmarks demonstrate that SkillOrchestra outperforms SoTA RL-based orchestrators by up to 22.5% with 700x and 300x learning cost reduction compared to Router-R1 and ToolOrchestra, respectively. These results show that explicit skill modeling enables scalable, interpretable, and sample-efficient orchestration, offering a principled alternative to data-intensive RL-based approaches. The code is available at: https://github.com/jiayuww/SkillOrchestra.

AI.tldr: SkillOrchestra is a skill-aware orchestration framework that learns fine-grained skills and models each agent’s competence and cost per skill, then dynamically selects agents to meet current skill demands under a performance–cost trade-off. It outperforms RL-based orchestrators by up to 22.5% while slashing learning costs (700x vs Router-R1; 300x vs ToolOrchestra).
AI.motivation: Compound AI systems need effective orchestration, but current methods either make coarse, static routing decisions or rely on data- and compute-heavy RL that can collapse to overusing a single strong (and expensive) option, especially in multi-turn tasks. A more adaptive, sample-efficient, and interpretable approach is needed.
AI.method: Rather than end-to-end routing via RL, SkillOrchestra: (1) learns fine-grained skills from execution experience; (2) builds agent-specific competence and cost models per skill; and (3) at inference time, infers the interaction’s evolving skill demands and selects agents that best satisfy them under an explicit performance–cost objective.
AI.result: Across ten benchmarks, SkillOrchestra surpasses state-of-the-art RL orchestrators by up to 22.5% while reducing learning cost by 700x relative to Router-R1 and 300x relative to ToolOrchestra, mitigating routing collapse and improving scalability and interpretability.
AI.conclusion: Explicit skill modeling provides a principled, scalable, and sample-efficient alternative to RL-based orchestration, enabling interpretable routing decisions and strong performance–cost trade-offs. Code is available at https://github.com/jiayuww/SkillOrchestra.

title: YOLOv10-Based Multi-Task Framework for Hand Localization and Laterality Classification in Surgical Videos
summary: Real-time hand tracking in trauma surgery is essential for supporting rapid and precise intraoperative decisions. We propose a YOLOv10-based framework that simultaneously localizes hands and classifies their laterality (left or right) in complex surgical scenes. The model is trained on the Trauma THOMPSON Challenge 2025 Task 2 dataset, consisting of first-person surgical videos with annotated hand bounding boxes. Extensive data augmentation and a multi-task detection design improve robustness against motion blur, lighting variations, and diverse hand appearances. Evaluation demonstrates accurate left-hand (67\%) and right-hand (71\%) classification, while distinguishing hands from the background remains challenging. The model achieves an $mAP_{[0.5:0.95]}$ of 0.33 and maintains real-time inference, highlighting its potential for intraoperative deployment. This work establishes a foundation for advanced hand-instrument interaction analysis in emergency surgical procedures.

AI.tldr: YOLOv10-based, real-time hand detection with left/right classification on first-person trauma surgery videos achieves moderate accuracy (mAP[0.5:0.95]=0.33; L=67%, R=71%) and runs in real time, forming a baseline for intraoperative use despite background confusion.
AI.motivation: Enable rapid, precise intraoperative decisions in trauma surgery by reliably tracking surgeons’ hands and their laterality from egocentric video, a prerequisite for downstream analysis of hand–instrument interactions.
AI.method: Train a multi-task YOLOv10 detector on the Trauma THOMPSON Challenge 2025 Task 2 dataset of first-person surgical videos with hand bounding boxes, adding a laterality classification head. Use extensive data augmentation to handle motion blur, lighting changes, and diverse hand appearances; maintain real-time inference.
AI.result: Left-hand classification 67% and right-hand 71%; overall detection performance mAP[0.5:0.95]=0.33. Distinguishing hands from background remains challenging, but inference speed meets real-time requirements.
AI.conclusion: The approach is feasible for intraoperative deployment as a baseline, though detection precision is limited. It lays groundwork for more advanced, robust hand–instrument interaction analytics in emergency surgery.

title: ReAttn: Improving Attention-based Re-ranking via Attention Re-weighting
summary: The strong capabilities of recent Large Language Models (LLMs) have made them highly effective for zero-shot re-ranking task. Attention-based re-ranking methods, which derive relevance scores directly from attention weights, offer an efficient and interpretable alternative to generation-based re-ranking methods. However, they still face two major limitations. First, attention signals are highly concentrated a small subset of tokens within a few documents, making others indistinguishable. Second, attention often overemphasizes phrases lexically similar to the query, yielding biased rankings that irrelevant documents with mere lexical resemblance are regarded as relevant. In this paper, we propose \textbf{ReAttn}, a post-hoc re-weighting strategy for attention-based re-ranking methods. It first compute the cross-document IDF weighting to down-weight attention on query-overlapping tokens that frequently appear across the candidate documents, reducing lexical bias and emphasizing distinctive terms. It then employs entropy-based regularization to mitigate over-concentrated attention, encouraging a more balanced distribution across informative tokens. Both adjustments operate directly on existing attention weights without additional training or supervision. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our method.

AI.tldr: ReAttn is a training-free, post-hoc reweighting of LLM attention for zero-shot re-ranking that down-weights spurious lexical matches via cross-document IDF and spreads attention with entropy regularization, yielding better, more robust rankings.
AI.motivation: Attention-based re-ranking is efficient and interpretable but suffers from two issues: (1) attention mass collapses onto a few tokens/documents, masking other informative evidence; (2) attention over-favors query-lexical overlap, promoting irrelevant yet similar-looking text. A lightweight fix is needed without retraining.
AI.method: Post-process existing cross-attention weights: (a) compute cross-document IDF over the candidate set and down-weight tokens that frequently overlap with the query, emphasizing distinctive terms; (b) apply entropy-based regularization to reduce over-concentration and promote a more balanced distribution across informative tokens. No additional training or supervision; operates directly on attention matrices.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments (details not provided in abstract), ReAttn improves re-ranking effectiveness and mitigates lexical-bias and over-concentration relative to attention-only baselines.
AI.conclusion: Simple, interpretable, and training-free post-hoc adjustments to attention can substantially improve zero-shot attention-based re-ranking by reducing lexical bias and distributing attention more evenly over informative evidence.

title: OpenClaw, Moltbook, and ClawdLab: From Agent-Only Social Networks to Autonomous Scientific Research
summary: In January 2026, the open-source agent framework OpenClaw and the agent-only social network Moltbook produced a large-scale dataset of autonomous AI-to-AI interaction, attracting six academic publications within fourteen days. This study conducts a multivocal literature review of that ecosystem and presents ClawdLab, an open-source platform for autonomous scientific research, as a design science response to the architectural failure modes identified. The literature documents emergent collective phenomena, security vulnerabilities spanning 131 agent skills and over 15,200 exposed control panels, and five recurring architectural patterns. ClawdLab addresses these failure modes through hard role restrictions, structured adversarial critique, PI-led governance, multi-model orchestration, and domain-specific evidence requirements encoded as protocol constraints that ground validation in computational tool outputs rather than social consensus; the architecture provides emergent Sybil resistance as a structural consequence. A three-tier taxonomy distinguishes single-agent pipelines, predetermined multi-agent workflows, and fully decentralised systems, analysing why leading AI co-scientist platforms remain confined to the first two tiers. ClawdLab's composable third-tier architecture, in which foundation models, capabilities, governance, and evidence requirements are independently modifiable, enables compounding improvement as the broader AI ecosystem advances.

AI.tldr: Reviews the OpenClaw/Moltbook AI-agent ecosystem’s early findings (emergent group behaviors, widespread vulnerabilities, recurring patterns) and introduces ClawdLab, a composable third-tier, governance- and evidence-constrained platform intended to make autonomous scientific research safer, more credible, and scalable, with emergent Sybil resistance.
AI.motivation: Rapid, large-scale AI-to-AI interactions exposed security holes and brittle architectures while current AI co-scientist systems remain stuck in single-agent or rigid multi-agent setups. The field needs a trustworthy, decentralized platform where validation depends on computational evidence rather than social consensus, and where components can evolve independently.
AI.method: Multivocal literature review of OpenClaw/Moltbook outputs and related work to identify failure modes and architectural patterns; design-science response in the form of ClawdLab. Proposes a three-tier taxonomy (single agent; predetermined multi-agent; fully decentralized) and encodes safeguards: hard role restrictions, structured adversarial critique, PI-led governance, multi-model orchestration, and protocol-level, domain-specific evidence requirements.
AI.result: Documents vulnerabilities across 131 agent skills and >15,200 exposed control panels, plus five recurring architectural patterns. Finds leading platforms confined to tiers 1–2. Designs ClawdLab with independently swappable foundation models, capabilities, governance, and evidence requirements, claiming emergent Sybil resistance and improved robustness/credibility.
AI.conclusion: Anchoring validation in tool-verifiable outputs and enforcing governance/role constraints can mitigate prevalent ecosystem failures. A composable, third-tier architecture enables compounding progress as models/tools advance and may unlock safer decentralized autonomous science; ClawdLab serves as a reference implementation.

title: Depth-Enhanced YOLO-SAM2 Detection for Reliable Ballast Insufficiency Identification
comment: Submitted to the IEEE International Symposium on Robotic and Sensors Environments (ROSE) 2026
summary:
This paper presents a depth-enhanced YOLO-SAM2 framework for detecting ballast insufficiency in railway tracks using RGB-D data. Although YOLOv8 provides reliable localization, the RGB-only model shows limited safety performance, achieving high precision (0.99) but low recall (0.49) due to insufficient ballast, as it tends to over-predict the sufficient class. To improve reliability, we incorporate depth-based geometric analysis enabled by a sleeper-aligned depth-correction pipeline that compensates for RealSense spatial distortion using polynomial modeling, RANSAC, and temporal smoothing. SAM2 segmentation further refines region-of-interest masks, enabling accurate extraction of sleeper and ballast profiles for geometric classification.
  Experiments on field-collected top-down RGB-D data show that depth-enhanced configurations substantially improve the detection of insufficient ballast. Depending on bounding-box sampling (AABB or RBB) and geometric criteria, recall increases from 0.49 to as high as 0.80, and F1-score improves from 0.66 to over 0.80. These results demonstrate that integrating depth correction with YOLO-SAM2 yields a more robust and reliable approach for automated railway ballast inspection, particularly in visually ambiguous or safety-critical scenarios.
