summary: How do large language models (LLMs) know what they know? Answering this question has been difficult because pre-training data is often a "black box" -- unknown or inaccessible. The recent release of nanochat -- a family of small LLMs with fully open pre-training data -- addresses this as it provides a transparent view into where a model's parametric knowledge comes from. Towards the goal of understanding how knowledge is encoded by LLMs, we release NanoKnow, a benchmark dataset that partitions questions from Natural Questions and SQuAD into splits based on whether their answers are present in nanochat's pre-training corpus. Using these splits, we can now properly disentangle the sources of knowledge that LLMs rely on when producing an output. To demonstrate NanoKnow's utility, we conduct experiments using eight nanochat checkpoints. Our findings show: (1) closed-book accuracy is strongly influenced by answer frequency in the pre-training data, (2) providing external evidence can mitigate this frequency dependence, (3) even with external evidence, models are more accurate when answers were seen during pre-training, demonstrating that parametric and external knowledge are complementary, and (4) non-relevant information is harmful, with accuracy decreasing based on both the position and the number of non-relevant contexts. We release all NanoKnow artifacts at https://github.com/castorini/NanoKnow.

AI.tldr: NanoKnow is a benchmark built on nanochat’s fully open pretraining corpus that cleanly separates parametric vs external knowledge in LLMs. Experiments across eight nanochat checkpoints show closed-book performance scales with how often an answer appeared in pretraining; retrieval reduces but doesn’t remove this effect; parametric and external knowledge are complementary; and irrelevant context harms accuracy depending on its amount and placement.
AI.motivation: Pretraining data for LLMs is typically opaque, obscuring where a model’s “knowledge” originates and how it is encoded. With nanochat’s fully transparent pretraining corpus, the authors aim to directly trace and quantify the impacts of pretraining exposure versus external evidence on QA performance.
AI.method: They construct NanoKnow by partitioning QA items from Natural Questions and SQuAD based on whether (and how frequently) their gold answers occur in nanochat’s pretraining data. Using eight nanochat checkpoints, they evaluate: (a) closed-book QA; (b) QA with provided external evidence; and (c) robustness to non-relevant (distractor) contexts varied in number and position. Accuracy and its dependence on answer frequency/exposure are measured across splits.
AI.result: Four main findings: (1) Closed-book accuracy increases with answer frequency in pretraining. (2) Supplying external evidence mitigates—but does not eliminate—this frequency dependence. (3) Even with evidence, models do better on answers seen during pretraining, indicating complementary roles of parametric and external knowledge. (4) Non-relevant information degrades accuracy, with stronger harm from more distractors and from distractors placed earlier/closer.
AI.conclusion: Transparent pretraining enables precise attribution of LLM knowledge. Parametric knowledge is heavily shaped by exposure frequency; retrieval helps but cannot fully substitute for learned internal knowledge. Effective systems should combine strong parametric priors with high-quality, relevance-filtered evidence, and minimize distractors. NanoKnow offers a principled benchmark for future studies on knowledge encoding and retrieval-augmented methods.

title: ReSyn: Autonomously Scaling Synthetic Environments for Reasoning Models
summary: Reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) has emerged as a promising approach for training reasoning language models (RLMs) by leveraging supervision from verifiers. Although verifier implementation is easier than solution annotation for many tasks, existing synthetic data generation methods remain largely solution-centric, while verifier-based methods rely on a few hand-crafted procedural environments. In this work, we scale RLVR by introducing ReSyn, a pipeline that generates diverse reasoning environments equipped with instance generators and verifiers, covering tasks such as constraint satisfaction, algorithmic puzzles, and spatial reasoning. A Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct model trained with RL on ReSyn data achieves consistent gains across reasoning benchmarks and out-of-domain math benchmarks, including a 27\% relative improvement on the challenging BBEH benchmark. Ablations show that verifier-based supervision and increased task diversity both contribute significantly, providing empirical evidence that generating reasoning environments at scale can enhance reasoning abilities in RLMs

AI.tldr: ReSyn scales reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards by programmatically generating diverse, verifier-equipped reasoning environments; RL on this data substantially improves a 7B RLM’s reasoning, including a 27% relative gain on BBEH.
AI.motivation: Solution annotation for reasoning tasks is expensive, while writing verifiers is often easier. However, existing synthetic data is mostly solution-centric or limited to a few procedural environments, constraining the scalability and diversity needed to robustly train reasoning language models.
AI.method: Introduce ReSyn, a pipeline that automatically creates diverse reasoning environments with instance generators and verifiers (e.g., constraint satisfaction, algorithmic puzzles, spatial reasoning). Train a Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct model with RL using verifier-derived rewards; evaluate across reasoning and out-of-domain math benchmarks; run ablations to isolate the effects of verifier-based supervision and task diversity.
AI.result: Models trained with ReSyn RL show consistent gains on multiple reasoning benchmarks and OOD math tasks, highlighted by a 27% relative improvement on the challenging BBEH benchmark. Ablations indicate both verifier rewards and increased task diversity contribute significantly.
AI.conclusion: Scaling verifier-based RL with diverse, automatically generated reasoning environments is an effective path to improve reasoning in language models; verifier supervision and task diversity are key drivers of the observed gains.

title: An interpretable framework using foundation models for fish sex identification
summary: Accurate sex identification in fish is vital for optimizing breeding and management strategies in aquaculture, particularly for species at the risk of extinction. However, most existing methods are invasive or stressful and may cause additional mortality, posing severe risks to threatened or endangered fish populations. To address these challenges, we propose FishProtoNet, a robust, non-invasive computer vision-based framework for sex identification of delta smelt (Hypomesus transpacificus), an endangered fish species native to California, across its full life cycle. Unlike the traditional deep learning methods, FishProtoNet provides interpretability through learned prototype representations while improving robustness by leveraging foundation models to reduce the influence of background noise. Specifically, the FishProtoNet framework consists of three key components: fish regions of interest (ROIs) extraction using visual foundation model, feature extraction from fish ROIs and fish sex identification based on an interpretable prototype network. FishProtoNet demonstrates strong performance in delta smelt sex identification during early spawning and post-spawning stages, achieving the accuracies of 74.40% and 81.16% and corresponding F1 scores of 74.27% and 79.43% respectively. In contrast, delta smelt sex identification at the subadult stage remains challenging for current computer vision methods, likely due to less pronounced morphological differences in immature fish. The source code of FishProtoNet is publicly available at: https://github.com/zhengmiao1/Fish_sex_identification

AI.tldr: FishProtoNet is a non-invasive, interpretable computer-vision framework that identifies sex in endangered delta smelt across life stages by combining visual-foundation-model ROI extraction with a prototype-based classifier, achieving strong accuracy in spawning stages but struggling with subadults.
AI.motivation: Conservation aquaculture and breeding programs need accurate sex identification without invasive, stressful, or lethal methods—especially critical for endangered species like delta smelt. Existing techniques are often invasive and opaque; a robust, explainable, and non-invasive alternative is needed.
AI.method: A three-stage pipeline: (1) extract fish regions of interest using a visual foundation model to suppress background noise, (2) extract features from these ROIs, and (3) classify sex with an interpretable prototype network that provides human-understandable evidence via learned prototypes.
AI.result: On delta smelt images, the method attains 74.40% accuracy (F1 74.27%) in early spawning and 81.16% accuracy (F1 79.43%) in post-spawning stages; performance is notably weaker for subadults, likely due to minimal morphological dimorphism.
AI.conclusion: FishProtoNet offers a practical, non-invasive, and interpretable solution for sexing delta smelt during spawning-related stages, reducing risk to endangered populations. However, immature-stage identification remains challenging, suggesting the need for additional cues or model refinements. Code is publicly available.

title: To Reason or Not to: Selective Chain-of-Thought in Medical Question Answering
summary:
Objective: To improve the efficiency of medical question answering (MedQA) with large language models (LLMs) by avoiding unnecessary reasoning while maintaining accuracy.
  Methods: We propose Selective Chain-of-Thought (Selective CoT), an inference-time strategy that first predicts whether a question requires reasoning and generates a rationale only when needed. Two open-source LLMs (Llama-3.1-8B and Qwen-2.5-7B) were evaluated on four biomedical QA benchmarks-HeadQA, MedQA-USMLE, MedMCQA, and PubMedQA. Metrics included accuracy, total generated tokens, and inference time.
  Results: Selective CoT reduced inference time by 13-45% and token usage by 8-47% with minimal accuracy loss ($\leq$4\%). In some model-task pairs, it achieved both higher accuracy and greater efficiency than standard CoT. Compared with fixed-length CoT, Selective CoT reached similar or superior accuracy at substantially lower computational cost.
  Discussion: Selective CoT dynamically balances reasoning depth and efficiency by invoking explicit reasoning only when beneficial, reducing redundancy on recall-type questions while preserving interpretability.
  Conclusion: Selective CoT provides a simple, model-agnostic, and cost-effective approach for medical QA, aligning reasoning effort with question complexity to enhance real-world deployability of LLM-based clinical systems.

AI.tldr: Selective CoT conditionally triggers chain-of-thought only when a question appears to require reasoning, cutting tokens and latency (8–47% and 13–45%) with ≤4% accuracy loss and sometimes higher accuracy than standard CoT across four MedQA benchmarks and two 7–8B LLMs.
AI.motivation: Standard CoT improves medical QA but induces unnecessary long rationales for many recall-style questions, inflating latency and cost—barriers to real-world clinical deployment where efficiency and interpretability both matter.
AI.method: An inference-time selector first predicts whether a question needs explicit reasoning; if yes, the model generates a rationale (CoT) before answering; otherwise it answers directly. The approach is tested with Llama‑3.1‑8B and Qwen‑2.5‑7B on HeadQA, MedQA‑USMLE, MedMCQA, and PubMedQA, comparing accuracy, generated tokens, and inference time against standard and fixed-length CoT baselines.
AI.result: Selective CoT reduces inference time by 13–45% and token usage by 8–47% with at most 4% accuracy loss; in some model–task pairs it improves both accuracy and efficiency relative to standard CoT and matches or exceeds fixed-length CoT accuracy at much lower cost.
AI.conclusion: A simple, model-agnostic mechanism that aligns reasoning effort with question complexity, preserving interpretability while improving computational efficiency, thereby enhancing deployability of LLM-based clinical QA systems.

title: Recurrent Structural Policy Gradient for Partially Observable Mean Field Games
summary: Mean Field Games (MFGs) provide a principled framework for modeling interactions in large population models: at scale, population dynamics become deterministic, with uncertainty entering only through aggregate shocks, or common noise. However, algorithmic progress has been limited since model-free methods are too high variance and exact methods scale poorly. Recent Hybrid Structural Methods (HSMs) use Monte Carlo rollouts for the common noise in combination with exact estimation of the expected return, conditioned on those samples. However, HSMs have not been scaled to Partially Observable settings. We propose Recurrent Structural Policy Gradient (RSPG), the first history-aware HSM for settings involving public information. We also introduce MFAX, our JAX-based framework for MFGs. By leveraging known transition dynamics, RSPG achieves state-of-the-art performance as well as an order-of-magnitude faster convergence and solves, for the first time, a macroeconomics MFG with heterogeneous agents, common noise and history-aware policies. MFAX is publicly available at: https://github.com/CWibault/mfax.

AI.tldr: They introduce RSPG, a history-aware hybrid structural policy-gradient method for Mean Field Games with public (common-noise) information, and MFAX, a JAX framework. Leveraging known dynamics, it attains state-of-the-art performance with ~10× faster convergence and solves a challenging heterogeneous-agent macro MFG with common noise and history-aware policies.
AI.motivation: Model-free MFG solvers suffer from high variance and exact solvers scale poorly. Hybrid Structural Methods reduce variance by conditioning on sampled common noise, but had not handled partially observable settings with public information. There is a need for scalable, lower-variance algorithms that exploit model structure in realistic MFGs with common shocks.
AI.method: Recurrent Structural Policy Gradient (RSPG): a history-aware (recurrent) policy-gradient algorithm within the Hybrid Structural Method paradigm. It samples trajectories of the common noise via Monte Carlo, then computes/estimates expected returns exactly (conditioned on those samples) using known transition dynamics, enabling variance reduction. Implemented in MFAX (JAX) to leverage automatic differentiation and parallelism.
AI.result: On benchmarks, RSPG achieves state-of-the-art returns and converges an order of magnitude faster than alternatives. It also provides the first solution to a macroeconomic MFG featuring heterogeneous agents, common noise, and history-aware policies. The MFAX framework is released publicly.
AI.conclusion: Exploiting known transition dynamics via a history-aware hybrid structural approach enables scalable, low-variance learning for partially observable MFGs with public information. This advances practical solvability of complex MFGs in economics and beyond and provides an open-source foundation (MFAX) for further research.

title: Towards Calibrating Prompt Tuning of Vision-Language Models
summary: Prompt tuning of large-scale vision-language models such as CLIP enables efficient task adaptation without updating model weights. However, it often leads to poor confidence calibration and unreliable predictive uncertainty. We address this problem by proposing a calibration framework that enhances predictive reliability while preserving the geometry of the pretrained CLIP embedding space, which is required for robust generalization. Our approach extends the standard cross-entropy loss with two complementary regularizers: (1) a mean-variance margin penalty that stabilizes inter-class logit margins by maximizing their average while minimizing dispersion, mitigating underconfidence and overconfidence spikes; and (2) a text moment-matching loss that aligns the first and second moments of tuned text embeddings with their frozen CLIP counterparts, preserving semantic dispersion crucial for generalization. Through extensive experiments across 7 prompt-tuning methods and 11 diverse datasets, we demonstrate that our approach significantly reduces the Expected Calibration Error (ECE) compared to competitive calibration techniques on both base and novel classes

AI.tldr: They introduce a calibration-aware prompt-tuning framework for CLIP that adds two regularizers to improve confidence reliability while preserving CLIP’s embedding geometry, yielding markedly lower ECE across many datasets and prompt-tuning methods.
AI.motivation: Prompt tuning adapts CLIP efficiently but often harms confidence calibration and uncertainty estimates. The authors aim to improve predictive reliability without destroying the pretrained embedding geometry that underpins robust generalization.
AI.method: Augment standard cross-entropy with two losses: (1) a mean–variance margin penalty that increases average inter-class logit margins while reducing their dispersion to avoid under/overconfidence spikes; and (2) a text moment-matching loss that aligns the first and second moments of tuned text embeddings with those of the frozen CLIP text embeddings, preserving semantic dispersion. The framework is applied on top of existing prompt-tuning methods.
AI.result: Across 7 prompt-tuning methods and 11 datasets, the approach significantly reduces Expected Calibration Error relative to strong calibration baselines, on both base and novel classes.
AI.conclusion: Geometry-preserving, regularization-based calibration during prompt tuning leads to more reliable confidence estimates without sacrificing the pretrained structure, and generalizes across methods and datasets.

title: KNIGHT: Knowledge Graph-Driven Multiple-Choice Question Generation with Adaptive Hardness Calibration
comment: Accepted at the Third Conference on Parsimony and Learning (CPAL 2026). 36 pages, 12 figures. (Equal contribution: Yasaman Amou Jafari and Mahdi Noori.)
summary: With the rise of large language models (LLMs), they have become instrumental in applications such as Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). Yet evaluating these systems remains bottlenecked by the time and cost of building specialized assessment datasets. We introduce KNIGHT, an LLM-based, knowledge-graph-driven framework for generating multiple-choice question (MCQ) datasets from external sources. KNIGHT constructs a topic-specific knowledge graph, a structured and parsimonious summary of entities and relations, that can be reused to generate instructor-controlled difficulty levels, including multi-hop questions, without repeatedly re-feeding the full source text. This knowledge graph acts as a compressed, reusable state, making question generation a cheap read over the graph. We instantiate KNIGHT on Wikipedia/Wikidata while keeping the framework domain- and ontology-agnostic. As a case study, KNIGHT produces six MCQ datasets in History, Biology, and Mathematics. We evaluate quality on five criteria: fluency, unambiguity (single correct answer), topic relevance, option uniqueness, and answerability given the provided sources (as a proxy for hallucination). Results show that KNIGHT enables token- and cost-efficient generation from a reusable graph representation, achieves high quality across these criteria, and yields model rankings aligned with MMLU-style benchmarks, while supporting topic-specific and difficulty-controlled evaluation.

AI.tldr: KNIGHT is a knowledge-graph-driven, LLM-based framework that cheaply generates high-quality, difficulty-controlled (including multi-hop) MCQ datasets from external sources (e.g., Wikipedia/Wikidata), producing model rankings aligned with MMLU while reducing token/cost overhead via a reusable graph state.
AI.motivation: Evaluating LLMs and RAG systems is constrained by the time and expense of crafting specialized, high-quality assessment datasets. There is a need for scalable, controllable, and low-cost generation that avoids repeatedly processing full source texts and supports multi-hop reasoning.
AI.method: Build a topic-specific knowledge graph from external sources to compress entities/relations into a reusable state. Use the graph to prompt LLMs to generate MCQs with instructor-controlled difficulty (including multi-hop) without re-consuming the full corpus. Instantiate on Wikipedia/Wikidata; remain domain- and ontology-agnostic. Produce six datasets across History, Biology, and Mathematics. Assess quality on fluency, unambiguity, topic relevance, option uniqueness, and answerability given sources.
AI.result: The approach reduces token and monetary costs by reusing the graph, generates questions that meet five quality criteria, supports topic specificity and difficulty control, and yields model rankings consistent with MMLU-style benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: A knowledge-graph-as-state paradigm enables efficient, scalable, and controllable MCQ dataset generation for LLM evaluation. KNIGHT generalizes across domains, supports multi-hop questions, and can complement or replace costly bespoke datasets while maintaining alignment with established benchmarks.

title: DEFNet: Multitasks-based Deep Evidential Fusion Network for Blind Image Quality Assessment
summary: Blind image quality assessment (BIQA) methods often incorporate auxiliary tasks to improve performance. However, existing approaches face limitations due to insufficient integration and a lack of flexible uncertainty estimation, leading to suboptimal performance. To address these challenges, we propose a multitasks-based Deep Evidential Fusion Network (DEFNet) for BIQA, which performs multitask optimization with the assistance of scene and distortion type classification tasks. To achieve a more robust and reliable representation, we design a novel trustworthy information fusion strategy. It first combines diverse features and patterns across sub-regions to enhance information richness, and then performs local-global information fusion by balancing fine-grained details with coarse-grained context. Moreover, DEFNet exploits advanced uncertainty estimation technique inspired by evidential learning with the help of normal-inverse gamma distribution mixture. Extensive experiments on both synthetic and authentic distortion datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed framework. Additional evaluation and analysis are carried out to highlight its strong generalization capability and adaptability to previously unseen scenarios.

AI.tldr: DEFNet is a multitask, evidential-learning BIQA model that fuses local–global features and estimates uncertainty (via a normal–inverse-gamma mixture), yielding robust quality prediction and strong generalization on synthetic and real distortions.
AI.motivation: Auxiliary tasks have helped BIQA, but prior work integrates them weakly and lacks flexible, well-calibrated uncertainty, causing unstable and suboptimal predictions, especially under distribution shifts.
AI.method: Multitask optimization couples BIQA with scene and distortion-type classification. A trustworthy information fusion strategy (i) aggregates diverse sub-region features to enrich representations, then (ii) performs local–global fusion to balance fine details with contextual cues. Uncertainty is modeled using evidential learning with a normal–inverse-gamma distribution mixture for predictive mean/variance estimation.
AI.result: Across synthetic and authentic distortion datasets, experiments show the framework is effective and robust, with additional analyses indicating strong generalization and adaptability to unseen scenarios.
AI.conclusion: By unifying auxiliary tasks, principled local–global fusion, and evidential uncertainty estimation, DEFNet delivers more reliable blind IQA, improving robustness and transfer to novel conditions.

title: OpenVO: Open-World Visual Odometry with Temporal Dynamics Awareness
summary: We introduce OpenVO, a novel framework for Open-world Visual Odometry (VO) with temporal awareness under limited input conditions. OpenVO effectively estimates real-world-scale ego-motion from monocular dashcam footage with varying observation rates and uncalibrated cameras, enabling robust trajectory dataset construction from rare driving events recorded in dashcam. Existing VO methods are trained on fixed observation frequency (e.g., 10Hz or 12Hz), completely overlooking temporal dynamics information. Many prior methods also require calibrated cameras with known intrinsic parameters. Consequently, their performance degrades when (1) deployed under unseen observation frequencies or (2) applied to uncalibrated cameras. These significantly limit their generalizability to many downstream tasks, such as extracting trajectories from dashcam footage. To address these challenges, OpenVO (1) explicitly encodes temporal dynamics information within a two-frame pose regression framework and (2) leverages 3D geometric priors derived from foundation models. We validate our method on three major autonomous-driving benchmarks - KITTI, nuScenes, and Argoverse 2 - achieving more than 20 performance improvement over state-of-the-art approaches. Under varying observation rate settings, our method is significantly more robust, achieving 46%-92% lower errors across all metrics. These results demonstrate the versatility of OpenVO for real-world 3D reconstruction and diverse downstream applications.

AI.tldr: OpenVO is a temporally aware, monocular VO framework that works across variable frame rates and uncalibrated cameras, using two-frame pose regression plus 3D priors from foundation models to recover real‑world‑scale motion; it outperforms SOTA on KITTI/nuScenes/Argoverse2 and is notably robust to observation‑rate shifts.
AI.motivation: Conventional VO models assume fixed observation frequencies and calibrated intrinsics, causing large performance drops when frame rates change or cameras are uncalibrated—scenarios common in crowd-sourced dashcam footage needed to build trajectories of rare events and for open-world 3D reconstruction.
AI.method: (1) Explicitly encode temporal dynamics within a two-frame pose regression setup to handle varying observation intervals; (2) integrate 3D geometric priors from foundation models to recover metric scale and improve generalization to uncalibrated cameras and open-world conditions.
AI.result: On KITTI, nuScenes, and Argoverse 2, OpenVO reports >20% performance gains over SOTA; under varying observation-rate settings, it yields 46%–92% lower errors across all metrics, demonstrating strong robustness to temporal sampling shifts and camera calibration variability.
AI.conclusion: OpenVO generalizes VO to open-world, real‑world settings with variable frame rates and unknown intrinsics, enabling accurate, metric‑scale trajectory extraction from monocular dashcams and supporting downstream 3D reconstruction and rare-event dataset curation.

title: NI-Tex: Non-isometric Image-based Garment Texture Generation
summary: Existing industrial 3D garment meshes already cover most real-world clothing geometries, yet their texture diversity remains limited. To acquire more realistic textures, generative methods are often used to extract Physically-based Rendering (PBR) textures and materials from large collections of wild images and project them back onto garment meshes. However, most image-conditioned texture generation approaches require strict topological consistency between the input image and the input 3D mesh, or rely on accurate mesh deformation to match to the image poses, which significantly constrains the texture generation quality and flexibility. To address the challenging problem of non-isometric image-based garment texture generation, we construct 3D Garment Videos, a physically simulated, garment-centric dataset that provides consistent geometry and material supervision across diverse deformations, enabling robust cross-pose texture learning. We further employ Nano Banana for high-quality non-isometric image editing, achieving reliable cross-topology texture generation between non-isometric image-geometry pairs. Finally, we propose an iterative baking method via uncertainty-guided view selection and reweighting that fuses multi-view predictions into seamless, production-ready PBR textures. Through extensive experiments, we demonstrate that our feedforward dual-branch architecture generates versatile and spatially aligned PBR materials suitable for industry-level 3D garment design.

AI.tldr: A dual-branch network, powered by a new garment-video dataset, non-isometric image editing, and uncertainty-guided multi-view baking, generates seamless, spatially aligned PBR textures for existing garment meshes without requiring topology/pose alignment.
AI.motivation: Industrial 3D garment meshes already exist and cover most shapes, but they lack texture diversity. Current image-conditioned texturing typically assumes strict topological consistency or accurate mesh deformation to match image poses, which constrains quality and applicability. The goal is to enable robust image-to-garment PBR texture transfer even when image and mesh are non-isometric (different topology/pose).
AI.method: (1) Construct 3D Garment Videos: a physically simulated, garment-centric dataset providing consistent geometry and material supervision across diverse deformations to enable cross-pose learning. (2) Employ Nano Banana for high-quality non-isometric image editing to bridge cross-topology gaps between image and mesh. (3) Use a feedforward dual-branch architecture that conditions on image and geometry cues to predict PBR materials. (4) Introduce iterative baking with uncertainty-guided view selection and reweighting to fuse multi-view predictions into seamless, production-ready PBR textures.
AI.result: Extensive experiments indicate robust cross-pose and cross-topology texture generation, yielding versatile, spatially aligned, and seamless PBR materials on industrial garment meshes that are ready for production use.
AI.conclusion: By combining a specialized dataset, non-isometric editing, and uncertainty-aware multi-view fusion within a dual-branch model, the method removes strict topology/pose constraints and achieves reliable, high-quality PBR texturing suitable for industry-level 3D garment design.

title: TeFlow: Enabling Multi-frame Supervision for Self-Supervised Feed-forward Scene Flow Estimation
summary: Self-supervised feed-forward methods for scene flow estimation offer real-time efficiency, but their supervision from two-frame point correspondences is unreliable and often breaks down under occlusions. Multi-frame supervision has the potential to provide more stable guidance by incorporating motion cues from past frames, yet naive extensions of two-frame objectives are ineffective because point correspondences vary abruptly across frames, producing inconsistent signals. In the paper, we present TeFlow, enabling multi-frame supervision for feed-forward models by mining temporally consistent supervision. TeFlow introduces a temporal ensembling strategy that forms reliable supervisory signals by aggregating the most temporally consistent motion cues from a candidate pool built across multiple frames. Extensive evaluations demonstrate that TeFlow establishes a new state-of-the-art for self-supervised feed-forward methods, achieving performance gains of up to 33\% on the challenging Argoverse 2 and nuScenes datasets. Our method performs on par with leading optimization-based methods, yet speeds up 150 times. The code is open-sourced at https://github.com/KTH-RPL/OpenSceneFlow along with trained model weights.

AI.tldr: TeFlow is a self-supervised, feed‑forward scene flow method that stabilizes multi‑frame training via temporal ensembling of consistent motion cues, yielding state‑of‑the‑art accuracy for feed‑forward approaches with large gains on Argoverse 2 and nuScenes, and matching optimization‑based methods while being ~150× faster.
AI.motivation: Two‑frame correspondence supervision in self‑supervised scene flow is noisy and breaks under occlusions. Naively extending to multi‑frame signals is ineffective because point correspondences change abruptly across frames, creating inconsistent supervision. The goal is to exploit multi‑frame motion cues without inheriting their inconsistency.
AI.method: Introduce TeFlow, which enables multi‑frame supervision for feed‑forward models by mining temporally consistent supervision. It builds a candidate pool of motion cues across multiple frames and applies a temporal ensembling strategy to aggregate the most temporally consistent cues into reliable supervisory signals for training.
AI.result: Across extensive evaluations on Argoverse 2 and nuScenes, TeFlow sets a new state of the art among self‑supervised feed‑forward methods, achieving up to 33% performance improvements. It attains accuracy on par with leading optimization‑based approaches while providing ~150× speedups. Code and pretrained weights are released.
AI.conclusion: Temporal ensembling can turn noisy multi‑frame signals into stable supervision, enabling robust, real‑time feed‑forward scene flow. TeFlow narrows the accuracy gap to optimization‑based methods while dramatically improving efficiency, indicating multi‑frame self‑supervision via consistency mining is a practical path for deployed systems.

title: Direction-aware 3D Large Multimodal Models
comment: In Proceedings of the IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR), 2026
summary: 3D large multimodal models (3D LMMs) rely heavily on ego poses for enabling directional question-answering and spatial reasoning. However, most existing point cloud benchmarks contain rich directional queries but lack the corresponding ego poses, making them inherently ill-posed in 3D large multimodal modelling. In this work, we redefine a new and rigorous paradigm that enables direction-aware 3D LMMs by identifying and supplementing ego poses into point cloud benchmarks and transforming the corresponding point cloud data according to the identified ego poses. We enable direction-aware 3D LMMs with two novel designs. The first is PoseRecover, a fully automatic pose recovery pipeline that matches questions with ego poses from RGB-D video extrinsics via object-frustum intersection and visibility check with Z-buffers. The second is PoseAlign that transforms the point cloud data to be aligned with the identified ego poses instead of either injecting ego poses into textual prompts or introducing pose-encoded features in the projection layers. Extensive experiments show that our designs yield consistent improvements across multiple 3D LMM backbones such as LL3DA, LL3DA-SONATA, Chat-Scene, and 3D-LLAVA, improving ScanRefer mIoU by 30.0% and Scan2Cap LLM-as-judge accuracy by 11.7%. In addition, our approach is simple, generic, and training-efficient, requiring only instruction tuning while establishing a strong baseline for direction-aware 3D-LMMs.

AI.tldr: They introduce a pose-centric paradigm for direction-aware 3D LMMs by automatically recovering ego poses from RGB-D videos (PoseRecover) and aligning point clouds to those poses (PoseAlign), yielding sizable gains across several 3D LMM backbones with minimal training overhead.
AI.motivation: Directional QA and spatial reasoning in 3D LMMs depend on the observer’s (ego) pose, but common point-cloud benchmarks contain directional queries without pose metadata, making evaluation and modeling ill-posed.
AI.method: 1) PoseRecover: fully automatic recovery of ego poses for each query by matching it to RGB-D video extrinsics using object–frustum intersection and Z-buffer visibility checks. 2) PoseAlign: transform point clouds to align with the recovered ego poses, rather than injecting pose text or pose-coded features. Train via instruction tuning on the aligned data.
AI.result: Consistent improvements across LL3DA, LL3DA-SONATA, Chat-Scene, and 3D-LLAVA. Reported gains include +30.0% mIoU on ScanRefer and +11.7% LLM-as-judge accuracy on Scan2Cap.
AI.conclusion: Supplying and aligning ego poses resolves a core missing piece for direction-aware 3D LMMs, is model-agnostic and training-efficient, and establishes a strong baseline that outperforms pose-in-text/feature-injection approaches.

title: L3DR: 3D-aware LiDAR Diffusion and Rectification
comment: In Proceedings of the IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR), 2026
summary: Range-view (RV) based LiDAR diffusion has recently made huge strides towards 2D photo-realism. However, it neglects 3D geometry realism and often generates various RV artifacts such as depth bleeding and wavy surfaces. We design L3DR, a 3D-aware LiDAR Diffusion and Rectification framework that can regress and cancel RV artifacts in 3D space and restore local geometry accurately. Our theoretical and empirical analysis reveals that 3D models are inherently superior to 2D models in generating sharp and authentic boundaries. Leveraging such analysis, we design a 3D residual regression network that rectifies RV artifacts and achieves superb geometry realism by predicting point-level offsets in 3D space. On top of that, we design a Welsch Loss that helps focus on local geometry and ignore anomalous regions effectively. Extensive experiments over multiple benchmarks including KITTI, KITTI360, nuScenes and Waymo show that the proposed L3DR achieves state-of-the-art generation and superior geometry-realism consistently. In addition, L3DR is generally applicable to different LiDAR diffusion models with little computational overhead.

AI.tldr: L3DR adds a lightweight 3D-aware rectification stage to range-view LiDAR diffusion that predicts point-level 3D offsets to remove RV artifacts (e.g., depth bleeding, wavy surfaces), guided by a Welsch loss, yielding state-of-the-art geometry realism across major benchmarks with little overhead.
AI.motivation: RV-based LiDAR diffusion excels at 2D photorealism but compromises true 3D geometry, producing artifacts and blurry/incorrect boundaries. The goal is to restore accurate local geometry and sharp boundaries while retaining generative quality and efficiency.
AI.method: Provide theoretical and empirical analysis arguing 3D models better preserve sharp, authentic boundaries than 2D RV models. Build a 3D residual regression network that, given RV diffusion outputs, predicts per-point 3D offsets to cancel artifacts directly in 3D space. Introduce a Welsch loss to emphasize local geometric fidelity and robustly downweight anomalous regions. Designed as a general, low-overhead plug-in compatible with various LiDAR diffusion backbones.
AI.result: Across KITTI, KITTI-360, nuScenes, and Waymo, L3DR delivers state-of-the-art generation with consistently superior geometry realism versus prior RV-based methods, with minimal computational overhead.
AI.conclusion: Rectifying RV diffusion outputs in 3D via residual point offsets and a robust Welsch loss substantially improves geometry realism while preserving generative quality. The approach generalizes across backbones and datasets efficiently, offering a practical path to artifact-free, boundary-sharp LiDAR synthesis.

title: ChordEdit: One-Step Low-Energy Transport for Image Editing
summary: The advent of one-step text-to-image (T2I) models offers unprecedented synthesis speed. However, their application to text-guided image editing remains severely hampered, as forcing existing training-free editors into a single inference step fails. This failure manifests as severe object distortion and a critical loss of consistency in non-edited regions, resulting from the high-energy, erratic trajectories produced by naive vector arithmetic on the models' structured fields. To address this problem, we introduce ChordEdit, a model agnostic, training-free, and inversion-free method that facilitates high-fidelity one-step editing. We recast editing as a transport problem between the source and target distributions defined by the source and target text prompts. Leveraging dynamic optimal transport theory, we derive a principled, low-energy control strategy. This strategy yields a smoothed, variance-reduced editing field that is inherently stable, facilitating the field to be traversed in a single, large integration step. A theoretically grounded and experimentally validated approach allows ChordEdit to deliver fast, lightweight and precise edits, finally achieving true real-time editing on these challenging models.

AI.tldr: ChordEdit enables accurate, real-time, one-step text-guided image editing by formulating edit guidance as a low-energy transport between source and target prompts, avoiding distortions and preserving unedited content without any training or inversion.
AI.motivation: One-step T2I models are extremely fast, but current training-free editing methods break when forced into a single step, causing object distortion and loss of background consistency due to high-energy, erratic guidance fields from naive vector arithmetic.
AI.method: Reformulate editing as transporting the source prompt distribution to the target prompt distribution. Using dynamic optimal transport, derive a principled low-energy control that smooths and reduces the variance of the editing field, making it stable enough to execute in a single large integration step. The approach is model-agnostic, training-free, and inversion-free.
AI.result: Theoretically justified and empirically validated edits that are fast, lightweight, and precise, maintaining non-edited regions while achieving targeted changes, and enabling true real-time one-step editing on challenging one-step T2I models.
AI.conclusion: By replacing ad-hoc vector arithmetic with a dynamic optimal transport control, ChordEdit stabilizes one-step editing, delivering high-fidelity, consistent results in real time and unlocking practical editing for one-step T2I systems.

title: VIGiA: Instructional Video Guidance via Dialogue Reasoning and Retrieval
summary: We introduce VIGiA, a novel multimodal dialogue model designed to understand and reason over complex, multi-step instructional video action plans. Unlike prior work which focuses mainly on text-only guidance, or treats vision and language in isolation, VIGiA supports grounded, plan-aware dialogue that requires reasoning over visual inputs, instructional plans, and interleaved user interactions. To this end, VIGiA incorporates two key capabilities: (1) multimodal plan reasoning, enabling the model to align uni- and multimodal queries with the current task plan and respond accurately; and (2) plan-based retrieval, allowing it to retrieve relevant plan steps in either textual or visual representations. Experiments were done on a novel dataset with rich Instructional Video Dialogues aligned with Cooking and DIY plans. Our evaluation shows that VIGiA outperforms existing state-of-the-art models on all tasks in a conversational plan guidance setting, reaching over 90\% accuracy on plan-aware VQA.

AI.tldr: VIGiA is a multimodal dialogue system that grounds user interactions in instructional video plans, combining visual understanding with plan-aware reasoning and retrieval to guide users through tasks, outperforming prior models (90%+ on plan-aware VQA).
AI.motivation: Existing systems either rely on text-only guidance or treat vision and language separately, limiting their ability to provide grounded, step-aware help during complex, multi-step tasks in instructional videos. There is a need for dialogue agents that can reason over visual evidence, explicit plans, and dynamic user queries.
AI.method: Introduce VIGiA with two core capabilities: (1) multimodal plan reasoning to align uni-/multimodal queries with the current step of a task plan and produce accurate, grounded responses; (2) plan-based retrieval to fetch relevant plan steps in text or visual form. Evaluate on a newly curated dataset of Instructional Video Dialogues aligned with Cooking and DIY plans.
AI.result: VIGiA outperforms state-of-the-art baselines across tasks in conversational plan guidance, achieving over 90% accuracy on plan-aware visual question answering (VQA).
AI.conclusion: Plan-aware multimodal reasoning combined with plan-step retrieval enables more accurate, grounded assistance in instructional dialogues. The new dataset and results suggest this approach is effective for complex, step-by-step guidance and sets a new benchmark for plan-aware VQA.

title: Restoration-Guided Kuzushiji Character Recognition Framework under Seal Interference
summary: Kuzushiji was one of the most popular writing styles in pre-modern Japan and was widely used in both personal letters and official documents. However, due to its highly cursive forms and extensive glyph variations, most modern Japanese readers cannot directly interpret Kuzushiji characters. Therefore, recent research has focused on developing automated Kuzushiji character recognition methods, which have achieved satisfactory performance on relatively clean Kuzushiji document images. However, existing methods struggle to maintain recognition accuracy under seal interference (e.g., when seals overlap characters), despite the frequent occurrence of seals in pre-modern Japanese documents. To address this challenge, we propose a three-stage restoration-guided Kuzushiji character recognition (RG-KCR) framework specifically designed to mitigate seal interference. We construct datasets for evaluating Kuzushiji character detection (Stage 1) and classification (Stage 3). Experimental results show that the YOLOv12-medium model achieves a precision of 98.0% and a recall of 93.3% on the constructed test set. We quantitatively evaluate the restoration performance of Stage 2 using PSNR and SSIM. In addition, we conduct an ablation study to demonstrate that Stage 2 improves the Top-1 accuracy of Metom, a Vision Transformer (ViT)-based Kuzushiji classifier employed in Stage 3, from 93.45% to 95.33%. The implementation code of this work is available at https://ruiyangju.github.io/RG-KCR.

AI.tldr: They introduce a three-stage, restoration-guided pipeline (RG-KCR) to recognize Kuzushiji characters when red seals overlap the text, achieving strong detection and improved classification accuracy over baselines.
AI.motivation: Kuzushiji, a cursive pre-modern Japanese script, is hard for modern readers and current automated recognizers—especially when ink seals overlap characters, a frequent real-world artifact that degrades recognition accuracy.
AI.method: RG-KCR is a three-stage framework: (1) detect character regions (YOLOv12-medium), (2) restore/seal-mitigate the detected regions to remove seal interference (restoration quality assessed via PSNR/SSIM), and (3) classify restored characters using Metom, a ViT-based Kuzushiji classifier. New datasets are constructed for Stage 1 (detection) and Stage 3 (classification).
AI.result: On the constructed test set, YOLOv12-medium attains 98.0% precision and 93.3% recall for detection. The restoration stage boosts the Top-1 accuracy of the Stage-3 Metom classifier from 93.45% to 95.33%. Restoration quality is quantitatively evaluated using PSNR and SSIM (values not specified).
AI.conclusion: Explicit restoration to counter seal interference materially improves Kuzushiji OCR robustness: the pipeline delivers high detection performance and raises classification accuracy. Resources (code) are released, indicating reproducibility and practical applicability for real-world historical documents with seals.

title: Ani3DHuman: Photorealistic 3D Human Animation with Self-guided Stochastic Sampling
summary: Current 3D human animation methods struggle to achieve photorealism: kinematics-based approaches lack non-rigid dynamics (e.g., clothing dynamics), while methods that leverage video diffusion priors can synthesize non-rigid motion but suffer from quality artifacts and identity loss. To overcome these limitations, we present Ani3DHuman, a framework that marries kinematics-based animation with video diffusion priors. We first introduce a layered motion representation that disentangles rigid motion from residual non-rigid motion. Rigid motion is generated by a kinematic method, which then produces a coarse rendering to guide the video diffusion model in generating video sequences that restore the residual non-rigid motion. However, this restoration task, based on diffusion sampling, is highly challenging, as the initial renderings are out-of-distribution, causing standard deterministic ODE samplers to fail. Therefore, we propose a novel self-guided stochastic sampling method, which effectively addresses the out-of-distribution problem by combining stochastic sampling (for photorealistic quality) with self-guidance (for identity fidelity). These restored videos provide high-quality supervision, enabling the optimization of the residual non-rigid motion field. Extensive experiments demonstrate that \MethodName can generate photorealistic 3D human animation, outperforming existing methods. Code is available in https://github.com/qiisun/ani3dhuman.

AI.tldr: Ani3DHuman achieves photorealistic 3D human animation by combining kinematics-driven rigid motion with a video-diffusion prior that restores non‑rigid dynamics, enabled by a new self-guided stochastic sampler that handles out-of-distribution coarse renders while preserving identity.
AI.motivation: Kinematics-based methods miss non-rigid dynamics (e.g., clothing), while diffusion-based video synthesis offers such detail but introduces artifacts and identity drift. A unified approach is needed to keep identity fidelity and structure from kinematics while gaining photorealistic non-rigid motion from diffusion, and to address the out-of-distribution nature of coarse render conditioning that breaks standard samplers.
AI.method: 1) Use a layered motion representation that disentangles rigid motion from residual non-rigid motion. 2) Generate rigid motion via a kinematic pipeline and produce coarse renderings. 3) Condition a video diffusion model to reconstruct the residual non-rigid motion from these renders. 4) Introduce a self-guided stochastic sampling procedure that blends stochasticity (for realism) with self-guidance (for identity) to robustly sample from out-of-distribution inputs. 5) Use the restored videos as high-quality supervision to optimize the residual non-rigid motion field.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show Ani3DHuman produces photorealistic human animations with high identity fidelity and realistic non-rigid effects, outperforming prior methods; code is released at the provided repository.
AI.conclusion: By marrying kinematics with a diffusion prior through a layered representation and a novel self-guided stochastic sampler, Ani3DHuman overcomes identity loss and artifact issues in diffusion-only methods and the rigidity of kinematics-only approaches, delivering state-of-the-art photorealistic 3D human animation.

title: CREM: Compression-Driven Representation Enhancement for Multimodal Retrieval and Comprehension
summary: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have shown remarkable success in comprehension tasks such as visual description and visual question answering. However, their direct application to embedding-based tasks like retrieval remains challenging due to the discrepancy between output formats and optimization objectives. Previous approaches often employ contrastive fine-tuning to adapt MLLMs for retrieval, but at the cost of losing their generative capabilities. We argue that both generative and embedding tasks fundamentally rely on shared cognitive mechanisms, specifically cross-modal representation alignment and contextual comprehension. To this end, we propose CREM (Compression-driven Representation Enhanced Model), with a unified framework that enhances multimodal representations for retrieval while preserving generative ability. Specifically, we introduce a compression-based prompt design with learnable chorus tokens to aggregate multimodal semantics and a compression-driven training strategy that integrates contrastive and generative objectives through compression-aware attention. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CREM achieves state-of-the-art retrieval performance on MMEB while maintaining strong generative performance on multiple comprehension benchmarks. Our findings highlight that generative supervision can further improve the representational quality of MLLMs under the proposed compression-driven paradigm.

AI.tldr: CREM is a compression-driven framework for MLLMs that uses learnable chorus tokens and compression-aware attention to jointly optimize generative and contrastive objectives, yielding state-of-the-art multimodal retrieval while preserving strong generative abilities.
AI.motivation: MLLMs excel at generative comprehension (captions, VQA) but struggle with embedding-based retrieval due to mismatched output formats and training objectives; contrastive fine-tuning helps retrieval yet degrades generation. The authors posit that both tasks share core mechanisms—cross-modal alignment and contextual understanding—so a unified approach should enhance retrieval without sacrificing generation.
AI.method: Design a compression-based prompting scheme with learnable chorus tokens that aggregate multimodal semantics into compact representations. Train with a compression-driven strategy that fuses contrastive (retrieval) and generative (instruction/comprehension) losses via compression-aware attention, thereby strengthening shared representations while maintaining decoding ability.
AI.result: On MMEB, CREM achieves state-of-the-art retrieval results. It also maintains strong performance on multiple generative comprehension benchmarks. Empirically, adding generative supervision further improves representation quality under the compression-driven setup.
AI.conclusion: A unified, compression-oriented representation learning paradigm can bridge generative and embedding tasks in MLLMs, delivering superior retrieval without sacrificing generative capabilities. Compression tokens and attention provide effective cross-modal aggregation, and mixed supervision is mutually beneficial.

title: Adaptive Data Augmentation with Multi-armed Bandit: Sample-Efficient Embedding Calibration for Implicit Pattern Recognition
summary: Recognizing implicit visual and textual patterns is essential in many real-world applications of modern AI. However, tackling long-tail pattern recognition tasks remains challenging for current pre-trained foundation models such as LLMs and VLMs. While finetuning pre-trained models can improve accuracy in recognizing implicit patterns, it is usually infeasible due to a lack of training data and high computational overhead. In this paper, we propose ADAMAB, an efficient embedding calibration framework for few-shot pattern recognition. To maximally reduce the computational costs, ADAMAB trains embedder-agnostic light-weight calibrators on top of fixed embedding models without accessing their parameters. To mitigate the need for large-scale training data, we introduce an adaptive data augmentation strategy based on the Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB) mechanism. With a modified upper confidence bound algorithm, ADAMAB diminishes the gradient shifting and offers theoretically guaranteed convergence in few-shot training. Our multi-modal experiments justify the superior performance of ADAMAB, with up to 40% accuracy improvement when training with less than 5 initial data samples of each class.

AI.tldr: ADAMAB is a lightweight, embedder-agnostic calibration framework that boosts few-shot, long-tail pattern recognition across modalities by training small calibrators on frozen embeddings and using a bandit-driven data augmentation scheme, achieving up to 40% accuracy gains with <5 shots per class.
AI.motivation: Foundational LLM/VLM embeddings struggle with implicit and long-tail patterns; full finetuning is often infeasible due to scarce labeled data and high compute. There is a need for a low-cost method that adapts pretrained embeddings to recognize subtle, underrepresented patterns with very few examples.
AI.method: Train lightweight, embedder-agnostic calibrators on top of fixed embedding models (no access to or updates of backbone parameters). Introduce adaptive data augmentation guided by a Multi-Armed Bandit with a modified UCB rule to select effective augmentations, reducing gradient shift and providing theoretical convergence guarantees under few-shot regimes.
AI.result: Across multimodal benchmarks, ADAMAB delivers superior few-shot performance, reporting up to 40% accuracy improvement with fewer than five labeled samples per class compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: Calibrating frozen embeddings with bandit-guided augmentation is an effective, compute-efficient alternative to finetuning for few-shot long-tail pattern recognition, backed by theoretical guarantees and strong empirical gains across modalities.

title: Universal 3D Shape Matching via Coarse-to-Fine Language Guidance
summary: Establishing dense correspondences between shapes is a crucial task in computer vision and graphics, while prior approaches depend on near-isometric assumptions and homogeneous subject types (i.e., only operate for human shapes). However, building semantic correspondences for cross-category objects remains challenging and has received relatively little attention. To achieve this, we propose UniMatch, a semantic-aware, coarse-to-fine framework for constructing dense semantic correspondences between strongly non-isometric shapes without restricting object categories. The key insight is to lift "coarse" semantic cues into "fine" correspondence, which is achieved through two stages. In the "coarse" stage, we perform class-agnostic 3D segmentation to obtain non-overlapping semantic parts and prompt multimodal large language models (MLLMs) to identify part names. Then, we employ pretrained vision language models (VLMs) to extract text embeddings, enabling the construction of matched semantic parts. In the "fine" stage, we leverage these coarse correspondences to guide the learning of dense correspondences through a dedicated rank-based contrastive scheme. Thanks to class-agnostic segmentation, language guiding, and rank-based contrastive learning, our method is versatile for universal object categories and requires no predefined part proposals, enabling universal matching for inter-class and non-isometric shapes. Extensive experiments demonstrate UniMatch consistently outperforms competing methods in various challenging scenarios.

AI.tldr: UniMatch builds dense, semantic correspondences across arbitrary 3D object categories—even with strong non‑isometric deformations—via a language‑guided, coarse‑to‑fine pipeline that first matches parts and then refines to pointwise maps, outperforming prior methods.
AI.motivation: Most correspondence methods assume near‑isometry and focus on homogeneous categories (e.g., humans), making cross‑category, strongly non‑isometric semantic matching underexplored and challenging.
AI.method: A two‑stage framework: (1) Coarse: class‑agnostic 3D segmentation yields non‑overlapping parts; multimodal LLMs assign part names; pretrained VLMs provide text embeddings to match corresponding parts across shapes. (2) Fine: the coarse part matches guide dense correspondence learning via a rank‑based contrastive loss, producing pointwise maps without predefined part proposals.
AI.result: Across diverse benchmarks and challenging settings, UniMatch consistently outperforms competing approaches on dense semantic correspondence tasks.
AI.conclusion: Language‑guided, class‑agnostic, coarse‑to‑fine matching with rank‑based contrastive learning enables universal, inter‑class, non‑isometric dense correspondence without category restrictions or hand‑crafted part proposals.

title: Keep it SymPL: Symbolic Projective Layout for Allocentric Spatial Reasoning in Vision-Language Models
summary: Perspective-aware spatial reasoning involves understanding spatial relationships from specific viewpoints-either egocentric (observer-centered) or allocentric (object-centered). While vision-language models (VLMs) perform well in egocentric settings, their performance deteriorates when reasoning from allocentric viewpoints, where spatial relations must be inferred from the perspective of objects within the scene. In this study, we address this underexplored challenge by introducing Symbolic Projective Layout (SymPL), a framework that reformulates allocentric reasoning into symbolic-layout forms that VLMs inherently handle well. By leveraging four key factors-projection, abstraction, bipartition, and localization-SymPL converts allocentric questions into structured symbolic-layout representations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that this reformulation substantially improves performance in both allocentric and egocentric tasks, enhances robustness under visual illusions and multi-view scenarios, and that each component contributes critically to these gains. These results show that SymPL provides an effective and principled approach for addressing complex perspective-aware spatial reasoning.

AI.tldr: SymPL reframes allocentric spatial questions into symbolic projective layouts—via projection, abstraction, bipartition, and localization—so VLMs can reason from object-centric perspectives, yielding strong gains, robustness to illusions/multi-view, and positive ablations.
AI.motivation: VLMs excel at egocentric (observer-centered) reasoning but struggle with allocentric (object-centered) perspectives where spatial relations must be inferred from an object’s viewpoint. The gap limits reliable perspective-aware reasoning in real scenes.
AI.method: Introduce Symbolic Projective Layout (SymPL), which converts allocentric questions into structured symbolic-layout representations that VLMs handle well. The pipeline uses: (1) projection to map scenes from relevant object viewpoints; (2) abstraction to simplify visual detail into symbolic entities/relations; (3) bipartition to discretize spatial relations into manageable partitions; and (4) localization to place entities within the symbolic layout. These structured prompts are fed to VLMs to perform reasoning.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, SymPL substantially improves performance on allocentric and also egocentric tasks, increases robustness under visual illusions and multi-view settings, and ablation studies show each of the four components is necessary and contributes meaningfully.
AI.conclusion: Reformulating perspective-aware spatial reasoning into symbolic projective layouts is an effective, principled approach that closes the allocentric gap in VLMs while also enhancing robustness and general performance.

title: StreetTree: A Large-Scale Global Benchmark for Fine-Grained Tree Species Classification
summary: The fine-grained classification of street trees is a crucial task for urban planning, streetscape management, and the assessment of urban ecosystem services. However, progress in this field has been significantly hindered by the lack of large-scale, geographically diverse, and publicly available benchmark datasets specifically designed for street trees. To address this critical gap, we introduce StreetTree, the world's first large-scale benchmark dataset dedicated to fine-grained street tree classification. The dataset contains over 12 million images covering more than 8,300 common street tree species, collected from urban streetscapes across 133 countries spanning five continents, and supplemented with expert-verified observational data. StreetTree poses substantial challenges for pretrained vision models under complex urban environments: high inter-species visual similarity, long-tailed natural distributions, significant intra-class variations caused by seasonal changes, and diverse imaging conditions such as lighting, occlusions from buildings, and varying camera angles. In addition, we provide a hierarchical taxonomy (order-family-genus-species) to support research in hierarchical classification and representation learning. Through extensive experiments with various visual models, we establish strong baselines and reveal the limitations of existing methods in handling such real-world complexities. We believe that StreetTree will serve as a key resource for the refined management and research of urban street trees, while also driving new advancements at the intersection of computer vision and urban science.

AI.tldr: StreetTree introduces a massive, globally diverse benchmark (12M images, 8.3k species, 133 countries) for fine-grained street-tree recognition, provides a hierarchical taxonomy, sets baselines, and exposes limits of current vision models in messy urban conditions.
AI.motivation: Fine-grained street-tree classification supports urban planning, streetscape management, and ecosystem-service assessment, but progress has stalled due to the absence of a large, public, geographically diverse benchmark tailored to street trees.
AI.method: Curate a large-scale dataset of street-tree images from urban streetscapes across 133 countries (five continents), augment with expert-verified observations, and construct a hierarchical taxonomy (order–family–genus–species). Evaluate a range of pretrained vision models to establish baselines and probe real-world challenges: inter-species similarity, long-tailed distributions, seasonal intra-class variation, and varied capture conditions (lighting, occlusions, viewpoints).
AI.result: Delivered the StreetTree dataset (12M+ images, 8.3k+ species) with hierarchical labels and comprehensive evaluations. Baseline experiments show current models struggle with the dataset’s real-world complexities, revealing notable performance limitations despite pretraining.
AI.conclusion: StreetTree fills a critical data gap and is poised to catalyze research in fine-grained and hierarchical classification, advancing computer vision methods and enabling more refined urban-tree management and urban-science applications.

title: Mapping Networks
summary: The escalating parameter counts in modern deep learning models pose a fundamental challenge to efficient training and resolution of overfitting. We address this by introducing the \emph{Mapping Networks} which replace the high dimensional weight space by a compact, trainable latent vector based on the hypothesis that the trained parameters of large networks reside on smooth, low-dimensional manifolds. Henceforth, the Mapping Theorem enforced by a dedicated Mapping Loss, shows the existence of a mapping from this latent space to the target weight space both theoretically and in practice. Mapping Networks significantly reduce overfitting and achieve comparable to better performance than target network across complex vision and sequence tasks, including Image Classification, Deepfake Detection etc, with $\mathbf{99.5\%}$, i.e., around $500\times$ reduction in trainable parameters.

AI.tldr: They propose Mapping Networks that replace a model’s full parameter set with a small trainable latent vector and a learned mapping to weights, claiming large reductions in parameters (~99.5%, ~500×) while maintaining or improving accuracy and reducing overfitting on vision and sequence tasks.
AI.motivation: Modern deep models have massive parameter counts, which are costly to train and prone to overfitting. The authors hypothesize that trained weights lie on smooth, low-dimensional manifolds, so a compact representation could suffice.
AI.method: Introduce a Mapping Network: a low-dimensional latent code plus a learned mapping function that generates the target network’s weights. They define a Mapping Loss and state a Mapping Theorem to justify/explain the existence and training of such mappings. The approach is evaluated on image classification, deepfake detection, and sequence tasks.
AI.result: The method reportedly achieves comparable or better performance than the original full-parameter models while cutting trainable parameters by ~99.5% (~500×) and reducing overfitting. They also provide theoretical support and empirical evidence for the mapping’s effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Weight spaces of large models can be effectively parameterized via low-dimensional latent codes with a learned mapping, yielding substantial efficiency gains and less overfitting without sacrificing accuracy across multiple domains.

title: CaReFlow: Cyclic Adaptive Rectified Flow for Multimodal Fusion
summary: Modality gap significantly restricts the effectiveness of multimodal fusion. Previous methods often use techniques such as diffusion models and adversarial learning to reduce the modality gap, but they typically focus on one-to-one alignment without exposing the data points of the source modality to the global distribution information of the target modality. To this end, leveraging the characteristic of rectified flow that can map one distribution to another via a straight trajectory, we extend rectified flow for modality distribution mapping. Specifically, we leverage the `one-to-many mapping' strategy in rectified flow that allows each data point of the source modality to observe the overall target distribution. This also alleviates the issue of insufficient paired data within each sample, enabling a more robust distribution transformation. Moreover, to achieve more accurate distribution mapping and address the ambiguous flow directions in one-to-many mapping, we design `adaptive relaxed alignment', enforcing stricter alignment for modality pairs belonging to the same sample, while applying relaxed mapping for pairs not belonging to the same sample or category. Additionally, to prevent information loss during distribution mapping, we introduce `cyclic rectified flow' to ensure the transferred features can be translated back to the original features, allowing multimodal representations to learn sufficient modality-specific information. After distribution alignment, our approach achieves very competitive results on multiple tasks of multimodal affective computing even with a simple fusion method, and visualizations verify that it can effectively reduce the modality gap.

AI.tldr: They propose a rectified-flow-based, one-to-many cross-modal distribution mapping with adaptive relaxed alignment and cyclic consistency to shrink modality gaps, preserving modality-specific info and delivering strong results on multimodal affective computing with even simple fusion.
AI.motivation: Multimodal fusion suffers from a modality gap. Prior diffusion/adversarial approaches mostly do one-to-one alignment, so each source sample only sees its paired target, missing the global target distribution and struggling when paired data are scarce.
AI.method: Extend rectified flow to modality distribution mapping. Use a one-to-many mapping so each source sample is exposed to the global target distribution. Resolve ambiguous flow directions via adaptive relaxed alignment: strict alignment for same-sample pairs; relaxed mapping for cross-sample or cross-category pairs. Add cyclic rectified flow (cycle consistency) to enable mapped features to reconstruct original ones, preserving modality-specific information. Perform fusion after alignment (even simple fusion suffices).
AI.result: Across multiple multimodal affective computing tasks, the method achieves very competitive performance; qualitative visualizations indicate the modality gap is effectively reduced. (No specific metrics reported in the abstract.)
AI.conclusion: Global, rectified-flow-based distribution alignment with adaptive relaxation and cyclic consistency reduces modality gaps, improves robustness under limited pairing, and maintains modality-specific details, enabling strong downstream performance with simple fusion.

title: Artefact-Aware Fungal Detection in Dermatophytosis: A Real-Time Transformer-Based Approach for KOH Microscopy
summary: Dermatophytosis is commonly assessed using potassium hydroxide (KOH) microscopy, yet accurate recognition of fungal hyphae is hindered by artefacts, heterogeneous keratin clearance, and notable inter-observer variability. This study presents a transformer-based detection framework using the RT-DETR model architecture to achieve precise, query-driven localization of fungal structures in high-resolution KOH images. A dataset of 2,540 routinely acquired microscopy images was manually annotated using a multi-class strategy to explicitly distinguish fungal elements from confounding artefacts. The model was trained with morphology-preserving augmentations to maintain the structural integrity of thin hyphae. Evaluation on an independent test set demonstrated robust object-level performance, with a recall of 0.9737, precision of 0.8043, and an AP@0.50 of 93.56%. When aggregated for image-level diagnosis, the model achieved 100% sensitivity and 98.8% accuracy, correctly identifying all positive cases without missing a single diagnosis. Qualitative outputs confirmed the robust localization of low-contrast hyphae even in artefact-rich fields. These results highlight that an artificial intelligence (AI) system can serve as a highly reliable, automated screening tool, effectively bridging the gap between image-level analysis and clinical decision-making in dermatomycology.

AI.tldr: Transformer-based RT-DETR detects fungal hyphae in KOH microscopy with high object-level performance (AP@0.50 93.56%, recall 0.97) and perfect image-level sensitivity, suggesting a reliable automated screening aid in dermatomycology.
AI.motivation: KOH microscopy for dermatophytosis is hampered by artefacts, uneven keratin clearance, and inter-observer variability; a robust, consistent, and localized AI aid is needed to reduce missed diagnoses and standardize reads.
AI.method: Built a 2,540-image dataset of routine KOH microscopy, manually annotated with a multi-class scheme to separate true fungal elements from look-alike artefacts. Trained an RT-DETR transformer detector with morphology-preserving augmentations to retain thin-hypha structure. Evaluated on an independent test set with object-level (precision, recall, AP@0.50) and image-level aggregated diagnosis; provided qualitative visualizations for low-contrast/artefact-rich fields.
AI.result: Object-level: recall 0.9737, precision 0.8043, AP@0.50 93.56%. Image-level aggregation: 100% sensitivity and 98.8% accuracy; no positives missed. Visuals show robust localization of faint hyphae amid artefacts.
AI.conclusion: A query-driven transformer detector can accurately localize hyphae in routine KOH slides and, when aggregated, achieve near-perfect screening performance, potentially reducing inter-observer variability and missed cases. Further external validation and workflow integration studies are warranted.

title: Flash-VAED: Plug-and-Play VAE Decoders for Efficient Video Generation
comment: Code will be released at https://github.com/Aoko955/Flash-VAED
summary: Latent diffusion models have enabled high-quality video synthesis, yet their inference remains costly and time-consuming. As diffusion transformers become increasingly efficient, the latency bottleneck inevitably shifts to VAE decoders. To reduce their latency while maintaining quality, we propose a universal acceleration framework for VAE decoders that preserves full alignment with the original latent distribution. Specifically, we propose (1) an independence-aware channel pruning method to effectively mitigate severe channel redundancy, and (2) a stage-wise dominant operator optimization strategy to address the high inference cost of the widely used causal 3D convolutions in VAE decoders. Based on these innovations, we construct a Flash-VAED family. Moreover, we design a three-phase dynamic distillation framework that efficiently transfers the capabilities of the original VAE decoder to Flash-VAED. Extensive experiments on Wan and LTX-Video VAE decoders demonstrate that our method outperforms baselines in both quality and speed, achieving approximately a 6$\times$ speedup while maintaining the reconstruction performance up to 96.9%. Notably, Flash-VAED accelerates the end-to-end generation pipeline by up to 36% with negligible quality drops on VBench-2.0.

AI.tldr: Flash-VAED accelerates video VAE decoders ~6× via independence-aware channel pruning and stage-wise optimization of causal 3D convs, using a three-phase dynamic distillation to preserve alignment and quality, yielding up to 36% faster end-to-end generation with negligible quality loss.
AI.motivation: As diffusion transformers speed up, inference latency shifts to VAE decoders in latent video diffusion pipelines. Reducing decoder latency without breaking compatibility with the original latent distribution is crucial to keep overall generation fast and high-quality.
AI.method: (1) Independence-aware channel pruning to remove redundant channels while preserving distributional alignment; (2) Stage-wise dominant operator optimization targeting costly causal 3D convolutions to cut compute; (3) A three-phase dynamic distillation to transfer the teacher decoder’s behavior to the pruned/optimized student (Flash-VAED), forming a universal acceleration framework.
AI.result: On Wan and LTX-Video VAE decoders, the approach outperforms baselines in speed and quality, delivering ~6× decoder speedup while retaining up to 96.9% reconstruction performance; end-to-end pipeline acceleration reaches up to 36% on VBench-2.0 with negligible quality drops.
AI.conclusion: A generally applicable framework can substantially reduce video VAE decoder latency while maintaining alignment to original latents and near-original reconstruction quality, improving practical throughput of latent video diffusion systems.

title: JavisDiT++: Unified Modeling and Optimization for Joint Audio-Video Generation
summary: AIGC has rapidly expanded from text-to-image generation toward high-quality multimodal synthesis across video and audio. Within this context, joint audio-video generation (JAVG) has emerged as a fundamental task that produces synchronized and semantically aligned sound and vision from textual descriptions. However, compared with advanced commercial models such as Veo3, existing open-source methods still suffer from limitations in generation quality, temporal synchrony, and alignment with human preferences. To bridge the gap, this paper presents JavisDiT++, a concise yet powerful framework for unified modeling and optimization of JAVG. First, we introduce a modality-specific mixture-of-experts (MS-MoE) design that enables cross-modal interaction efficacy while enhancing single-modal generation quality. Then, we propose a temporal-aligned RoPE (TA-RoPE) strategy to achieve explicit, frame-level synchronization between audio and video tokens. Besides, we develop an audio-video direct preference optimization (AV-DPO) method to align model outputs with human preference across quality, consistency, and synchrony dimensions. Built upon Wan2.1-1.3B-T2V, our model achieves state-of-the-art performance merely with around 1M public training entries, significantly outperforming prior approaches in both qualitative and quantitative evaluations. Comprehensive ablation studies have been conducted to validate the effectiveness of our proposed modules.
