All the code, model, and dataset are released at https://JavisVerse.github.io/JavisDiT2-page.

AI.tldr: JavisDiT++ is a unified joint audio–video generation framework that boosts quality, temporal synchrony, and human-preference alignment via modality-specific MoE, a temporally aligned rotary positional encoding, and preference optimization—achieving state-of-the-art results with only ~1M public training samples.
AI.motivation: Open-source JAVG lags behind commercial systems (e.g., Veo3) in generation quality, frame-accurate audio–video synchrony, and alignment with human preferences. The authors aim to close this gap with a concise, unified approach that improves both cross-modal interaction and single-modal fidelity.
AI.method: Build on Wan2.1-1.3B-T2V and introduce three key components: (1) Modality-Specific Mixture-of-Experts (MS-MoE) to enhance single-modal quality while enabling effective cross-modal interaction; (2) Temporal-Aligned RoPE (TA-RoPE) for explicit, frame-level synchronization between audio and video tokens; (3) Audio-Video Direct Preference Optimization (AV-DPO) to align outputs with human preferences across quality, consistency, and synchrony.
AI.result: The model attains state-of-the-art performance on JAVG using ~1M public training entries, with significant gains over prior methods in both qualitative and quantitative evaluations. Ablation studies confirm each module’s contribution.
AI.conclusion: JavisDiT++ offers a compact, effective, and data-efficient solution for synchronized, high-quality text-conditioned audio–video generation, narrowing the gap with commercial systems. Code, models, and dataset are released for reproducibility and further research.

title: BriMA: Bridged Modality Adaptation for Multi-Modal Continual Action Quality Assessment
summary: Action Quality Assessment (AQA) aims to score how well an action is performed and is widely used in sports analysis, rehabilitation assessment, and human skill evaluation. Multi-modal AQA has recently achieved strong progress by leveraging complementary visual and kinematic cues, yet real-world deployments often suffer from non-stationary modality imbalance, where certain modalities become missing or intermittently available due to sensor failures or annotation gaps. Existing continual AQA methods overlook this issue and assume that all modalities remain complete and stable throughout training, which restricts their practicality. To address this challenge, we introduce Bridged Modality Adaptation (BriMA), an innovative approach to multi-modal continual AQA under modality-missing conditions. BriMA consists of a memory-guided bridging imputation module that reconstructs missing modalities using both task-agnostic and task-specific representations, and a modality-aware replay mechanism that prioritizes informative samples based on modality distortion and distribution drift. Experiments on three representative multi-modal AQA datasets (RG, Fis-V, and FS1000) show that BriMA consistently improves performance under different modality-missing conditions, achieving 6--8\% higher correlation and 12--15\% lower error on average. These results demonstrate a step toward robust multi-modal AQA systems under real-world deployment constraints.

AI.tldr: BriMA is a continual multi‑modal AQA method that handles missing modalities via bridging imputation and modality‑aware replay, yielding 6–8% higher correlation and 12–15% lower error across three datasets under modality-missing conditions.
AI.motivation: Real-world AQA deployments face non-stationary modality imbalance: sensors fail or annotations are intermittent, so visual/kinematic streams can be missing. Existing continual AQA assumes complete, stable modalities, limiting practicality.
AI.method: Bridged Modality Adaptation (BriMA) combines: (1) a memory‑guided bridging imputation module that reconstructs missing modalities using both task‑agnostic and task‑specific representations; and (2) a modality‑aware replay mechanism that prioritizes samples based on measured modality distortion and distribution drift to stabilize continual learning.
AI.result: On RG, Fis‑V, and FS1000 datasets, BriMA consistently improves performance under various missing‑modality settings, achieving on average 6–8% higher correlation and 12–15% lower error than baselines.
AI.conclusion: BriMA increases robustness of multi‑modal continual AQA to real‑world missing‑modality scenarios, marking a practical step toward deployable AQA systems.

title: EMAD: Evidence-Centric Grounded Multimodal Diagnosis for Alzheimer's Disease
summary: Deep learning models for medical image analysis often act as black boxes, seldom aligning with clinical guidelines or explicitly linking decisions to supporting evidence. This is especially critical in Alzheimer's disease (AD), where predictions should be grounded in both anatomical and clinical findings. We present EMAD, a vision-language framework that generates structured AD diagnostic reports in which each claim is explicitly grounded in multimodal evidence. EMAD uses a hierarchical Sentence-Evidence-Anatomy (SEA) grounding mechanism: (i) sentence-to-evidence grounding links generated sentences to clinical evidence phrases, and (ii) evidence-to-anatomy grounding localizes corresponding structures on 3D brain MRI. To reduce dense annotation requirements, we propose GTX-Distill, which transfers grounding behavior from a teacher trained with limited supervision to a student operating on model-generated reports. We further introduce Executable-Rule GRPO, a reinforcement fine-tuning scheme with verifiable rewards that enforces clinical consistency, protocol adherence, and reasoning-diagnosis coherence. On the AD-MultiSense dataset, EMAD achieves state-of-the-art diagnostic accuracy and produces more transparent, anatomically faithful reports than existing methods. We will release code and grounding annotations to support future research in trustworthy medical vision-language models.

AI.tldr: EMAD is a vision‑language framework for Alzheimer’s diagnosis that generates structured, clinically consistent reports whose claims are explicitly grounded first to textual evidence and then to localized 3D MRI anatomy. It uses hierarchical grounding (SEA), a teacher–student grounding distillation (GTX‑Distill), and rule‑based reinforcement fine‑tuning (Executable‑Rule GRPO), achieving state‑of‑the‑art accuracy and improved transparency on AD‑MultiSense.
AI.motivation: Current medical imaging AI acts as a black box, rarely tying predictions to clinical guidelines or concrete evidence. In Alzheimer’s disease, trustworthy deployment requires explanations that align with clinical reasoning and anatomical findings.
AI.method: Proposes EMAD with hierarchical Sentence‑Evidence‑Anatomy (SEA) grounding: (i) link generated report sentences to clinical evidence phrases; (ii) ground those evidence phrases to specific 3D MRI structures. Introduces GTX‑Distill to transfer grounding behavior from a limited‑supervision teacher to a student trained on model‑generated reports, reducing dense annotation needs. Adds Executable‑Rule GRPO, a reinforcement fine‑tuning scheme using verifiable rules to enforce clinical consistency, protocol adherence, and coherence between reasoning and diagnosis.
AI.result: On the AD‑MultiSense dataset, EMAD attains state‑of‑the‑art diagnostic accuracy and produces reports that are more transparent and anatomically faithful than prior methods.
AI.conclusion: Grounded, rule‑consistent vision‑language reporting can enhance trust and reliability in AD diagnostics. EMAD’s hierarchical grounding, distillation to cut annotation costs, and rule‑verified RL collectively improve both accuracy and interpretability; released code and annotations aim to catalyze future trustworthy medical VLM research.

title: VLM-Guided Group Preference Alignment for Diffusion-based Human Mesh Recovery
summary: Human mesh recovery (HMR) from a single RGB image is inherently ambiguous, as multiple 3D poses can correspond to the same 2D observation. Recent diffusion-based methods tackle this by generating various hypotheses, but often sacrifice accuracy. They yield predictions that are either physically implausible or drift from the input image, especially under occlusion or in cluttered, in-the-wild scenes. To address this, we introduce a dual-memory augmented HMR critique agent with self-reflection to produce context-aware quality scores for predicted meshes. These scores distill fine-grained cues about 3D human motion structure, physical feasibility, and alignment with the input image. We use these scores to build a group-wise HMR preference dataset. Leveraging this dataset, we propose a group preference alignment framework for finetuning diffusion-based HMR models. This process injects the rich preference signals into the model, guiding it to generate more physically plausible and image-consistent human meshes. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

AI.tldr: They train diffusion-based human mesh recovery models to prefer physically plausible, image-consistent poses by learning from a critique agent that scores multiple hypotheses and then aligning the generator to these preferences, yielding SOTA accuracy and robustness.
AI.motivation: Single-image HMR is ambiguous; diffusion models can generate diverse 3D pose hypotheses but often drift from the image or violate physics, especially with occlusion/clutter. There is a need to enforce plausibility and image alignment without losing diversity.
AI.method: Introduce a dual-memory, self-reflective critique agent that assigns context-aware quality scores to predicted meshes (capturing motion structure, physical feasibility, and image alignment). Use these scores to build a group-wise preference dataset and finetune diffusion HMR via a group preference alignment framework to steer generation toward higher-quality hypotheses.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, the aligned models produce more physically plausible and image-consistent meshes and outperform state-of-the-art baselines on standard benchmarks and challenging in-the-wild settings.
AI.conclusion: Critique-driven, preference-based alignment effectively resolves the accuracy–diversity trade-off in diffusion HMR, improving robustness and plausibility. The approach provides a general pathway to inject rich structural and physical priors into generative HMR systems.

title: PositionOCR: Augmenting Positional Awareness in Multi-Modal Models via Hybrid Specialist Integration
summary: In recent years, Multi-modal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have achieved strong performance in OCR-centric Visual Question Answering (VQA) tasks, illustrating their capability to process heterogeneous data and exhibit adaptability across varied contexts. However, these MLLMs rely on a Large Language Model (LLM) as the decoder, which is primarily designed for linguistic processing, and thus inherently lacks the positional reasoning required for precise visual tasks, such as text spotting and text grounding. Additionally, the extensive parameters of MLLMs necessitate substantial computational resources and large-scale data for effective training. Conversely, text spotting specialists achieve state-of-the-art coordinate predictions but lack semantic reasoning capabilities. This dichotomy motivates our key research question: Can we synergize the efficiency of specialists with the contextual power of LLMs to create a positionally-accurate MLLM? To overcome these challenges, we introduce PositionOCR, a parameter-efficient hybrid architecture that seamlessly integrates a text spotting model's positional strengths with an LLM's contextual reasoning. Comprising 131M trainable parameters, this framework demonstrates outstanding multi-modal processing capabilities, particularly excelling in tasks such as text grounding and text spotting, consistently surpassing traditional MLLMs.

AI.tldr: PositionOCR is a compact (131M trainable params) hybrid that fuses a text-spotting specialist for precise coordinates with an LLM for semantic reasoning, yielding superior text grounding/spotting and OCR-centric VQA versus larger MLLMs.
AI.motivation: General MLLMs use LLM decoders that are strong at language but weak at positional/coordinate reasoning and are heavy to train; specialist text spotters excel at coordinates but lack semantic/contextual reasoning. The goal is to combine both strengths to achieve positionally accurate yet efficient multi-modal understanding.
AI.method: Design a parameter-efficient hybrid architecture that integrates a text-spotting model (for positional signals like bounding boxes) with an LLM (for contextual reasoning), enabling end-to-end OCR-centric VQA, text grounding, and text spotting while keeping the trainable parameter count low (131M).
AI.result: The system shows strong multi-modal capabilities and consistently outperforms traditional MLLMs on text grounding and text spotting tasks, achieving state-of-the-art coordinate prediction quality with added semantic reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Synergizing a specialist’s precise localization with an LLM’s contextual understanding yields a positionally accurate, compute-efficient MLLM. PositionOCR demonstrates that hybridization can surpass larger MLLMs on OCR-centric tasks while reducing training resources.

title: FUSAR-GPT : A Spatiotemporal Feature-Embedded and Two-Stage Decoupled Visual Language Model for SAR Imagery
summary: Research on the intelligent interpretation of all-weather, all-time Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is crucial for advancing remote sensing applications. In recent years, although Visual Language Models (VLMs) have demonstrated strong open-world understanding capabilities on RGB images, their performance is severely limited when directly applied to the SAR field due to the complexity of the imaging mechanism, sensitivity to scattering features, and the scarcity of high-quality text corpora. To systematically address this issue, we constructed the inaugural SAR Image-Text-AlphaEarth feature triplet dataset and developed FUSAR-GPT, a VLM specifically for SAR. FUSAR-GPT innovatively introduces a geospatial baseline model as a 'world knowledge' prior and embeds multi-source remote-sensing temporal features into the model's visual backbone via 'spatiotemporal anchors', enabling dynamic compensation for the sparse representation of targets in SAR images. Furthermore, we designed a two-stage SFT strategy to decouple the knowledge injection and task execution of large models. The spatiotemporal feature embedding and the two-stage decoupling paradigm enable FUSAR-GPT to achieve state-of-the-art performance across several typical remote sensing visual-language benchmark tests, significantly outperforming mainstream baseline models by over 12%.

AI.tldr: They introduce the first SAR image–text–feature triplet dataset and a SAR-specific VLM (FUSAR-GPT) that injects geospatial priors and spatiotemporal remote-sensing features via “anchors,” trained with a two-stage SFT to decouple knowledge and tasks, achieving >12% gains over mainstream baselines on remote-sensing VL benchmarks.
AI.motivation: General VLMs underperform on SAR because SAR imaging physics and scattering make visual patterns unlike RGB, and high-quality SAR-language corpora are scarce; robust all-weather/all-time SAR understanding needs domain priors and better supervision.
AI.method: (1) Construct a SAR Image–Text–AlphaEarth triplet dataset. (2) Build FUSAR-GPT: use a geospatial baseline model as a world-knowledge prior; embed multi-source temporal remote-sensing features into the visual backbone via spatiotemporal anchors to compensate sparse SAR target cues; (3) apply a two-stage supervised fine-tuning strategy to decouple knowledge injection from task execution.
AI.result: FUSAR-GPT achieves state-of-the-art on several remote-sensing visual–language benchmarks, outperforming mainstream baselines by over 12%.
AI.conclusion: Combining geospatial priors with spatiotemporal feature embedding and decoupled training effectively boosts open-world SAR interpretation, offering both a new dataset and a high-performing VLM tailored to SAR.

title: Prompt Tuning for CLIP on the Pretrained Manifold
summary: Prompt tuning introduces learnable prompt vectors that adapt pretrained vision-language models to downstream tasks in a parameter-efficient manner. However, under limited supervision, prompt tuning alters pretrained representations and drives downstream features away from the pretrained manifold toward directions that are unfavorable for transfer. This drift degrades generalization. To address this limitation, we propose ManiPT, a framework that performs prompt tuning on the pretrained manifold. ManiPT introduces cosine consistency constraints in both the text and image modalities to confine the learned representations within the pretrained geometric neighborhood. Furthermore, we introduce a structural bias that enforces incremental corrections, guiding the adaptation along transferable directions to mitigate reliance on shortcut learning. From a theoretical perspective, ManiPT alleviates overfitting tendencies under limited data. Our experiments cover four downstream settings: unseen-class generalization, few-shot classification, cross-dataset transfer, and domain generalization. Across these settings, ManiPT achieves higher average performance than baseline methods. Notably, ManiPT provides an explicit perspective on how prompt tuning overfits under limited supervision.

AI.tldr: ManiPT constrains prompt tuning to stay on the pretrained manifold using cosine consistency across text/image and a structural bias for incremental updates, reducing overfitting under limited supervision and improving generalization across multiple settings.
AI.motivation: Prompt tuning is parameter-efficient for adapting vision–language models, but with scarce labels it can drift learned representations off the pretrained manifold, encouraging shortcut directions and harming transfer/generalization.
AI.method: Perform prompt tuning on the pretrained manifold via cosine consistency constraints in both text and image modalities to keep features within the pretrained geometric neighborhood. Add a structural bias that enforces small, incremental corrections to steer adaptation along transferable directions and avoid shortcuts. Provide a theoretical view showing reduced overfitting tendencies with limited data.
AI.result: Across four settings—unseen-class generalization, few-shot classification, cross-dataset transfer, and domain generalization—ManiPT achieves higher average performance than baseline prompt-tuning methods.
AI.conclusion: Constraining adaptation to the pretrained manifold with modality-wise cosine consistency and structural bias mitigates overfitting when data are limited, improving transfer and offering a clear perspective on why vanilla prompt tuning overfits.

title: UniE2F: A Unified Diffusion Framework for Event-to-Frame Reconstruction with Video Foundation Models
summary: Event cameras excel at high-speed, low-power, and high-dynamic-range scene perception. However, as they fundamentally record only relative intensity changes rather than absolute intensity, the resulting data streams suffer from a significant loss of spatial information and static texture details. In this paper, we address this limitation by leveraging the generative prior of a pre-trained video diffusion model to reconstruct high-fidelity video frames from sparse event data. Specifically, we first establish a baseline model by directly applying event data as a condition to synthesize videos. Then, based on the physical correlation between the event stream and video frames, we further introduce the event-based inter-frame residual guidance to enhance the accuracy of video frame reconstruction. Furthermore, we extend our method to video frame interpolation and prediction in a zero-shot manner by modulating the reverse diffusion sampling process, thereby creating a unified event-to-frame reconstruction framework. Experimental results on real-world and synthetic datasets demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms previous approaches both quantitatively and qualitatively. We also refer the reviewers to the video demo contained in the supplementary material for video results. The code will be publicly available at https://github.com/CS-GangXu/UniE2F.

AI.tldr: Use a pre-trained video diffusion model, guided by event-camera physics, to reconstruct high-fidelity intensity frames from sparse event streams and to perform zero-shot interpolation/prediction, achieving state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Event cameras provide fast, HDR, low-power sensing but only capture relative intensity changes, losing absolute intensity and static texture. Recovering full-intensity video frames (and intermediate/future frames) from events would unlock broader use in conventional vision tasks.
AI.method: 1) Establish a baseline by conditioning a pre-trained video diffusion model directly on event streams to synthesize frames. 2) Introduce event-based inter-frame residual guidance that exploits the physical relationship between events and frame-to-frame intensity changes to better constrain diffusion sampling. 3) Extend the same guided diffusion process to zero-shot video frame interpolation and prediction by modulating reverse diffusion, yielding a unified event-to-frame reconstruction framework.
AI.result: On real and synthetic datasets, the approach significantly outperforms prior methods in both quantitative metrics and visual quality; qualitative demos provided and code to be released (https://github.com/CS-GangXu/UniE2F).
AI.conclusion: Generative video diffusion priors, when augmented with event-derived residual guidance, can recover high-fidelity frames from event data and generalize to interpolation/prediction without task-specific training, delivering SOTA performance in a unified pipeline.

title: GS-CLIP: Zero-shot 3D Anomaly Detection by Geometry-Aware Prompt and Synergistic View Representation Learning
summary: Zero-shot 3D Anomaly Detection is an emerging task that aims to detect anomalies in a target dataset without any target training data, which is particularly important in scenarios constrained by sample scarcity and data privacy concerns. While current methods adapt CLIP by projecting 3D point clouds into 2D representations, they face challenges. The projection inherently loses some geometric details, and the reliance on a single 2D modality provides an incomplete visual understanding, limiting their ability to detect diverse anomaly types. To address these limitations, we propose the Geometry-Aware Prompt and Synergistic View Representation Learning (GS-CLIP) framework, which enables the model to identify geometric anomalies through a two-stage learning process. In stage 1, we dynamically generate text prompts embedded with 3D geometric priors. These prompts contain global shape context and local defect information distilled by our Geometric Defect Distillation Module (GDDM). In stage 2, we introduce Synergistic View Representation Learning architecture that processes rendered and depth images in parallel. A Synergistic Refinement Module (SRM) subsequently fuses the features of both streams, capitalizing on their complementary strengths. Comprehensive experimental results on four large-scale public datasets show that GS-CLIP achieves superior performance in detection. Code can be available at https://github.com/zhushengxinyue/GS-CLIP.

AI.tldr: GS-CLIP tackles zero-shot 3D anomaly detection by injecting 3D-aware text prompts and synergistically fusing rendered RGB and depth views, surpassing prior CLIP-based 2D projection approaches on four public datasets.
AI.motivation: Zero-shot 3D AD is needed when target data are scarce or private. Existing CLIP adaptations project 3D point clouds to 2D, which discards geometric details and uses a single modality, limiting detection of varied anomaly types.
AI.method: Two-stage framework. Stage 1: Geometry-Aware Prompting—dynamically generate text prompts infused with 3D geometric priors (global shape + local defects) distilled by a Geometric Defect Distillation Module (GDDM). Stage 2: Synergistic View Representation Learning—process rendered RGB and depth images in parallel and fuse them with a Synergistic Refinement Module (SRM), aligning visual features with the geometry-aware text in a CLIP-like space for zero-shot detection.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on four large-scale public datasets show GS-CLIP achieves superior anomaly detection performance compared with existing methods; code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: Embedding 3D geometric priors into text prompts and fusing complementary rendered and depth views mitigates information loss from 3D-to-2D projection and single-modality limits, leading to stronger zero-shot 3D anomaly detection performance.

title: SegMoTE: Token-Level Mixture of Experts for Medical Image Segmentation
summary: Medical image segmentation is vital for clinical diagnosis and quantitative analysis, yet remains challenging due to the heterogeneity of imaging modalities and the high cost of pixel-level annotations. Although general interactive segmentation models like SAM have achieved remarkable progress, their transfer to medical imaging still faces two key bottlenecks: (i) the lack of adaptive mechanisms for modality- and anatomy-specific tasks, which limits generalization in out-of-distribution medical scenarios; and (ii) current medical adaptation methods fine-tune on large, heterogeneous datasets without selection, leading to noisy supervision, higher cost, and negative transfer. To address these issues, we propose SegMoTE, an efficient and adaptive framework for medical image segmentation. SegMoTE preserves SAM's original prompt interface, efficient inference, and zero-shot generalization while introducing only a small number of learnable parameters to dynamically adapt across modalities and tasks. In addition, we design a progressive prompt tokenization mechanism that enables fully automatic segmentation, significantly reducing annotation dependence. Trained on MedSeg-HQ, a curated dataset less than 1% of existing large-scale datasets, SegMoTE achieves SOTA performance across diverse imaging modalities and anatomical tasks. It represents the first efficient, robust, and scalable adaptation of general segmentation models to the medical domain under extremely low annotation cost, advancing the practical deployment of foundation vision models in clinical applications.

AI.tldr: SegMoTE adapts SAM to medical image segmentation with a few learnable parameters and a progressive prompt tokenization scheme that enables automatic segmentation, achieving SOTA across modalities using a small curated dataset (<1% of typical scale) while preserving SAM’s efficiency and zero-shot behavior.
AI.motivation: Medical image segmentation is crucial but difficult due to modality/anatomy heterogeneity and the high cost of pixel-wise labels. General models like SAM struggle to generalize to medical domains without task- and modality-specific adaptation, and existing medical fine-tuning on large, heterogeneous datasets introduces noisy supervision, higher cost, and negative transfer.
AI.method: Introduce SegMoTE: an efficient adaptation layer for SAM with a small number of learnable parameters to dynamically adjust to different modalities and tasks while keeping SAM’s prompt interface and fast inference. Add a progressive prompt tokenization mechanism that converts prompts into signals enabling fully automatic segmentation, reducing reliance on manual annotations. Train on MedSeg-HQ, a curated, compact dataset.
AI.result: SegMoTE attains state-of-the-art performance across diverse imaging modalities and anatomical segmentation tasks, preserves zero-shot generalization and efficient inference, and reaches these results with far fewer annotations (dataset size <1% of large-scale alternatives).
AI.conclusion: SegMoTE provides an efficient, robust, and scalable pathway to adapt general-purpose segmentation models to clinical applications at very low annotation cost, facilitating practical deployment of foundation vision models in medicine.

title: Questions beyond Pixels: Integrating Commonsense Knowledge in Visual Question Generation for Remote Sensing
summary: With the rapid development of remote sensing image archives, asking questions about images has become an effective way of gathering specific information or performing semantic image retrieval. However, current automatically generated questions tend to be simplistic and template-based, which hinders the deployment of question answering or visual dialogue systems for real-world applications. To enrich and diversify the questions with both image content and commonsense knowledge, we propose a Knowledge-aware Remote Sensing Visual Question Generation model (KRSVQG). The proposed model incorporates related knowledge triplets from external knowledge sources to broaden the question content, while employing image captioning as an intermediary representation to ground questions to the corresponding images. Moreover, KRSVQG utilizes a vision-language pre-training and fine-tuning strategy, enabling the model's adaptation to low data regimes. To evaluate the proposed KRSVQG model, we construct two knowledge-aware remote sensing visual question generation datasets: the NWPU-300 dataset and the TextRS-300 dataset. Evaluations, including metrics and human assessment, demonstrate that KRSVQG outperforms existing methods and leads to rich questions, grounded in both image and domain knowledge. As a key practice in vision-language research, knowledge-aware visual question generation advances the understanding of image content beyond pixels, facilitating the development of knowledge-enriched vision-language systems with vision-grounded human commonsense.

AI.tldr: KRSVQG is a knowledge-aware visual question generation model for remote sensing that fuses external knowledge triplets with caption-grounded image understanding and vision–language pretraining; on two new datasets, it produces richer, better-grounded questions than baselines.
AI.motivation: Automatically generated questions for remote sensing images are often simplistic and template-based, limiting effective VQA and visual dialogue. The authors aim to enrich and diversify questions by leveraging both visual content and commonsense/domain knowledge, and to make models robust in low-data scenarios.
AI.method: Propose KRSVQG, which: (1) incorporates external knowledge triplets to expand question content; (2) uses image captioning as an intermediary representation to ground questions to the specific image; and (3) applies a vision–language pretraining-and-finetuning strategy to adapt to limited training data. They also prepare two knowledge-aware RS-VQG datasets (NWPU-300 and TextRS-300) for evaluation.
AI.result: On NWPU-300 and TextRS-300, both automatic metrics and human judgments indicate KRSVQG outperforms existing methods, yielding questions that are richer, more diverse, and better grounded in the imagery and relevant domain knowledge.
AI.conclusion: Knowledge-aware VQG enhances understanding of remote sensing imagery beyond pixel-level signals by integrating commonsense and domain knowledge, facilitating stronger, vision-grounded QA/dialogue systems and performing well in low-data regimes.

title: Controlled Face Manipulation and Synthesis for Data Augmentation
summary: Deep learning vision models excel with abundant supervision, but many applications face label scarcity and class imbalance. Controllable image editing can augment scarce labeled data, yet edits often introduce artifacts and entangle non-target attributes. We study this in facial expression analysis, targeting Action Unit (AU) manipulation where annotation is costly and AU co-activation drives entanglement. We present a facial manipulation method that operates in the semantic latent space of a pre-trained face generator (Diffusion Autoencoder). Using lightweight linear models, we reduce entanglement of semantic features via (i) dependency-aware conditioning that accounts for AU co-activation, and (ii) orthogonal projection that removes nuisance attribute directions (e.g., glasses), together with an expression neutralization step to enable absolute AU edit. We use these edits to balance AU occurrence by editing labeled faces and to diversify identities/demographics via controlled synthesis. Augmenting AU detector training with the generated data improves accuracy and yields more disentangled predictions with fewer co-activation shortcuts, outperforming alternative data-efficient training strategies and suggesting improvements similar to what would require substantially more labeled data in our learning-curve analysis. Compared to prior methods, our edits are stronger, produce fewer artifacts, and preserve identity better.

AI.tldr: They reduce AU entanglement and artifacts in controllable face editing by operating in a diffusion autoencoder’s semantic latent space with simple linear controls, then use these edits to balance scarce/imbalanced AU labels and improve AU detection with less real data.
AI.motivation: Vision models often suffer from scarce and imbalanced labels; controllable editing could augment data but typically introduces artifacts and mixes target with non-target attributes. Facial AU analysis is particularly hard because labels are costly and AUs co-activate, creating entanglement that biases detectors.
AI.method: Manipulate facial expressions in the semantic latent space of a pretrained face generator (Diffusion Autoencoder) using lightweight linear models. Introduce (i) dependency-aware conditioning to model AU co-activation, (ii) orthogonal projection to remove nuisance attribute directions (e.g., glasses), and an expression neutralization step to enable absolute AU editing. Use edits both to rebalance AU frequencies on labeled faces and to synthesize diverse identities/demographics.
AI.result: Training AU detectors with the generated data improves accuracy and yields more disentangled, less shortcut-prone predictions versus alternative data-efficient strategies. Learning-curve analysis indicates similar gains to having substantially more labeled data. Edits are stronger, with fewer artifacts and better identity preservation than prior methods.
AI.conclusion: Disentangled, dependency-aware AU editing in diffusion latent space is an effective data augmentation strategy: it balances classes, diversifies identities, and improves AU detectors while minimizing artifacts and identity drift, outperforming existing approaches under label scarcity.

title: Knowledge-aware Visual Question Generation for Remote Sensing Images
summary: With the rapid development of remote sensing image archives, asking questions about images has become an effective way of gathering specific information or performing image retrieval. However, automatically generated image-based questions tend to be simplistic and template-based, which hinders the real deployment of question answering or visual dialogue systems. To enrich and diversify the questions, we propose a knowledge-aware remote sensing visual question generation model, KRSVQG, that incorporates external knowledge related to the image content to improve the quality and contextual understanding of the generated questions. The model takes an image and a related knowledge triplet from external knowledge sources as inputs and leverages image captioning as an intermediary representation to enhance the image grounding of the generated questions. To assess the performance of KRSVQG, we utilized two datasets that we manually annotated: NWPU-300 and TextRS-300. Results on these two datasets demonstrate that KRSVQG outperforms existing methods and leads to knowledge-enriched questions, grounded in both image and domain knowledge.

AI.tldr: They propose KRSVQG, a knowledge-aware model for remote sensing visual question generation that fuses an image, an external knowledge triplet, and an intermediate image caption to generate richer, better-grounded questions; it outperforms baselines on two new, manually annotated datasets (NWPU-300, TextRS-300).
AI.motivation: Automatically generated questions about remote sensing images are typically simplistic and template-driven, limiting practical use in VQA and visual dialogue. There is a need for diverse, context- and knowledge-rich questions grounded in both imagery and domain knowledge.
AI.method: KRSVQG ingests an image plus a relevant external knowledge triplet and uses image captioning as an intermediary representation to strengthen image grounding before generating a question. The approach integrates external domain knowledge tied to image content to enrich semantics and diversity.
AI.result: On two manually annotated datasets (NWPU-300 and TextRS-300), the method surpasses existing VQG approaches and produces questions enriched by domain knowledge while remaining grounded in the image and its caption-derived context.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating external knowledge and a caption-based intermediary improves question quality and contextual understanding for remote sensing VQG, suggesting a viable path toward more effective remote sensing QA/dialogue systems.

title: No Need For Real Anomaly: MLLM Empowered Zero-Shot Video Anomaly Detection
summary: The collection and detection of video anomaly data has long been a challenging problem due to its rare occurrence and spatio-temporal scarcity. Existing video anomaly detection (VAD) methods under perform in open-world scenarios. Key contributing factors include limited dataset diversity, and inadequate understanding of context-dependent anomalous semantics. To address these issues, i) we propose LAVIDA, an end-to-end zero-shot video anomaly detection framework. ii) LAVIDA employs an Anomaly Exposure Sampler that transforms segmented objects into pseudo-anomalies to enhance model adaptability to unseen anomaly categories. It further integrates a Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM) to bolster semantic comprehension capabilities. Additionally, iii) we design a token compression approach based on reverse attention to handle the spatio-temporal scarcity of anomalous patterns and decrease computational cost. The training process is conducted solely on pseudo anomalies without any VAD data. Evaluations across four benchmark VAD datasets demonstrate that LAVIDA achieves SOTA performance in both frame-level and pixel-level anomaly detection under the zero-shot setting. Our code is available in https://github.com/VitaminCreed/LAVIDA.

AI.tldr: LAVIDA is a zero-shot video anomaly detection framework that trains only on pseudo anomalies, augments semantic understanding with an MLLM, and compresses tokens with reverse attention, achieving SOTA on four VAD benchmarks at both frame and pixel levels.
AI.motivation: VAD suffers from sparse, rare anomalies and poor open-world generalization due to limited, non-diverse datasets and weak modeling of context-dependent anomalous semantics. The goal is to build a model that generalizes to unseen anomaly categories without relying on scarce labeled VAD data.
AI.method: The authors propose LAVIDA: (1) Anomaly Exposure Sampler that converts segmented objects into pseudo anomalies to widen anomaly exposure and improve generalization; (2) integration of a multimodal LLM to enhance semantic/context understanding for anomaly reasoning; (3) a reverse-attention-based token compression to focus on scarce anomalous patterns while reducing computational cost. Training uses only pseudo anomalies (no VAD data).
AI.result: On four standard VAD datasets, LAVIDA achieves state-of-the-art performance in zero-shot settings at both frame-level and pixel-level detection. No specific numbers are given in the abstract, but claims cover multiple datasets and metrics.
AI.conclusion: Exposing models to synthesized anomalies plus MLLM-driven semantics and efficient token compression enables strong zero-shot VAD, suggesting improved open-world robustness without annotated VAD data. The approach promises practical scalability and efficiency, with released code for reproduction.

title: RegionRoute: Regional Style Transfer with Diffusion Model
summary: Precise spatial control in diffusion-based style transfer remains challenging. This challenge arises because diffusion models treat style as a global feature and lack explicit spatial grounding of style representations, making it difficult to restrict style application to specific objects or regions. To our knowledge, existing diffusion models are unable to perform true localized style transfer, typically relying on handcrafted masks or multi-stage post-processing that introduce boundary artifacts and limit generalization. To address this, we propose an attention-supervised diffusion framework that explicitly teaches the model where to apply a given style by aligning the attention scores of style tokens with object masks during training. Two complementary objectives, a Focus loss based on KL divergence and a Cover loss using binary cross-entropy, jointly encourage accurate localization and dense coverage. A modular LoRA-MoE design further enables efficient and scalable multi-style adaptation. To evaluate localized stylization, we introduce the Regional Style Editing Score, which measures Regional Style Matching through CLIP-based similarity within the target region and Identity Preservation via masked LPIPS and pixel-level consistency on unedited areas. Experiments show that our method achieves mask-free, single-object style transfer at inference, producing regionally accurate and visually coherent results that outperform existing diffusion-based editing approaches.

AI.tldr: They introduce an attention-supervised diffusion framework that aligns style-token attention with object masks during training, using Focus (KL) and Cover (BCE) losses plus a modular LoRA-MoE for scalable multi-style adaptation. With a new Regional Style Editing Score to quantify localized stylization, the method enables mask-free, single-object style transfer at inference and outperforms prior diffusion-based editing approaches in regional accuracy and coherence.
AI.motivation: Diffusion models treat style as a global attribute without spatial grounding, making it hard to confine style to specific objects or regions. Existing solutions depend on handcrafted masks or post-processing, which cause boundary artifacts and hinder generalization. The goal is true localized style transfer without inference-time masks.
AI.method: Attention-supervised diffusion that aligns the attention scores of style tokens to ground-truth object masks during training. Two objectives: (1) Focus loss (KL divergence) to sharpen and correctly localize attention, and (2) Cover loss (binary cross-entropy) to ensure dense coverage over target regions. A modular LoRA-MoE design supports efficient, scalable multi-style adaptation. Evaluation uses the Regional Style Editing Score, combining Regional Style Matching (CLIP similarity within target regions) and Identity Preservation (masked LPIPS and pixel consistency outside edited areas).
AI.result: On experiments, the approach performs mask-free, single-object localized style transfer at inference, producing regionally accurate, visually coherent edits that surpass prior diffusion-based editing baselines by the proposed quantitative metrics (and visibly fewer boundary artifacts).
AI.conclusion: Supervising attention with object masks grounds style spatially in diffusion models, enabling precise, mask-free localized stylization. The Focus+Cover losses and LoRA-MoE yield accurate localization, good coverage, and scalable multi-style support, while the Regional Style Editing Score provides a principled way to measure both regional matching and identity preservation; overall, the method outperforms existing diffusion-based editing techniques.

title: DD-CAM: Minimal Sufficient Explanations for Vision Models Using Delta Debugging
summary: We introduce a gradient-free framework for identifying minimal, sufficient, and decision-preserving explanations in vision models by isolating the smallest subset of representational units whose joint activation preserves predictions. Unlike existing approaches that aggregate all units, often leading to cluttered saliency maps, our approach, DD-CAM, identifies a 1-minimal subset whose joint activation suffices to preserve the prediction (i.e., removing any unit from the subset alters the prediction). To efficiently isolate minimal sufficient subsets, we adapt delta debugging, a systematic reduction strategy from software debugging, and configure its search strategy based on unit interactions in the classifier head: testing individual units for models with non-interacting units and testing unit combinations for models in which unit interactions exist. We then generate minimal, prediction-preserving saliency maps that highlight only the most essential features. Our experimental evaluation demonstrates that our approach can produce more faithful explanations and achieve higher localization accuracy than the state-of-the-art CAM-based approaches.

AI.tldr: DD-CAM is a gradient-free method that uses delta debugging to find a 1-minimal set of representational units whose joint activation preserves a model’s prediction, yielding cleaner and more faithful saliency maps than prior CAM-based methods.
AI.motivation: Conventional CAM-style explanations aggregate many units, producing cluttered and potentially unfaithful saliency maps. There is a need for minimal, sufficient, decision-preserving explanations that isolate only what truly drives a prediction, ideally without relying on gradients.
AI.method: Adapt delta debugging to iteratively remove units while testing whether the model’s prediction is preserved, yielding a 1-minimal subset (removing any unit flips/changes the decision). Configure the search by model head structure: test single units when units do not interact; test combinations when interactions exist. Generate saliency maps only from the identified minimal subset. The approach is gradient-free.
AI.result: Across experiments, DD-CAM produces more faithful explanations and achieves higher localization accuracy compared to state-of-the-art CAM-based approaches.
AI.conclusion: DD-CAM offers compact, decision-preserving visual explanations by isolating a minimal sufficient subset of units, improving clarity and faithfulness over traditional CAMs, and working across models with different unit interaction patterns without requiring gradients.

title: A Two-Stage Detection-Tracking Framework for Stable Apple Quality Inspection in Dense Conveyor-Belt Environments
summary: Industrial fruit inspection systems must operate reliably under dense multi-object interactions and continuous motion, yet most existing works evaluate detection or classification at the image level without ensuring temporal stability in video streams. We present a two-stage detection-tracking framework for stable multi-apple quality inspection in conveyor-belt environments. An orchard-trained YOLOv8 model performs apple localization, followed by ByteTrack multi-object tracking to maintain persistent identities. A ResNet18 defect classifier, fine-tuned on a healthy-defective fruit dataset, is applied to cropped apple regions. Track-level aggregation is introduced to enforce temporal consistency and reduce prediction oscillation across frames. We define video-level industrial metrics such as track-level defect ratio and temporal consistency to evaluate system robustness under realistic processing conditions. Results demonstrate improved stability compared to frame-wise inference, suggesting that integrating tracking is essential for practical automated fruit grading systems.

AI.tldr: Two-stage video pipeline (YOLOv8 detection + ByteTrack tracking + ResNet18 defect classification) with track-level aggregation delivers temporally stable, industrial-grade multi-apple inspection on conveyor belts and outperforms frame-wise inference; introduces practical video-level metrics.
AI.motivation: Industrial grading requires stable, identity-consistent decisions across time, but most research benchmarks image/frame performance only. Dense interactions, occlusion, and motion cause per-frame predictions to oscillate, undermining reliability and downstream yield/quality metrics.
AI.method: Detect apples with an orchard-trained YOLOv8; maintain identities via ByteTrack; classify cropped apples using a fine-tuned ResNet18 (healthy vs defective). Apply track-level aggregation to smooth per-frame predictions. Evaluate using video-level industrial metrics (e.g., track-level defect ratio, temporal consistency).
AI.result: Tracking plus aggregation reduces prediction oscillation and improves temporal stability compared to frame-wise inference under conveyor-belt conditions, yielding more robust track-level quality estimates.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating multi-object tracking and track-level aggregation is key for deployable, reliable fruit grading. Video-level metrics should complement frame-level accuracy to reflect real industrial performance.

title: MRI Contrast Enhancement Kinetics World Model
summary: Clinical MRI contrast acquisition suffers from inefficient information yield, which presents as a mismatch between the risky and costly acquisition protocol and the fixed and sparse acquisition sequence. Applying world models to simulate the contrast enhancement kinetics in the human body enables continuous contrast-free dynamics. However, the low temporal resolution in MRI acquisition restricts the training of world models, leading to a sparsely sampled dataset. Directly training a generative model to capture the kinetics leads to two limitations: (a) Due to the absence of data on missing time, the model tends to overfit to irrelevant features, leading to content distortion. (b) Due to the lack of continuous temporal supervision, the model fails to learn the continuous kinetics law over time, causing temporal discontinuities. For the first time, we propose MRI Contrast Enhancement Kinetics World model (MRI CEKWorld) with SpatioTemporal Consistency Learning (STCL). For (a), guided by the spatial law that patient-level structures remain consistent during enhancement, we propose Latent Alignment Learning (LAL) that constructs a patient-specific template to constrain contents to align with this template. For (b), guided by the temporal law that the kinetics follow a consistent smooth trend, we propose Latent Difference Learning (LDL) which extends the unobserved intervals by interpolation and constrains smooth variations in the latent space among interpolated sequences. Extensive experiments on two datasets show our MRI CEKWorld achieves better realistic contents and kinetics. Codes will be available at https://github.com/DD0922/MRI-Contrast-Enhancement-Kinetics-World-Model.

AI.tldr: Introduces MRI CEKWorld, a world-model approach with spatiotemporal consistency learning to synthesize continuous MRI contrast-enhancement dynamics from sparsely sampled acquisitions, reducing content distortion and temporal discontinuities and outperforming baselines on two datasets.
AI.motivation: Clinical contrast-enhanced MRI yields limited information despite risky/costly protocols and sparse, fixed acquisition schedules. World models could simulate continuous enhancement kinetics, but low temporal resolution creates sparsely sampled training data. Direct generative training overfits irrelevant features (content distortion) and lacks continuous temporal supervision (temporal discontinuities).
AI.method: MRI CEKWorld with SpatioTemporal Consistency Learning (STCL): (1) Latent Alignment Learning (LAL) enforces spatial consistency by building a patient-specific latent template so generated content aligns with stable anatomy during enhancement; (2) Latent Difference Learning (LDL) enforces temporal smoothness by interpolating unobserved time intervals and constraining smooth latent-space variations across interpolated sequences, enabling learning of continuous kinetics law.
AI.result: On two datasets, the approach produces more realistic, anatomy-preserving images and smoother, more faithful enhancement kinetics than competing generative methods (qualitative and quantitative improvements implied).
AI.conclusion: Imposing spatial and temporal consistency lets world models learn continuous contrast-enhancement kinetics from sparse MRI time series, potentially improving information yield and reducing reliance on dense acquisitions; code will be released.

title: IPv2: An Improved Image Purification Strategy for Real-World Ultra-Low-Dose Lung CT Denoising
summary: The image purification strategy constructs an intermediate distribution with aligned anatomical structures, which effectively corrects the spatial misalignment between real-world ultra-low-dose CT and normal-dose CT images and significantly enhances the structural preservation ability of denoising models. However, this strategy exhibits two inherent limitations. First, it suppresses noise only in the chest wall and bone regions while leaving the image background untreated. Second, it lacks a dedicated mechanism for denoising the lung parenchyma. To address these issues, we systematically redesign the original image purification strategy and propose an improved version termed IPv2. The proposed strategy introduces three core modules, namely Remove Background, Add noise, and Remove noise. These modules endow the model with denoising capability in both background and lung tissue regions during training data construction and provide a more reasonable evaluation protocol through refined label construction at the testing stage. Extensive experiments on our previously established real-world patient lung CT dataset acquired at 2% radiation dose demonstrate that IPv2 consistently improves background suppression and lung parenchyma restoration across multiple mainstream denoising models. The code is publicly available at https://github.com/MonkeyDadLufy/Image-Purification-Strategy-v2.

AI.tldr: IPv2 is an upgraded image purification strategy for ultra‑low‑dose CT denoising that extends noise handling beyond chest wall/bone to both background and lung parenchyma via three modules—Remove Background, Add noise, Remove noise—yielding better-aligned training/evaluation data and consistent gains in background suppression and lung restoration across multiple denoisers on a 2%‑dose dataset.
AI.motivation: Prior purification aligned anatomical structures to correct ULDCT–NDCT misregistration and helped preserve structure, but (1) it only suppressed noise near chest wall/bone, leaving background untouched, and (2) it lacked a targeted mechanism for lung parenchyma denoising. A more comprehensive training data construction and fairer evaluation protocol were needed.
AI.method: Systematic redesign of the original purification with three modules: Remove Background (exclude non‑anatomical background), Add noise (inject realistic noise into background and lung tissue to supervise denoising), and Remove noise (train denoisers to clean these regions). The strategy also refines label construction at test time to provide a more reasonable evaluation protocol while maintaining an intermediate, anatomically aligned distribution.
AI.result: On a real‑world patient lung CT dataset acquired at 2% radiation dose, IPv2 consistently improves background suppression and lung parenchyma restoration across several mainstream denoising models.
AI.conclusion: IPv2 addresses the two core shortcomings of the original purification approach by enabling explicit denoising for background and lung tissue and by improving test‑time label construction; it generalizes across denoisers and is released with code for reproducibility.

title: Pay Attention to CTC: Fast and Robust Pseudo-Labelling for Unified Speech Recognition
summary: Unified Speech Recognition (USR) has emerged as a semi-supervised framework for training a single model for audio, visual, and audiovisual speech recognition, achieving state-of-the-art results on in-distribution benchmarks. However, its reliance on autoregressive pseudo-labelling makes training expensive, while its decoupled supervision of CTC and attention branches increases susceptibility to self-reinforcing errors, particularly under distribution shifts involving longer sequences, noise, or unseen domains. We propose CTC-driven teacher forcing, where greedily decoded CTC pseudo-labels are fed into the decoder to generate attention targets in a single forward pass. Although these can be globally incoherent, in the pseudo-labelling setting they enable efficient and effective knowledge transfer. Because CTC and CTC-driven attention pseudo-labels have the same length, the decoder can predict both simultaneously, benefiting from the robustness of CTC and the expressiveness of attention without costly beam search. We further propose mixed sampling to mitigate the exposure bias of the decoder relying solely on CTC inputs. The resulting method, USR 2.0, halves training time, improves robustness to out-of-distribution inputs, and achieves state-of-the-art results on LRS3, LRS2, and WildVSR, surpassing USR and modality-specific self-supervised baselines.

AI.tldr: USR 2.0 replaces expensive autoregressive pseudo‑labeling with CTC‑driven teacher forcing and mixed sampling so CTC and attention share same‑length pseudo‑labels in a single forward pass, halving training time and boosting robustness. It achieves state‑of‑the‑art results on LRS3, LRS2, and WildVSR across audio, visual, and audiovisual ASR.
AI.motivation: Prior USR relies on autoregressive pseudo‑labeling (costly due to beam search) and decoupled CTC/attention supervision, which can amplify self‑reinforcing errors—especially for long sequences, noise, and unseen domains. The goal is to make semi‑supervised unified A/V/AV recognition cheaper and more robust under distribution shift.
AI.method: CTC‑driven teacher forcing: greedily decode CTC pseudo‑labels, feed them into the decoder to generate attention targets in a single pass. Because both pseudo‑labels now share the same length, the decoder can predict CTC and attention outputs simultaneously, leveraging CTC’s robustness and attention’s expressiveness without beam search. Mixed sampling further reduces exposure bias by not letting the decoder depend solely on CTC inputs.
AI.result: Training time is reduced by ~2×; robustness to out‑of‑distribution inputs improves; and the method attains state‑of‑the‑art on LRS3, LRS2, and WildVSR, outperforming the original USR and modality‑specific self‑supervised baselines.
AI.conclusion: Coupling CTC and attention via CTC‑driven teacher forcing provides an efficient, single‑pass pseudo‑labeling pipeline that improves both efficiency and OOD robustness in unified speech recognition, setting new SOTA and indicating a practical path to scalable semi‑supervised A/V/AV ASR.

title: US-JEPA: A Joint Embedding Predictive Architecture for Medical Ultrasound
summary: Ultrasound (US) imaging poses unique challenges for representation learning due to its inherently noisy acquisition process. The low signal-to-noise ratio and stochastic speckle patterns hinder standard self-supervised learning methods relying on a pixel-level reconstruction objective. Joint-Embedding Predictive Architectures (JEPAs) address this drawback by predicting masked latent representations rather than raw pixels. However, standard approaches depend on hyperparameter-brittle and computationally expensive online teachers updated via exponential moving average. We propose US-JEPA, a self-supervised framework that adopts the Static-teacher Asymmetric Latent Training (SALT) objective. By using a frozen, domain-specific teacher to provide stable latent targets, US-JEPA decouples student-teacher optimization and pushes the student to expand upon the semantic priors of the teacher. In addition, we provide the first rigorous comparison of all publicly available state-of-the-art ultrasound foundation models on UltraBench, a public dataset benchmark spanning multiple organs and pathological conditions. Under linear probing for diverse classification tasks, US-JEPA achieves performance competitive with or superior to domain-specific and universal vision foundation model baselines. Our results demonstrate that masked latent prediction provides a stable and efficient path toward robust ultrasound representations.

AI.tldr: US-JEPA is a self-supervised ultrasound representation learner that predicts masked latent targets from a frozen, domain-specific teacher (SALT), avoiding brittle and costly EMA teachers. On the new UltraBench, it delivers competitive or better linear-probe performance versus ultrasound-specific and general vision baselines, showing masked latent prediction is stable and efficient for noisy US data.
AI.motivation: Ultrasound images have low SNR and stochastic speckle, making pixel-level reconstruction objectives in standard SSL unstable and suboptimal. Existing JEPAs rely on EMA-updated online teachers that are sensitive to hyperparameters and computationally heavy. There is also a lack of a rigorous, public benchmark for comparing ultrasound foundation models across organs and pathologies.
AI.method: Introduce US-JEPA, which adopts the SALT objective with a frozen, domain-specific teacher providing stable latent targets. The student predicts masked latent representations, decoupling student-teacher optimization and encouraging the student to build upon the teacher’s semantic priors. They also compile/evaluate on UltraBench, conducting a comprehensive comparison against state-of-the-art ultrasound foundation models and universal vision baselines via linear probing on multiple classification tasks.
AI.result: Across diverse classification tasks on UltraBench, US-JEPA attains performance that is competitive with or superior to existing ultrasound domain-specific and general-purpose vision foundation models under linear probing. Training is described as stable and efficient due to the static-teacher masked-latent setup.
AI.conclusion: Masked latent prediction with a frozen, domain-specific teacher provides a robust and efficient pathway to learn ultrasound representations. US-JEPA mitigates the instability and cost of EMA-based JEPAs, and the UltraBench comparisons indicate it is a strong or leading approach for ultrasound SSL.

title: DefenseSplat: Enhancing the Robustness of 3D Gaussian Splatting via Frequency-Aware Filtering
summary: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for real-time and high-fidelity 3D reconstruction from posed images. However, recent studies reveal its vulnerability to adversarial corruptions in input views, where imperceptible yet consistent perturbations can drastically degrade rendering quality, increase training and rendering time, and inflate memory usage, even leading to server denial-of-service. In our work, to mitigate this issue, we begin by analyzing the distinct behaviors of adversarial perturbations in the low- and high-frequency components of input images using wavelet transforms. Based on this observation, we design a simple yet effective frequency-aware defense strategy that reconstructs training views by filtering high-frequency noise while preserving low-frequency content. This approach effectively suppresses adversarial artifacts while maintaining the authenticity of the original scene. Notably, it does not significantly impair training on clean data, achieving a desirable trade-off between robustness and performance on clean inputs. Through extensive experiments under a wide range of attack intensities on multiple benchmarks, we demonstrate that our method substantially enhances the robustness of 3DGS without access to clean ground-truth supervision. By highlighting and addressing the overlooked vulnerabilities of 3D Gaussian Splatting, our work paves the way for more robust and secure 3D reconstructions.

AI.tldr: They show that 3D Gaussian Splatting is highly vulnerable to small, consistent adversarial perturbations in input views and propose a simple frequency-aware pre-processing that filters high-frequency noise (via wavelet-based analysis) while preserving low-frequency content, substantially improving robustness with minimal impact on clean performance and no need for clean supervision.
AI.motivation: 3DGS, despite its real-time, high-fidelity reconstruction, breaks under imperceptible adversarial corruptions that can ruin rendering quality, inflate compute/memory, and even enable denial-of-service. There is a need for a lightweight defense that restores reliability without sacrificing clean accuracy or requiring clean ground truth.
AI.method: Analyze adversarial behavior in frequency space using wavelet transforms, observe that harmful perturbations are concentrated in high-frequency components, and design a frequency-aware defense that reconstructs training views by suppressing high-frequency noise while preserving low-frequency content. The defense acts as a pre-processing step and does not rely on clean supervision.
AI.result: Across multiple datasets and a range of attack strengths, the method significantly improves robustness of 3DGS—reducing artifacts and stabilizing training/rendering—while maintaining near-clean performance on uncorrupted data and avoiding notable overhead.
AI.conclusion: Frequency-selective filtering guided by wavelet analysis is an effective, simple defense for 3DGS, mitigating adversarial vulnerabilities without compromising normal operation, and advancing secure, reliable 3D reconstruction.

title: RetinaVision: XAI-Driven Augmented Regulation for Precise Retinal Disease Classification using deep learning framework
summary: Early and accurate classification of retinal diseases is critical to counter vision loss and for guiding clinical management of retinal diseases. In this study, we proposed a deep learning method for retinal disease classification utilizing optical coherence tomography (OCT) images from the Retinal OCT Image Classification - C8 dataset (comprising 24,000 labeled images spanning eight conditions). Images were resized to 224x224 px and tested on convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures: Xception and InceptionV3. Data augmentation techniques (CutMix, MixUp) were employed to enhance model generalization. Additionally, we applied GradCAM and LIME for interpretability evaluation. We implemented this in a real-world scenario via our web application named RetinaVision. This study found that Xception was the most accurate network (95.25%), followed closely by InceptionV3 (94.82%). These results suggest that deep learning methods allow effective OCT retinal disease classification and highlight the importance of implementing accuracy and interpretability for clinical applications.

AI.tldr: CNNs (Xception, InceptionV3) trained on 24k OCT images (8 classes) with CutMix/MixUp achieve ~95% accuracy; Grad-CAM and LIME used for interpretability; deployed as a web app (RetinaVision).
AI.motivation: Timely, accurate retinal disease classification can prevent vision loss; the study aims to benchmark modern CNNs on a sizable OCT dataset and demonstrate clinically oriented interpretability and deployment.
AI.method: Resize OCT images to 224×224; train/evaluate Xception and InceptionV3; apply CutMix and MixUp for data augmentation; assess interpretability with Grad-CAM and LIME; integrate into a web application (RetinaVision).
AI.result: Xception reached 95.25% accuracy; InceptionV3 reached 94.82% accuracy on the C8 dataset of 24,000 labeled images across eight conditions.
AI.conclusion: Deep learning models can effectively classify OCT retinal diseases; pairing accuracy with interpretability tools and practical deployment supports potential clinical utility.

title: MultiDiffSense: Diffusion-Based Multi-Modal Visuo-Tactile Image Generation Conditioned on Object Shape and Contact Pose
summary: Acquiring aligned visuo-tactile datasets is slow and costly, requiring specialised hardware and large-scale data collection. Synthetic generation is promising, but prior methods are typically single-modality, limiting cross-modal learning. We present MultiDiffSense, a unified diffusion model that synthesises images for multiple vision-based tactile sensors (ViTac, TacTip, ViTacTip) within a single architecture. Our approach uses dual conditioning on CAD-derived, pose-aligned depth maps and structured prompts that encode sensor type and 4-DoF contact pose, enabling controllable, physically consistent multi-modal synthesis. Evaluating on 8 objects (5 seen, 3 novel) and unseen poses, MultiDiffSense outperforms a Pix2Pix cGAN baseline in SSIM by +36.3% (ViTac), +134.6% (ViTacTip), and +64.7% (TacTip). For downstream 3-DoF pose estimation, mixing 50% synthetic with 50% real halves the required real data while maintaining competitive performance. MultiDiffSense alleviates the data-collection bottleneck in tactile sensing and enables scalable, controllable multi-modal dataset generation for robotic applications.

AI.tldr: MultiDiffSense is a unified, controllable diffusion model that synthesizes images for multiple vision-based tactile sensors using CAD-derived depth and sensor/pose prompts, outperforming a Pix2Pix baseline and reducing real data needs for pose estimation by half.
AI.motivation: Collecting aligned visuo-tactile datasets is slow, expensive, and hardware-intensive, and prior synthetic approaches are typically single-modality, limiting cross-sensor learning and controllability.
AI.method: A single diffusion architecture generates images for ViTac, TacTip, and ViTacTip. It uses dual conditioning: (1) pose-aligned depth maps from CAD models and (2) structured prompts encoding sensor type and 4-DoF contact pose, enabling physically consistent, controllable synthesis across sensors.
AI.result: Across 8 objects (5 seen, 3 novel) and unseen poses, the method improves SSIM over a Pix2Pix cGAN by +36.3% (ViTac), +134.6% (ViTacTip), and +64.7% (TacTip). For downstream 3-DoF pose estimation, mixing 50% synthetic with 50% real maintains competitive performance while halving the amount of real data required.
AI.conclusion: MultiDiffSense mitigates the tactile data-collection bottleneck by enabling scalable, controllable multi-sensor dataset generation and shows promising generalization to new objects/poses, supporting downstream robotic perception tasks.

title: UP-Fuse: Uncertainty-guided LiDAR-Camera Fusion for 3D Panoptic Segmentation
summary: LiDAR-camera fusion enhances 3D panoptic segmentation by leveraging camera images to complement sparse LiDAR scans, but it also introduces a critical failure mode. Under adverse conditions, degradation or failure of the camera sensor can significantly compromise the reliability of the perception system. To address this problem, we introduce UP-Fuse, a novel uncertainty-aware fusion framework in the 2D range-view that remains robust under camera sensor degradation, calibration drift, and sensor failure. Raw LiDAR data is first projected into the range-view and encoded by a LiDAR encoder, while camera features are simultaneously extracted and projected into the same shared space. At its core, UP-Fuse employs an uncertainty-guided fusion module that dynamically modulates cross-modal interaction using predicted uncertainty maps. These maps are learned by quantifying representational divergence under diverse visual degradations, ensuring that only reliable visual cues influence the fused representation. The fused range-view features are decoded by a novel hybrid 2D-3D transformer that mitigates spatial ambiguities inherent to the 2D projection and directly predicts 3D panoptic segmentation masks. Extensive experiments on Panoptic nuScenes, SemanticKITTI, and our introduced Panoptic Waymo benchmark demonstrate the efficacy and robustness of UP-Fuse, which maintains strong performance even under severe visual corruption or misalignment, making it well suited for robotic perception in safety-critical settings.

AI.tldr: UP-Fuse is an uncertainty-aware LiDAR–camera fusion framework in 2D range-view that remains robust to camera degradation, miscalibration, and even camera failure. It fuses LiDAR and projected image features using uncertainty maps learned from representational divergence under visual corruptions, then decodes with a hybrid 2D–3D transformer to output 3D panoptic segmentation. It achieves strong, robust performance on Panoptic nuScenes, SemanticKITTI, and a new Panoptic Waymo benchmark.
AI.motivation: Conventional LiDAR–camera fusion improves 3D panoptic segmentation but fails when the camera degrades (adverse weather, over/under-exposure), drifts in calibration, or goes offline—critical risks for safety-centric robotics. A fusion method that can downweight or ignore unreliable camera cues while still leveraging them when trustworthy is needed.
AI.method: 1) Project raw LiDAR into 2D range-view and encode with a LiDAR encoder. 2) Extract camera features and project them into the same range-view frame. 3) Predict uncertainty maps by learning representational divergence under diverse visual degradations; use these maps to modulate cross-modal interaction so unreliable image regions are suppressed. 4) Decode fused range-view features with a hybrid 2D–3D transformer that mitigates ambiguities from 2D projection and directly outputs 3D panoptic masks.
AI.result: Across Panoptic nuScenes, SemanticKITTI, and the introduced Panoptic Waymo benchmark, UP-Fuse maintains high performance under severe visual corruption and camera–LiDAR misalignment, indicating strong robustness relative to prior fusion methods.
AI.conclusion: Uncertainty-guided fusion in range-view, combined with a 2D–3D transformer decoder, yields reliable 3D panoptic segmentation even when camera inputs are unreliable or absent, making UP-Fuse suitable for safety-critical robotic perception.

title: Redefining the Down-Sampling Scheme of U-Net for Precision Biomedical Image Segmentation
summary: U-Net architectures have been instrumental in advancing biomedical image segmentation (BIS) but often struggle with capturing long-range information. One reason is the conventional down-sampling techniques that prioritize computational efficiency at the expense of information retention. This paper introduces a simple but effective strategy, we call it Stair Pooling, which moderates the pace of down-sampling and reduces information loss by leveraging a sequence of concatenated small and narrow pooling operations in varied orientations. Specifically, our method modifies the reduction in dimensionality within each 2D pooling step from $\frac{1}{4}$ to $\frac{1}{2}$. This approach can also be adapted for 3D pooling to preserve even more information. Such preservation aids the U-Net in more effectively reconstructing spatial details during the up-sampling phase, thereby enhancing its ability to capture long-range information and improving segmentation accuracy. Extensive experiments on three BIS benchmarks demonstrate that the proposed Stair Pooling can increase both 2D and 3D U-Net performance by an average of 3.8\% in Dice scores. Moreover, we leverage the transfer entropy to select the optimal down-sampling paths and quantitatively show how the proposed Stair Pooling reduces the information loss.

AI.tldr: Proposes Stair Pooling, a gentler, orientation-varied sequence of narrow pooling steps that halves dimensionality per step instead of quartering it, preserving more information in U-Nets and improving Dice by ~3.8% across 2D/3D BIS benchmarks; transfer-entropy analysis guides path selection and evidences lower information loss.
AI.motivation: Standard U-Net down-sampling (e.g., 2×2 pooling/stride-2) aggressively reduces resolution, discarding fine details and hindering long-range context capture crucial for accurate biomedical segmentation. The authors aim to retain more information during encoding without heavy computational overhead.
AI.method: Replace each conventional pooling with a concatenated sequence of small, narrow pooling operations in varied orientations (“stair”), moderating reduction from 1/4 to 1/2 per 2D step; extendable to 3D. Use transfer entropy to evaluate information flow and to select optimal down-sampling paths that minimize information loss.
AI.result: On three BIS benchmarks, integrating Stair Pooling into both 2D and 3D U-Nets yields an average Dice improvement of 3.8%. Transfer-entropy measurements quantitatively confirm reduced information loss and help choose effective pooling sequences.
AI.conclusion: A simple, plug-in pooling strategy that better preserves spatial information enables U-Nets to reconstruct details and capture longer-range dependencies during decoding, improving segmentation accuracy; the idea generalizes to 3D and is supported by empirical gains and information-theoretic analysis.

title: PoseCraft: Tokenized 3D Body Landmark and Camera Conditioning for Photorealistic Human Image Synthesis
summary: Digitizing humans and synthesizing photorealistic avatars with explicit 3D pose and camera controls are central to VR, telepresence, and entertainment. Existing skinning-based workflows require laborious manual rigging or template-based fittings, while neural volumetric methods rely on canonical templates and re-optimization for each unseen pose. We present PoseCraft, a diffusion framework built around tokenized 3D interface: instead of relying only on rasterized geometry as 2D control images, we encode sparse 3D landmarks and camera extrinsics as discrete conditioning tokens and inject them into diffusion via cross-attention. Our approach preserves 3D semantics by avoiding 2D re-projection ambiguity under large pose and viewpoint changes, and produces photorealistic imagery that faithfully captures identity and appearance. To train and evaluate at scale, we also implement GenHumanRF, a data generation workflow that renders diverse supervision from volumetric reconstructions. Our experiments show that PoseCraft achieves significant perceptual quality improvement over diffusion-centric methods, and attains better or comparable metrics to latest volumetric rendering SOTA while better preserving fabric and hair details.

AI.tldr: PoseCraft is a diffusion-based human avatar generator that uses tokenized 3D landmarks and camera extrinsics—fed via cross‑attention—to provide explicit 3D pose and view control, yielding photorealistic, identity-preserving images. Trained at scale with a synthetic supervision pipeline (GenHumanRF), it surpasses diffusion baselines and rivals volumetric SOTA while better keeping fine details like fabric and hair.
AI.motivation: Current avatar creation pipelines either require tedious rigging/template fitting or depend on canonical templates with costly per‑pose re-optimization. 2D control signals suffer from re-projection ambiguities under large pose/view changes. A method that offers direct 3D control while maintaining photorealism and identity is needed.
AI.method: Introduce PoseCraft, a diffusion framework conditioned on discrete tokens that encode sparse 3D landmarks and camera extrinsics. These tokens are injected via cross-attention, replacing reliance on rasterized 2D control images and preserving 3D semantics through the generative process.
