For scalable supervision, implement GenHumanRF, which renders diverse training signals from volumetric reconstructions.
AI.result: Compared to diffusion-centric baselines, PoseCraft yields significant perceptual quality gains. Against state-of-the-art volumetric renderers, it achieves better or comparable quantitative metrics and more faithfully preserves high-frequency details such as fabric textures and hair strands.
AI.conclusion: Tokenized 3D conditioning within diffusion effectively resolves 2D re-projection ambiguities and provides explicit 3D control, enabling photorealistic, identity-consistent human synthesis. Together with the GenHumanRF data pipeline, PoseCraft advances quality and detail without manual rigging or per‑pose re-optimization, achieving competitive or superior performance to leading volumetric methods.

title: FinSight-Net:A Physics-Aware Decoupled Network with Frequency-Domain Compensation for Underwater Fish Detection in Smart Aquaculture
summary: Underwater fish detection (UFD) is a core capability for smart aquaculture and marine ecological monitoring. While recent detectors improve accuracy by stacking feature extractors or introducing heavy attention modules, they often incur substantial computational overhead and, more importantly, neglect the physics that fundamentally limits UFD: wavelength-dependent absorption and turbidity-induced scattering significantly degrade contrast, blur fine structures, and introduce backscattering noise, leading to unreliable localization and recognition. To address these challenges, we propose FinSight-Net, an efficient and physics-aware detection framework tailored for complex aquaculture environments. FinSight-Net introduces a Multi-Scale Decoupled Dual-Stream Processing (MS-DDSP) bottleneck that explicitly targets frequency-specific information loss via heterogeneous convolutional branches, suppressing backscattering artifacts while compensating distorted biological cues through scale-aware and channel-weighted pathways. We further design an Efficient Path Aggregation FPN (EPA-FPN) as a detail-filling mechanism: it restores high-frequency spatial information typically attenuated in deep layers by establishing long-range skip connections and pruning redundant fusion routes, enabling robust detection of non-rigid fish targets under severe blur and turbidity. Extensive experiments on DeepFish, AquaFishSet, and our challenging UW-BlurredFish benchmark demonstrate that FinSight-Net achieves state-of-the-art performance. In particular, on UW-BlurredFish, FinSight-Net reaches 92.8% mAP, outperforming YOLOv11s by 4.8% while reducing parameters by 29.0%, providing a strong and lightweight solution for real-time automated monitoring in smart aquaculture.

AI.tldr: FinSight-Net is a lightweight, physics-aware underwater fish detector that counters wavelength absorption and turbidity scattering via a multi-scale dual-stream bottleneck and an efficient FPN, delivering SOTA results (92.8% mAP on UW-BlurredFish), +4.8 mAP over YOLOv11s with 29% fewer parameters.
AI.motivation: Underwater imaging physics—wavelength-dependent absorption and turbidity-induced scattering/backscatter—reduces contrast and fine detail, undermining fish localization/recognition. Existing detectors often ignore these effects and rely on heavy attention/feature stacks, increasing compute and limiting real-time deployment in aquaculture.
AI.method: Introduce FinSight-Net with a Multi-Scale Decoupled Dual-Stream Processing (MS-DDSP) bottleneck that uses heterogeneous convolutional branches to target frequency-specific information loss, suppress backscattering, and reweight scales/channels to recover distorted biological cues. Add an Efficient Path Aggregation FPN (EPA-FPN) that restores high-frequency spatial details through long-range skips and pruned fusion paths, improving robustness to blur and non-rigid fish shapes under turbidity.
AI.result: Across DeepFish, AquaFishSet, and the proposed UW-BlurredFish, FinSight-Net achieves state-of-the-art performance; on UW-BlurredFish it reaches 92.8% mAP, surpasses YOLOv11s by 4.8 mAP, and reduces parameters by 29%, suggesting real-time suitability.
AI.conclusion: Embedding physics-aware processing into an efficient detection architecture yields substantial gains for underwater fish detection in challenging, turbid conditions. FinSight-Net offers a strong, lightweight solution for real-time aquaculture monitoring with demonstrated cross-dataset effectiveness.

title: MentalBlackboard: Evaluating Spatial Visualization via Mathematical Transformations
summary: Spatial visualization is the mental ability to imagine, transform, and manipulate the spatial characteristics of objects and actions. This intelligence is a part of human cognition where actions and perception are connected on a mental level. To explore whether state-of-the-art Vision-Language Models (VLMs) exhibit this ability, we develop MentalBlackboard, an open-ended spatial visualization benchmark for Paper Folding and Hole Punching tests within two core tasks: prediction and planning. Our prediction experiments reveal that models struggle with applying symmetrical transformations, even when they predict the sequence of unfolding steps correctly. Also, rotations introduce a significant challenge to the physical situational awareness for models. The planning task reveals limitations of models in analyzing symmetrical relationships and in implementing the multi-stage symmetry process, with Claude Opus 4.1 achieving the highest planning score at an accuracy of 10\%. The top-performing model, o3, attains a peak performance of 71.6\% on the generalization task, which does not require spatial visualization but transfers spatial data; however, it achieves only 25\% accuracy on text-based prediction tasks.

AI.tldr: MentalBlackboard tests VLMs’ spatial visualization (paper folding/hole punching) via prediction and planning, showing broad failures on symmetry and rotation; planning tops out at 10% (Claude Opus 4.1). The o3 model excels only on a non-visual generalization task (71.6%) but achieves 25% on text prediction.
AI.motivation: Probe whether modern VLMs possess human-like spatial visualization—the ability to mentally transform and manipulate objects—an area under-tested by current benchmarks and essential for grounded reasoning and planning.
AI.method: Introduce MentalBlackboard, an open-ended benchmark built on Paper Folding and Hole Punching tasks with two settings: (1) prediction of outcomes given folds/punches (including unfolded step sequences and rotations), and (2) planning multi-step actions to reach target patterns leveraging symmetry. Also include a generalization task that requires transferring spatial data without true visualization. Evaluate multiple state-of-the-art VLMs.
AI.result:
- Models often fail to apply symmetrical transformations even when unfolding steps are correctly predicted.
- Rotations substantially impair models’ situational awareness.
- Planning shows severe limitations in analyzing and composing multi-stage symmetries; best planning accuracy is 10% (Claude Opus 4.1).
- The top model (o3) reaches 71.6% on the generalization (data-transfer) task but only 25% on text-based prediction tasks.
AI.conclusion: Current VLMs lack reliable spatial visualization skills, especially symmetry handling, rotation invariance, and multi-step spatial planning. Success on data-transfer tasks does not translate to genuine mental manipulation. MentalBlackboard exposes these gaps and can drive research toward models with structured, symmetry-aware, and rotation-robust spatial reasoning.

title: Referring Layer Decomposition
summary: Precise, object-aware control over visual content is essential for advanced image editing and compositional generation. Yet, most existing approaches operate on entire images holistically, limiting the ability to isolate and manipulate individual scene elements. In contrast, layered representations, where scenes are explicitly separated into objects, environmental context, and visual effects, provide a more intuitive and structured framework for interpreting and editing visual content. To bridge this gap and enable both compositional understanding and controllable editing, we introduce the Referring Layer Decomposition (RLD) task, which predicts complete RGBA layers from a single RGB image, conditioned on flexible user prompts, such as spatial inputs (e.g., points, boxes, masks), natural language descriptions, or combinations thereof. At the core is the RefLade, a large-scale dataset comprising 1.11M image-layer-prompt triplets produced by our scalable data engine, along with 100K manually curated, high-fidelity layers. Coupled with a perceptually grounded, human-preference-aligned automatic evaluation protocol, RefLade establishes RLD as a well-defined and benchmarkable research task. Building on this foundation, we present RefLayer, a simple baseline designed for prompt-conditioned layer decomposition, achieving high visual fidelity and semantic alignment. Extensive experiments show our approach enables effective training, reliable evaluation, and high-quality image decomposition, while exhibiting strong zero-shot generalization capabilities.

AI.tldr: Introduces Referring Layer Decomposition (RLD): predicting complete RGBA object/environment/effects layers from a single RGB image conditioned on flexible prompts (points/boxes/masks/text). Provides a large, benchmarkable dataset (RefLade: 1.11M triplets + 100K curated layers), a human-aligned automatic evaluation protocol, and a strong baseline model (RefLayer) showing high-fidelity, semantically aligned, zero-shot-capable decompositions.
AI.motivation: Current image editing/generation methods act holistically on full images, limiting object-level control. Layered scene representations are more intuitive for editing and understanding but lack scalable data and standardized benchmarks. The work aims to enable precise, object-aware, compositional control and to formalize/benchmark this capability.
AI.method: Define the RLD task: from a single RGB image and user prompt (spatial points/boxes/masks, natural language, or combinations), predict complete RGBA layers. Build RefLade via a scalable data engine to generate 1.11M image–layer–prompt triplets and add 100K manually curated, high-fidelity layers. Propose a perceptually grounded, human-preference-aligned automatic evaluation protocol. Implement RefLayer, a simple baseline for prompt-conditioned layer decomposition.
AI.result: RefLayer achieves high visual fidelity and strong semantic alignment in decomposing images into RGBA layers; experiments demonstrate effective training on RefLade, reliable automatic evaluation consistent with human judgment, and strong zero-shot generalization across prompts and images.
AI.conclusion: RLD is established as a well-defined, benchmarkable task supported by a large dataset and human-aligned metrics. The simple baseline performs well, indicating that the formulation and data enable high-quality, controllable, object-aware layer decomposition, advancing compositional understanding and practical image editing.

title: Fore-Mamba3D: Mamba-based Foreground-Enhanced Encoding for 3D Object Detection
summary: Linear modeling methods like Mamba have been merged as the effective backbone for the 3D object detection task. However, previous Mamba-based methods utilize the bidirectional encoding for the whole non-empty voxel sequence, which contains abundant useless background information in the scenes. Though directly encoding foreground voxels appears to be a plausible solution, it tends to degrade detection performance. We attribute this to the response attenuation and restricted context representation in the linear modeling for fore-only sequences. To address this problem, we propose a novel backbone, termed Fore-Mamba3D, to focus on the foreground enhancement by modifying Mamba-based encoder. The foreground voxels are first sampled according to the predicted scores. Considering the response attenuation existing in the interaction of foreground voxels across different instances, we design a regional-to-global slide window (RGSW) to propagate the information from regional split to the entire sequence. Furthermore, a semantic-assisted and state spatial fusion module (SASFMamba) is proposed to enrich contextual representation by enhancing semantic and geometric awareness within the Mamba model. Our method emphasizes foreground-only encoding and alleviates the distance-based and causal dependencies in the linear autoregression model. The superior performance across various benchmarks demonstrates the effectiveness of Fore-Mamba3D in the 3D object detection task.

AI.tldr: Fore-Mamba3D is a Mamba-based 3D detection backbone that encodes only foreground voxels while preserving global context via a regional-to-global sliding window and a semantic–spatial state fusion module, overcoming response attenuation and causal/distance biases to achieve superior benchmark results.
AI.motivation: Prior Mamba-based backbones bidirectionally encode all non-empty voxels, expending capacity on background and injecting noise. Simply restricting modeling to foreground voxels degrades accuracy because linear sequence modeling suffers response attenuation across instances and limited context when sequences are short or sparsely connected.
AI.method: 1) Select foreground voxels using predicted scores. 2) Mitigate cross-instance response attenuation with a Regional-to-Global Slide Window (RGSW) that propagates information from local splits to the full sequence. 3) Enrich context via SASFMamba, a semantic-assisted and state spatial fusion module that injects semantic and geometric cues into the Mamba state. The design emphasizes foreground-only encoding and reduces distance-based and causal dependency constraints inherent to linear autoregressive models.
AI.result: Reported superior performance on multiple 3D object detection benchmarks (exact numbers not given in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Foreground-centric linear backbones can outperform whole-scene encoders when supplemented with mechanisms for global propagation and semantic–geometric fusion. Fore-Mamba3D effectively improves 3D object detection by focusing computation on informative voxels while maintaining rich context.

title: Detector-in-the-Loop Tracking: Active Memory Rectification for Stable Glottic Opening Localization
comment: Accepted to Medical Imaging with Deep Learning (MIDL) 2026
summary: Temporal stability in glottic opening localization remains challenging due to the complementary weaknesses of single-frame detectors and foundation-model trackers: the former lacks temporal context, while the latter suffers from memory drift. Specifically, in video laryngoscopy, rapid tissue deformation, occlusions, and visual ambiguities in emergency settings require a robust, temporally aware solution that can prevent progressive tracking errors. We propose Closed-Loop Memory Correction (CL-MC), a detector-in-the-loop framework that supervises Segment Anything Model 2(SAM2) through confidence-aligned state decisions and active memory rectification. High-confidence detections trigger semantic resets that overwrite corrupted tracker memory, effectively mitigating drift accumulation with a training-free foundation tracker in complex endoscopic scenes. On emergency intubation videos, CL-MC achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly reducing drift and missing rate compared with the SAM2 variants and open loop based methods. Our results establish memory correction as a crucial component for reliable clinical video tracking. Our code will be available in https://github.com/huayuww/CL-MR.

AI.tldr: CL-MC is a detector-in-the-loop scheme that supervises SAM2 and periodically resets/rectifies its memory using high-confidence detections, preventing drift and improving temporally stable glottic opening localization in emergency laryngoscopy videos, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy with fewer drifts and misses.
AI.motivation: Temporal stability in glottic opening tracking is hard: single-frame detectors ignore temporal context and foundation-model trackers (e.g., SAM2) suffer memory drift under deformation, occlusion, and visual ambiguity, especially in high-stakes emergency intubation. A robust, training-free way to prevent progressive tracking errors is needed.
AI.method: Closed-Loop Memory Correction (CL-MC): a detector supervises SAM2 through confidence-aligned state decisions and active memory rectification. High-confidence detections trigger semantic resets that overwrite corrupted tracker memory, mitigating drift accumulation. Operates training-free and is tailored to complex endoscopic scenes.
AI.result: On emergency intubation videos, CL-MC attains state-of-the-art performance, significantly reducing drift and miss rates compared with SAM2 variants and open-loop methods. (The abstract does not report exact metrics.)
AI.conclusion: Actively correcting foundation tracker memory with detector-driven, confidence-based resets is crucial for reliable clinical video tracking. CL-MC provides a robust, training-free path to temporally stable tracking, establishing new SOTA; code to be released.

title: A Green Learning Approach to LDCT Image Restoration
comment: Published in IEEE International Conference on Image Processing (ICIP), 2025, pp. 1762-1767. Final version available at IEEE Xplore
summary: This work proposes a green learning (GL) approach to restore medical images. Without loss of generality, we use low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) images as examples. LDCT images are susceptible to noise and artifacts, where the imaging process introduces distortion. LDCT image restoration is an important preprocessing step for further medical analysis. Deep learning (DL) methods have been developed to solve this problem. We examine an alternative solution using the Green Learning (GL) methodology. The new restoration method is characterized by mathematical transparency, computational and memory efficiency, and high performance. Experiments show that our GL method offers state-of-the-art restoration performance at a smaller model size and with lower inference complexity.

AI.tldr: Introduces a Green Learning (GL) approach for medical image restoration, exemplified on low-dose CT, achieving state-of-the-art quality with smaller, more efficient, and more transparent models than typical deep learning baselines.
AI.motivation: LDCT images suffer from noise and artifacts due to the imaging process, and high-quality restoration is crucial for downstream medical analysis. While deep learning solutions exist, they can be large, computationally heavy, and opaque; the authors seek a mathematically transparent and resource-efficient alternative.
AI.method: Apply the Green Learning (GL) methodology to image restoration. The approach emphasizes mathematical transparency and low computational/memory footprint; specific architectural details are not provided in the abstract but GL is positioned as an alternative to conventional deep neural networks for LDCT denoising/deartifacting.
AI.result: Experiments reportedly demonstrate state-of-the-art restoration performance while using a smaller model and lower inference complexity than competing methods.
AI.conclusion: GL is presented as a viable, efficient, and transparent alternative to deep learning for medical image restoration, likely generalizable beyond LDCT to other modalities or tasks.

title: DICArt: Advancing Category-level Articulated Object Pose Estimation in Discrete State-Spaces
summary: Articulated object pose estimation is a core task in embodied AI. Existing methods typically regress poses in a continuous space, but often struggle with 1) navigating a large, complex search space and 2) failing to incorporate intrinsic kinematic constraints. In this work, we introduce DICArt (DIsCrete Diffusion for Articulation Pose Estimation), a novel framework that formulates pose estimation as a conditional discrete diffusion process. Instead of operating in a continuous domain, DICArt progressively denoises a noisy pose representation through a learned reverse diffusion procedure to recover the GT pose. To improve modeling fidelity, we propose a flexible flow decider that dynamically determines whether each token should be denoised or reset, effectively balancing the real and noise distributions during diffusion. Additionally, we incorporate a hierarchical kinematic coupling strategy, estimating the pose of each rigid part hierarchically to respect the object's kinematic structure. We validate DICArt on both synthetic and real-world datasets. Experimental results demonstrate its superior performance and robustness. By integrating discrete generative modeling with structural priors, DICArt offers a new paradigm for reliable category-level 6D pose estimation in complex environments.

AI.tldr: DICArt reframes articulated 6D pose estimation as conditional discrete diffusion over tokenized poses, adding a dynamic token flow decider and hierarchical kinematic coupling to enforce structure, achieving superior, robust performance on synthetic and real datasets.
AI.motivation: Continuous regression methods face a vast search space and often ignore intrinsic kinematic constraints of articulated objects, hurting accuracy and robustness.
AI.method: Represent poses discretely and perform conditional discrete diffusion that progressively denoises tokens to the ground-truth pose. Introduce a flexible flow decider to choose per token whether to denoise or reset, balancing real and noise distributions. Apply hierarchical kinematic coupling to estimate rigid-part poses in a structure-respecting order.
AI.result: On both synthetic and real-world benchmarks, DICArt outperforms prior methods and shows improved robustness; specifics are not quantified in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: Discrete generative modeling combined with structural (kinematic) priors provides a reliable new paradigm for category-level articulated 6D pose estimation in complex environments.

title: PA-Attack: Guiding Gray-Box Attacks on LVLM Vision Encoders with Prototypes and Attention
summary: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) are foundational to modern multimodal applications, yet their susceptibility to adversarial attacks remains a critical concern. Prior white-box attacks rarely generalize across tasks, and black-box methods depend on expensive transfer, which limits efficiency. The vision encoder, standardized and often shared across LVLMs, provides a stable gray-box pivot with strong cross-model transfer. Building on this premise, we introduce PA-Attack (Prototype-Anchored Attentive Attack). PA-Attack begins with a prototype-anchored guidance that provides a stable attack direction towards a general and dissimilar prototype, tackling the attribute-restricted issue and limited task generalization of vanilla attacks. Building on this, we propose a two-stage attention enhancement mechanism: (i) leverage token-level attention scores to concentrate perturbations on critical visual tokens, and (ii) adaptively recalibrate attention weights to track the evolving attention during the adversarial process. Extensive experiments across diverse downstream tasks and LVLM architectures show that PA-Attack achieves an average 75.1% score reduction rate (SRR), demonstrating strong attack effectiveness, efficiency, and task generalization in LVLMs. Code is available at https://github.com/hefeimei06/PA-Attack.

AI.tldr: PA-Attack is a gray-box adversarial method for large vision–language models that exploits the shared vision encoder and attention to craft transferable, efficient, and task-general perturbations, yielding a reported 75.1% average score reduction across diverse tasks and models.
AI.motivation: Existing white-box attacks on LVLMs often overfit to tasks/attributes and fail to transfer; black-box approaches rely on costly transfer queries. Since many LVLMs share standardized vision encoders, this component can serve as a stable pivot for more transferable, efficient attacks.
AI.method: Prototype-Anchored Attentive Attack: (1) prototype-anchored guidance steers perturbations toward a general, dissimilar prototype to avoid attribute-restricted directions and improve task generalization; (2) a two-stage attention enhancement that (i) uses token-level attention scores to focus perturbations on critical visual tokens and (ii) adaptively recalibrates attention weights during optimization to follow evolving attention patterns. Operates in a gray-box setting leveraging the shared vision encoder for cross-model transfer.
AI.result: Across multiple downstream tasks and LVLM architectures, PA-Attack attains an average 75.1% score reduction rate, indicating strong attack effectiveness, cross-model transferability, and computational efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging the standardized vision encoder as a gray-box pivot plus prototype-anchored and attention-aware perturbation strategies enables broadly transferable, efficient attacks on LVLMs. This underscores security vulnerabilities in current multimodal systems and motivates defenses that consider encoder-level robustness and attention dynamics.

title: CLCR: Cross-Level Semantic Collaborative Representation for Multimodal Learning
comment: This study has been Accepted by CVPR 2026
summary: Multimodal learning aims to capture both shared and private information from multiple modalities. However, existing methods that project all modalities into a single latent space for fusion often overlook the asynchronous, multi-level semantic structure of multimodal data. This oversight induces semantic misalignment and error propagation, thereby degrading representation quality. To address this issue, we propose Cross-Level Co-Representation (CLCR), which explicitly organizes each modality's features into a three-level semantic hierarchy and specifies level-wise constraints for cross-modal interactions. First, a semantic hierarchy encoder aligns shallow, mid, and deep features across modalities, establishing a common basis for interaction. And then, at each level, an Intra-Level Co-Exchange Domain (IntraCED) factorizes features into shared and private subspaces and restricts cross-modal attention to the shared subspace via a learnable token budget. This design ensures that only shared semantics are exchanged and prevents leakage from private channels. To integrate information across levels, the Inter-Level Co-Aggregation Domain (InterCAD) synchronizes semantic scales using learned anchors, selectively fuses the shared representations, and gates private cues to form a compact task representation. We further introduce regularization terms to enforce separation of shared and private features and to minimize cross-level interference. Experiments on six benchmarks spanning emotion recognition, event localization, sentiment analysis, and action recognition show that CLCR achieves strong performance and generalizes well across tasks.

AI.tldr: CLCR introduces a level-aware multimodal framework that aligns shallow/mid/deep features, exchanges only shared semantics via budgeted attention, aggregates across levels with learned anchors, and regularizes shared–private separation—yielding strong, generalizable performance across diverse benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Projecting all modalities into a single latent space ignores asynchronous, multi-level semantics across modalities, which causes semantic misalignment and error propagation and ultimately weakens multimodal representations.
AI.method: 1) Semantic Hierarchy Encoder: organizes each modality’s features into three semantic levels (shallow/mid/deep) and aligns them across modalities. 2) Intra-Level Co-Exchange Domain (IntraCED): at each level, factorizes features into shared and private subspaces; restricts cross-modal attention to the shared subspace using a learnable token budget to prevent private-information leakage. 3) Inter-Level Co-Aggregation Domain (InterCAD): synchronizes semantic scales via learned anchors, selectively fuses shared features across levels, and gates private cues to form a compact task representation. 4) Regularization: encourages clean separation of shared vs. private features and reduces cross-level interference.
AI.result: Across six benchmarks spanning emotion recognition, event localization, sentiment analysis, and action recognition, CLCR delivers strong performance and shows good cross-task generalization (no specific metrics reported in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Enforcing a hierarchical, level-specific co-representation with constrained cross-modal exchange mitigates misalignment and leakage, producing compact, robust multimodal representations that transfer well across tasks.

title: Prefer-DAS: Learning from Local Preferences and Sparse Prompts for Domain Adaptive Segmentation of Electron Microscopy
summary: Domain adaptive segmentation (DAS) is a promising paradigm for delineating intracellular structures from various large-scale electron microscopy (EM) without incurring extensive annotated data in each domain. However, the prevalent unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) strategies often demonstrate limited and biased performance, which hinders their practical applications. In this study, we explore sparse points and local human preferences as weak labels in the target domain, thereby presenting a more realistic yet annotation-efficient setting. Specifically, we develop Prefer-DAS, which pioneers sparse promptable learning and local preference alignment. The Prefer-DAS is a promptable multitask model that integrates self-training and prompt-guided contrastive learning. Unlike SAM-like methods, the Prefer-DAS allows for the use of full, partial, and even no point prompts during both training and inference stages and thus enables interactive segmentation. Instead of using image-level human preference alignment for segmentation, we introduce Local direct Preference Optimization (LPO) and sparse LPO (SLPO), plug-and-play solutions for alignment with spatially varying human feedback or sparse feedback. To address potential missing feedback, we also introduce Unsupervised Preference Optimization (UPO), which leverages self-learned preferences. As a result, the Prefer-DAS model can effectively perform both weakly-supervised and unsupervised DAS, depending on the availability of points and human preferences. Comprehensive experiments on four challenging DAS tasks demonstrate that our model outperforms SAM-like methods as well as unsupervised and weakly-supervised DAS methods in both automatic and interactive segmentation modes, highlighting strong generalizability and flexibility. Additionally, the performance of our model is very close to or even exceeds that of supervised models.

AI.tldr: Prefer-DAS is a promptable, preference-aligned domain adaptive EM segmentation framework that exploits sparse point prompts and local human feedback. Using LPO/SLPO/UPO with self-training and prompt-guided contrastive learning, it supports automatic and interactive modes and outperforms SAM-like and UDA/weakly supervised baselines across four tasks, approaching supervised performance.
AI.motivation: Unsupervised domain adaptation for EM segmentation often underperforms and can be biased, while dense annotations for each new domain are costly. The authors aim to leverage realistic, low-cost weak labels—sparse points and spatially local human preferences—to achieve effective, flexible, and interactive segmentation with minimal annotation burden.
AI.method: They propose Prefer-DAS, a multitask, promptable model that integrates self-training and prompt-guided contrastive learning. It can ingest full, partial, or no point prompts during training and inference. For alignment with human feedback, they introduce Local direct Preference Optimization (LPO) and sparse LPO (SLPO) to handle spatially varying or sparse preferences, plus Unsupervised Preference Optimization (UPO) to learn preferences when explicit feedback is missing. The system supports both weakly supervised and unsupervised DAS, depending on available signals.
AI.result: Across four challenging DAS tasks, Prefer-DAS outperforms SAM-like approaches and state-of-the-art unsupervised/weakly supervised DAS methods in both automatic and interactive settings. It shows strong generalizability and flexibility, with performance near or surpassing fully supervised models.
AI.conclusion: Combining sparse promptable learning with local preference alignment yields an annotation-efficient, flexible, and generalizable solution for EM DAS. The approach enables practical interactive segmentation and achieves performance competitive with or better than supervised baselines.

title: Satellite-Based Detection of Looted Archaeological Sites Using Machine Learning
summary: Looting at archaeological sites poses a severe risk to cultural heritage, yet monitoring thousands of remote locations remains operationally difficult. We present a scalable and satellite-based pipeline to detect looted archaeological sites, using PlanetScope monthly mosaics (4.7m/pixel) and a curated dataset of 1,943 archaeological sites in Afghanistan (898 looted, 1,045 preserved) with multi-year imagery (2016--2023) and site-footprint masks. We compare (i) end-to-end CNN classifiers trained on raw RGB patches and (ii) traditional machine learning (ML) trained on handcrafted spectral/texture features and embeddings from recent remote-sensing foundation models. Results indicate that ImageNet-pretrained CNNs combined with spatial masking reach an F1 score of 0.926, clearly surpassing the strongest traditional ML setup, which attains an F1 score of 0.710 using SatCLIP-V+RF+Mean, i.e., location and vision embeddings fed into a Random Forest with mean-based temporal aggregation. Ablation studies demonstrate that ImageNet pretraining (even in the presence of domain shift) and spatial masking enhance performance. In contrast, geospatial foundation model embeddings perform competitively with handcrafted features, suggesting that looting signatures are extremely localized. The repository is available at https://github.com/microsoft/looted_site_detection.

AI.tldr: Scalable satellite pipeline for detecting looted archaeological sites: ImageNet-pretrained CNNs with spatial masking on PlanetScope mosaics achieve F1 0.926 on an Afghanistan dataset (2016–2023), outperforming traditional ML and foundation-model-embedding baselines; code released.
AI.motivation: Looting threatens cultural heritage, but monitoring thousands of remote sites is logistically hard. The goal is to build an automated, scalable, satellite-based detector that reliably flags looted sites over large areas and long time spans.
AI.method: Curate 1,943 Afghan archaeological sites with footprint masks and multi-year PlanetScope (4.7 m) monthly mosaics (2016–2023). Compare (i) end-to-end CNN classifiers on raw RGB patches (ImageNet-pretrained, with spatial masking) versus (ii) traditional ML (Random Forests) on handcrafted spectral/texture features and on embeddings from remote-sensing foundation models (e.g., SatCLIP-V), using mean-based temporal aggregation. Conduct ablations on pretraining and masking.
AI.result: ImageNet-pretrained CNNs + spatial masking reach F1=0.926, surpassing strongest traditional ML baseline (SatCLIP-V location+vision embeddings → RF with mean temporal aggregation), which reaches F1=0.710. Ablations show both ImageNet pretraining and spatial masking materially boost performance. Foundation-model embeddings perform similarly to handcrafted features, indicating the discriminative cues are highly localized.
AI.conclusion: A practical, scalable satellite workflow can detect looted sites with high accuracy. Transfer learning from ImageNet and precise spatial masks are key; generic geospatial foundation-model embeddings offer limited gains for this localized task. Open-source repo provided for reproducibility and extension.

title: Hepato-LLaVA: An Expert MLLM with Sparse Topo-Pack Attention for Hepatocellular Pathology Analysis on Whole Slide Images
summary: Hepatocellular Carcinoma diagnosis relies heavily on the interpretation of gigapixel Whole Slide Images. However, current computational approaches are constrained by fixed-resolution processing mechanisms and inefficient feature aggregation, which inevitably lead to either severe information loss or high feature redundancy. To address these challenges, we propose Hepato-LLaVA, a specialized Multi-modal Large Language Model designed for fine-grained hepatocellular pathology analysis. We introduce a novel Sparse Topo-Pack Attention mechanism that explicitly models 2D tissue topology. This mechanism effectively aggregates local diagnostic evidence into semantic summary tokens while preserving global context. Furthermore, to overcome the lack of multi-scale data, we present HepatoPathoVQA, a clinically grounded dataset comprising 33K hierarchically structured question-answer pairs validated by expert pathologists. Our experiments demonstrate that Hepato-LLaVA achieves state-of-the-art performance on HCC diagnosis and captioning tasks, significantly outperforming existing methods. Our code and implementation details are available at https://pris-cv.github.io/Hepto-LLaVA/.

AI.tldr: Hepato-LLaVA is a multimodal LLM with a topology-aware attention mechanism that aggregates WSI evidence efficiently and achieves SOTA on hepatocellular carcinoma diagnosis and captioning, aided by a new 33K-pathology VQA dataset.
AI.motivation: HCC diagnosis from gigapixel WSIs suffers from fixed-resolution pipelines and inefficient feature aggregation, causing information loss or redundancy. There is also a lack of multi-scale, clinically grounded data for training/evaluating reasoning models.
AI.method: Propose Hepato-LLaVA, a specialized multimodal LLM for pathology. Introduce Sparse Topo-Pack Attention that explicitly encodes 2D tissue topology to compress local evidence into semantic summary tokens while preserving global context. Release HepatoPathoVQA with 33K hierarchically structured, expert-validated Q&A pairs to support multi-scale reasoning. Evaluate on HCC diagnosis and captioning.
AI.result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on HCC diagnosis and pathology captioning, significantly outperforming existing methods (exact metrics not provided in abstract).
AI.conclusion: Topology-aware evidence aggregation combined with a clinically grounded, hierarchical VQA dataset enables fine-grained, context-preserving WSI analysis, advancing automated HCC pathology; code and implementation are publicly available.

title: PedaCo-Gen: Scaffolding Pedagogical Agency in Human-AI Collaborative Video Authoring
summary: While advancements in Text-to-Video (T2V) generative AI offer a promising path toward democratizing content creation, current models are often optimized for visual fidelity rather than instructional efficacy. This study introduces PedaCo-Gen, a pedagogically-informed human-AI collaborative video generating system for authoring instructional videos based on Mayer's Cognitive Theory of Multimedia Learning (CTML). Moving away from traditional "one-shot" generation, PedaCo-Gen introduces an Intermediate Representation (IR) phase, enabling educators to interactively review and refine video blueprints-comprising scripts and visual descriptions-with an AI reviewer. Our study with 23 education experts demonstrates that PedaCo-Gen significantly enhances video quality across various topics and CTML principles compared to baselines. Participants perceived the AI-driven guidance not merely as a set of instructions but as a metacognitive scaffold that augmented their instructional design expertise, reporting high production efficiency (M=4.26) and guide validity (M=4.04). These findings highlight the importance of reclaiming pedagogical agency through principled co-creation, providing a foundation for future AI authoring tools that harmonize generative power with human professional expertise.

AI.tldr: PedaCo-Gen is a CTML-guided, human–AI co-authoring system that inserts an interactive intermediate representation (scripts + visual plans) before T2V generation, yielding higher instructional video quality and perceived design support than baselines in a study with 23 experts.
AI.motivation: Most T2V generators optimize for visual fidelity, not instructional efficacy; educators need workflows that embed pedagogy and preserve human agency in authoring.
AI.method: Introduce a collaborative pipeline centered on an Intermediate Representation where educators iteratively refine scripts and visual descriptions with an AI reviewer grounded in CTML principles; compare against one-shot/baseline workflows via a study with 23 education experts across topics and CTML principles.
AI.result: PedaCo-Gen significantly improves video quality versus baselines; participants perceived the AI guidance as a metacognitive scaffold and reported high production efficiency (M=4.26) and guide validity (M=4.04).
AI.conclusion: IR-based, pedagogy-first co-creation can align generative AI with instructional goals, helping reclaim pedagogical agency; this approach should guide future AI authoring tools to harmonize generative power with human expertise.

title: TherA: Thermal-Aware Visual-Language Prompting for Controllable RGB-to-Thermal Infrared Translation
summary: Despite the inherent advantages of thermal infrared(TIR) imaging, large-scale data collection and annotation remain a major bottleneck for TIR-based perception. A practical alternative is to synthesize pseudo TIR data via image translation; however, most RGB-to-TIR approaches heavily rely on RGB-centric priors that overlook thermal physics, yielding implausible heat distributions. In this paper, we introduce TherA, a controllable RGB-to-TIR translation framework that produces diverse and thermally plausible images at both scene and object level. TherA couples TherA-VLM with a latent-diffusion-based translator. Given a single RGB image and a user-prompted condition pair, TherA-VLM yields a thermal-aware embedding that encodes scene, object, material, and heat-emission context reflecting the input scene-condition pair. Conditioning the diffusion model on this embedding enables realistic TIR synthesis and fine-grained control across time of day, weather, and object state. Compared to other baselines, TherA achieves state-of-the-art translation performance, demonstrating improved zero-shot translation performance up to 33% increase averaged across all metrics.

AI.tldr: TherA is a controllable RGB-to-thermal (TIR) image translation framework that combines a thermal-aware VLM embedding with a latent diffusion model to generate diverse, physically plausible TIR images under varying conditions, achieving state-of-the-art and up to 33% zero-shot gains over baselines.
AI.motivation: TIR imaging is valuable but hampered by scarce labeled data. Existing RGB→TIR translators overfit to RGB priors and ignore thermal physics, producing implausible heat distributions. A controllable, physically grounded synthesis method can mitigate data scarcity and improve realism.
AI.method: Couple a specialized vision-language module (TherA-VLM) with a latent diffusion translator. Given an RGB image and a user-specified condition pair (e.g., time of day, weather, object state), TherA-VLM outputs a thermal-aware embedding encoding scene, object, material, and heat-emission context. The diffusion model is conditioned on this embedding to synthesize realistic, controllable TIR imagery with diversity at scene and object levels.
AI.result: TherA delivers state-of-the-art RGB→TIR translation quality and control, with reported zero-shot translation improvements up to 33% on average across evaluation metrics compared to prior methods.
AI.conclusion: Embedding thermal semantics and physical cues via a VLM and conditioning a diffusion model enables controllable, thermally plausible TIR synthesis, offering a practical path to augment TIR datasets and enhance TIR-based perception systems.

title: Localized Concept Erasure in Text-to-Image Diffusion Models via High-Level Representation Misdirection
comment: Accepted at ICLR 2026. The first two authors contributed equally
summary: Recent advances in text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models have seen rapid and widespread adoption. However, their powerful generative capabilities raise concerns about potential misuse for synthesizing harmful, private, or copyrighted content. To mitigate such risks, concept erasure techniques have emerged as a promising solution. Prior works have primarily focused on fine-tuning the denoising component (e.g., the U-Net backbone). However, recent causal tracing studies suggest that visual attribute information is localized in the early self-attention layers of the text encoder, indicating a potential alternative for concept erasing. Building on this insight, we conduct preliminary experiments and find that directly fine-tuning early layers can suppress target concepts but often degrades the generation quality of non-target concepts. To overcome this limitation, we propose High-Level Representation Misdirection (HiRM), which misdirects high-level semantic representations of target concepts in the text encoder toward designated vectors such as random directions or semantically defined directions (e.g., supercategories), while updating only early layers that contain causal states of visual attributes. Our decoupling strategy enables precise concept removal with minimal impact on unrelated concepts, as demonstrated by strong results on UnlearnCanvas and NSFW benchmarks across diverse targets (e.g., objects, styles, nudity). HiRM also preserves generative utility at low training cost, transfers to state-of-the-art architectures such as Flux without additional training, and shows synergistic effects with denoiser-based concept erasing methods.

AI.tldr: HiRM erases targeted concepts in text-to-image diffusion by misdirecting high-level text-encoder representations while only updating early layers, enabling precise removal with little collateral damage, low cost, transferability, and complementarity to denoiser-based methods.
AI.motivation: Powerful T2I models can be misused to generate harmful or copyrighted content. Prior concept-erasure methods mainly fine-tune the denoiser (U-Net), but causal tracing indicates key visual attributes live in early self-attention layers of the text encoder. Naively fine-tuning these layers suppresses targets but degrades unrelated generations, motivating a strategy that removes concepts without broad quality loss.
AI.method: High-Level Representation Misdirection (HiRM): identify high-level semantic embeddings for target concepts in the text encoder and misdirect them toward designated vectors (random or semantically meaningful directions such as supercategories). Train only the early text-encoder layers that hold causal visual attributes, decoupling concept suppression from general semantics to limit collateral effects. The approach can combine with denoiser-based unlearning.
AI.result: On UnlearnCanvas and NSFW benchmarks, HiRM removes diverse targets (objects, styles, nudity) more precisely than baselines, with minimal degradation to unrelated content. It maintains generative utility at low training cost, transfers to SOTA architectures (e.g., Flux) without extra training, and shows synergy with denoiser-based erasure.
AI.conclusion: Misdirecting high-level text-encoder representations while updating only early layers provides an efficient, precise, and generalizable path for concept erasure in T2I models. HiRM preserves model utility, generalizes across architectures, and can enhance existing U-Net-based unlearning approaches.

title: CountEx: Fine-Grained Counting via Exemplars and Exclusion
summary: This paper presents CountEx, a discriminative visual counting framework designed to address a key limitation of existing prompt-based methods: the inability to explicitly exclude visually similar distractors. While current approaches allow users to specify what to count via inclusion prompts, they often struggle in cluttered scenes with confusable object categories, leading to ambiguity and overcounting. CountEx enables users to express both inclusion and exclusion intent, specifying what to count and what to ignore, through multimodal prompts including natural language descriptions and optional visual exemplars. At the core of CountEx is a novel Discriminative Query Refinement module, which jointly reasons over inclusion and exclusion cues by first identifying shared visual features, then isolating exclusion-specific patterns, and finally applying selective suppression to refine the counting query. To support systematic evaluation of fine-grained counting methods, we introduce CoCount, a benchmark comprising 1,780 videos and 10,086 annotated frames across 97 category pairs. Experiments show that CountEx achieves substantial improvements over state-of-the-art methods for counting objects from both known and novel categories. The data and code are available at https://github.com/bbvisual/CountEx.

AI.tldr: CountEx is a visual counting framework that adds explicit exclusion prompts and a discriminative query refinement module to avoid overcounting look‑alike distractors, showing strong gains and introducing the CoCount benchmark.
AI.motivation: Existing prompt-based counting lets users specify what to include but cannot explicitly exclude visually similar distractors, causing ambiguity and overcounting in cluttered, fine‑grained scenarios. The paper aims to let users express both inclusion and exclusion intent to improve precision and robustness.
AI.method: Users provide inclusion and exclusion instructions via natural language and optional visual exemplars. A Discriminative Query Refinement module jointly reasons over both signals by (1) extracting shared visual features, (2) isolating exclusion-specific patterns, and (3) applying selective suppression to refine the counting query. The framework is designed to handle both known and novel categories.
AI.result: CountEx achieves substantial improvements over state-of-the-art fine‑grained counting methods on both known and novel categories. The authors also introduce CoCount, a benchmark with 1,780 videos and 10,086 annotated frames across 97 category pairs, for systematic evaluation.
AI.conclusion: Modeling explicit exclusion via multimodal prompts and discriminative refinement reduces confusion from similar distractors, leading to more accurate and generalizable visual counting. CoCount supports standardized assessment of such discriminative counting approaches.

title: TeHOR: Text-Guided 3D Human and Object Reconstruction with Textures
comment: Published at CVPR 2026, 20 pages including the supplementary material
summary: Joint reconstruction of 3D human and object from a single image is an active research area, with pivotal applications in robotics and digital content creation. Despite recent advances, existing approaches suffer from two fundamental limitations. First, their reconstructions rely heavily on physical contact information, which inherently cannot capture non-contact human-object interactions, such as gazing at or pointing toward an object. Second, the reconstruction process is primarily driven by local geometric proximity, neglecting the human and object appearances that provide global context crucial for understanding holistic interactions. To address these issues, we introduce TeHOR, a framework built upon two core designs. First, beyond contact information, our framework leverages text descriptions of human-object interactions to enforce semantic alignment between the 3D reconstruction and its textual cues, enabling reasoning over a wider spectrum of interactions, including non-contact cases. Second, we incorporate appearance cues of the 3D human and object into the alignment process to capture holistic contextual information, thereby ensuring visually plausible reconstructions. As a result, our framework produces accurate and semantically coherent reconstructions, achieving state-of-the-art performance.

AI.tldr: TeHOR jointly reconstructs 3D humans and objects from a single image by aligning the reconstruction with text-described interactions and with appearance cues, enabling non-contact interaction reasoning and achieving state-of-the-art, semantically coherent results.
AI.motivation: Existing methods depend on physical contact cues and local geometric proximity, which fail to capture non-contact interactions (e.g., gaze, pointing) and ignore global contextual information from human/object appearance.
AI.method: A two-part framework: (1) use textual descriptions of human–object interactions to semantically align 3D reconstructions with language cues, broadening interaction coverage beyond contact; (2) incorporate appearance information of both human and object into the alignment process to encode holistic, global context and enforce visual plausibility.
AI.result: Produces accurate and semantically coherent human–object 3D reconstructions from a single image, handles non-contact interactions, and achieves state-of-the-art performance compared to prior work.
AI.conclusion: Integrating language-based interaction cues and appearance-driven context overcomes contact-only and local-geometry limitations, yielding visually plausible, context-aware, and superior joint 3D human–object reconstructions.

title: Efficient endometrial carcinoma screening via cross-modal synthesis and gradient distillation
summary: Early detection of myometrial invasion is critical for the staging and life-saving management of endometrial carcinoma (EC), a prevalent global malignancy. Transvaginal ultrasound serves as the primary, accessible screening modality in resource-constrained primary care settings; however, its diagnostic reliability is severely hindered by low tissue contrast, high operator dependence, and a pronounced scarcity of positive pathological samples. Existing artificial intelligence solutions struggle to overcome this severe class imbalance and the subtle imaging features of invasion, particularly under the strict computational limits of primary care clinics. Here we present an automated, highly efficient two-stage deep learning framework that resolves both data and computational bottlenecks in EC screening. To mitigate pathological data scarcity, we develop a structure-guided cross-modal generation network that synthesizes diverse, high-fidelity ultrasound images from unpaired magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data, strictly preserving clinically essential anatomical junctions. Furthermore, we introduce a lightweight screening network utilizing gradient distillation, which transfers discriminative knowledge from a high-capacity teacher model to dynamically guide sparse attention towards task-critical regions. Evaluated on a large, multicenter cohort of 7,951 participants, our model achieves a sensitivity of 99.5\%, a specificity of 97.2\%, and an area under the curve of 0.987 at a minimal computational cost (0.289 GFLOPs), substantially outperforming the average diagnostic accuracy of expert sonographers. Our approach demonstrates that combining cross-modal synthetic augmentation with knowledge-driven efficient modeling can democratize expert-level, real-time cancer screening for resource-constrained primary care settings.

AI.tldr: A two-stage, compute-efficient deep learning pipeline augments scarce ultrasound data with structure-preserving MRI→US synthesis and deploys a lightweight, knowledge-distilled screening model to detect myometrial invasion in endometrial cancer, achieving expert-surpassing accuracy on 7,951 patients at very low FLOPs.
AI.motivation: Early, accurate assessment of myometrial invasion is vital for endometrial cancer staging and management. Primary-care transvaginal ultrasound is widespread but limited by low tissue contrast, operator dependence, and few positive cases, creating class imbalance. Existing AI struggles with subtle invasion cues and clinic-level compute constraints.
AI.method: Stage 1: A structure-guided cross-modal generation network produces diverse, high-fidelity ultrasound images from unpaired MRI while preserving critical anatomical junctions, addressing data scarcity and class imbalance. Stage 2: A lightweight screening network uses gradient distillation from a high-capacity teacher to guide sparse attention toward task-relevant regions, enabling high accuracy under tight computational budgets.
AI.result: On a multicenter cohort of 7,951 participants, the model reaches 99.5% sensitivity, 97.2% specificity, and 0.987 AUC with only 0.289 GFLOPs, outperforming expert sonographers.
AI.conclusion: Cross-modal synthetic augmentation combined with knowledge-distilled, efficient modeling can deliver expert-level, real-time screening for endometrial carcinoma in resource-limited primary care, potentially democratizing access to high-quality diagnostics.

title: UrbanAlign: Post-hoc Semantic Calibration for VLM-Human Preference Alignment
summary: Aligning vision-language model (VLM) outputs with human preferences in domain-specific tasks typically requires fine-tuning or reinforcement learning, both of which demand labelled data and GPU compute. We show that for subjective perception tasks, this alignment can be achieved without any model training: VLMs are already strong concept extractors but poor decision calibrators, and the gap can be closed externally. We propose a training-free post-hoc concept-bottleneck pipeline consisting of three tightly coupled stages: concept mining, multi-agent structured scoring, and geometric calibration, unified by an end-to-end dimension optimization loop. Interpretable evaluation dimensions are mined from a handful of human annotations; an Observer-Debater-Judge chain extracts robust continuous concept scores from a frozen VLM; and locally-weighted ridge regression on a hybrid visual-semantic manifold calibrates these scores against human ratings. Applied to urban perception as UrbanAlign, the framework achieves 72.2% accuracy ($κ=0.45$) on Place Pulse 2.0 across six categories, outperforming the best supervised baseline by +15.1 pp and uncalibrated VLM scoring by +16.3 pp, with full dimension-level interpretability and zero model-weight modification.

AI.tldr: Training-free, post-hoc concept-bottleneck alignment turns frozen VLM concept extraction into calibrated, human-aligned decisions via interpretable dimensions, multi-agent scoring, and geometric calibration—outperforming supervised baselines on urban perception without updating model weights.
AI.motivation: Align VLM outputs with human preferences in subjective, domain-specific tasks without costly fine-tuning/RL and large labeled datasets; exploit that VLMs extract concepts well but are poorly calibrated for final decisions; provide interpretable reasoning dimensions.
AI.method: A zero-training, post-hoc pipeline: (1) concept mining from a few human annotations to define interpretable evaluation dimensions; (2) multi-agent structured scoring (Observer–Debater–Judge) to derive robust continuous concept scores from a frozen VLM; (3) geometric calibration via locally weighted ridge regression on a hybrid visual–semantic manifold to map scores to human ratings; all tied by an end-to-end dimension optimization loop.
AI.result: As UrbanAlign on Place Pulse 2.0 (six urban perception categories), achieves 72.2% accuracy (κ=0.45), surpassing the best supervised baseline by +15.1 pp and uncalibrated VLM scoring by +16.3 pp; delivers full dimension-level interpretability with zero model-weight modification.
AI.conclusion: Training-free external calibration can close the gap between VLM concept extraction and human-aligned decisions, yielding interpretable, strong performance without labeled-data-heavy or compute-intensive fine-tuning; approach is likely generalizable to other subjective perception domains.

title: GOAL: Geometrically Optimal Alignment for Continual Generalized Category Discovery
summary: Continual Generalized Category Discovery (C-GCD) requires identifying novel classes from unlabeled data while retaining knowledge of known classes over time. Existing methods typically update classifier weights dynamically, resulting in forgetting and inconsistent feature alignment. We propose GOAL, a unified framework that introduces a fixed Equiangular Tight Frame (ETF) classifier to impose a consistent geometric structure throughout learning. GOAL conducts supervised alignment for labeled samples and confidence-guided alignment for novel samples, enabling stable integration of new classes without disrupting old ones. Experiments on four benchmarks show that GOAL outperforms the prior method Happy, reducing forgetting by 16.1% and boosting novel class discovery by 3.2%, establishing a strong solution for long-horizon continual discovery.

AI.tldr: GOAL fixes classifier geometry with an Equiangular Tight Frame (ETF) and aligns features (supervised for known classes, confidence-guided for novel ones), reducing forgetting by 16.1% and improving novel class discovery by 3.2% across four benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Continual generalized category discovery must uncover new classes from unlabeled data while retaining knowledge of known classes. Methods that continually update classifier weights suffer from catastrophic forgetting and drifting, leading to inconsistent feature alignment over time. A stable, consistent geometric structure is needed to mitigate these issues.
AI.method: Introduce a unified framework (GOAL) that replaces dynamically updated classifiers with a fixed Equiangular Tight Frame (ETF) classifier to serve as stable class anchors. Apply supervised alignment for labeled/known samples and confidence-guided alignment for unlabeled/novel samples so new classes integrate without disrupting previously learned ones.
AI.result: Across four benchmarks, GOAL outperforms the prior state of the art (Happy), achieving a 16.1% reduction in forgetting and a 3.2% increase in novel-class discovery performance.
AI.conclusion: Enforcing a fixed geometric structure via an ETF classifier, combined with supervised and confidence-guided alignment, stabilizes continual discovery, yielding lower forgetting and better novel-class discovery over long horizons than dynamic classifier approaches.

title: Decoupling Vision and Language: Codebook Anchored Visual Adaptation
comment: 17 pages, accepted to CVPR2026 main conference
summary: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) use their vision encoders to translate images into representations for downstream reasoning, but the encoders often underperform in domain-specific visual tasks such as medical image diagnosis or fine-grained classification, where representation errors can cascade through the language model, leading to incorrect responses. Existing adaptation methods modify the continuous feature interface between encoder and language model through projector tuning or other parameter-efficient updates, which still couples the two components and requires re-alignment whenever the encoder changes. We introduce CRAFT (Codebook RegulAted Fine-Tuning), a lightweight method that fine-tunes the encoder using a discrete codebook that anchors visual representations to a stable token space, achieving domain adaptation without modifying other parts of the model. This decoupled design allows the adapted encoder to seamlessly boost the performance of LVLMs with different language architectures, as long as they share the same codebook. Empirically, CRAFT achieves an average gain of 13.51% across 10 domain-specific benchmarks such as VQARAD and PlantVillage, while preserving the LLM's linguistic capabilities and outperforming peer methods that operate on continuous tokens.

AI.tldr: CRAFT fine-tunes the vision encoder of an LVLM using a discrete codebook to anchor visual features to a stable token space, enabling domain adaptation without changing the language model or projector, yielding sizable gains on specialized benchmarks.
AI.motivation: LVLM vision encoders often fail on domain-specific or fine-grained tasks (e.g., medical imaging, plant disease) and errors propagate into the LLM. Existing adaptation methods tweak the continuous interface (projectors/PEFT), tightly coupling encoder and LLM and forcing re-alignment whenever the encoder changes.
AI.method: Introduce CRAFT: a lightweight, decoupled fine-tuning scheme that regulates the encoder with a discrete codebook. The encoder learns to map images to discrete visual tokens anchored in a shared codebook, stabilizing the interface without modifying the LLM or other components. Because multiple LVLMs can share the same codebook, an adapted encoder becomes plug-and-play across different language backbones.
AI.result: Across 10 domain-specific benchmarks (e.g., VQARAD, PlantVillage), CRAFT delivers an average performance gain of 13.51%, preserves the language model’s general linguistic abilities, and outperforms methods that operate on continuous visual tokens.
AI.conclusion: Anchoring encoder outputs to a discrete, shared codebook decouples vision adaptation from the LLM, enabling transferable domain-specialized encoders that boost LVLM performance without re-aligning the cross-modal interface.

title: Make Some Noise: Unsupervised Remote Sensing Change Detection Using Latent Space Perturbations
summary: Unsupervised change detection (UCD) in remote sensing aims to localise semantic changes between two images of the same region without relying on labelled data during training. Most recent approaches rely either on frozen foundation models in a training-free manner or on training with synthetic changes generated in pixel space. Both strategies inherently rely on predefined assumptions about change types, typically introduced through handcrafted rules, external datasets, or auxiliary generative models. Due to these assumptions, such methods fail to generalise beyond a few change types, limiting their real-world usage, especially in rare or complex scenarios. To address this, we propose MaSoN (Make Some Noise), an end-to-end UCD framework that synthesises diverse changes directly in the latent feature space during training. It generates changes that are dynamically estimated using feature statistics of target data, enabling diverse yet data-driven variation aligned with the target domain. It also easily extends to new modalities, such as SAR. MaSoN generalises strongly across diverse change types and achieves state-of-the-art performance on five benchmarks, improving the average F1 score by 14.1 percentage points. Project page: https://blaz-r.github.io/mason_ucd

AI.tldr: MaSoN is an end-to-end unsupervised change detection framework that synthesizes diverse, data-driven changes in latent feature space using target-domain statistics, generalizing across change types and modalities (incl. SAR) and achieving state-of-the-art results (+14.1 F1 on average across five benchmarks).
AI.motivation: Existing UCD methods depend on predefined assumptions about change types—via frozen foundation models, pixel-space augmentations, handcrafted rules, or external datasets—which limits generalization to rare or complex real-world changes.
AI.method: Generate synthetic changes directly in the model’s latent feature space during training. The perturbations are parameterized by and adapted to the feature statistics of the target data, enabling diverse yet domain-aligned change synthesis; the approach is end-to-end and modality-agnostic (easily extends to SAR).
AI.result: Strong cross-type generalization and state-of-the-art performance on five UCD benchmarks, with an average F1 improvement of 14.1 percentage points over prior work.
AI.conclusion: Data-driven latent-space change synthesis reduces reliance on restrictive assumptions, improving robustness and generalization of UCD across diverse scenarios and modalities.

title: HD-TTA: Hypothesis-Driven Test-Time Adaptation for Safer Brain Tumor Segmentation
summary: Standard Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) methods typically treat inference as a blind optimization task, applying generic objectives to all or filtered test samples. In safety-critical medical segmentation, this lack of selectivity often causes the tumor mask to spill into healthy brain tissue or degrades predictions that were already correct. We propose Hypothesis-Driven TTA, a novel framework that reformulates adaptation as a dynamic decision process. Rather than forcing a single optimization trajectory, our method generates intuitive competing geometric hypotheses: compaction (is the prediction noisy? trim artifacts) versus inflation (is the valid tumor under-segmented? safely inflate to recover). It then employs a representation-guided selector to autonomously identify the safest outcome based on intrinsic texture consistency. Additionally, a pre-screening Gatekeeper prevents negative transfer by skipping adaptation on confident cases. We validate this proof-of-concept on a cross-domain binary brain tumor segmentation task, applying a source model trained on adult BraTS gliomas to unseen pediatric and more challenging meningioma target domains. HD-TTA improves safety-oriented outcomes (Hausdorff Distance (HD95) and Precision) over several state-of-the-art representative baselines in the challenging safety regime, reducing the HD95 by approximately 6.4 mm and improving Precision by over 4%, while maintaining comparable Dice scores. These results demonstrate that resolving the safety-adaptation trade-off via explicit hypothesis selection is a viable, robust path for safe clinical model deployment. Code will be made publicly available upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: They introduce Hypothesis-Driven Test-Time Adaptation (HD-TTA) for medical image segmentation, which generates and selects between two intuitive geometric adaptations—compaction vs. inflation—guided by texture consistency, and guarded by a pre-screening gatekeeper to avoid harmful updates. On cross-domain brain tumor segmentation, it improves safety metrics (HD95 −6.4 mm, Precision +4%) while keeping Dice comparable to baselines.
AI.motivation: Conventional TTA treats inference as blind optimization and can harm safety in medical segmentation—e.g., tumor masks spilling into healthy tissue or degrading already-correct predictions. The field needs selective, risk-aware adaptation that avoids negative transfer and prioritizes clinically safe outcomes.
AI.method: Reformulate TTA as a dynamic decision process with explicit, competing geometric hypotheses: (1) compaction to trim noisy/over-segmented artifacts, and (2) inflation to recover under-segmented valid tumor. A representation-guided selector chooses the safer hypothesis using intrinsic texture consistency. A pre-screening Gatekeeper skips adaptation on confident cases to prevent negative transfer. Evaluated by adapting a BraTS-trained adult glioma model to pediatric glioma and meningioma domains.
AI.result: Across challenging cross-domain settings, HD-TTA improves safety-oriented metrics over several state-of-the-art baselines: ~6.4 mm reduction in HD95 and >4% increase in Precision, while maintaining Dice scores comparable to alternatives.
AI.conclusion: Explicit hypothesis selection can navigate the safety–adaptation trade-off, yielding safer clinical segmentation without sacrificing overlap accuracy. HD-TTA is a robust path to deployable, risk-aware TTA; code to be released upon acceptance.

title: When Pretty Isn't Useful: Investigating Why Modern Text-to-Image Models Fail as Reliable Training Data Generators
summary: Recent text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models produce visually stunning images and demonstrate excellent prompt following. But do they perform well as synthetic vision data generators? In this work, we revisit the promise of synthetic data as a scalable substitute for real training sets and uncover a surprising performance regression. We generate large-scale synthetic datasets using state-of-the-art T2I models released between 2022 and 2025, train standard classifiers solely on this synthetic data, and evaluate them on real test data. Despite observable advances in visual fidelity and prompt adherence, classification accuracy on real test data consistently declines with newer T2I models as training data generators. Our analysis reveals a hidden trend: These models collapse to a narrow, aesthetic-centric distribution that undermines diversity and label-image alignment. Overall, our findings challenge a growing assumption in vision research, namely that progress in generative realism implies progress in data realism. We thus highlight an urgent need to rethink the capabilities of modern T2I models as reliable training data generators.

AI.tldr: Newer text-to-image diffusion models make prettier, better prompt-following pictures, but when used to generate training data for classifiers, they yield worse real-world accuracy than older models—likely due to a collapse toward a narrow, aesthetic-biased distribution that harms diversity and label alignment.
AI.motivation: Test the long-standing promise that scalable synthetic data can substitute for real datasets, and interrogate the prevalent assumption that gains in generative realism translate into better training data ("data realism") for vision models.
AI.method: Create large synthetic image datasets with state-of-the-art T2I models from 2022–2025, train standard image classifiers solely on this synthetic data, and evaluate on real test sets; analyze diversity, label-image alignment, and distributional characteristics of the generated data.
AI.result: Despite improved visual fidelity and prompt adherence, classifiers trained on newer models’ synthetic images achieve consistently lower accuracy on real test data. Analysis indicates a hidden trend: the generation distribution collapses toward aesthetically pleasing but less diverse outputs with poorer label-image alignment.
AI.conclusion: Progress in generative realism does not ensure progress in data realism or utility for training. Modern T2I models, as-is, are unreliable synthetic data generators; the community should rethink how to enforce diversity and label alignment if synthetic data is to substitute for real data.

title: Laplacian Multi-scale Flow Matching for Generative Modeling
summary: In this paper, we present Laplacian multiscale flow matching (LapFlow), a novel framework that enhances flow matching by leveraging multi-scale representations for image generative modeling. Our approach decomposes images into Laplacian pyramid residuals and processes different scales in parallel through a mixture-of-transformers (MoT) architecture with causal attention mechanisms. Unlike previous cascaded approaches that require explicit renoising between scales, our model generates multi-scale representations in parallel, eliminating the need for bridging processes. The proposed multi-scale architecture not only improves generation quality but also accelerates the sampling process and promotes scaling flow matching methods. Through extensive experimentation on CelebA-HQ and ImageNet, we demonstrate that our method achieves superior sample quality with fewer GFLOPs and faster inference compared to single-scale and multi-scale flow matching baselines. The proposed model scales effectively to high-resolution generation (up to 1024$\times$1024) while maintaining lower computational overhead.

AI.tldr: LapFlow is a parallel, multi‑scale flow-matching framework that decomposes images via a Laplacian pyramid and models all scales concurrently with a mixture‑of‑transformers, improving quality and speed while avoiding cross‑scale renoising; it scales to 1024×1024 with lower compute.
AI.motivation: Conventional flow matching for image generation struggles to scale efficiently to high resolutions; multi‑scale cascades often require explicit renoising/bridging between scales, adding latency and complexity. The authors seek a multi‑scale method that boosts sample quality, reduces compute and inference time, and cleanly scales to high resolution.
AI.method: Decompose images into Laplacian pyramid residuals and process all scales in parallel using a mixture‑of‑transformers with causal attention. This parallel multi‑scale design eliminates explicit inter‑scale renoising/bridging steps and accelerates sampling while preserving flow‑matching training objectives.
AI.result: On CelebA‑HQ and ImageNet, LapFlow achieves better sample quality than single‑ and multi‑scale flow‑matching baselines while using fewer GFLOPs and providing faster inference. It scales to 1024×1024 generation with lower computational overhead than prior approaches.
AI.conclusion: Parallel Laplacian multi‑scale flow matching with a MoT architecture delivers higher fidelity and faster sampling without bridging between scales, enabling more efficient, scalable high‑resolution image generation.

title: Physics-informed Active Polarimetric 3D Imaging for Specular Surfaces
summary: 3D imaging of specular surfaces remains challenging in real-world scenarios, such as in-line inspection or hand-held scanning, requiring fast and accurate measurement of complex geometries. Optical metrology techniques such as deflectometry achieve high accuracy but typically rely on multi-shot acquisition, making them unsuitable for dynamic environments. Fourier-based single-shot approaches alleviate this constraint, yet their performance deteriorates when measuring surfaces with high spatial frequency structure or large curvature. Alternatively, polarimetric 3D imaging in computer vision operates in a single-shot fashion and exhibits robustness to geometric complexity. However, its accuracy is fundamentally limited by the orthographic imaging assumption. In this paper, we propose a physics-informed deep learning framework for single-shot 3D imaging of complex specular surfaces. Polarization cues provide orientation priors that assist in interpreting geometric information encoded by structured illumination. These complementary cues are processed through a dual-encoder architecture with mutual feature modulation, allowing the network to resolve their nonlinear coupling and directly infer surface normals. The proposed method achieves accurate and robust normal estimation in single-shot with fast inference, enabling practical 3D imaging of complex specular surfaces.

AI.tldr: Single-shot, physics-informed deep learning fuses polarization cues with structured illumination to directly estimate surface normals of complex specular objects accurately and fast, overcoming multi-shot and orthographic limits of prior methods.
AI.motivation: Real-world inspection and hand-held scanning need fast, accurate 3D of shiny, highly curved surfaces. Classical deflectometry is accurate but multi-shot; single-shot Fourier methods fail on high-frequency/large-curvature shapes; polarimetric imaging is single-shot but limited by orthographic assumptions that cap accuracy.
AI.method: A physics-informed deep network that combines complementary signals: polarization provides orientation priors and structured illumination encodes geometry. A dual-encoder architecture with mutual feature modulation resolves their nonlinear coupling and directly predicts surface normals from a single exposure.
