AI.result: Demonstrates accurate, robust, and fast single-shot normal estimation on complex specular surfaces, outperforming limits of prior single-shot approaches and approaching deflectometry-like accuracy while retaining single-shot speed.
AI.conclusion: Fusing polarization and structured illumination within a physics-guided dual-encoder enables practical, single-shot 3D imaging of specular objects, delivering robust, accurate normals suitable for dynamic scenarios and complex geometries.

title: Forgetting-Resistant and Lesion-Aware Source-Free Domain Adaptive Fundus Image Analysis with Vision-Language Model
summary: Source-free domain adaptation (SFDA) aims to adapt a model trained in the source domain to perform well in the target domain, with only unlabeled target domain data and the source model. Taking into account that conventional SFDA methods are inevitably error-prone under domain shift, recently greater attention has been directed to SFDA assisted with off-the-shelf foundation models, e.g., vision-language (ViL) models. However, existing works of leveraging ViL models for SFDA confront two issues: (i) Although mutual information is exploited to consider the joint distribution between the predictions of ViL model and the target model, we argue that the forgetting of some superior predictions of the target model still occurs, as indicated by the decline of the accuracies of certain classes during adaptation; (ii) Prior research disregards the rich, fine-grained knowledge embedded in the ViL model, which offers detailed grounding for fundus image diagnosis. In this paper, we introduce a novel forgetting-resistant and lesion-aware (FRLA) method for SFDA of fundus image diagnosis with ViL model. Specifically, a forgetting-resistant adaptation module explicitly preserves the confident predictions of the target model, and a lesion-aware adaptation module yields patch-wise predictions from ViL model and employs them to help the target model be aware of the lesion areas and leverage the ViL model's fine-grained knowledge. Extensive experiments show that our method not only significantly outperforms the vision-language model, but also achieves consistent improvements over the state-of-the-art methods. Our code will be released.

AI.tldr: FRLA is a source-free domain adaptation method for fundus image diagnosis that prevents class-wise forgetting and injects lesion-level, patch-wise guidance from a vision–language model, yielding consistent gains over both ViL baselines and prior SFDA methods.
AI.motivation: Conventional SFDA under domain shift is error-prone, and recent ViL-assisted SFDA still (i) forgets some initially correct target predictions during adaptation and (ii) leaves untapped the ViL model’s fine-grained, lesion-level knowledge crucial for fundus diagnosis.
AI.method: FRLA introduces two modules: (1) a forgetting-resistant adaptation module that explicitly preserves confident predictions from the target model to avoid class-wise performance drops; (2) a lesion-aware adaptation module that extracts patch-wise (lesion-grounded) predictions from a ViL model to guide the target model toward lesion regions and transfer fine-grained knowledge.
AI.result: Across extensive experiments, FRLA significantly outperforms the ViL baseline and delivers consistent improvements over state-of-the-art SFDA approaches (quantitative details not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: By combining confidence-preserving adaptation with ViL-driven, patch-wise lesion awareness, FRLA mitigates forgetting and better exploits foundation-model knowledge, improving SFDA for fundus image diagnosis; code to be released.

title: Descriptor: Dataset of Parasitoid Wasps and Associated Hymenoptera (DAPWH)
summary: Accurate taxonomic identification is the cornerstone of biodiversity monitoring and agricultural management, particularly for the hyper-diverse superfamily Ichneumonoidea. Comprising the families Ichneumonidae and Braconidae, these parasitoid wasps are ecologically critical for regulating insect populations, yet they remain one of the most taxonomically challenging groups due to their cryptic morphology and vast number of undescribed species. To address the scarcity of robust digital resources for these key groups, we present a curated image dataset designed to advance automated identification systems. The dataset contains 3,556 high-resolution images, primarily focused on Neotropical Ichneumonidae and Braconidae, while also including supplementary families such as Andrenidae, Apidae, Bethylidae, Chrysididae, Colletidae, Halictidae, Megachilidae, Pompilidae, and Vespidae to improve model robustness. Crucially, a subset of 1,739 images is annotated in COCO format, featuring multi-class bounding boxes for the full insect body, wing venation, and scale bars. This resource provides a foundation for developing computer vision models capable of identifying these families.

AI.tldr: They release a curated, high‑resolution image dataset of parasitoid wasps (Ichneumonoidea) with 3,556 images—1,739 COCO‑annotated with multi‑class boxes for body, wing venation, and scale bars—plus related Hymenoptera families, to support robust automated identification.
AI.motivation: Accurate taxonomic identification underpins biodiversity monitoring and agriculture. Ichneumonidae and Braconidae are ecologically vital but difficult to identify due to cryptic morphology and many undescribed species, and there is a shortage of robust digital resources for machine learning.
AI.method: Curate a high‑resolution image dataset focused on Neotropical Ichneumonidae and Braconidae; include supplementary Hymenoptera families to enhance model robustness; annotate a substantial subset in COCO format with multi‑class bounding boxes for whole body, wing venation, and scale bars.
AI.result: Provide 3,556 total images, of which 1,739 are COCO‑annotated with multi‑class bounding boxes; coverage includes target Ichneumonoidea families and additional Hymenoptera families to aid generalization.
AI.conclusion: The dataset forms a foundational resource for developing computer‑vision models to detect and identify parasitoid wasps (at least to family level), advancing automated taxonomy for biodiversity monitoring and agricultural applications.

title: Exploiting Label-Independent Regularization from Spatial Dependencies for Whole Slide Image Analysis
summary: Whole slide images, with their gigapixel-scale panoramas of tissue samples, are pivotal for precise disease diagnosis. However, their analysis is hindered by immense data size and scarce annotations. Existing MIL methods face challenges due to the fundamental imbalance where a single bag-level label must guide the learning of numerous patch-level features. This sparse supervision makes it difficult to reliably identify discriminative patches during training, leading to unstable optimization and suboptimal solutions. We propose a spatially regularized MIL framework that leverages inherent spatial relationships among patch features as label-independent regularization signals. Our approach learns a shared representation space by jointly optimizing feature-induced spatial reconstruction and label-guided classification objectives, enforcing consistency between intrinsic structural patterns and supervisory signals. Experimental results on multiple public datasets demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods, offering a promising direction.

AI.tldr: Spatially regularized MIL for whole-slide images: learn a shared embedding by jointly reconstructing spatial structure of patch features and performing bag-level classification, yielding more stable training and better-than-SOTA accuracy.
AI.motivation: WSIs are gigapixel-scale with scarce annotations. MIL suffers from extreme label sparsity: one bag label supervises many patch features, making it hard to identify discriminative patches and causing unstable, suboptimal training.
AI.method: Introduce a spatially regularized MIL framework that treats spatial relations among patches as label-independent signals. Optimize a joint objective: (1) feature-induced spatial reconstruction (e.g., reconstruct/encode neighborhood structure across patches), and (2) label-guided bag classification, enforcing consistency between intrinsic spatial patterns and supervisory signals within a shared representation space.
AI.result: On multiple public WSI datasets, the approach shows significant improvements over state-of-the-art MIL baselines and yields more reliable patch selection/optimization (quantitative details not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Leveraging intrinsic spatial structure as a regularizer mitigates sparse supervision in MIL for WSIs, stabilizes training, and improves performance, offering a promising general direction for gigapixel pathology analysis.

title: MICON-Bench: Benchmarking and Enhancing Multi-Image Context Image Generation in Unified Multimodal Models
summary: Recent advancements in Unified Multimodal Models (UMMs) have enabled remarkable image understanding and generation capabilities. However, while models like Gemini-2.5-Flash-Image show emerging abilities to reason over multiple related images, existing benchmarks rarely address the challenges of multi-image context generation, focusing mainly on text-to-image or single-image editing tasks. In this work, we introduce \textbf{MICON-Bench}, a comprehensive benchmark covering six tasks that evaluate cross-image composition, contextual reasoning, and identity preservation. We further propose an MLLM-driven Evaluation-by-Checkpoint framework for automatic verification of semantic and visual consistency, where multimodal large language model (MLLM) serves as a verifier. Additionally, we present \textbf{Dynamic Attention Rebalancing (DAR)}, a training-free, plug-and-play mechanism that dynamically adjusts attention during inference to enhance coherence and reduce hallucinations. Extensive experiments on various state-of-the-art open-source models demonstrate both the rigor of MICON-Bench in exposing multi-image reasoning challenges and the efficacy of DAR in improving generation quality and cross-image coherence. Github: https://github.com/Angusliuuu/MICON-Bench.

AI.tldr: They introduce MICON-Bench to rigorously evaluate multi-image context generation in UMMs, propose an MLLM-based automatic verifier (Evaluation-by-Checkpoint), and a training-free Dynamic Attention Rebalancing (DAR) method that improves coherence and reduces hallucinations across models.
AI.motivation: UMMs are starting to reason over multiple related images, but existing benchmarks and evaluations focus on single-image or text-to-image tasks, leaving cross-image composition, contextual reasoning, and identity preservation under-assessed. There’s also a need for lightweight methods to boost multi-image coherence without retraining.
AI.method: 1) Build MICON-Bench with six tasks targeting cross-image composition, contextual reasoning, and identity preservation. 2) Create an MLLM-driven Evaluation-by-Checkpoint pipeline for automatic semantic and visual consistency verification. 3) Propose Dynamic Attention Rebalancing (DAR), a training-free, plug-and-play inference technique that adjusts attention weights to enhance multi-image coherence and reduce hallucination.
AI.result: Across state-of-the-art open-source models, MICON-Bench exposes significant weaknesses in multi-image reasoning. DAR consistently improves generation quality and cross-image coherence, with qualitative and (implied) quantitative gains verified by the MLLM-based evaluator.
AI.conclusion: MICON-Bench offers a needed, comprehensive benchmark for multi-image context generation; the MLLM-based evaluator enables scalable automatic assessment; and DAR provides a practical, model-agnostic improvement pathway. Together, they set a foundation for advancing and fairly evaluating multi-image reasoning in UMMs.

title: SEAL-pose: Enhancing 3D Human Pose Estimation via a Learned Loss for Structural Consistency
summary: 3D human pose estimation (HPE) is characterized by intricate local and global dependencies among joints. Conventional supervised losses are limited in capturing these correlations because they treat each joint independently. Previous studies have attempted to promote structural consistency through manually designed priors or rule-based constraints; however, these approaches typically require manual specification and are often non-differentiable, limiting their use as end-to-end training objectives. We propose SEAL-pose, a data-driven framework in which a learnable loss-net trains a pose-net by evaluating structural plausibility. Rather than relying on hand-crafted priors, our joint-graph-based design enables the loss-net to learn complex structural dependencies directly from data. Extensive experiments on three 3D HPE benchmarks with eight backbones show that SEAL-pose reduces per-joint errors and improves pose plausibility compared with the corresponding backbones across all settings. Beyond improving each backbone, SEAL-pose also outperforms models with explicit structural constraints, despite not enforcing any such constraints. Finally, we analyze the relationship between the loss-net and structural consistency, and evaluate SEAL-pose in cross-dataset and in-the-wild settings.

AI.tldr: SEAL-pose introduces a learnable, data-driven loss network that judges structural plausibility to train 3D human pose estimators, capturing joint dependencies better than independent per-joint losses or hand-crafted constraints, and improves accuracy and plausibility across benchmarks and backbones.
AI.motivation: Standard supervised losses in 3D HPE treat joints independently and miss complex local–global dependencies; prior structure-enforcing methods rely on manual, often non-differentiable rules that limit end-to-end learning. A differentiable, learnable way to encode structural consistency is needed.
AI.method: Train a pose network under the guidance of a learnable loss network (“loss-net”) that scores structural plausibility. The loss-net is built on a joint-graph design to learn inter-joint dependencies directly from data, providing a data-driven training objective instead of hand-crafted priors or fixed constraints.
AI.result: Across three 3D HPE benchmarks and eight backbone architectures, SEAL-pose consistently reduces per-joint errors and yields more plausible poses than the respective baselines. It also surpasses models that use explicit structural constraints while not enforcing any hard constraints itself. Additional studies examine the link between the learned loss and structural consistency, and demonstrate robustness in cross-dataset and in-the-wild scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Learning a differentiable loss for structural plausibility via a joint-graph-based loss-net is an effective, general strategy to improve 3D HPE. It enhances accuracy and plausibility across diverse backbones and settings without manual priors, suggesting a scalable path for structure-aware supervision.

title: A Text-Guided Vision Model for Enhanced Recognition of Small Instances
comment: Accepted for publication in Applied Computer Science (2026)
summary: As drone-based object detection technology continues to evolve, the demand is shifting from merely detecting objects to enabling users to accurately identify specific targets. For example, users can input particular targets as prompts to precisely detect desired objects. To address this need, an efficient text-guided object detection model has been developed to enhance the detection of small objects. Specifically, an improved version of the existing YOLO-World model is introduced. The proposed method replaces the C2f layer in the YOLOv8 backbone with a C3k2 layer, enabling more precise representation of local features, particularly for small objects or those with clearly defined boundaries. Additionally, the proposed architecture improves processing speed and efficiency through parallel processing optimization, while also contributing to a more lightweight model design. Comparative experiments on the VisDrone dataset show that the proposed model outperforms the original YOLO-World model, with precision increasing from 40.6% to 41.6%, recall from 30.8% to 31%, F1 score from 35% to 35.5%, and mAP@0.5 from 30.4% to 30.7%, confirming its enhanced accuracy. Furthermore, the model demonstrates superior lightweight performance, with the parameter count reduced from 4 million to 3.8 million and FLOPs decreasing from 15.7 billion to 15.2 billion. These results indicate that the proposed approach provides a practical and effective solution for precise object detection in drone-based applications.

AI.tldr: They introduce a lightweight, text-guided drone object detector by modifying YOLO-World: replacing C2f with C3k2 to better capture local details for small targets and optimizing parallelism. On VisDrone it yields modest accuracy (+0.3 mAP@0.5) and efficiency gains with fewer parameters and FLOPs.
AI.motivation: Move beyond generic detection to user-specified, text-prompted targets in UAV scenarios, where small objects dominate and onboard compute is limited. Improve small-object sensitivity while keeping the model lightweight and fast.
AI.method: Start from YOLO-World and swap the YOLOv8 backbone’s C2f blocks for C3k2 to enhance local/edge feature representation; add parallel processing optimizations for speed and a lighter design. Evaluate text-guided detection on VisDrone.
AI.result: Compared to YOLO-World: precision 40.6%→41.6%, recall 30.8%→31.0%, F1 35.0%→35.5%, mAP@0.5 30.4%→30.7%; parameters 4.0M→3.8M; FLOPs 15.7B→15.2B.
AI.conclusion: The approach yields small but consistent accuracy and compute reductions, indicating a practical improvement for UAV text-guided detection of small objects. However, gains are modest and further validation and analysis are warranted.

title: Test-Time Computing for Referring Multimodal Large Language Models
comment: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:2407.21534
summary: We propose ControlMLLM++, a novel test-time adaptation framework that injects learnable visual prompts into frozen multimodal large language models (MLLMs) to enable fine-grained region-based visual reasoning without any model retraining or fine-tuning. Leveraging the insight that cross-modal attention maps intrinsically encode semantic correspondences between textual tokens and visual regions, ControlMLLM++ optimizes a latent visual token modifier during inference via a task-specific energy function to steer model attention towards user-specified areas. To enhance optimization stability and mitigate language prompt biases, ControlMLLM++ incorporates an improved optimization strategy (Optim++) and a prompt debiasing mechanism (PromptDebias). Supporting diverse visual prompt types including bounding boxes, masks, scribbles, and points, our method demonstrates strong out-of-domain generalization and interpretability. The code is available at https://github.com/mrwu-mac/ControlMLLM.

AI.tldr: ControlMLLM++ is a test-time adaptation method that injects and optimizes learnable visual prompts in frozen multimodal LLMs to steer cross-modal attention toward user-specified regions (boxes/masks/scribbles/points), stabilized by an improved optimizer (Optim++) and debiased via PromptDebias, enabling fine-grained region-based reasoning without retraining and demonstrating strong OOD generalization and interpretability.
AI.motivation: Existing MLLMs often lack precise, controllable grounding to image regions and can be biased or imprecise when guided only by textual prompts. Retraining or finetuning for region-aware reasoning is costly and limits deployment. The goal is to gain fine-grained, user-controlled visual reasoning at inference time, robustly and without modifying model weights.
AI.method: Inject a latent, learnable visual token modifier into the visual input stream of a frozen MLLM and optimize it during inference via a task-specific energy function, leveraging cross-modal attention maps as semantic correspondences between text tokens and visual regions. Introduce Optim++ for more stable, effective prompt optimization and PromptDebias to counteract language prompt biases. Support varied visual prompt modalities: bounding boxes, masks, scribbles, and points.
AI.result: The approach steers attention to specified regions, yields fine-grained, interpretable region-based reasoning, generalizes out of domain, and works across diverse visual prompt types, all without any retraining or finetuning. The abstract reports qualitative strengths and interpretability; code is publicly available.
AI.conclusion: ControlMLLM++ offers practical, interpretable, and controllable test-time adaptation for frozen MLLMs, improving region-specific reasoning through optimized visual prompts while avoiding retraining; optimization stability and prompt bias are addressed by Optim++ and PromptDebias, enabling robust OOD performance.

title: HeatPrompt: Zero-Shot Vision-Language Modeling of Urban Heat Demand from Satellite Images
summary: Accurate heat-demand maps play a crucial role in decarbonizing space heating, yet most municipalities lack detailed building-level data needed to calculate them. We introduce HeatPrompt, a zero-shot vision-language energy modeling framework that estimates annual heat demand using semantic features extracted from satellite images, basic Geographic Information System (GIS), and building-level features. We feed pretrained Large Vision Language Models (VLMs) with a domain-specific prompt to act as an energy planner and extract the visual attributes such as roof age, building density, etc, from the RGB satellite image that correspond to the thermal load. A Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) regressor trained on these captions shows an $R^2$ uplift of 93.7% and shrinks the mean absolute error (MAE) by 30% compared to the baseline model. Qualitative analysis shows that high-impact tokens align with high-demand zones, offering lightweight support for heat planning in data-scarce regions.

AI.tldr: HeatPrompt uses zero-shot vision–language prompting on satellite imagery to extract heat-relevant building/urban attributes, then trains a lightweight MLP regressor (with basic GIS/building features) to predict annual heat demand, delivering large accuracy gains over a baseline and interpretable spatial cues—useful for data-scarce heat planning.
AI.motivation: Decarbonizing space heating needs accurate heat-demand maps, but most municipalities lack detailed building-level inputs. Leveraging ubiquitous satellite imagery and pretrained VLMs can infer proxy attributes (e.g., roof age, density) without costly surveys, enabling scalable mapping where data are limited.
AI.method: Prompt pretrained Large Vision-Language Models as an “energy planner” to caption RGB satellite images with heat-relevant semantics (roof age, building density, etc.). Use these captions as features, alongside basic GIS/building attributes, to train a Multi-Layer Perceptron regressor for annual heat demand. Evaluate against a baseline and perform qualitative token-importance analysis to check spatial alignment with high-demand zones.
AI.result: Relative to a baseline, the caption-powered MLP shows a 93.7% uplift in R² and a 30% reduction in MAE. Qualitative analyses indicate high-impact tokens coincide with areas of elevated heat demand.
AI.conclusion: Zero-shot VLM-derived semantics from satellite imagery significantly improve heat-demand estimation using lightweight inputs and offer interpretable signals for planners, making the approach promising for data-poor regions.

title: Relational Feature Caching for Accelerating Diffusion Transformers
summary: Feature caching approaches accelerate diffusion transformers (DiTs) by storing the output features of computationally expensive modules at certain timesteps, and exploiting them for subsequent steps to reduce redundant computations. Recent forecasting-based caching approaches employ temporal extrapolation techniques to approximate the output features with cached ones. Although effective, relying exclusively on temporal extrapolation still suffers from significant prediction errors, leading to performance degradation. Through a detailed analysis, we find that 1) these errors stem from the irregular magnitude of changes in the output features, and 2) an input feature of a module is strongly correlated with the corresponding output. Based on this, we propose relational feature caching (RFC), a novel framework that leverages the input-output relationship to enhance the accuracy of the feature prediction. Specifically, we introduce relational feature estimation (RFE) to estimate the magnitude of changes in the output features from the inputs, enabling more accurate feature predictions. We also present relational cache scheduling (RCS), which estimates the prediction errors using the input features and performs full computations only when the errors are expected to be substantial. Extensive experiments across various DiT models demonstrate that RFC consistently outperforms prior approaches significantly. Project page is available at https://cvlab.yonsei.ac.kr/projects/RFC

AI.tldr: RFC is a feature-caching framework for diffusion transformers that uses input–output relations to predict feature changes and schedule recomputations, yielding faster inference with less accuracy loss than temporal extrapolation–only baselines.
AI.motivation: Existing feature caching speeds up DiTs by reusing module outputs across timesteps, but pure temporal extrapolation often incurs large prediction errors because feature-change magnitudes are irregular. The authors observe a strong correlation between a module’s input and its output, suggesting inputs can inform how much the output will change and when caching will fail.
AI.method: Relational Feature Caching (RFC) has two parts: (1) Relational Feature Estimation (RFE) predicts the magnitude of output-feature change directly from the current inputs, enabling more accurate cached-feature updates than time-only extrapolation; (2) Relational Cache Scheduling (RCS) predicts the prospective error from inputs and triggers full computation only when the predicted error is large, otherwise reusing or adjusting cached outputs.
AI.result: Across multiple DiT architectures, RFC consistently outperforms prior forecasting-based caching methods, providing larger speedups at comparable or better image quality (exact numbers not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: Leveraging input–output relationships allows more reliable feature prediction and adaptive recomputation, reducing redundant compute while maintaining generation quality; RFC offers a practical, general acceleration strategy for DiTs beyond temporal extrapolation.

title: StructXLIP: Enhancing Vision-language Models with Multimodal Structural Cues
summary: Edge-based representations are fundamental cues for visual understanding, a principle rooted in early vision research and still central today. We extend this principle to vision-language alignment, showing that isolating and aligning structural cues across modalities can greatly benefit fine-tuning on long, detail-rich captions, with a specific focus on improving cross-modal retrieval. We introduce StructXLIP, a fine-tuning alignment paradigm that extracts edge maps (e.g., Canny), treating them as proxies for the visual structure of an image, and filters the corresponding captions to emphasize structural cues, making them "structure-centric". Fine-tuning augments the standard alignment loss with three structure-centric losses: (i) aligning edge maps with structural text, (ii) matching local edge regions to textual chunks, and (iii) connecting edge maps to color images to prevent representation drift. From a theoretical standpoint, while standard CLIP maximizes the mutual information between visual and textual embeddings, StructXLIP additionally maximizes the mutual information between multimodal structural representations. This auxiliary optimization is intrinsically harder, guiding the model toward more robust and semantically stable minima, enhancing vision-language alignment. Beyond outperforming current competitors on cross-modal retrieval in both general and specialized domains, our method serves as a general boosting recipe that can be integrated into future approaches in a plug-and-play manner. Code and pretrained models are publicly available at: https://github.com/intelligolabs/StructXLIP.

AI.tldr: StructXLIP fine-tunes CLIP-style models by explicitly aligning edge-based structural cues with structure-centric text, adding global, local, and edge↔RGB consistency losses to boost cross-modal retrieval.
AI.motivation: Edges capture the underlying structure of images, a stable cue often underused in vision–language models. Long, detail-rich captions can misalign with visuals if models focus on non-structural semantics. Making structure a shared anchor across modalities should yield more robust, semantically stable alignment and better retrieval.
AI.method: 1) Extract edge maps (e.g., Canny) as proxies for image structure. 2) Filter/reshape captions to emphasize structural content (structure-centric text). 3) Fine-tune with augmented losses: (i) global edge–structural text alignment, (ii) local edge-region to textual-chunk matching, and (iii) edge–RGB consistency to avoid representation drift. Theoretically, beyond standard CLIP MI maximization for image–text embeddings, also maximizes MI between multimodal structural representations.
AI.result: Outperforms current baselines on cross-modal retrieval across general and specialized domains. Acts as a plug-and-play “booster” for other approaches; code and pretrained models released.
AI.conclusion: Elevating structural cues as a first-class alignment signal strengthens vision–language alignment, guiding optimization toward more robust, semantically stable minima and improving retrieval. The approach is general and easily integrated into future systems.

title: OSInsert: Towards High-authenticity and High-fidelity Image Composition
summary: Generative image composition aims to regenerate the given foreground object in the background image to produce a realistic composite image. Some high-authenticity methods can adjust foreground pose/view to be compatible with background, while some high-fidelity methods can preserve the foreground details accurately. However, existing methods can hardly achieve both goals at the same time. In this work, we propose a two-stage strategy to achieve both goals. In the first stage, we use high-authenticity method to generate reasonable foreground shape, serving as the condition of high-fidelity method in the second stage. The experiments on MureCOM dataset verify the effectiveness of our two-stage strategy. The code and model have been released at https://github.com/bcmi/OSInsert-Image-Composition.

AI.tldr: A two-stage image composition pipeline first re-poses/re-shapes the foreground for background compatibility (authenticity), then synthesizes a high-detail composite conditioned on that result (fidelity), yielding more realistic and faithful composites on MureCOM; code released.
AI.motivation: Single-stage methods face a trade-off: those that maximize realism often distort or lose foreground details, while detail-preserving methods can look implausible in the target background. The work aims to reconcile authenticity and fidelity simultaneously.
AI.method: Stage 1: apply a high-authenticity generator to adapt the foreground’s pose/view/shape to the background, producing a geometry-consistent conditional. Stage 2: feed this as guidance to a high-fidelity generator that reconstructs fine details while respecting Stage-1 geometry, producing the final composite. The approach is modular, allowing different authenticity/fidelity models.
AI.result: On the MureCOM dataset, the two-stage strategy is empirically validated to outperform prior methods on both realism and detail preservation (no specific metrics given in the abstract). Implementation and pretrained models are publicly available.
AI.conclusion: Decomposing composition into authenticity-first then fidelity yields better trade-offs than prior single-stage approaches. The method is practical, modular, and reproducible; results indicate improved composites that are both realistic in context and faithful to the source foreground.

title: Transcending the Annotation Bottleneck: AI-Powered Discovery in Biology and Medicine
summary: The dependence on expert annotation has long constituted the primary rate-limiting step in the application of artificial intelligence to biomedicine. While supervised learning drove the initial wave of clinical algorithms, a paradigm shift towards unsupervised and self-supervised learning (SSL) is currently unlocking the latent potential of biobank-scale datasets. By learning directly from the intrinsic structure of data - whether pixels in a magnetic resonance image (MRI), voxels in a volumetric scan, or tokens in a genomic sequence - these methods facilitate the discovery of novel phenotypes, the linkage of morphology to genetics, and the detection of anomalies without human bias. This article synthesises seminal and recent advances in "learning without labels," highlighting how unsupervised frameworks can derive heritable cardiac traits, predict spatial gene expression in histology, and detect pathologies with performance that rivals or exceeds supervised counterparts.

AI.tldr: A concise review arguing that unsupervised and self‑supervised learning can unlock biobank‑scale biomedical data by learning from intrinsic data structure, enabling phenotype discovery, genotype–morphology linkage, and anomaly detection—often matching or surpassing supervised methods—illustrated with cardiac, histology, and pathology examples.
AI.motivation: Expert labeling is the main bottleneck for clinical AI. Supervised learning is constrained by scarce, costly, and potentially biased annotations. The paper motivates methods that scale to large multimodal datasets (imaging, volumetric scans, genomics) while reducing human bias and unlocking latent biological signal.
AI.method: Narrative synthesis of seminal and recent “learning without labels” approaches (unsupervised and self‑supervised) across biomedical modalities. It highlights representation learning directly from pixels/voxels/tokens and surveys applications to phenotype discovery, morphology‑genetics linkage, and anomaly detection, comparing to supervised baselines where available.
AI.result: Evidence compiled that such methods can: (i) derive heritable cardiac traits from imaging; (ii) predict spatial gene expression from histology; and (iii) detect pathologies, achieving performance on par with or better than supervised models, while requiring far fewer expert annotations and revealing novel phenotypes.
AI.conclusion: Un/SSL is emerging as a practical paradigm for clinical and biological discovery, leveraging biobank‑scale datasets to reduce reliance on labels and human bias. These approaches can reshape phenotyping and diagnostic pipelines and strengthen genotype‑phenotype mapping, warranting broader adoption and integration into biomedical research and clinical workflows.

title: ORION: ORthonormal Text Encoding for Universal VLM AdaptatION
summary: Vision language models (VLMs) have demonstrated remarkable generalization across diverse tasks, yet their performance remains constrained by the quality and geometry of the textual prototypes used to represent classes. Standard zero shot classifiers, derived from frozen text encoders and handcrafted prompts, may yield correlated or weakly separated embeddings that limit task specific discriminability. We introduce ORION, a text encoder fine tuning framework that improves pretrained VLMs using only class names. Our method optimizes, via low rank adaptation, a novel loss integrating two terms, one promoting pairwise orthogonality between the textual representations of the classes of a given task and the other penalizing deviations from the initial class prototypes. Furthermore, we provide a probabilistic interpretation of our orthogonality penalty, connecting it to the general maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) principle via Huygens theorem. We report extensive experiments on 11 benchmarks and three large VLM backbones, showing that the refined textual embeddings yield powerful replacements for the standard CLIP prototypes. Added as plug and play module on top of various state of the art methods, and across different prediction settings (zero shot, few shot and test time adaptation), ORION improves the performance consistently and significantly.

AI.tldr: ORION fine-tunes the text encoder of pretrained VLMs (via low‑rank adaptation) using only class names, enforcing pairwise orthogonality among class embeddings while keeping them close to the original CLIP prototypes; the resulting textual prototypes plug into zero-/few-shot and TTA pipelines and consistently improve accuracy across many datasets and backbones.
AI.motivation: Zero-shot VLMs typically rely on frozen text encoders with handcrafted prompts whose class embeddings can be correlated and poorly separated, hurting discriminability. The goal is to reshape the geometry of textual prototypes—without using images or labels—to better separate classes for downstream tasks.
AI.method: Apply LoRA to the VLM text encoder and optimize a loss with two parts: (1) an orthogonality term that encourages pairwise orthogonality of class embeddings for a target task, and (2) a prototype-preserving term that penalizes deviation from the initial (frozen) class prototypes. The orthogonality penalty is given a probabilistic interpretation connected to MLE using Huygens’ theorem. The refined text embeddings then replace standard CLIP prototypes as a plug-and-play module within various methods and settings.
AI.result: Across 11 benchmarks and three large VLM backbones, the refined textual embeddings outperform standard CLIP prototypes, yielding consistent and significant gains in zero-shot, few-shot, and test-time adaptation settings, and improving SOTA methods when used as a drop-in replacement.
AI.conclusion: Optimizing the geometry of textual prototypes—making them more orthogonal while preserving proximity to the originals—provides a simple, data-free, plug-and-play enhancement for VLMs that reliably boosts performance across tasks and backbones.

title: Benchmarking Unlearning for Vision Transformers
summary: Research in machine unlearning (MU) has gained strong momentum: MU is now widely regarded as a critical capability for building safe and fair AI. In parallel, research into transformer architectures for computer vision tasks has been highly successful: Increasingly, Vision Transformers (VTs) emerge as strong alternatives to CNNs. Yet, MU research for vision tasks has largely centered on CNNs, not VTs. While benchmarking MU efforts have addressed LLMs, diffusion models, and CNNs, none exist for VTs. This work is the first to attempt this, benchmarking MU algorithm performance in different VT families (ViT and Swin-T) and at different capacities. The work employs (i) different datasets, selected to assess the impacts of dataset scale and complexity; (ii) different MU algorithms, selected to represent fundamentally different approaches for MU; and (iii) both single-shot and continual unlearning protocols. Additionally, it focuses on benchmarking MU algorithms that leverage training data memorization, since leveraging memorization has been recently discovered to significantly improve the performance of previously SOTA algorithms. En route, the work characterizes how VTs memorize training data relative to CNNs, and assesses the impact of different memorization proxies on performance. The benchmark uses unified evaluation metrics that capture two complementary notions of forget quality along with accuracy on unseen (test) data and on retained data. Overall, this work offers a benchmarking basis, enabling reproducible, fair, and comprehensive comparisons of existing (and future) MU algorithms on VTs. And, for the first time, it sheds light on how well existing algorithms work in VT settings, establishing a promising reference performance baseline.

AI.tldr: First comprehensive benchmark of machine unlearning (MU) on Vision Transformers (ViT, Swin-T) across model sizes, datasets, algorithms, and protocols, with unified metrics. It analyzes VT memorization vs. CNNs, evaluates memorization-based MU techniques, and establishes reference baselines and insights for VT-specific unlearning.
AI.motivation: MU is essential for safe/fair AI, but existing MU benchmarks focus on CNNs, LLMs, and diffusion models—not Vision Transformers, which now dominate many vision tasks. A gap exists in understanding how VTs memorize and how MU methods perform on them, necessitating a reproducible, fair benchmark.
AI.method: Benchmark across VT families (ViT, Swin-T) and capacities; multiple datasets varying in scale/complexity; a diverse set of MU algorithms emphasizing those that leverage memorization; both single-shot and continual unlearning protocols. Unified evaluation captures two complementary forget-quality notions plus accuracy on test and retained data. The study also compares memorization behavior of VTs to CNNs and tests different memorization proxies.
AI.result: Provides the first systematic performance comparison of MU methods on VTs and establishes a reference baseline. Characterizes how VTs memorize relative to CNNs and shows how choice of memorization proxy affects MU performance. Demonstrates that leveraging memorization can notably boost previously SOTA MU methods in VT settings.
AI.conclusion: Delivers a reproducible, fair, and comprehensive MU benchmark for VTs, clarifying how well current MU algorithms work on ViT/Swin-T and offering baseline results to guide future algorithm design—especially around exploiting memorization and selecting effective proxies.

title: Can a Teenager Fool an AI? Evaluating Low-Cost Cosmetic Attacks on Age Estimation Systems
summary: Age estimation systems are increasingly deployed as gatekeepers for age-restricted online content, yet their robustness to cosmetic modifications has not been systematically evaluated. We investigate whether simple, household-accessible cosmetic changes, including beards, grey hair, makeup, and simulated wrinkles, can cause AI age estimators to classify minors as adults. To study this threat at scale without ethical concerns, we simulate these physical attacks on 329 facial images of individuals aged 10 to 21 using a VLM image editor (Gemini 2.5 Flash Image). We then evaluate eight models from our prior benchmark: five specialized architectures (MiVOLO, Custom-Best, Herosan, MiViaLab, DEX) and three vision-language models (Gemini 3 Flash, Gemini 2.5 Flash, GPT-5-Nano). We introduce the Attack Conversion Rate (ACR), defined as the fraction of images predicted as minor at baseline that flip to adult after attack, a population-agnostic metric that does not depend on the ratio of minors to adults in the test set. Our results reveal that a synthetic beard alone achieves 28 to 69 percent ACR across all eight models; combining all four attacks shifts predicted age by +7.7 years on average across all 329 subjects and reaches up to 83 percent ACR; and vision-language models exhibit lower ACR (59 to 71 percent) than specialized models (63 to 83 percent) under the full attack, although the ACR ranges overlap and the difference is not statistically tested. These findings highlight a critical vulnerability in deployed age-verification pipelines and call for adversarial robustness evaluation as a mandatory criterion for model selection.

AI.tldr: Simple, household-accessible cosmetic edits (beards, grey hair, makeup, simulated wrinkles) can make AI age estimators flip many minors to “adult,” with combined edits shifting predicted age by ~7.7 years and achieving up to 83% attack conversion.
AI.motivation: Age estimators are increasingly used to gate age-restricted content, but their robustness to everyday cosmetic changes is unclear. If vulnerable, minors could bypass safety checks; thus, a systematic, scalable, and ethically sound robustness evaluation is needed.
AI.method: Simulate physical cosmetic attacks on 329 facial images (ages 10–21) using a VLM image editor (Gemini 2.5 Flash Image) to add beards, grey hair, makeup, and wrinkles. Evaluate eight age-estimation models—five specialized (MiVOLO, Custom-Best, Herosan, MiViaLab, DEX) and three VLMs (Gemini 3 Flash, Gemini 2.5 Flash, GPT-5-Nano). Introduce Attack Conversion Rate (ACR): the fraction of faces predicted as minors at baseline that flip to adults after attack. Measure ACR and mean age shift for single and combined edits.
AI.result: A synthetic beard alone yields 28–69% ACR across all models. Combining all four edits shifts predicted age by +7.7 years on average across 329 subjects and reaches up to 83% ACR. Under the full attack, VLMs show somewhat lower ACR (59–71%) than specialized models (63–83%), though ranges overlap and no statistical tests are reported.
AI.conclusion: Deployed age-verification pipelines are critically vulnerable to simple cosmetic manipulations. Robustness to such adversarial edits should be a mandatory selection and deployment criterion. VLMs may be marginally more robust than specialized models, but evidence is preliminary and requires statistical confirmation.

title: Vinedresser3D: Agentic Text-guided 3D Editing
summary: Text-guided 3D editing aims to modify existing 3D assets using natural-language instructions. Current methods struggle to jointly understand complex prompts, automatically localize edits in 3D, and preserve unedited content. We introduce Vinedresser3D, an agentic framework for high-quality text-guided 3D editing that operates directly in the latent space of a native 3D generative model. Given a 3D asset and an editing prompt, Vinedresser3D uses a multimodal large language model to infer rich descriptions of the original asset, identify the edit region and edit type (addition, modification, deletion), and generate decomposed structural and appearance-level text guidance. The agent then selects an informative view and applies an image editing model to obtain visual guidance. Finally, an inversion-based rectified-flow inpainting pipeline with an interleaved sampling module performs editing in the 3D latent space, enforcing prompt alignment while maintaining 3D coherence and unedited regions. Experiments on diverse 3D edits demonstrate that Vinedresser3D outperforms prior baselines in both automatic metrics and human preference studies, while enabling precise, coherent, and mask-free 3D editing.

AI.tldr: Vinedresser3D is an agent-based, mask-free system for text-guided 3D editing that decomposes instructions, localizes edits, and edits directly in a native 3D model’s latent space via inversion-based rectified-flow inpainting, yielding precise, coherent edits that preserve unedited content and outperform prior methods.
AI.motivation: Existing text-guided 3D editing methods struggle to jointly parse complex natural-language prompts, automatically localize edits in 3D, and preserve untouched regions with 3D coherence. A unified approach is needed to couple strong language understanding with accurate, localized, and consistency-preserving 3D editing.
AI.method: An agentic pipeline: (1) A multimodal LLM analyzes the input 3D asset and prompt to infer a rich asset description, identify the edit region and edit type (addition/modification/deletion), and produce decomposed structural and appearance guidance; (2) the agent picks an informative view and uses an image-editing model to obtain visual guidance; (3) editing is executed in the latent space of a native 3D generative model using an inversion-based rectified-flow inpainting pipeline with interleaved sampling, enforcing prompt alignment while preserving 3D coherence and unedited areas.
AI.result: Across diverse 3D edits, Vinedresser3D outperforms baselines on automatic metrics and human preference studies, delivering precise, coherent, and mask-free 3D edits.
AI.conclusion: Combining agentic prompt/asset understanding with latent 3D inpainting enables high-quality, localized, and 3D-coherent text-guided editing without manual masks; Vinedresser3D provides a strong, general framework for practical 3D asset editing.

title: A Very Big Video Reasoning Suite
summary: Rapid progress in video models has largely focused on visual quality, leaving their reasoning capabilities underexplored. Video reasoning grounds intelligence in spatiotemporally consistent visual environments that go beyond what text can naturally capture, enabling intuitive reasoning over spatiotemporal structure such as continuity, interaction, and causality. However, systematically studying video reasoning and its scaling behavior is hindered by the lack of large-scale training data. To address this gap, we introduce the Very Big Video Reasoning (VBVR) Dataset, an unprecedentedly large-scale resource spanning 200 curated reasoning tasks following a principled taxonomy and over one million video clips, approximately three orders of magnitude larger than existing datasets. We further present VBVR-Bench, a verifiable evaluation framework that moves beyond model-based judging by incorporating rule-based, human-aligned scorers, enabling reproducible and interpretable diagnosis of video reasoning capabilities. Leveraging the VBVR suite, we conduct one of the first large-scale scaling studies of video reasoning and observe early signs of emergent generalization to unseen reasoning tasks. Together, VBVR lays a foundation for the next stage of research in generalizable video reasoning. The data, benchmark toolkit, and models are publicly available at https://video-reason.com/ .

AI.tldr: They introduce VBVR: a 1M+ clip, 200-task, taxonomized dataset and a verifiable benchmark (VBVR-Bench) with rule-based human-aligned scorers to rigorously study and scale video reasoning; initial scaling experiments show early emergent generalization to unseen tasks; all resources are public.
AI.motivation: Video models have advanced in visual fidelity but lag in reasoning. Systematic research and scaling of video reasoning are blocked by the absence of sufficiently large, principled training/evaluation data.
AI.method: Construct an unprecedentedly large video reasoning dataset organized by a principled taxonomy of 200 reasoning tasks (>1M clips). Develop VBVR-Bench, a verifiable evaluation framework using rule-based, human-aligned scorers rather than model-based judges. Use the suite to run a large-scale scaling study of video reasoning.
AI.result: VBVR is ~three orders of magnitude larger than prior reasoning datasets; VBVR-Bench enables reproducible, interpretable evaluation; scaling experiments reveal early signs of generalization to unseen reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: VBVR (data + benchmark + models) establishes a foundation for research into generalizable video reasoning, offering scalable training data and verifiable evaluation; resources are publicly released at https://video-reason.com/.

title: VALD: Multi-Stage Vision Attack Detection for Efficient LVLM Defense
summary: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) can be vulnerable to adversarial images that subtly bias their outputs toward plausible yet incorrect responses. We introduce a general, efficient, and training-free defense that combines image transformations with agentic data consolidation to recover correct model behavior. A key component of our approach is a two-stage detection mechanism that quickly filters out the majority of clean inputs. We first assess image consistency under content-preserving transformations at negligible computational cost. For more challenging cases, we examine discrepancies in a text-embedding space. Only when necessary do we invoke a powerful LLM to resolve attack-induced divergences. A key idea is to consolidate multiple responses, leveraging both their similarities and their differences. We show that our method achieves state-of-the-art accuracy while maintaining notable efficiency: most clean images skip costly processing, and even in the presence of numerous adversarial examples, the overhead remains minimal.

AI.tldr: Training-free, efficient defense for LVLMs that detects adversarial images via cheap consistency checks under content-preserving transforms, escalates uncertain cases using a text-embedding discrepancy test, and resolves remaining conflicts with an LLM that consolidates multiple responses—achieving state-of-the-art robustness with minimal overhead and fast pass-through for clean inputs.
AI.motivation: LVLMs can be subtly steered by adversarial images to produce plausible but incorrect answers. There is a need for a general, retraining-free, and computationally efficient defense that restores correct behavior without slowing down benign workloads.
AI.method: A selective, three-tier pipeline: (1) generate transformed image variants and test response consistency to cheaply filter the majority of clean inputs; (2) for ambiguous cases, measure discrepancies in a text-embedding space; (3) only when necessary, invoke a strong LLM to reconcile attack-induced divergences through agentic consolidation that leverages agreements and disagreements across multiple responses.
AI.result: Reported state-of-the-art accuracy against adversarial attacks with notable efficiency: most clean inputs bypass costly steps, and even with many adversarial examples, added compute remains small. (No specific metrics provided in the abstract.)
AI.conclusion: A general, training-free, and efficient defense that selectively escalates analysis and consolidates multi-view responses can robustly mitigate adversarial image attacks on LVLMs while keeping computational overhead low.

title: HOCA-Bench: Beyond Semantic Perception to Predictive World Modeling via Hegelian Ontological-Causal Anomalies
summary: Video-LLMs have improved steadily on semantic perception, but they still fall short on predictive world modeling, which is central to physically grounded intelligence. We introduce HOCA-Bench, a benchmark that frames physical anomalies through a Hegelian lens. HOCA-Bench separates anomalies into two types: ontological anomalies, where an entity violates its own definition or persistence, and causal anomalies, where interactions violate physical relations. Using state-of-the-art generative video models as adversarial simulators, we build a testbed of 1,439 videos (3,470 QA pairs). Evaluations on 17 Video-LLMs show a clear cognitive lag: models often identify static ontological violations (e.g., shape mutations) but struggle with causal mechanisms (e.g., gravity or friction), with performance dropping by more than 20% on causal tasks. System-2 "Thinking" modes improve reasoning, but they do not close the gap, suggesting that current architectures recognize visual patterns more readily than they apply basic physical laws.

AI.tldr: HOCA-Bench is a new video benchmark that distinguishes ontological vs. causal physical anomalies and shows that current Video-LLMs can spot static entity violations but struggle with causal, physics-based reasoning, even with chain-of-thought modes.
AI.motivation: Despite advances in semantic perception, Video-LLMs lack robust predictive world modeling and physical reasoning. The field needs a principled way to probe whether models understand object persistence/identity versus causal physical laws (e.g., gravity, friction).
AI.method: Define two anomaly classes—ontological (violations of identity/persistence) and causal (violations of physical relations). Construct a 1,439-video testbed (3,470 QA pairs) using state-of-the-art generative video models as adversarial simulators. Evaluate 17 Video-LLMs, including with System-2/"Thinking" reasoning modes.
AI.result: Models perform relatively well on ontological anomalies but drop by >20% on causal tasks. "Thinking" modes improve scores but leave a persistent gap between ontological and causal understanding.
AI.conclusion: Current Video-LLMs mainly recognize visual patterns rather than applying basic physical laws. HOCA-Bench exposes this limitation and motivates architectures and training regimes that integrate causal, physics-grounded modeling.

title: ConceptPrism: Concept Disentanglement in Personalized Diffusion Models via Residual Token Optimization
summary: Personalized text-to-image generation suffers from concept entanglement, where irrelevant residual information from reference images is captured, leading to a trade-off between concept fidelity and text alignment. Recent disentanglement approaches attempt to solve this utilizing manual guidance, such as linguistic cues or segmentation masks, which limits their applicability and fails to fully articulate the target concept. In this paper, we propose ConceptPrism, a novel framework that automatically disentangles the shared visual concept from image-specific residuals by comparing images within a set. Our method jointly optimizes a target token and image-wise residual tokens using two complementary objectives: a reconstruction loss to ensure fidelity, and a novel exclusion loss that compels residual tokens to discard the shared concept. This process allows the target token to capture the pure concept without direct supervision. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ConceptPrism effectively resolves concept entanglement, achieving a significantly improved trade-off between fidelity and alignment.

AI.tldr: ConceptPrism disentangles a person/object’s shared visual concept from image‑specific residuals for personalized text‑to‑image generation by jointly learning a concept token and per‑image residual tokens with reconstruction and a novel exclusion loss, yielding better fidelity–text alignment without manual annotations.
AI.motivation: Personalized T2I models often entangle identity/style with background, pose, lighting, etc., forcing a trade‑off between staying faithful to the reference and following the prompt. Prior fixes rely on manual cues (text hints, masks), which are labor‑intensive, brittle, and still fail to isolate the true concept.
AI.method: Given a set of reference images, the framework compares them to separate shared versus image‑specific factors. It optimizes: (1) a target token representing the shared concept; (2) per‑image residual tokens capturing remaining idiosyncrasies. Two losses drive learning: a reconstruction loss to preserve fidelity and a new exclusion loss that forces residual tokens to avoid encoding what is common across images, so the target token captures the core concept without direct supervision.
AI.result: On extensive experiments (details not in abstract), ConceptPrism reduces concept entanglement and achieves a substantially better balance between concept fidelity and prompt alignment than prior methods, and does so without manual guidance such as masks or handcrafted text cues.
AI.conclusion: Automatically separating shared concept and residuals via exclusion‑guided token learning effectively addresses entanglement in personalized T2I, improving controllability and quality while reducing annotation burden; it provides a cleaner concept representation for downstream generation.

title: Learning Mutual View Information Graph for Adaptive Adversarial Collaborative Perception
summary: Collaborative perception (CP) enables data sharing among connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) to enhance driving safety. However, CP systems are vulnerable to adversarial attacks where malicious agents forge false objects via feature-level perturbations. Current defensive systems use threshold-based consensus verification by comparing collaborative and ego detection results. Yet, these defenses remain vulnerable to more sophisticated attack strategies that could exploit two critical weaknesses: (i) lack of robustness against attacks with systematic timing and target region optimization, and (ii) inadvertent disclosure of vulnerability knowledge through implicit confidence information in shared collaboration data. In this paper, we propose MVIG attack, a novel adaptive adversarial CP framework learning to capture vulnerability knowledge disclosed by different defensive CP systems from a unified mutual view information graph (MVIG) representation. Our approach combines MVIG representation with temporal graph learning to generate evolving fabrication risk maps and employs entropy-aware vulnerability search to optimize attack location, timing and persistence, enabling adaptive attacks with generalizability across various defensive configurations. Extensive evaluations on OPV2V and Adv-OPV2V datasets demonstrate that MVIG attack reduces defense success rates by up to 62\% against state-of-the-art defenses while achieving 47\% lower detection for persistent attacks at 29.9 FPS, exposing critical security gaps in CP systems. Code will be released at https://github.com/yihangtao/MVIG.git

AI.tldr: MVIG is an adaptive adversarial framework that exploits information leaked by collaborative perception (CP) defenses via a mutual-view information graph and temporal graph learning, enabling stealthy, persistent fabrication attacks that markedly degrade state-of-the-art defenses in real time.
AI.motivation: CP improves safety by sharing perception among CAVs, but prevailing threshold/consensus defenses are fragile: attackers can time and localize perturbations and exploit implicit confidence cues in shared data, exposing systemic vulnerabilities.
AI.method: Unify defense-exposed cues into a Mutual View Information Graph (MVIG); apply temporal graph learning to produce evolving fabrication risk maps; use entropy-aware vulnerability search to optimize attack location, timing, and persistence, yielding adaptive, transferable attacks across diverse defensive configurations.
AI.result: On OPV2V and Adv-OPV2V, MVIG cuts defense success rates by up to 62% and achieves 47% lower detection for persistent attacks at 29.9 FPS, demonstrating effective, real-time attack generalization against multiple defenses.
AI.conclusion: Current CP defenses unintentionally leak exploitable information and lack robustness to temporally and spatially optimized attacks. MVIG highlights critical security gaps and motivates defenses that reduce information leakage and withstand adaptive, temporally aware adversaries; code to be released.

title: RAID: Retrieval-Augmented Anomaly Detection
summary: Unsupervised Anomaly Detection (UAD) aims to identify abnormal regions by establishing correspondences between test images and normal templates. Existing methods primarily rely on image reconstruction or template retrieval but face a fundamental challenge: matching between test images and normal templates inevitably introduces noise due to intra-class variations, imperfect correspondences, and limited templates. Observing that Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) leverages retrieved samples directly in the generation process, we reinterpret UAD through this lens and introduce \textbf{RAID}, a retrieval-augmented UAD framework designed for noise-resilient anomaly detection and localization. Unlike standard RAG that enriches context or knowledge, we focus on using retrieved normal samples to guide noise suppression in anomaly map generation. RAID retrieves class-, semantic-, and instance-level representations from a hierarchical vector database, forming a coarse-to-fine pipeline. A matching cost volume correlates the input with retrieved exemplars, followed by a guided Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) network that leverages the retrieved samples to adaptively suppress matching noise and produce fine-grained anomaly maps. RAID achieves state-of-the-art performance across full-shot, few-shot, and multi-dataset settings on MVTec, VisA, MPDD, and BTAD benchmarks. \href{https://github.com/Mingxiu-Cai/RAID}{https://github.com/Mingxiu-Cai/RAID}.

AI.tldr: RAID reframes unsupervised anomaly detection as retrieval‑augmented generation: it hierarchically retrieves normal exemplars, builds a matching cost volume, and uses a guided Mixture‑of‑Experts to suppress matching noise, yielding fine‑grained anomaly maps and SOTA results on MVTec, VisA, MPDD, and BTAD under full/few‑shot and multi‑dataset settings.
AI.motivation: Conventional UAD methods hinge on reconstruction or template retrieval, but test–template matching is noisy due to intra‑class variability, imperfect correspondences, and limited normal templates. A noise‑resilient mechanism is needed to avoid false positives/negatives while preserving localization detail.
AI.method: A retrieval‑augmented framework: (1) build a hierarchical vector database to retrieve class‑, semantic‑, and instance‑level normal representations in a coarse‑to‑fine manner; (2) compute a matching cost volume between the input and retrieved exemplars; (3) feed this into a guided Mixture‑of‑Experts that adaptively leverages retrieved samples to suppress matching noise and generate high‑resolution anomaly maps.
AI.result: Demonstrates state‑of‑the‑art performance for both detection and localization across full‑shot, few‑shot, and multi‑dataset scenarios on standard benchmarks (MVTec, VisA, MPDD, BTAD).
AI.conclusion: Treating UAD through a RAG lens and guiding a MoE with hierarchically retrieved normals effectively reduces matching noise and improves anomaly detection/localization robustness and generalization across datasets and data regimes.

title: Seeing Clearly, Reasoning Confidently: Plug-and-Play Remedies for Vision Language Model Blindness
summary: Vision language models (VLMs) have achieved remarkable success in broad visual understanding, yet they remain challenged by object-centric reasoning on rare objects due to the scarcity of such instances in pretraining data. While prior efforts alleviate this issue by retrieving additional data or introducing stronger vision encoders, these methods are still computationally intensive during finetuning VLMs and don't fully exploit the original training data. In this paper, we introduce an efficient plug-and-play module that substantially improves VLMs' reasoning over rare objects by refining visual tokens and enriching input text prompts, without VLMs finetuning. Specifically, we propose to learn multi-modal class embeddings for rare objects by leveraging prior knowledge from vision foundation models and synonym-augmented text descriptions, compensating for limited training examples. These embeddings refine the visual tokens in VLMs through a lightweight attention-based enhancement module that improves fine-grained object details. In addition, we use the learned embeddings as object-aware detectors to generate informative hints, which are injected into the text prompts to help guide the VLM's attention toward relevant image regions. Experiments on two benchmarks show consistent and substantial gains for pretrained VLMs in rare object recognition and reasoning. Further analysis reveals how our method strengthens the VLM's ability to focus on and reason about rare objects.

AI.tldr: Plug-and-play rare-object booster for VLMs that learns multimodal class embeddings to refine visual tokens and augment prompts, delivering strong rare-object recognition/reasoning gains without finetuning the base VLM.
AI.motivation: VLMs struggle with object-centric reasoning on rare categories because such instances are scarce in pretraining; existing fixes (extra retrieval, stronger encoders, finetuning) are compute-heavy and underuse original data. A lightweight alternative is needed to target rare objects efficiently.
AI.method: Learn multimodal class embeddings for rare objects by combining priors from vision foundation models with synonym-augmented text descriptions. Use these embeddings (1) in a lightweight attention-based enhancement module to refine visual tokens for finer object details and (2) as object-aware detectors to create informative textual hints injected into prompts, guiding VLM attention to relevant regions. No finetuning of the base VLM is required.
AI.result: Across two benchmarks, the plug-and-play module yields consistent, substantial improvements for pretrained VLMs on rare-object recognition and reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: An efficient, finetune-free approach that better exploits existing data strengthens VLM focus and reasoning on rare objects by refining visual features and enriching prompts; analyses indicate improved attention and reasoning over rare categories.

title: Accurate Planar Tracking With Robust Re-Detection
summary: We present SAM-H and WOFTSAM, novel planar trackers that combine robust long-term segmentation tracking provided by SAM 2 with 8 degrees-of-freedom homography pose estimation. SAM-H estimates homographies from segmentation mask contours and is thus highly robust to target appearance changes. WOFTSAM significantly improves the current state-of-the-art planar tracker WOFT by exploiting lost target re-detection provided by SAM-H. The proposed methods are evaluated on POT-210 and PlanarTrack tracking benchmarks, setting the new state-of-the-art performance on both. On the latter, they outperform the second best by a large margin, +12.4 and +15.2pp on the p@15 metric. We also present improved ground-truth annotations of initial PlanarTrack poses, enabling more accurate benchmarking in the high-precision p@5 metric. The code and the re-annotations are available at https://github.com/serycjon/WOFTSAM

AI.tldr: SAM-H and WOFTSAM fuse SAM 2’s long-term segmentation with 8-DoF homography estimation to robustly track planar targets and re-detect losses, achieving new SOTA on POT-210 and PlanarTrack with large p@15 gains; they also release improved initial-pose annotations for PlanarTrack.
AI.motivation: Planar tracking often fails under appearance change, occlusion, and long-term target loss; WOFT lacked robust re-detection, and high-precision evaluation (p@5) was hindered by noisy initial pose annotations.
AI.method: SAM-H derives homographies from SAM 2 segmentation mask contours, boosting robustness to appearance changes. WOFTSAM augments WOFT with SAM-H-powered lost-target re-detection. The authors also re-annotate initial poses in PlanarTrack to improve high-precision benchmarking.
AI.result: Both methods set new SOTA on POT-210 and PlanarTrack; on PlanarTrack they surpass the second best by +12.4 and +15.2 percentage points on p@15. The refined initial-pose annotations support more accurate p@5 evaluations.
AI.conclusion: Coupling segmentation-driven long-term tracking with geometric homography estimation substantially improves planar tracking accuracy and robustness; adding reliable re-detection to existing trackers yields large gains. Code and re-annotations are publicly available.

title: Personalized Longitudinal Medical Report Generation via Temporally-Aware Federated Adaptation
summary:
Longitudinal medical report generation is clinically important yet remains challenging due to strict privacy constraints and the evolving nature of disease progression. Although federated learning (FL) enables collaborative training without data sharing, existing FL methods largely overlook longitudinal dynamics by assuming stationary client distributions, making them unable to model temporal shifts across visits or patient-specific heterogeneity-ultimately leading to unstable optimization and suboptimal report generation.
  We introduce Federated Temporal Adaptation (FTA), a federated setting that explicitly accounts for the temporal evolution of client data. Building upon this setting, we propose FedTAR, a framework that integrates demographic-driven personalization with time-aware global aggregation. FedTAR generates lightweight LoRA adapters from demographic embeddings and performs temporal residual aggregation, where updates from different visits are weighted by a meta-learned temporal policy optimized via first-order MAML.
  Experiments on J-MID (1M exams) and MIMIC-CXR demonstrate consistent improvements in linguistic accuracy, temporal coherence, and cross-site generalization, establishing FedTAR as a robust and privacy-preserving paradigm for federated longitudinal modeling.

AI.tldr: FedTAR introduces a federated temporal adaptation setting for longitudinal medical report generation, combining demographic-conditioned LoRA personalization with a meta-learned, time-aware aggregation policy (first-order MAML) to better handle non-stationary client distributions and temporal shifts, yielding improved linguistic accuracy, temporal coherence, and cross-site generalization on J-MID and MIMIC-CXR.
AI.motivation: Longitudinal report generation must respect data privacy while modeling disease progression over time. Standard federated learning assumes stationary client distributions and ignores temporal evolution and patient heterogeneity, causing unstable optimization and poor temporal reasoning in generated reports.
AI.method: (1) Define Federated Temporal Adaptation (FTA) to explicitly model temporally evolving client data. (2) Propose FedTAR: personalize via lightweight LoRA adapters generated from demographic embeddings; perform temporal residual aggregation where client updates from different visits are weighted by a meta-learned temporal policy optimized with first-order MAML; combine demographic-driven personalization with global, time-aware aggregation.
AI.result: On J-MID (≈1M exams) and MIMIC-CXR, FedTAR consistently outperforms baselines in linguistic accuracy, temporal coherence across visits, and cross-site generalization, indicating better robustness under privacy constraints.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating temporal dynamics and demographic-aware personalization into FL yields a robust, privacy-preserving paradigm for longitudinal medical report generation; FedTAR provides a practical approach with consistent gains across large-scale datasets.

title: BayesFusion-SDF: Probabilistic Signed Distance Fusion with View Planning on CPU
summary: Key part of robotics, augmented reality, and digital inspection is dense 3D reconstruction from depth observations. Traditional volumetric fusion techniques, including truncated signed distance functions (TSDF), enable efficient and deterministic geometry reconstruction; however, they depend on heuristic weighting and fail to transparently convey uncertainty in a systematic way. Recent neural implicit methods, on the other hand, get very high fidelity but usually need a lot of GPU power for optimization and aren't very easy to understand for making decisions later on. This work presents BayesFusion-SDF, a CPU-centric probabilistic signed distance fusion framework that conceptualizes geometry as a sparse Gaussian random field with a defined posterior distribution over voxel distances. First, a rough TSDF reconstruction is used to create an adaptive narrow-band domain. Then, depth observations are combined using a heteroscedastic Bayesian formulation that is solved using sparse linear algebra and preconditioned conjugate gradients. Randomized diagonal estimators are a quick way to get an idea of posterior uncertainty. This makes it possible to extract surfaces and plan the next best view while taking into account uncertainty. Tests on a controlled ablation scene and a CO3D object sequence show that the new method is more accurate geometrically than TSDF baselines and gives useful estimates of uncertainty for active sensing. The proposed formulation provides a clear and easy-to-use alternative to GPU-heavy neural reconstruction methods while still being able to be understood in a probabilistic way and acting in a predictable way. GitHub: https://mazumdarsoumya.github.io/BayesFusionSDF

AI.tldr: BayesFusion-SDF is a CPU-centric Bayesian fusion method that models the signed distance field as a sparse Gaussian random field, delivering both geometry and calibrated uncertainty; it outperforms TSDF baselines and supports uncertainty-aware tasks like next-best-view planning without GPU-heavy neural optimization.
AI.motivation: Dense 3D reconstruction needs efficiency, determinism, and trustworthy uncertainty. Classic TSDF fusion is fast but relies on ad‑hoc weights and offers no principled uncertainty, while neural implicit methods are accurate but computationally heavy and hard to interpret for downstream decision-making.
AI.method: 1) Build an adaptive narrow-band with a coarse TSDF. 2) Formulate depth fusion as a heteroscedastic Bayesian (linear-Gaussian) inference over voxel SDF values. 3) Solve for the posterior using sparse linear algebra with preconditioned conjugate gradients. 4) Estimate posterior uncertainties efficiently via randomized diagonal estimators. 5) Use the posterior (mean/variance) for surface extraction and next-best-view planning.
AI.result: On a controlled ablation scene and a CO3D object sequence, the method achieves higher geometric accuracy than TSDF baselines and produces useful, calibrated uncertainty estimates that enable effective active sensing and planning, all on CPU.
AI.conclusion: A practical, interpretable probabilistic SDF fusion framework that retains TSDF-like efficiency while adding principled uncertainty and improving accuracy, offering a clear alternative to GPU-intensive neural reconstruction approaches.

title: HDR Reconstruction Boosting with Training-Free and Exposure-Consistent Diffusion
summary: Single LDR to HDR reconstruction remains challenging for over-exposed regions where traditional methods often fail due to complete information loss. We present a training-free approach that enhances existing indirect and direct HDR reconstruction methods through diffusion-based inpainting. Our method combines text-guided diffusion models with SDEdit refinement to generate plausible content in over-exposed areas while maintaining consistency across multi-exposure LDR images. Unlike previous approaches requiring extensive training, our method seamlessly integrates with existing HDR reconstruction techniques through an iterative compensation mechanism that ensures luminance coherence across multiple exposures. We demonstrate significant improvements in both perceptual quality and quantitative metrics on standard HDR datasets and in-the-wild captures. Results show that our method effectively recovers natural details in challenging scenarios while preserving the advantages of existing HDR reconstruction pipelines. Project page: https://github.com/EusdenLin/HDR-Reconstruction-Boosting

AI.tldr: A plug-and-play, training-free booster for LDR-to-HDR that uses text-guided diffusion inpainting with SDEdit refinement and an iterative luminance compensation loop to plausibly recover saturated regions while staying consistent across exposures, improving both perceptual and quantitative HDR metrics.
AI.motivation: Single-image (and multi-exposure) HDR reconstruction struggles in over-exposed areas due to irretrievable information loss; many prior fixes require costly retraining. The goal is to recover plausible content in blown-out regions and keep luminance/exposure coherence without training new models, while leveraging existing HDR pipelines.
AI.method: Identify over-exposed regions and inpaint them using a text-guided diffusion model; refine with SDEdit to better align with the original structure.
