Integrate this into existing indirect/direct HDR methods via an iterative compensation mechanism that enforces luminance coherence across multiple exposures and preserves pipeline consistency. The approach is training-free and acts as a drop-in enhancement.
AI.result: On standard HDR benchmarks and in-the-wild photos, the approach yields notable gains in perceptual quality and standard quantitative metrics. Visual results show more natural details restored in saturated zones while retaining the strengths of existing HDR reconstruction methods.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion-based, training-free inpainting can effectively recover plausible detail in over-exposed regions and improve HDR outputs. It serves as a plug-in module that preserves luminance coherence and augments current HDR pipelines without additional training, delivering measurable and visual improvements.

title: ChimeraLoRA: Multi-Head LoRA-Guided Synthetic Datasets
summary: Beyond general recognition tasks, specialized domains including privacy-constrained medical applications and fine-grained settings often encounter data scarcity, especially for tail classes. To obtain less biased and more reliable models under such scarcity, practitioners leverage diffusion models to supplement underrepresented regions of real data. Specifically, recent studies fine-tune pretrained diffusion models with LoRA on few-shot real sets to synthesize additional images. While an image-wise LoRA trained on a single image captures fine-grained details yet offers limited diversity, a class-wise LoRA trained over all shots produces diverse images as it encodes class priors yet tends to overlook fine details. To combine both benefits, we separate the adapter into a class-shared LoRA~$A$ for class priors and per-image LoRAs~$\mathcal{B}$ for image-specific characteristics. To expose coherent class semantics in the shared LoRA~$A$, we propose a semantic boosting by preserving class bounding boxes during training. For generation, we compose $A$ with a mixture of $\mathcal{B}$ using coefficients drawn from a Dirichlet distribution. Across diverse datasets, our synthesized images are both diverse and detail-rich while closely aligning with the few-shot real distribution, yielding robust gains in downstream classification accuracy.

AI.tldr: Hybrid LoRA tuning for diffusion models—combining a class-shared adapter with per-image adapters, plus semantic boosting via bounding boxes and Dirichlet-mixture composition—yields diverse yet detail-faithful synthetic images that improve few-shot classification.
AI.motivation: Few-shot settings in specialized domains (e.g., privacy-limited medical, fine-grained) suffer from data scarcity, especially for tail classes. Existing diffusion augmentation with LoRA faces a trade-off: image-wise LoRA preserves fine details but lacks diversity; class-wise LoRA offers diversity via class priors but loses fine-grained details. The goal is to overcome this trade-off to produce reliable, less biased models.
AI.method: Split the LoRA adapter into (1) a class-shared LoRA A capturing class priors, and (2) per-image LoRAs B encoding image-specific details. During training, apply semantic boosting for A by preserving class bounding boxes to concentrate coherent class semantics. At generation, compose A with a mixture of B’s using Dirichlet-distributed coefficients to blend image-specific details while retaining class priors, producing diverse and detailed synthetic images.
AI.result: Across multiple datasets, the synthesized images are both diverse and rich in fine details, align closely with the few-shot real data distribution, and lead to robust improvements in downstream classification accuracy compared to prior augmentation approaches.
AI.conclusion: A principled combination of class-level and instance-level LoRA adapters, augmented with bounding-box-based semantic boosting and Dirichlet-mixture composition, effectively addresses data scarcity in few-shot settings, generating high-quality augmentations that improve model reliability and reduce bias.

title: Universal Pose Pretraining for Generalizable Vision-Language-Action Policies
summary:
Existing Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models often suffer from feature collapse and low training efficiency because they entangle high-level perception with sparse, embodiment-specific action supervision. Since these models typically rely on VLM backbones optimized for Visual Question Answering (VQA), they excel at semantic identification but often overlook subtle 3D state variations that dictate distinct action patterns.
  To resolve these misalignments, we propose Pose-VLA, a decoupled paradigm that separates VLA training into a pre-training phase for extracting universal 3D spatial priors in a unified camera-centric space, and a post-training phase for efficient embodiment alignment within robot-specific action space. By introducing discrete pose tokens as a universal representation, Pose-VLA seamlessly integrates spatial grounding from diverse 3D datasets with geometry-level trajectories from robotic demonstrations. Our framework follows a two-stage pre-training pipeline, establishing fundamental spatial grounding via poses followed by motion alignment through trajectory supervision.
  Extensive evaluations demonstrate that Pose-VLA achieves state-of-the-art results on RoboTwin 2.0 with a 79.5% average success rate and competitive performance on LIBERO at 96.0%. Real-world experiments further showcase robust generalization across diverse objects using only 100 demonstrations per task, validating the efficiency of our pre-training paradigm.

AI.tldr: Pose‑VLA decouples perception from control by pretraining universal 3D spatial priors with discrete pose tokens in a camera‑centric space, then aligning to robot‑specific action spaces, yielding SOTA/competitive performance and strong real‑world generalization with few demos.
AI.motivation: Current VLA models entangle high‑level perception with sparse, embodiment‑specific action labels, causing feature collapse, low data efficiency, and insensitivity to subtle 3D state changes—partly due to reliance on VQA‑tuned backbones that favor semantics over geometry. A better approach should explicitly ground 3D spatial structure and then map it efficiently to robot embodiments.
AI.method: Introduce discrete pose tokens as a universal, camera‑centric representation and decouple training into: (1) pretraining to learn universal 3D spatial priors and spatial grounding from diverse 3D datasets; (2) post‑training (embodiment alignment) to map those priors to robot‑specific action spaces using geometry‑level trajectory supervision. A two‑stage pretraining pipeline first builds spatial grounding via poses, then performs motion alignment via trajectory supervision.
AI.result: State‑of‑the‑art on RoboTwin 2.0 (79.5% average success) and competitive on LIBERO (96.0%). Real‑world experiments show robust cross‑object generalization using only 100 demonstrations per task, indicating data efficiency and transferability.
AI.conclusion: Separating spatial perception from action control with pose tokens yields better 3D grounding, improved training efficiency, and stronger generalization across embodiments and objects. The approach supports a scalable pretraining paradigm for VLA with fewer demonstrations while maintaining high success rates.

title: Pixels Don't Lie (But Your Detector Might): Bootstrapping MLLM-as-a-Judge for Trustworthy Deepfake Detection and Reasoning Supervision
summary: Deepfake detection models often generate natural-language explanations, yet their reasoning is frequently ungrounded in visual evidence, limiting reliability. Existing evaluations measure classification accuracy but overlook reasoning fidelity. We propose DeepfakeJudge, a framework for scalable reasoning supervision and evaluation, that integrates an out-of-distribution benchmark containing recent generative and editing forgeries, a human-annotated subset with visual reasoning labels, and a suite of evaluation models, that specialize in evaluating reasoning rationales without the need for explicit ground truth reasoning rationales. The Judge is optimized through a bootstrapped generator-evaluator process that scales human feedback into structured reasoning supervision and supports both pointwise and pairwise evaluation. On the proposed meta-evaluation benchmark, our reasoning-bootstrapped model achieves an accuracy of 96.2\%, outperforming \texttt{30x} larger baselines. The reasoning judge attains very high correlation with human ratings and 98.9\% percent pairwise agreement on the human-annotated meta-evaluation subset. These results establish reasoning fidelity as a quantifiable dimension of deepfake detection and demonstrate scalable supervision for interpretable deepfake reasoning. Our user study shows that participants preferred the reasonings generated by our framework 70\% of the time, in terms of faithfulness, groundedness, and usefulness, compared to those produced by other models and datasets. All of our datasets, models, and codebase are \href{https://github.com/KjAeRsTuIsK/DeepfakeJudge}{open-sourced}.

AI.tldr: DeepfakeJudge is a framework to supervise and evaluate the faithfulness of deepfake detectors’ natural-language reasoning, combining new datasets and a learned judge that aligns closely with human assessments.
AI.motivation: Current deepfake detectors often produce ungrounded explanations; existing benchmarks emphasize classification accuracy while neglecting whether the textual rationale truly reflects visual evidence. Reliable, interpretable detection requires measuring and improving reasoning fidelity at scale.
AI.method: Construct an out-of-distribution benchmark of recent generative/editing forgeries, create a human-annotated subset with visual reasoning labels, and train a suite of evaluator models specialized for judging rationales without needing gold rationales. Optimize a reasoning judge via a bootstrapped generator–evaluator loop that scales human feedback into structured supervision, supporting both pointwise and pairwise evaluation. Evaluate on a meta-evaluation set for reasoning quality.
AI.result: The reasoning-bootstrapped model achieves 96.2% accuracy on the meta-evaluation benchmark, outperforming baselines up to 30× larger. The judge shows very high correlation with human ratings and 98.9% pairwise agreement on the human-annotated subset. In a user study, participants preferred the framework’s reasonings 70% of the time for faithfulness, groundedness, and usefulness.
AI.conclusion: Reasoning fidelity in deepfake detection is measurable and improvable. DeepfakeJudge offers scalable supervision and evaluation for interpretable deepfake reasoning, with datasets, models, and code released open-source.

title: Generative 6D Pose Estimation via Conditional Flow Matching
summary: Existing methods for instance-level 6D pose estimation typically rely on neural networks that either directly regress the pose in $\mathrm{SE}(3)$ or estimate it indirectly via local feature matching. The former struggle with object symmetries, while the latter fail in the absence of distinctive local features. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel formulation of 6D pose estimation as a conditional flow matching problem in $\mathbb{R}^3$. We introduce Flose, a generative method that infers object poses via a denoising process conditioned on local features. While prior approaches based on conditional flow matching perform denoising solely based on geometric guidance, Flose integrates appearance-based semantic features to mitigate ambiguities caused by object symmetries. We further incorporate RANSAC-based registration to handle outliers. We validate Flose on five datasets from the established BOP benchmark. Flose outperforms prior methods with an average improvement of +4.5 Average Recall. Project Website : https://tev-fbk.github.io/Flose/

AI.tldr: Flose reframes 6D pose estimation as conditional flow matching in R^3, fusing geometric guidance with appearance-based semantic features and a RANSAC registration step to handle outliers, yielding +4.5 Average Recall over prior methods on BOP datasets.
AI.motivation: Direct pose regression in SE(3) struggles with object symmetries, and local feature–matching methods fail when objects lack distinctive features. The goal is to design a pose estimator that is robust to symmetries and weak local texture while remaining resilient to outliers.
AI.method: Model 6D pose estimation as a conditional flow matching (CFM) problem in R^3. Propose a generative denoising process (Flose) conditioned on local features that integrates both geometric guidance and appearance-based semantic cues to disambiguate symmetric poses. Employ a RANSAC-based registration step to reject outliers and refine alignment.
AI.result: Validated on five datasets from the BOP benchmark; achieves an average improvement of +4.5 Average Recall over prior state-of-the-art methods, indicating stronger robustness to symmetries and scenes with weak local features.
AI.conclusion: Combining CFM-driven denoising with semantic appearance cues and robust registration effectively addresses symmetry-induced ambiguities and outliers in 6D pose estimation, establishing new state-of-the-art performance on BOP. A project website is provided for further resources.

title: Towards Personalized Multi-Modal MRI Synthesis across Heterogeneous Datasets
summary: Synthesizing missing modalities in multi-modal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is vital for ensuring diagnostic completeness, particularly when full acquisitions are infeasible due to time constraints, motion artifacts, and patient tolerance. Recent unified synthesis models have enabled flexible synthesis tasks by accommodating various input-output configurations. However, their training and evaluation are typically restricted to a single dataset, limiting their generalizability across diverse clinical datasets and impeding practical deployment. To address this limitation, we propose PMM-Synth, a personalized MRI synthesis framework that not only supports various synthesis tasks but also generalizes effectively across heterogeneous datasets. PMM-Synth is jointly trained on multiple multi-modal MRI datasets that differ in modality coverage, disease types, and intensity distributions. It achieves cross-dataset generalization through three core innovations: a Personalized Feature Modulation module that dynamically adapts feature representations based on dataset identifier to mitigate the impact of distributional shifts; a Modality-Consistent Batch Scheduler that facilitates stable and efficient batch training under inconsistent modality conditions; and a selective supervision loss to ensure effective learning when ground truth modalities are partially missing. Evaluated on four clinical multi-modal MRI datasets, PMM-Synth consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both one-to-one and many-to-one synthesis tasks, achieving superior PSNR and SSIM scores. Qualitative results further demonstrate improved preservation of anatomical structures and pathological details. Additionally, downstream tumor segmentation and radiological reporting studies suggest that PMM-Synth holds potential for supporting reliable diagnosis under real-world modality-missing scenarios.

AI.tldr: PMM-Synth is a multi-dataset, personalized MRI synthesis framework that flexibly handles missing-modality setups and generalizes across heterogeneous clinical datasets, outperforming prior methods in PSNR/SSIM and downstream tasks.
AI.motivation: MRI exams often lack some modalities due to time, motion, or tolerance limits. While unified synthesis models exist, they are usually trained/evaluated on a single dataset, leading to poor cross-dataset generalizability and limiting real-world adoption.
AI.method: Joint training on multiple multi-modal MRI datasets with heterogeneous modality coverage and diseases. Three key components: (1) Personalized Feature Modulation that conditions feature representations on a dataset identifier to counter distribution shifts; (2) Modality-Consistent Batch Scheduler to maintain stable, efficient training despite inconsistent modality availability; (3) Selective supervision loss to learn effectively when some ground-truth modalities are missing. Supports one-to-one and many-to-one synthesis.
AI.result: On four clinical multi-modal MRI datasets, PMM-Synth consistently surpasses state-of-the-art unified synthesis approaches in both 1→1 and many→1 tasks, achieving higher PSNR and SSIM. Qualitative analyses show better preservation of anatomy and pathology. In downstream tumor segmentation and radiology reporting, the synthesized outputs improve performance, indicating clinical utility.
AI.conclusion: Personalizing feature representations and stabilizing training across heterogeneous datasets enables robust cross-dataset MRI synthesis under missing-modality conditions. PMM-Synth provides flexible, accurate synthesis that preserves clinically relevant details and shows promise for real-world deployment to support reliable diagnosis.

title: VGGT-MPR: VGGT-Enhanced Multimodal Place Recognition in Autonomous Driving Environments
summary: In autonomous driving, robust place recognition is critical for global localization and loop closure detection. While inter-modality fusion of camera and LiDAR data in multimodal place recognition (MPR) has shown promise in overcoming the limitations of unimodal counterparts, existing MPR methods basically attend to hand-crafted fusion strategies and heavily parameterized backbones that require costly retraining. To address this, we propose VGGT-MPR, a multimodal place recognition framework that adopts the Visual Geometry Grounded Transformer (VGGT) as a unified geometric engine for both global retrieval and re-ranking. In the global retrieval stage, VGGT extracts geometrically-rich visual embeddings through prior depth-aware and point map supervision, and densifies sparse LiDAR point clouds with predicted depth maps to improve structural representation. This enhances the discriminative ability of fused multimodal features and produces global descriptors for fast retrieval. Beyond global retrieval, we design a training-free re-ranking mechanism that exploits VGGT's cross-view keypoint-tracking capability. By combining mask-guided keypoint extraction with confidence-aware correspondence scoring, our proposed re-ranking mechanism effectively refines retrieval results without additional parameter optimization. Extensive experiments on large-scale autonomous driving benchmarks and our self-collected data demonstrate that VGGT-MPR achieves state-of-the-art performance, exhibiting strong robustness to severe environmental changes, viewpoint shifts, and occlusions. Our code and data will be made publicly available.

AI.tldr: VGGT-MPR is a multimodal place recognition framework that unifies camera–LiDAR fusion and re-ranking using a Visual Geometry Grounded Transformer, delivering SOTA robustness to viewpoint, environment changes, and occlusions without retraining-heavy fusion/backbones.
AI.motivation: Current multimodal place recognition relies on hand-crafted fusion and large, heavily parameterized models that need costly retraining and struggle with robustness under severe appearance/viewpoint changes.
AI.method: Use VGGT as a unified geometric engine: (1) Global retrieval—extract geometry-rich visual embeddings via depth/point-map supervision; densify sparse LiDAR with predicted depth to strengthen structural cues; fuse to form compact global descriptors. (2) Training-free re-ranking—leverage VGGT’s cross-view keypoint tracking with mask-guided keypoint extraction and confidence-aware correspondence scoring to refine top retrievals without additional parameter optimization.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on large-scale autonomous driving benchmarks and in-house datasets show state-of-the-art performance and strong robustness to environmental variations, viewpoint shifts, and occlusions.
AI.conclusion: Geometry-grounded multimodal fusion with VGGT plus training-free re-ranking yields accurate, efficient, and robust place recognition for autonomous driving; code and data will be released.

title: InfScene-SR: Spatially Continuous Inference for Arbitrary-Size Image Super-Resolution
summary: Image Super-Resolution (SR) aims to recover high-resolution (HR) details from low-resolution (LR) inputs, a task where Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs) have recently shown superior performance compared to Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) based approaches. However, standard diffusion-based SR models, such as SR3, are typically trained on fixed-size patches and struggle to scale to arbitrary-sized images due to memory constraints. Applying these models via independent patch processing leads to visible seams and inconsistent textures across boundaries. In this paper, we propose InfScene-SR, a framework enabling spatially continuous super-resolution for large, arbitrary scenes. We adapt the iterative refinement process of diffusion models with a novel guided and variance-corrected fusion mechanism, allowing for the seamless generation of large-scale high-resolution imagery without retraining. We validate our approach on remote sensing datasets, demonstrating that InfScene-SR not only reconstructs fine details with high perceptual quality but also eliminates boundary artifacts, benefiting downstream tasks such as semantic segmentation.

AI.tldr: InfScene-SR enables seamless, training-free, diffusion-based super-resolution on arbitrarily large images by fusing overlapping tiles with a guided, variance-corrected mechanism during the denoising process, removing seams and improving downstream performance on remote sensing tasks.
AI.motivation: Diffusion SR models (e.g., SR3) are trained on fixed-size patches and are memory-bound at inference, making them hard to apply to large scenes. Naively tiling introduces visible seams and texture inconsistencies across patch boundaries. A method is needed to scale diffusion SR to large images while preserving spatial continuity.
AI.method: They adapt the iterative denoising refinement of DDPM-based SR to operate on overlapping tiles and introduce a guided, variance-corrected fusion scheme that aggregates intermediate predictions across tile boundaries over diffusion steps. This yields spatially consistent high-resolution outputs without retraining the base diffusion model.
AI.result: On remote sensing datasets, the approach reconstructs finer details with higher perceptual quality and eliminates boundary artifacts compared to independent patch processing, and it improves downstream semantic segmentation accuracy.
AI.conclusion: InfScene-SR turns patch-trained diffusion SR models into spatially continuous, scalable super-resolvers for large scenes, delivering perceptually superior, seam-free outputs and practical gains for downstream tasks, all without retraining.

title: RAP: Fast Feedforward Rendering-Free Attribute-Guided Primitive Importance Score Prediction for Efficient 3D Gaussian Splatting Processing
summary: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has emerged as a leading technology for high-quality 3D scene reconstruction. However, the iterative refinement and densification process leads to the generation of a large number of primitives, each contributing to the reconstruction to a substantially different extent. Estimating primitive importance is thus crucial, both for removing redundancy during reconstruction and for enabling efficient compression and transmission. Existing methods typically rely on rendering-based analyses, where each primitive is evaluated through its contribution across multiple camera viewpoints. However, such methods are sensitive to the number and selection of views, rely on specialized differentiable rasterizers, and have long calculation times that grow linearly with view count, making them difficult to integrate as plug-and-play modules and limiting scalability and generalization. To address these issues, we propose RAP, a fast feedforward rendering-free attribute-guided method for efficient importance score prediction in 3DGS. RAP infers primitive significance directly from intrinsic Gaussian attributes and local neighborhood statistics, avoiding rendering-based or visibility-dependent computations. A compact MLP predicts per-primitive importance scores using rendering loss, pruning-aware loss, and significance distribution regularization. After training on a small set of scenes, RAP generalizes effectively to unseen data and can be seamlessly integrated into reconstruction, compression, and transmission pipelines. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/yyyykf/RAP.

AI.tldr: They introduce RAP, a fast, rendering-free MLP that predicts per-primitive importance in 3D Gaussian Splatting from intrinsic attributes and neighborhood stats, enabling efficient pruning, compression, and transmission without view-dependent evaluation.
AI.motivation: 3DGS reconstruction produces many Gaussian primitives with uneven contributions. Estimating their importance is key for pruning redundancy and efficient compression/transmission. Existing importance estimators depend on rendering across many views, are slow, sensitive to view choice, require special rasterizers, and scale poorly—hindering plug-and-play use and generalization.
AI.method: RAP is a compact feedforward model that takes intrinsic Gaussian attributes and local neighborhood statistics to predict importance scores, avoiding any rendering/visibility computations. Training uses (1) a rendering loss to tie scores to reconstruction quality, (2) a pruning-aware loss to encourage decisions aligned with removal of unimportant primitives, and (3) significance distribution regularization to maintain a well-shaped score distribution. Once trained on a small set of scenes, RAP is applied inference-time to unseen scenes.
AI.result: RAP quickly predicts per-primitive importance and generalizes to new scenes after training on few scenes. It integrates into reconstruction, compression, and transmission pipelines and removes the view-count linear cost and sensitivity of rendering-based methods. The abstract implies strong speed and scalability gains, though no specific metrics are provided.
AI.conclusion: RAP provides a scalable, plug-and-play, rendering-free solution for importance estimation in 3DGS, improving efficiency for pruning and compression while avoiding view dependence and heavy computation. Code is available, facilitating adoption.

title: Multimodal Dataset Distillation Made Simple by Prototype-Guided Data Synthesis
summary: Recent advances in multimodal learning have achieved remarkable success across diverse vision-language tasks. However, such progress heavily relies on large-scale image-text datasets, making training costly and inefficient. Prior efforts in dataset filtering and pruning attempt to mitigate this issue, but still require relatively large subsets to maintain performance and fail under very small subsets. Dataset distillation offers a promising alternative, yet existing multimodal dataset distillation methods require full-dataset training and joint optimization of image pixels and text features, making them architecture-dependent and limiting cross-architecture generalization. To overcome this, we propose a learning-free dataset distillation framework that eliminates the need for large-scale training and optimization while enhancing generalization across architectures. Our method uses CLIP to extract aligned image-text embeddings, obtains prototypes, and employs an unCLIP decoder to synthesize images, enabling efficient and scalable multimodal dataset distillation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms optimization-based dataset distillation and subset selection methods, achieving state-of-the-art cross-architecture generalization.

AI.tldr: Learning-free multimodal dataset distillation: extract CLIP-aligned image–text embeddings, select/summarize via prototypes, and synthesize images with an unCLIP decoder—avoiding heavy optimization/training—achieving better performance and cross-architecture generalization than optimization-based distillation and subset selection.
AI.motivation: Training multimodal models needs massive image–text data, which is costly. Filtering/pruning still needs sizable subsets and breaks at very small budgets. Existing multimodal distillation jointly optimizes pixels and text and depends on full-dataset training and model architecture, limiting scalability and transfer. A scalable, architecture-agnostic alternative is needed.
AI.method: Use a frozen CLIP to obtain aligned embeddings, derive representative prototypes (e.g., via clustering/selection) to summarize the dataset, and employ an unCLIP decoder to synthesize images from the prototype signals, producing a compact distilled set without gradient-based optimization or architecture coupling.
AI.result: Across benchmarks, the distilled sets consistently outperform optimization-based distillation and subset-selection baselines, and set a new state of the art for cross-architecture transfer/generalization, while being efficient and scalable.
AI.conclusion: A training-free, architecture-agnostic multimodal dataset distillation pipeline can replace heavy optimization, maintains or improves downstream performance under tight data budgets, and generalizes well across model architectures.

title: Training Deep Stereo Matching Networks on Tree Branch Imagery: A Benchmark Study for Real-Time UAV Forestry Applications
summary: Autonomous drone-based tree pruning needs accurate, real-time depth estimation from stereo cameras. Depth is computed from disparity maps using $Z = f B/d$, so even small disparity errors cause noticeable depth mistakes at working distances. Building on our earlier work that identified DEFOM-Stereo as the best reference disparity generator for vegetation scenes, we present the first study to train and test ten deep stereo matching networks on real tree branch images. We use the Canterbury Tree Branches dataset -- 5,313 stereo pairs from a ZED Mini camera at 1080P and 720P -- with DEFOM-generated disparity maps as training targets. The ten methods cover step-by-step refinement, 3D convolution, edge-aware attention, and lightweight designs. Using perceptual metrics (SSIM, LPIPS, ViTScore) and structural metrics (SIFT/ORB feature matching), we find that BANet-3D produces the best overall quality (SSIM = 0.883, LPIPS = 0.157), while RAFT-Stereo scores highest on scene-level understanding (ViTScore = 0.799). Testing on an NVIDIA Jetson Orin Super (16 GB, independently powered) mounted on our drone shows that AnyNet reaches 6.99 FPS at 1080P -- the only near-real-time option -- while BANet-2D gives the best quality-speed balance at 1.21 FPS. We also compare 720P and 1080P processing times to guide resolution choices for forestry drone systems.

AI.tldr: First real-world study training and benchmarking 10 deep stereo networks on tree-branch imagery for drone pruning. BANet-3D yields best perceptual quality, RAFT-Stereo best scene-level score, AnyNet is the only near–real-time option on Jetson Orin at 1080P; BANet-2D offers the best quality–speed trade-off; resolution trade-offs (720P vs 1080P) are quantified.
AI.motivation: Accurate, real-time depth from stereo is critical for autonomous pruning; small disparity errors cause large depth errors (Z=fB/d). Vegetation scenes are challenging, and prior work flagged DEFOM-Stereo as the strongest reference on foliage, motivating a focused, application-driven benchmark on real branches.
AI.method: Use the Canterbury Tree Branches dataset (5,313 ZED Mini stereo pairs at 1080P/720P) with DEFOM-generated disparities as training targets to train/test 10 stereo networks spanning stepwise refinement, 3D conv, edge-aware attention, and lightweight designs. Evaluate with perceptual metrics (SSIM, LPIPS), scene-level (ViTScore), and structural (SIFT/ORB matching), and measure embedded performance on an NVIDIA Jetson Orin Super (16 GB) at 720P/1080P.
AI.result: BANet-3D achieves the best perceptual quality (SSIM 0.883, LPIPS 0.157). RAFT-Stereo leads in scene-level understanding (ViTScore 0.799). On-device, AnyNet reaches 6.99 FPS at 1080P (near real time), while BANet-2D provides the best quality–speed balance at 1.21 FPS. Processing-time comparisons between 720P and 1080P are reported.
AI.conclusion: Model choice depends on deployment priorities: AnyNet for responsiveness, BANet-2D for balanced accuracy-speed, BANet-3D for highest quality (offline), and RAFT-Stereo for scene-level understanding. Reported 720P/1080P timings guide resolution selection for forestry drones; the study establishes a domain-specific benchmark for vegetation stereo.

title: One2Scene: Geometric Consistent Explorable 3D Scene Generation from a Single Image
summary: Generating explorable 3D scenes from a single image is a highly challenging problem in 3D vision. Existing methods struggle to support free exploration, often producing severe geometric distortions and noisy artifacts when the viewpoint moves far from the original perspective. We introduce \textbf{One2Scene}, an effective framework that decomposes this ill-posed problem into three tractable sub-tasks to enable immersive explorable scene generation. We first use a panorama generator to produce anchor views from a single input image as initialization. Then, we lift these 2D anchors into an explicit 3D geometric scaffold via a generalizable, feed-forward Gaussian Splatting network. Instead of treating the panorama as a single image for reconstruction, we project it into multiple sparse anchor views and reformulate the reconstruction task as multi-view stereo matching, which allows us to leverage robust geometric priors learned from large-scale multi-view datasets. A bidirectional feature fusion module is used to enforce cross-view consistency, yielding an efficient and geometrically reliable scaffold. Finally, the scaffold serves as a strong prior for a novel view generator to produce photorealistic and geometrically accurate views at arbitrary cameras. By explicitly conditioning on a 3D-consistent scaffold to perform reconstruction, One2Scene works stably under large camera motions, supporting immersive scene exploration. Extensive experiments show that One2Scene substantially outperforms state-of-the-art methods in panorama depth estimation, feed-forward 360° reconstruction, and explorable 3D scene generation. Code and models will be released.

AI.tldr: One2Scene converts a single image into an explorable 3D scene by hallucinating panoramic anchors, lifting them into a 3D Gaussian-splat scaffold via multi‑view‑style reconstruction with cross‑view fusion, then generating photorealistic novel views conditioned on that scaffold—achieving stable large‑baseline exploration and SOTA performance.
AI.motivation: Single‑image 3D scene generation is ill‑posed: when the camera moves away from the input viewpoint, current methods often produce geometric distortions and noise, limiting free exploration. The authors aim to enable immersive, geometry‑consistent navigation from just one photo by leveraging stronger geometric priors and decoupling appearance from structure.
AI.method: Decompose into three stages: (1) Use a panorama generator to synthesize anchor views from the single input. (2) Lift these 2D anchors into an explicit 3D scaffold with a generalizable, feed‑forward Gaussian Splatting network. Instead of treating the panorama as a single image, project it into multiple sparse anchor views and perform multi‑view stereo matching; apply a bidirectional feature‑fusion module to enforce cross‑view consistency and obtain a reliable scaffold. (3) Condition a novel‑view generator on the scaffold to render photorealistic, geometrically accurate views at arbitrary cameras, supporting large camera motions.
AI.result: Experiments indicate substantial improvements over prior work on panorama depth estimation, feed‑forward 360° reconstruction, and single‑image‑to‑explorable‑3D generation, with stable performance under large viewpoint changes. The authors plan to release code and models.
AI.conclusion: By explicitly conditioning view synthesis on a 3D‑consistent Gaussian scaffold learned via multi‑view priors, One2Scene makes single‑image, immersive scene exploration feasible and more reliable than previous approaches.

title: TraceVision: Trajectory-Aware Vision-Language Model for Human-Like Spatial Understanding
summary: Recent Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) demonstrate remarkable capabilities in image understanding and natural language generation. However, current approaches focus predominantly on global image understanding, struggling to simulate human visual attention trajectories and explain associations between descriptions and specific regions. We propose TraceVision, a unified vision-language model integrating trajectory-aware spatial understanding in an end-to-end framework. TraceVision employs a Trajectory-aware Visual Perception (TVP) module for bidirectional fusion of visual features and trajectory information. We design geometric simplification to extract semantic keypoints from raw trajectories and propose a three-stage training pipeline where trajectories guide description generation and region localization. We extend TraceVision to trajectory-guided segmentation and video scene understanding, enabling cross-frame tracking and temporal attention analysis. We construct the Reasoning-based Interactive Localized Narratives (RILN) dataset to enhance logical reasoning and interpretability. Extensive experiments on trajectory-guided captioning, text-guided trajectory prediction, understanding, and segmentation demonstrate that TraceVision achieves state-of-the-art performance, establishing a foundation for intuitive spatial interaction and interpretable visual understanding.

AI.tldr: TraceVision is a unified LVLM that fuses visual features with human‑like trajectory cues to produce grounded, interpretable captions and predictions, achieving SOTA across trajectory-guided and grounding tasks and extending to segmentation and video understanding with a new reasoning-focused dataset (RILN).
AI.motivation: Current LVLMs emphasize global scene understanding and struggle to model human visual attention paths or explicitly link language to specific image regions, limiting interpretability and spatial interaction.
AI.method: Introduce a Trajectory-aware Visual Perception (TVP) module for bidirectional fusion of visual and trajectory signals; perform geometric simplification to extract semantic keypoints from raw trajectories; adopt a three‑stage training pipeline where trajectories supervise description generation and region localization; extend the framework to trajectory‑guided segmentation and video scene understanding (cross‑frame tracking, temporal attention); release the Reasoning-based Interactive Localized Narratives (RILN) dataset to support logical reasoning and interpretability.
AI.result: Across tasks—trajectory-guided captioning, text‑guided trajectory prediction, trajectory-aware understanding, and segmentation—TraceVision attains state-of-the-art performance. It demonstrates effective cross‑frame tracking, improved temporal attention analysis, and stronger grounding/interpretability compared to prior LVLMs.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating trajectory cues into LVLMs yields more interpretable, spatially grounded vision‑language reasoning. TraceVision offers a unified, extensible approach that supports fine-grained interaction, segmentation, and video analysis, with the RILN dataset further enabling reasoning‑centric, explainable evaluation.

title: Open-vocabulary 3D scene perception in industrial environments
summary: Autonomous vision applications in production, intralogistics, or manufacturing environments require perception capabilities beyond a small, fixed set of classes. Recent open-vocabulary methods, leveraging 2D Vision-Language Foundation Models (VLFMs), target this task but often rely on class-agnostic segmentation models pre-trained on non-industrial datasets (e.g., household scenes). In this work, we first demonstrate that such models fail to generalize, performing poorly on common industrial objects. Therefore, we propose a training-free, open-vocabulary 3D perception pipeline that overcomes this limitation. Instead of using a pre-trained model to generate instance proposals, our method simply generates masks by merging pre-computed superpoints based on their semantic features. Following, we evaluate the domain-adapted VLFM "IndustrialCLIP" on a representative 3D industrial workshop scene for open-vocabulary querying. Our qualitative results demonstrate successful segmentation of industrial objects.

AI.tldr: Training-free open-vocabulary 3D perception for industrial scenes: generate instance masks by merging semantic superpoints and query them with a domain-adapted VLFM (IndustrialCLIP), achieving successful industrial object segmentation where generic class-agnostic models fail.
AI.motivation: Industrial robotics/logistics require recognizing many object types beyond fixed taxonomies. Existing open-vocab pipelines depend on class-agnostic segmentation trained on household/non-industrial data, which fails to generalize to common industrial objects.
AI.method: Replace learned proposal generators with a training-free instance proposal stage: merge pre-computed 3D superpoints using their semantic features to form masks; then apply a domain-adapted vision-language model (IndustrialCLIP) for open-vocabulary querying/labeling in 3D scenes.
AI.result: Demonstrates, qualitatively on a representative 3D industrial workshop, that the approach segments industrial objects effectively, while standard class-agnostic models underperform. No quantitative metrics reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: A simple, training-free superpoint-merging pipeline combined with a domain-adapted VLFM enables open-vocabulary 3D perception in industrial environments and overcomes poor generalization of non-industrial pretraining; suggests the value of domain adaptation and proposal-free segmentation strategies for industrial perception.

title: TextShield-R1: Reinforced Reasoning for Tampered Text Detection
summary: The growing prevalence of tampered images poses serious security threats, highlighting the urgent need for reliable detection methods. Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) demonstrate strong potential in analyzing tampered images and generating interpretations. However, they still struggle with identifying micro-level artifacts, exhibit low accuracy in localizing tampered text regions, and heavily rely on expensive annotations for forgery interpretation. To this end, we introduce TextShield-R1, the first reinforcement learning based MLLM solution for tampered text detection and reasoning. Specifically, our approach introduces Forensic Continual Pre-training, an easy-to-hard curriculum that well prepares the MLLM for tampered text detection by harnessing the large-scale cheap data from natural image forensic and OCR tasks. During fine-tuning, we perform Group Relative Policy Optimization with novel reward functions to reduce annotation dependency and improve reasoning capabilities. At inference time, we enhance localization accuracy via OCR Rectification, a method that leverages the MLLM's strong text recognition abilities to refine its predictions. Furthermore, to support rigorous evaluation, we introduce the Text Forensics Reasoning (TFR) benchmark, comprising over 45k real and tampered images across 16 languages, 10 tampering techniques, and diverse domains. Rich reasoning-style annotations are included, allowing for comprehensive assessment. Our TFR benchmark simultaneously addresses seven major limitations of existing benchmarks and enables robust evaluation under cross-style, cross-method, and cross-language conditions. Extensive experiments demonstrate that TextShield-R1 significantly advances the state of the art in interpretable tampered text detection.

AI.tldr: TextShield-R1 is an RL-driven multimodal LLM for detecting and reasoning about tampered text in images. It uses a curriculum pretraining on cheap forensic/OCR data, GRPO with novel rewards to cut annotation needs and boost reasoning, OCR-guided rectification at inference for better localization, and introduces the large, multilingual TFR benchmark. It achieves state-of-the-art interpretable tampered text detection and localization.
AI.motivation: Tampered images are a growing security risk. While MLLMs can interpret images, they struggle with micro-level artifacts, have poor localization of manipulated text, and require costly annotations for training and evaluation. Existing benchmarks are limited in language, manipulation styles, and reasoning annotations.
AI.method: 1) Forensic Continual Pre-training: an easy-to-hard curriculum leveraging large-scale, low-cost data from natural image forensics and OCR to prime the MLLM for tampered text detection. 2) Fine-tuning with Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) and tailored reward functions to reduce annotation dependence and enhance reasoning. 3) Inference-time OCR Rectification to exploit the model’s text recognition for refining tamper localization. 4) Creation of the Text Forensics Reasoning (TFR) benchmark with 45k+ real/tampered images across 16 languages and 10 tampering techniques, with rich reasoning-style annotations.
AI.result: TextShield-R1 delivers significant gains over prior art in interpretable tampered text detection, with improved localization accuracy, stronger reasoning, reduced reliance on expensive labels, and robust performance across styles, methods, and languages on the new TFR benchmark.
AI.conclusion: A reinforcement learning framework combined with curriculum pretraining and OCR-guided rectification substantially advances tampered text detection and reasoning. The TFR benchmark fills key gaps in evaluation, enabling comprehensive, multilingual, and cross-method assessment while establishing new state-of-the-art performance.

title: M3S-Net: Multimodal Feature Fusion Network Based on Multi-scale Data for Ultra-short-term PV Power Forecasting
summary: The inherent intermittency and high-frequency variability of solar irradiance, particularly during rapid cloud advection, present significant stability challenges to high-penetration photovoltaic grids. Although multimodal forecasting has emerged as a viable mitigation strategy, existing architectures predominantly rely on shallow feature concatenation and binary cloud segmentation, thereby failing to capture the fine-grained optical features of clouds and the complex spatiotemporal coupling between visual and meteorological modalities. To bridge this gap, this paper proposes M3S-Net, a novel multimodal feature fusion network based on multi-scale data for ultra-short-term PV power forecasting. First, a multi-scale partial channel selection network leverages partial convolutions to explicitly isolate the boundary features of optically thin clouds, effectively transcending the precision limitations of coarse-grained binary masking. Second, a multi-scale sequence to image analysis network employs Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)-based time-frequency representation to disentangle the complex periodicity of meteorological data across varying time horizons. Crucially, the model incorporates a cross-modal Mamba interaction module featuring a novel dynamic C-matrix swapping mechanism. By exchanging state-space parameters between visual and temporal streams, this design conditions the state evolution of one modality on the context of the other, enabling deep structural coupling with linear computational complexity, thus overcoming the limitations of shallow concatenation. Experimental validation on the newly constructed fine-grained PV power dataset demonstrates that M3S-Net achieves a mean absolute error reduction of 6.2% in 10-minute forecasts compared to state-of-the-art baselines. The dataset and source code will be available at https://github.com/she1110/FGPD.

AI.tldr: M3S-Net is a multimodal, multi-scale PV power forecaster that fuses sky images and meteorological time series via partial-convolutional cloud-boundary extraction, FFT-based time–frequency encoding, and a cross-modal Mamba module with dynamic C-matrix swapping, achieving a 6.2% MAE reduction for 10-minute forecasts on a new fine-grained dataset.
AI.motivation: High-penetration PV grids suffer from rapid, cloud-driven irradiance fluctuations. Existing multimodal forecasters mainly do shallow feature concatenation and coarse binary cloud masks, missing thin-cloud optics and deep visual–meteorological coupling needed for stable ultra-short-term forecasting.
AI.method: Three key components: (1) Multi-scale partial channel selection network uses partial convolutions to isolate thin-cloud boundary features beyond binary masks. (2) Multi-scale sequence-to-image analysis converts meteorological time series into FFT-based time–frequency images to separate periodicities across horizons. (3) Cross-modal Mamba interaction with dynamic C-matrix swapping exchanges state-space parameters between visual and temporal streams, conditioning each modality’s state evolution on the other with linear computational complexity; overall end-to-end multimodal fusion for 10-minute PV forecasts.
AI.result: On a newly built fine-grained PV power dataset, M3S-Net reduces MAE by 6.2% for 10-minute ahead forecasts versus state-of-the-art baselines; code and data to be released at the provided repository.
AI.conclusion: Fine-grained cloud optics modeling plus deep, efficient cross-modal coupling improves ultra-short-term PV forecasting over prior multimodal approaches. The design offers linear-complexity fusion and demonstrates state-of-the-art accuracy, with resources to support reproducibility.

title: DerMAE: Improving skin lesion classification through conditioned latent diffusion and MAE distillation
summary: Skin lesion classification datasets often suffer from severe class imbalance, with malignant cases significantly underrepresented, leading to biased decision boundaries during deep learning training. We address this challenge using class-conditioned diffusion models to generate synthetic dermatological images, followed by self-supervised MAE pretraining to enable huge ViT models to learn robust, domain-relevant features. To support deployment in practical clinical settings, where lightweight models are required, we apply knowledge distillation to transfer these representations to a smaller ViT student suitable for mobile devices. Our results show that MAE pretraining on synthetic data, combined with distillation, improves classification performance while enabling efficient on-device inference for practical clinical use.

AI.tldr: Use class-conditioned diffusion to synthesize minority-class skin lesion images, pretrain a large ViT with MAE on this synthetic data, then distill to a small ViT for mobile deployment—yielding better classification and efficient on-device inference.
AI.motivation: Skin lesion datasets are heavily imbalanced, especially lacking malignant cases, which biases deep models. Clinics also need compact models that run on-device, so methods must both mitigate imbalance and produce deployable models.
AI.method: (1) Generate class-balanced synthetic dermatology images with class-conditioned diffusion models; (2) Pretrain a large ViT using self-supervised MAE on the (synthetic) domain data to learn robust features; (3) Distill knowledge from the large MAE-pretrained teacher to a smaller ViT student suitable for mobile devices.
AI.result: Compared to baselines without this pipeline, classification performance improves when using MAE pretraining on synthetic data, and the distilled student enables efficient on-device inference. (No specific metrics provided in the abstract.)
AI.conclusion: Combining synthetic data from diffusion models, MAE pretraining, and knowledge distillation effectively addresses class imbalance while yielding lightweight, clinically practical skin lesion classifiers.

title: Contrastive meta-domain adaptation for robust skin lesion classification across clinical and acquisition conditions
summary: Deep learning models for dermatological image analysis remain sensitive to acquisition variability and domain-specific visual characteristics, leading to performance degradation when deployed in clinical settings. We investigate how visual artifacts and domain shifts affect deep learning-based skin lesion classification. We propose an adaptation strategy, grounded in the idea of visual meta-domains, that transfers visual representations from larger dermoscopic datasets into clinical image domains, thereby improving generalization robustness. Experiments across multiple dermatology datasets show consistent gains in classification performance and reduced gaps between dermoscopic and clinical images. These results emphasize the importance of domain-aware training for deployable systems.

AI.tldr: They study domain shift in dermatology imaging and introduce a visual meta-domain adaptation strategy that transfers representations from large dermoscopic data to clinical images, yielding more robust skin-lesion classification and narrowing dermoscopic–clinical performance gaps.
AI.motivation: Deep models for skin-lesion analysis degrade when moving from controlled dermoscopic images to variable clinical photos due to acquisition artifacts and domain-specific visual differences; robust, deployable performance requires addressing these shifts.
AI.method: A domain-aware training approach based on visual meta-domains that learns and transfers visual representations from large dermoscopic datasets into clinical-image domains to improve generalization (i.e., a representation transfer/adaptation strategy across related but visually distinct domains).
AI.result: Across multiple dermatology datasets, the approach consistently improves classification accuracy and reduces the performance disparity between dermoscopic and clinical images.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating domain-aware, meta-domain-driven adaptation meaningfully enhances robustness and is key for real-world deployment of dermatology image classifiers.

title: Brewing Stronger Features: Dual-Teacher Distillation for Multispectral Earth Observation
summary: Foundation models are transforming Earth Observation (EO), yet the diversity of EO sensors and modalities makes a single universal model unrealistic. Multiple specialized EO foundation models (EOFMs) will likely coexist, making efficient knowledge transfer across modalities essential. Most existing EO pretraining relies on masked image modeling, which emphasizes local reconstruction but provides limited control over global semantic structure. To address this, we propose a dual-teacher contrastive distillation framework for multispectral imagery that aligns the student's pretraining objective with the contrastive self-distillation paradigm of modern optical vision foundation models (VFMs). Our approach combines a multispectral teacher with an optical VFM teacher, enabling coherent cross-modal representation learning. Experiments across diverse optical and multispectral benchmarks show that our model adapts to multispectral data without compromising performance on optical-only inputs, achieving state-of-the-art results in both settings, with an average improvement of 3.64 percentage points in semantic segmentation, 1.2 in change detection, and 1.31 in classification tasks. This demonstrates that contrastive distillation provides a principled and efficient approach to scalable representation learning across heterogeneous EO data sources. Project page: \textcolor{magenta}{https://wolfilip.github.io/DEO/}.

AI.tldr: They introduce a dual-teacher contrastive distillation framework that transfers knowledge from an optical vision foundation model and a multispectral teacher to a student model, yielding state-of-the-art multispectral and optical EO performance and demonstrating scalable cross-modal representation learning.
AI.motivation: EO will comprise multiple specialized foundation models due to heterogeneous sensors and modalities, so efficient knowledge transfer across modalities is crucial. Existing masked image modeling pretraining emphasizes local reconstruction and lacks control over global semantics, motivating a contrastive, semantics-aligned objective compatible with modern optical VFMs.
AI.method: A dual-teacher contrastive self-distillation scheme for multispectral imagery: the student is trained to align with both a multispectral teacher and an optical vision foundation model teacher, enforcing coherent cross-modal embeddings and aligning the student’s pretraining objective with contrastive paradigms used in optical VFMs.
AI.result: Across diverse optical and multispectral benchmarks, the student adapts to multispectral data without sacrificing optical-only performance, achieving SOTA with average gains of +3.64 pp in semantic segmentation, +1.2 pp in change detection, and +1.31 pp in classification.
AI.conclusion: Contrastive distillation with dual teachers is a principled and efficient way to unify and scale representation learning across heterogeneous EO sources, enabling effective cross-modal transfer while preserving performance on individual modalities.

title: ApET: Approximation-Error Guided Token Compression for Efficient VLMs
summary: Recent Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have demonstrated remarkable multimodal understanding capabilities, yet the redundant visual tokens incur prohibitive computational overhead and degrade inference efficiency. Prior studies typically relies on [CLS] attention or text-vision cross-attention to identify and discard redundant visual tokens. Despite promising results, such solutions are prone to introduce positional bias and, more critically, are incompatible with efficient attention kernels such as FlashAttention, limiting their practical deployment for VLM acceleration. In this paper, we step away from attention dependencies and revisit visual token compression from an information-theoretic perspective, aiming to maximally preserve visual information without any attention involvement. We present ApET, an Approximation-Error guided Token compression framework. ApET first reconstructs the original visual tokens with a small set of basis tokens via linear approximation, then leverages the approximation error to identify and drop the least informative tokens. Extensive experiments across multiple VLMs and benchmarks demonstrate that ApET retains 95.2% of the original performance on image-understanding tasks and even attains 100.4% on video-understanding tasks, while compressing the token budgets by 88.9% and 87.5%, respectively. Thanks to its attention-free design, ApET seamlessly integrates with FlashAttention, enabling further inference acceleration and making VLM deployment more practical. Code is available at https://github.com/MaQianKun0/ApET.

AI.tldr: ApET is an attention-free, information-theoretic visual token compression method that linearly approximates visual tokens with a small basis and prunes tokens using approximation error, achieving ~89% token reduction while largely preserving (or slightly improving) VLM accuracy and remaining compatible with FlashAttention for faster inference.
AI.motivation: VLMs suffer from redundant visual tokens that slow inference. Prior pruning relies on [CLS] or cross-attention importance, which can induce positional bias and breaks compatibility with efficient attention kernels like FlashAttention, limiting real-world acceleration.
AI.method: Construct a compact set of basis tokens to linearly reconstruct original visual tokens; compute per-token approximation error as an informativeness signal; drop tokens with low error (least informative). This compression is attention-free and can be plugged into VLMs without modifying attention, enabling use of FlashAttention.
AI.result: Across multiple VLMs and benchmarks, ApET keeps 95.2% of baseline performance on image tasks and 100.4% on video tasks while compressing token counts by 88.9% (image) and 87.5% (video). Its attention-free design allows seamless integration with FlashAttention for additional speedups.
AI.conclusion: Information-theoretic, attention-independent token pruning via approximation error is an effective and practical route for VLM acceleration, providing substantial token reduction with minimal or no accuracy loss and enabling deployment with modern efficient attention kernels.

title: BigMaQ: A Big Macaque Motion and Animation Dataset Bridging Image and 3D Pose Representations
summary: The recognition of dynamic and social behavior in animals is fundamental for advancing ethology, ecology, medicine and neuroscience. Recent progress in deep learning has enabled automated behavior recognition from video, yet an accurate reconstruction of the three-dimensional (3D) pose and shape has not been integrated into this process. Especially for non-human primates, mesh-based tracking efforts lag behind those for other species, leaving pose descriptions restricted to sparse keypoints that are unable to fully capture the richness of action dynamics. To address this gap, we introduce the $\textbf{Big Ma}$ca$\textbf{Q}$ue 3D Motion and Animation Dataset ($\texttt{BigMaQ}$), a large-scale dataset comprising more than 750 scenes of interacting rhesus macaques with detailed 3D pose descriptions. Extending previous surface-based animal tracking methods, we construct subject-specific textured avatars by adapting a high-quality macaque template mesh to individual monkeys. This allows us to provide pose descriptions that are more accurate than previous state-of-the-art surface-based animal tracking methods. From the original dataset, we derive BigMaQ500, an action recognition benchmark that links surface-based pose vectors to single frames across multiple individual monkeys. By pairing features extracted from established image and video encoders with and without our pose descriptors, we demonstrate substantial improvements in mean average precision (mAP) when pose information is included. With these contributions, $\texttt{BigMaQ}$ establishes the first dataset that both integrates dynamic 3D pose-shape representations into the learning task of animal action recognition and provides a rich resource to advance the study of visual appearance, posture, and social interaction in non-human primates. The code and data are publicly available at https://martinivis.github.io/BigMaQ/ .

AI.tldr: BigMaQ is a large-scale 3D mesh-based macaque dataset and benchmark that builds subject-specific avatars and links surface-based pose vectors to frames, yielding substantial action-recognition mAP gains over prior methods that rely on sparse keypoints.
AI.motivation: Automated behavior recognition in animals needs accurate, dynamic 3D pose-shape representations, which are lacking—especially for non-human primates where mesh-based tracking lags and keypoints fail to capture rich action dynamics.
AI.method: Construct a dataset (>750 scenes) of interacting rhesus macaques with detailed 3D pose and shape by adapting a high-quality macaque template mesh into subject-specific textured avatars; extend surface-based tracking; derive BigMaQ500, a benchmark linking surface-based pose vectors to single frames; evaluate action recognition by pairing standard image/video encoders with and without the new pose descriptors.
AI.result: Subject-specific mesh avatars provide more accurate pose descriptions than prior state-of-the-art surface-based tracking; incorporating the surface-based pose descriptors into encoders yields substantial improvements in mean average precision for action recognition across multiple individuals; code and data are publicly released.
AI.conclusion: BigMaQ is the first dataset to integrate dynamic 3D pose–shape into animal action recognition, offering a robust resource to study appearance, posture, and social interaction in non-human primates and enabling performance gains in behavior recognition tasks.

title: Monocular Mesh Recovery and Body Measurement of Female Saanen Goats
summary: The lactation performance of Saanen dairy goats, renowned for their high milk yield, is intrinsically linked to their body size, making accurate 3D body measurement essential for assessing milk production potential, yet existing reconstruction methods lack goat-specific authentic 3D data. To address this limitation, we establish the FemaleSaanenGoat dataset containing synchronized eight-view RGBD videos of 55 female Saanen goats (6-18 months). Using multi-view DynamicFusion, we fuse noisy, non-rigid point cloud sequences into high-fidelity 3D scans, overcoming challenges from irregular surfaces and rapid movement. Based on these scans, we develop SaanenGoat, a parametric 3D shape model specifically designed for female Saanen goats. This model features a refined template with 41 skeletal joints and enhanced udder representation, registered with our scan data. A comprehensive shape space constructed from 48 goats enables precise representation of diverse individual variations. With the help of SaanenGoat model, we get high-precision 3D reconstruction from single-view RGBD input, and achieve automated measurement of six critical body dimensions: body length, height, chest width, chest girth, hip width, and hip height. Experimental results demonstrate the superior accuracy of our method in both 3D reconstruction and body measurement, presenting a novel paradigm for large-scale 3D vision applications in precision livestock farming.

AI.tldr: They build the first goat-specific multi-view RGBD dataset and a parametric 3D shape model for female Saanen goats, enabling accurate single-view 3D reconstruction and automated body measurements critical for predicting milk production.
AI.motivation: Lactation performance in Saanen goats correlates with body size, so precise 3D body measurements are needed. Existing reconstruction methods lack authentic, goat-specific 3D data and struggle with non-rigid, fast-moving, irregular animal surfaces.
AI.method: 1) Collect FemaleSaanenGoat: synchronized 8-view RGBD videos of 55 female Saanen goats (6–18 months). 2) Use multi-view DynamicFusion to fuse non-rigid point cloud sequences into high-fidelity 3D scans. 3) Build SaanenGoat, a goat-specific parametric model with a refined template (41 skeletal joints, enhanced udder) registered to scans. 4) Learn a shape space from 48 goats to capture inter-individual variation. 5) Perform single-view RGBD reconstruction and automatically extract six body measurements (body length/height, chest width/girth, hip width/height).
AI.result: Produces high-fidelity 3D scans and achieves high-precision single-view reconstructions and automated measurements, outperforming alternatives in accuracy (exact numbers not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: A new dataset and parametric model tailored to Saanen goats enable accurate, scalable 3D reconstruction and measurement, advancing precision livestock farming and improving assessment of milk-production-related morphology.

title: ExpPortrait: Expressive Portrait Generation via Personalized Representation
summary: While diffusion models have shown great potential in portrait generation, generating expressive, coherent, and controllable cinematic portrait videos remains a significant challenge. Existing intermediate signals for portrait generation, such as 2D landmarks and parametric models, have limited disentanglement capabilities and cannot express personalized details due to their sparse or low-rank representation. Therefore, existing methods based on these models struggle to accurately preserve subject identity and expressions, hindering the generation of highly expressive portrait videos. To overcome these limitations, we propose a high-fidelity personalized head representation that more effectively disentangles expression and identity. This representation captures both static, subject-specific global geometry and dynamic, expression-related details. Furthermore, we introduce an expression transfer module to achieve personalized transfer of head pose and expression details between different identities. We use this sophisticated and highly expressive head model as a conditional signal to train a diffusion transformer (DiT)-based generator to synthesize richly detailed portrait videos. Extensive experiments on self- and cross-reenactment tasks demonstrate that our method outperforms previous models in terms of identity preservation, expression accuracy, and temporal stability, particularly in capturing fine-grained details of complex motion.

AI.tldr: A new personalized, high-fidelity head representation plus an expression‑transfer module conditions a DiT-based diffusion generator to produce portrait videos that better preserve identity, capture expressions, and remain temporally stable—especially on fine, complex motions—outperforming prior methods on self- and cross-reenactment.
AI.motivation: Existing intermediate controls (2D landmarks, parametric head models) are too sparse/low-rank to disentangle identity from expression or encode personalized details, causing identity drift, expression inaccuracy, and weak controllability in portrait video synthesis.
AI.method: Construct a high-fidelity, personalized head model that separates static, subject-specific global geometry from dynamic, expression-related details. Introduce an expression transfer module to personalize pose/expression transfer across identities. Use this rich head representation as the conditioning signal for a Diffusion Transformer (DiT)-based video generator.
AI.result: Across self- and cross-reenactment tasks, the method surpasses prior work in identity preservation, expression accuracy, and temporal stability, with notable gains on fine-grained details during complex motion.
AI.conclusion: Disentangling identity and expression via a personalized head representation, and conditioning a DiT generator on it, yields more expressive, coherent, and controllable cinematic portrait videos, improving reenactment fidelity and motion detail capture.

title: Gradient based Severity Labeling for Biomarker Classification in OCT
comment: Accepted at International Conference on Image Processing (ICIP) 2022
summary: In this paper, we propose a novel selection strategy for contrastive learning for medical images. On natural images, contrastive learning uses augmentations to select positive and negative pairs for the contrastive loss. However, in the medical domain, arbitrary augmentations have the potential to distort small localized regions that contain the biomarkers we are interested in detecting. A more intuitive approach is to select samples with similar disease severity characteristics, since these samples are more likely to have similar structures related to the progression of a disease. To enable this, we introduce a method that generates disease severity labels for unlabeled OCT scans on the basis of gradient responses from an anomaly detection algorithm. These labels are used to train a supervised contrastive learning setup to improve biomarker classification accuracy by as much as 6% above self-supervised baselines for key indicators of Diabetic Retinopathy.

AI.tldr: Replace augmentation-based pair selection with disease-severity–aware pairing for contrastive learning on OCT; create pseudo-severity labels from anomaly-detection gradients and train supervised contrastive embeddings, yielding up to 6% better DR biomarker classification than self-supervised baselines.
AI.motivation: Standard contrastive learning on natural images relies on heavy augmentations to define positives/negatives, but such transforms can corrupt small, localized medical biomarkers. A semantically grounded criterion—similar disease severity—should produce pairs that better preserve pathology-relevant structure.
AI.method: 1) Run an anomaly detection model on unlabeled OCT scans and derive gradient-based responses that correlate with pathology extent; 2) Convert these responses into pseudo disease-severity labels; 3) Use these labels in a supervised contrastive learning framework to select positives (similar severity) and negatives (different severity); 4) Train an embedding and evaluate it on downstream DR biomarker classification.
AI.result: Using severity-driven supervised contrastive learning improves biomarker classification accuracy by up to 6% over self-supervised contrastive baselines on key diabetic retinopathy indicators from OCT.
AI.conclusion: Severity-aware pair selection guided by anomaly-gradient pseudo-labels is an effective alternative to augmentation-based contrastive learning for medical imaging, producing embeddings that better capture disease-relevant structures and improving downstream diagnosis tasks.

title: Multi-Modal Representation Learning via Semi-Supervised Rate Reduction for Generalized Category Discovery
summary: Generalized Category Discovery (GCD) aims to identify both known and unknown categories, with only partial labels given for the known categories, posing a challenging open-set recognition problem. State-of-the-art approaches for GCD task are usually built on multi-modality representation learning, which is heavily dependent upon inter-modality alignment. However, few of them cast a proper intra-modality alignment to generate a desired underlying structure of representation distributions. In this paper, we propose a novel and effective multi-modal representation learning framework for GCD via Semi-Supervised Rate Reduction, called SSR$^2$-GCD, to learn cross-modality representations with desired structural properties based on emphasizing to properly align intra-modality relationships. Moreover, to boost knowledge transfer, we integrate prompt candidates by leveraging the inter-modal alignment offered by Vision Language Models. We conduct extensive experiments on generic and fine-grained benchmark datasets demonstrating superior performance of our approach.

AI.tldr: SSR^2-GCD is a multi-modal framework for generalized category discovery that uses semi-supervised rate reduction to enforce strong intra-modality alignment while leveraging vision–language prompts for inter-modal knowledge transfer, yielding state-of-the-art results on generic and fine-grained benchmarks.
AI.motivation: GCD must discover both known and unknown classes under partial labeling, an open-set challenge. Prior multi-modal methods emphasize inter-modality alignment but overlook shaping robust within-modality structure, leading to suboptimal, poorly clustered representations. The authors aim to induce better representation geometry to improve discovery and recognition.
AI.method: They propose SSR^2-GCD, a multi-modal representation learning framework driven by a Semi-Supervised Rate Reduction objective that explicitly aligns intra-modality relationships to produce compact, separable structures. For knowledge transfer across modalities, they incorporate prompt candidates derived from vision–language models to exploit inter-modal alignment. The approach jointly learns from partial labels and unlabeled data.
AI.result: Across generic and fine-grained benchmarks, SSR^2-GCD consistently outperforms state-of-the-art GCD methods. The gains suggest improved clustering/separation and better handling of both known and unknown categories; specific numbers are not provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: Balancing intra-modality alignment (via SSR^2) with inter-modal guidance (via VLM prompts) yields cross-modal representations with desirable structure, improving open-set discovery under partial labels. The framework is effective and general across datasets, indicating a promising direction for GCD.

title: Augmented Radiance Field: A General Framework for Enhanced Gaussian Splatting
summary: Due to the real-time rendering performance, 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has emerged as the leading method for radiance field reconstruction. However, its reliance on spherical harmonics for color encoding inherently limits its ability to separate diffuse and specular components, making it challenging to accurately represent complex reflections. To address this, we propose a novel enhanced Gaussian kernel that explicitly models specular effects through view-dependent opacity. Meanwhile, we introduce an error-driven compensation strategy to improve rendering quality in existing 3DGS scenes. Our method begins with 2D Gaussian initialization and then adaptively inserts and optimizes enhanced Gaussian kernels, ultimately producing an augmented radiance field. Experiments demonstrate that our method not only surpasses state-of-the-art NeRF methods in rendering performance but also achieves greater parameter efficiency. Project page at: https://xiaoxinyyx.github.io/augs.

AI.tldr: They augment 3D Gaussian Splatting with a specular-aware Gaussian kernel using view-dependent opacity and an error-driven compensation step, yielding better handling of reflections and higher efficiency than prior NeRF methods.
AI.motivation: Standard 3DGS uses spherical harmonics for color, which poorly disentangles diffuse and specular components, limiting fidelity for complex, view-dependent reflections.
AI.method: Start from 2D Gaussian initialization, then adaptively insert and optimize enhanced Gaussian kernels whose opacity varies with view to model specular effects. An error-driven compensation strategy further refines and boosts quality for existing 3DGS scenes, producing an augmented radiance field.
AI.result: Experiments show improved rendering quality on specular scenes, surpassing state-of-the-art NeRF methods in performance while using fewer parameters (greater parameter efficiency).
AI.conclusion: Explicitly modeling specularities via view-dependent opacity within 3DGS enhances reflective realism without sacrificing speed, suggesting a practical, efficient path to high-fidelity, real-time radiance fields and a retrofit path to upgrade existing 3DGS reconstructions.

title: Learning Positive-Incentive Point Sampling in Neural Implicit Fields for Object Pose Estimation
summary: Learning neural implicit fields of 3D shapes is a rapidly emerging field that enables shape representation at arbitrary resolutions. Due to the flexibility, neural implicit fields have succeeded in many research areas, including shape reconstruction, novel view image synthesis, and more recently, object pose estimation. Neural implicit fields enable learning dense correspondences between the camera space and the object's canonical space-including unobserved regions in camera space-significantly boosting object pose estimation performance in challenging scenarios like highly occluded objects and novel shapes. Despite progress, predicting canonical coordinates for unobserved camera-space regions remains challenging due to the lack of direct observational signals. This necessitates heavy reliance on the model's generalization ability, resulting in high uncertainty. Consequently, densely sampling points across the entire camera space may yield inaccurate estimations that hinder the learning process and compromise performance. To alleviate this problem, we propose a method combining an SO(3)-equivariant convolutional implicit network and a positive-incentive point sampling (PIPS) strategy.
