The SO(3)-equivariant convolutional implicit network estimates point-level attributes with SO(3)-equivariance at arbitrary query locations, demonstrating superior performance compared to most existing baselines. The PIPS strategy dynamically determines sampling locations based on the input, thereby boosting the network's accuracy and training efficiency. Our method outperforms the state-of-the-art on three pose estimation datasets. Notably, it demonstrates significant improvements in challenging scenarios, such as objects captured with unseen pose, high occlusion, novel geometry, and severe noise.

AI.tldr: They propose a pose-estimation approach that fuses an SO(3)-equivariant convolutional implicit network with an adaptive sampling scheme (PIPS) to reliably predict canonical coordinates from sparse/occluded views, achieving state-of-the-art results and better robustness to occlusion, unseen poses, novel shapes, and noise.
AI.motivation: Neural implicit fields can learn dense correspondences between camera and canonical spaces and thus help pose estimation, but predicting canonical coordinates in unobserved camera-space regions lacks direct supervision, causing high uncertainty. Uniformly sampling the whole space amplifies these errors and slows/harms training, motivating a rotation-aware model and input-adaptive sampling to reduce uncertainty and focus learning where it matters.
AI.method: 1) An SO(3)-equivariant convolutional implicit network that outputs point-level attributes at arbitrary 3D query locations while respecting rotational symmetries, improving generalization. 2) Positive-Incentive Point Sampling (PIPS), which dynamically selects informative query locations conditioned on the input to emphasize reliable/beneficial points, improving accuracy and training efficiency. Together, they learn canonical correspondences more robustly, including for unobserved regions.
AI.result: Across three pose-estimation benchmarks, the method surpasses prior state-of-the-art. Gains are especially large under challenging conditions: unseen object poses, heavy occlusion, novel geometries, and strong noise. (Abstract reports qualitative/relative improvements; no exact metrics provided.)
AI.conclusion: Coupling SO(3)-equivariant implicit modeling with adaptive, incentive-driven sampling reduces uncertainty in unobserved regions and streamlines training, yielding more accurate, robust, and generalizable 6D pose estimation. The approach underscores the value of rotational equivariance and data-dependent sampling for neural implicit correspondence learning.

title: Discover, Segment, and Select: A Progressive Mechanism for Zero-shot Camouflaged Object Segmentation
summary: Current zero-shot Camouflaged Object Segmentation methods typically employ a two-stage pipeline (discover-then-segment): using MLLMs to obtain visual prompts, followed by SAM segmentation. However, relying solely on MLLMs for camouflaged object discovery often leads to inaccurate localization, false positives, and missed detections. To address these issues, we propose the \textbf{D}iscover-\textbf{S}egment-\textbf{S}elect (\textbf{DSS}) mechanism, a progressive framework designed to refine segmentation step by step. The proposed method contains a Feature-coherent Object Discovery (FOD) module that leverages visual features to generate diverse object proposals, a segmentation module that refines these proposals through SAM segmentation, and a Semantic-driven Mask Selection (SMS) module that employs MLLMs to evaluate and select the optimal segmentation mask from multiple candidates. Without requiring any training or supervision, DSS achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple COS benchmarks, especially in multiple-instance scenes.

AI.tldr: Training-free, progressive Discover–Segment–Select pipeline for zero-shot camouflaged object segmentation that combines feature-based proposal discovery, SAM refinement, and MLLM-driven semantic mask selection to surpass prior methods, especially in multi-instance scenes.
AI.motivation: Prior zero-shot COS pipelines depend on MLLMs to localize objects before SAM segmentation, which often causes mislocalization, false positives, and missed detections—issues amplified in complex or multi-instance scenarios. A more reliable, training-free approach is needed to robustly identify camouflaged objects without supervision.
AI.method: DSS comprises three stages: (1) Feature-coherent Object Discovery (FOD) generates diverse object proposals from visual features; (2) a segmentation stage refines each proposal using SAM; (3) Semantic-driven Mask Selection (SMS) uses MLLMs to evaluate semantic plausibility and select the best mask among candidates. The pipeline is fully zero-shot and requires no additional training.
AI.result: Without any training or supervision, DSS achieves state-of-the-art performance across multiple camouflaged object segmentation benchmarks, with notable gains in multi-instance scenes.
AI.conclusion: By shifting MLLMs from noisy discovery to semantic selection and introducing feature-based discovery plus SAM refinement, DSS mitigates localization errors and improves robustness, yielding SOTA zero-shot COS and highlighting a general, training-free strategy for challenging object discovery-segmentation tasks.

title: RL-RIG: A Generative Spatial Reasoner via Intrinsic Reflection
summary: Recent advancements in image generation have achieved impressive results in producing high-quality images. However, existing image generation models still generally struggle with a spatial reasoning dilemma, lacking the ability to accurately capture fine-grained spatial relationships from the prompt and correctly generate scenes with structural integrity. To mitigate this dilemma, we propose RL-RIG, a Reinforcement Learning framework for Reflection-based Image Generation. Our architecture comprises four primary components: Diffuser, Checker, Actor, and Inverse Diffuser, following a Generate-Reflect-Edit paradigm to spark the Chain of Thought reasoning ability in image generation for addressing the dilemma. To equip the model with better intuition over generation trajectories, we further develop Reflection-GRPO to train the VLM Actor for edit prompts and the Image Editor for better image quality under a given prompt, respectively. Unlike traditional approaches that solely produce visually stunning yet structurally unreasonable content, our evaluation metrics prioritize spatial accuracy, utilizing Scene Graph IoU and employing a VLM-as-a-Judge strategy to assess the spatial consistency of generated images on LAION-SG dataset. Experimental results show that RL-RIG outperforms existing state-of-the-art open-source models by up to 11% in terms of controllable and precise spatial reasoning in image generation.

AI.tldr: RL-RIG introduces a Generate–Reflect–Edit reinforcement learning framework that trains a VLM “Actor” and an image editor to iteratively correct spatial relations in generated images, yielding up to 11% better spatial accuracy on LAION-SG.
AI.motivation: State-of-the-art image generators often fail at fine-grained spatial reasoning—objects’ relative positions, relations, and structural coherence—producing visually appealing but spatially inconsistent scenes. The paper aims to make generation controllable and spatially precise.
AI.method: A four-module system: Diffuser (initial image), Checker (assesses spatial consistency), Actor (a VLM that proposes targeted edit prompts), and Inverse Diffuser (applies edits). These operate in a Generate–Reflect–Edit loop. Training uses Reflection-GRPO (an RL variant) to optimize both the VLM Actor and the Image Editor under rewards that emphasize spatial accuracy. Evaluation prioritizes spatial metrics (Scene Graph IoU) and uses a VLM-as-a-Judge for spatial consistency.
AI.result: On the LAION-SG dataset, RL-RIG outperforms open-source state-of-the-art baselines by up to 11% in controllable, precise spatial reasoning, as measured by Scene Graph IoU and VLM-judge assessments.
AI.conclusion: Reflection-driven RL for image generation improves structural integrity and spatial alignment versus traditional, aesthetics-focused methods, indicating that iterative reasoning and RL optimization can meaningfully enhance spatial controllability in generative models.

title: RADE-Net: Robust Attention Network for Radar-Only Object Detection in Adverse Weather
comment: Accepted to 2026 IEEE Intelligent Vehicles Symposium (IV)
summary: Automotive perception systems are obligated to meet high requirements. While optical sensors such as Camera and Lidar struggle in adverse weather conditions, Radar provides a more robust perception performance, effectively penetrating fog, rain, and snow. Since full Radar tensors have large data sizes and very few datasets provide them, most Radar-based approaches work with sparse point clouds or 2D projections, which can result in information loss. Additionally, deep learning methods show potential to extract richer and more dense features from low level Radar data and therefore significantly increase the perception performance. Therefore, we propose a 3D projection method for fast-Fourier-transformed 4D Range-Azimuth-Doppler-Elevation (RADE) tensors. Our method preserves rich Doppler and Elevation features while reducing the required data size for a single frame by 91.9% compared to a full tensor, thus achieving higher training and inference speed as well as lower model complexity. We introduce RADE-Net, a lightweight model tailored to 3D projections of the RADE tensor. The backbone enables exploitation of low-level and high-level cues of Radar tensors with spatial and channel-attention. The decoupled detection heads predict object center-points directly in the Range-Azimuth domain and regress rotated 3D bounding boxes from rich feature maps in the cartesian scene. We evaluate the model on scenes with multiple different road users and under various weather conditions on the large-scale K-Radar dataset and achieve a 16.7% improvement compared to their baseline, as well as 6.5% improvement over current Radar-only models. Additionally, we outperform several Lidar approaches in scenarios with adverse weather conditions. The code is available under https://github.com/chr-is-tof/RADE-Net.

AI.tldr: They introduce a compact 3D projection of 4D Radar Range–Azimuth–Doppler–Elevation (RADE) tensors and a lightweight RADE-Net detector that preserves Doppler and elevation cues while shrinking data ~92%, yielding faster, more accurate radar-only 3D detection that beats radar baselines and some LiDAR models in bad weather.
AI.motivation: Optical sensors underperform in adverse weather and existing radar pipelines often down-project to sparse points or 2D views, losing rich Doppler/elevation information. Full radar tensors are large and rarely available, hindering efficient learning and deployment. A method is needed to retain informative low-level radar cues while controlling data volume and model complexity.
AI.method: Propose a 3D projection for FFT-processed 4D RADE tensors that retains Doppler and elevation information with major size reduction. Design RADE-Net, a lightweight architecture with spatial and channel attention to fuse low- and high-level radar cues. Use decoupled heads: (1) predict object center points in the Range–Azimuth domain and (2) regress rotated 3D boxes from Cartesian feature maps. This reduces memory/computation and accelerates training/inference.
AI.result: On the large-scale K-Radar dataset across diverse road users and weather, the approach reduces per-frame data by 91.9% and achieves +16.7% over the dataset’s baseline and +6.5% over current radar-only models. It also surpasses several LiDAR approaches in adverse weather.
AI.conclusion: Compact RADE 3D projection plus RADE-Net enables efficient, weather-robust radar-only 3D detection with improved accuracy, speed, and lower complexity. The approach preserves crucial Doppler/elevation cues despite compression and shows practical advantages over both radar and some LiDAR baselines; code is released for reproducibility.

title: Token-UNet: A New Case for Transformers Integration in Efficient and Interpretable 3D UNets for Brain Imaging Segmentation
summary:
We present Token-UNet, adopting the TokenLearner and TokenFuser modules to encase Transformers into UNets.
  While Transformers have enabled global interactions among input elements in medical imaging, current computational challenges hinder their deployment on common hardware. Models like (Swin)UNETR adapt the UNet architecture by incorporating (Swin)Transformer encoders, which process tokens that each represent small subvolumes ($8^3$ voxels) of the input.
  The Transformer attention mechanism scales quadratically with the number of tokens, which is tied to the cubic scaling of 3D input resolution.
  This work reconsiders the role of convolution and attention, introducing Token-UNets, a family of 3D segmentation models that can operate in constrained computational environments and time frames.
  To mitigate computational demands, our approach maintains the convolutional encoder of UNet-like models, and applies TokenLearner to 3D feature maps. This module pools a preset number of tokens from local and global structures.
  Our results show this tokenization effectively encodes task-relevant information, yielding naturally interpretable attention maps. The memory footprint, computation times at inference, and parameter counts of our heaviest model are reduced to 33\%, 10\%, and 35\% of the SwinUNETR values, with better average performance (86.75\% $\pm 0.19\%$ Dice score for SwinUNETR vs our 87.21\% $\pm 0.35\%$).
  This work opens the way to more efficient trainings in contexts with limited computational resources, such as 3D medical imaging. Easing model optimization, fine-tuning, and transfer-learning in limited hardware settings can accelerate and diversify the development of approaches, for the benefit of the research community.

AI.tldr: Token-UNet integrates TokenLearner/TokenFuser within a UNet, keeping a convolutional encoder and attending over a compact set of learned tokens to capture global context. It cuts memory, inference compute, and parameters dramatically versus SwinUNETR while slightly improving Dice on 3D medical segmentation.
AI.motivation: 3D Transformers enable global interactions but are prohibitively expensive because attention scales quadratically with token count, which grows cubically with 3D resolution. Existing UNet+Transformer hybrids (e.g., SwinUNETR) are heavy for common hardware, limiting training, fine-tuning, and transfer learning in resource-constrained settings.
AI.method: Retain a UNet-like convolutional encoder; apply TokenLearner to 3D feature maps to pool a preset, compact set of informative tokens capturing local and global structures; apply attention on this reduced token set; use TokenFuser to inject/fuse token-derived global information back into the UNet pipeline for decoding. The family of Token-UNets targets constrained compute and time budgets.
AI.result: Tokenization yields interpretable attention maps and preserves task-relevant information. Compared to SwinUNETR, the heaviest Token-UNet cuts memory to 33%, inference computation time to 10%, and parameters to 35%, while improving average Dice from 86.75% ± 0.19% to 87.21% ± 0.35%.
AI.conclusion: Compact tokenization plus convolution enables globally aware yet efficient 3D segmentation. Token-UNets make training, optimization, fine-tuning, and transfer learning feasible on limited hardware, potentially accelerating and broadening progress in medical imaging research.

title: Closing the gap in multimodal medical representation alignment
summary: In multimodal learning, CLIP has emerged as the de-facto approach for mapping different modalities into a shared latent space by bringing semantically similar representations closer while pushing apart dissimilar ones. However, CLIP-based contrastive losses exhibit unintended behaviors that negatively impact true semantic alignment, leading to sparse and fragmented latent spaces. This phenomenon, known as the modality gap, has been partially mitigated for standard text and image pairs but remains unknown and unresolved in more complex multimodal settings, such as the medical domain. In this work, we study this phenomenon in the latter case, revealing that the modality gap is present also in medical alignment, and we propose a modality-agnostic framework that closes this gap, ensuring that semantically related representations are more aligned, regardless of their source modality. Our method enhances alignment between radiology images and clinical text, improving cross-modal retrieval and image captioning.

AI.tldr: The paper identifies a persistent “modality gap” in CLIP-style contrastive learning for medical multimodal data and proposes a modality-agnostic alignment framework that better unifies radiology images and clinical text, yielding gains in cross-modal retrieval and image captioning.
AI.motivation: CLIP’s contrastive objective can produce sparse, fragmented latent spaces where representations cluster by modality rather than meaning. While partially addressed for general image–text, this issue remains underexplored and unresolved in high-stakes, complex medical settings. Closing this gap is essential to achieve reliable semantic alignment for downstream tasks such as retrieval and captioning.
AI.method: Introduce a modality-agnostic alignment approach that explicitly reduces inter-modality discrepancies in the shared embedding space so semantically related samples align regardless of source modality; instantiated on radiology images and clinical narratives. The framework modifies/augments contrastive learning to densify and harmonize the joint space.
AI.result: Improved alignment between clinical text and radiology images with downstream performance gains in cross-modal retrieval and medical image captioning (details/metrics not provided in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: The modality gap affects medical multimodal learning; a modality-agnostic alignment strategy can mitigate it and enhance practical tasks, suggesting broader benefits for robust multimodal understanding in specialized domains.

title: Decoupling Defense Strategies for Robust Image Watermarking
summary: Deep learning-based image watermarking, while robust against conventional distortions, remains vulnerable to advanced adversarial and regeneration attacks. Conventional countermeasures, which jointly optimize the encoder and decoder via a noise layer, face 2 inevitable challenges: (1) decrease of clean accuracy due to decoder adversarial training and (2) limited robustness due to simultaneous training of all three advanced attacks. To overcome these issues, we propose AdvMark, a novel two-stage fine-tuning framework that decouples the defense strategies. In stage 1, we address adversarial vulnerability via a tailored adversarial training paradigm that primarily fine-tunes the encoder while only conditionally updating the decoder. This approach learns to move the image into a non-attackable region, rather than modifying the decision boundary, thus preserving clean accuracy. In stage 2, we tackle distortion and regeneration attacks via direct image optimization. To preserve the adversarial robustness gained in stage 1, we formulate a principled, constrained image loss with theoretical guarantees, which balances the deviation from cover and previous encoded images. We also propose a quality-aware early-stop to further guarantee the lower bound of visual quality. Extensive experiments demonstrate AdvMark outperforms with the highest image quality and comprehensive robustness, i.e. up to 29\%, 33\% and 46\% accuracy improvement for distortion, regeneration and adversarial attacks, respectively.

AI.tldr: AdvMark is a two‑stage fine‑tuning framework for deep image watermarking that decouples defenses: adversarial robustness is gained by mostly training the encoder, and robustness to distortions/regeneration is added via direct image optimization with a constrained loss and a quality‑aware early stop. It preserves clean accuracy and boosts robustness, achieving up to 29%, 33%, and 46% accuracy gains on distortion, regeneration, and adversarial attacks, respectively, while maintaining top image quality.
AI.motivation: Deep learning watermarking systems that survive common distortions fail against stronger adversarial and regeneration attacks. Existing joint encoder–decoder training with noise layers causes (i) reduced clean accuracy due to decoder adversarial training and (ii) limited robustness when forced to learn all advanced attacks at once. A method is needed that improves robustness without sacrificing clean performance or image quality.
AI.method: Two-stage decoupled defense. Stage 1: a tailored adversarial training scheme that primarily fine‑tunes the encoder and only conditionally updates the decoder, pushing watermarked images into non‑attackable regions instead of altering the decoder’s decision boundary, thereby preserving clean accuracy. Stage 2: direct image optimization to handle distortion and regeneration attacks using a principled constrained image loss (with theoretical guarantees) that balances deviations from the cover image and the stage‑1 encoded image, plus a quality‑aware early‑stopping criterion to ensure a lower bound on visual quality.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show AdvMark delivers the highest image quality and broad robustness, with accuracy improvements up to 29% for distortions, 33% for regeneration, and 46% for adversarial attacks compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling adversarial and distortion/regeneration defenses via encoder‑centric adversarial training and constrained image optimization preserves clean accuracy and visual quality while substantially improving robustness against diverse attacks.

title: MeanFuser: Fast One-Step Multi-Modal Trajectory Generation and Adaptive Reconstruction via MeanFlow for End-to-End Autonomous Driving
summary: Generative models have shown great potential in trajectory planning. Recent studies demonstrate that anchor-guided generative models are effective in modeling the uncertainty of driving behaviors and improving overall performance. However, these methods rely on discrete anchor vocabularies that must sufficiently cover the trajectory distribution during testing to ensure robustness, inducing an inherent trade-off between vocabulary size and model performance. To overcome this limitation, we propose MeanFuser, an end-to-end autonomous driving method that enhances both efficiency and robustness through three key designs. (1) We introduce Gaussian Mixture Noise (GMN) to guide generative sampling, enabling a continuous representation of the trajectory space and eliminating the dependency on discrete anchor vocabularies. (2) We adapt ``MeanFlow Identity" to end-to-end planning, which models the mean velocity field between GMN and trajectory distribution instead of the instantaneous velocity field used in vanilla flow matching methods, effectively eliminating numerical errors from ODE solvers and significantly accelerating inference. (3) We design a lightweight Adaptive Reconstruction Module (ARM) that enables the model to implicitly select from all sampled proposals or reconstruct a new trajectory when none is satisfactory via attention weights. Experiments on the NAVSIM closed-loop benchmark demonstrate that MeanFuser achieves outstanding performance without the supervision of the PDM Score. and exceptional inference efficiency, offering a robust and efficient solution for end-to-end autonomous driving. Our code and model are available at https://github.com/wjl2244/MeanFuser.

AI.tldr: MeanFuser is an end-to-end autonomous driving planner that replaces discrete anchor vocabularies with a continuous Gaussian Mixture Noise (GMN) prior for sampling, adopts a MeanFlow Identity to avoid ODE-solver errors and speed up inference, and adds an Adaptive Reconstruction Module (ARM) to select or reconstruct trajectories. It reports state-of-the-art closed-loop NAVSIM results and high efficiency without PDM Score supervision.
AI.motivation: Anchor-guided generative planners depend on a discrete set of trajectory anchors that must cover test-time behaviors. Ensuring coverage forces a trade-off: large vocabularies improve robustness but hurt efficiency and learning, while small vocabularies risk missing modes. The work aims to remove this dependency, improve robustness to distributional uncertainty, and accelerate inference.
AI.method: (1) Gaussian Mixture Noise (GMN) to guide generative sampling, providing a continuous representation of trajectory space and eliminating discrete anchors. (2) Adaptation of MeanFlow Identity to E2E planning: model the mean velocity field between the GMN prior and the trajectory distribution instead of the instantaneous flow, avoiding numerical ODE errors and accelerating inference. (3) A lightweight Adaptive Reconstruction Module (ARM) that attends over sampled proposals to pick the best or reconstruct a new trajectory if none suffices.
AI.result: On the NAVSIM closed-loop benchmark, MeanFuser achieves outstanding performance and exceptional inference efficiency, despite not using PDM Score supervision. Qualitatively, it is both robust and fast; quantitative details are not provided in the abstract but imply SOTA-level metrics.
AI.conclusion: A continuous-noise, mean-flow-matched, and adaptively reconstructive planner removes the anchor coverage bottleneck, improves robustness and speed, and delivers strong closed-loop performance. The approach is promising for practical E2E driving; code/models are released for reproducibility.

title: The Invisible Gorilla Effect in Out-of-distribution Detection
summary: Deep Neural Networks achieve high performance in vision tasks by learning features from regions of interest (ROI) within images, but their performance degrades when deployed on out-of-distribution (OOD) data that differs from training data. This challenge has led to OOD detection methods that aim to identify and reject unreliable predictions. Although prior work shows that OOD detection performance varies by artefact type, the underlying causes remain underexplored. To this end, we identify a previously unreported bias in OOD detection: for hard-to-detect artefacts (near-OOD), detection performance typically improves when the artefact shares visual similarity (e.g. colour) with the model's ROI and drops when it does not - a phenomenon we term the Invisible Gorilla Effect. For example, in a skin lesion classifier with red lesion ROI, we show the method Mahalanobis Score achieves a 31.5% higher AUROC when detecting OOD red ink (similar to ROI) compared to black ink (dissimilar) annotations. We annotated artefacts by colour in 11,355 images from three public datasets (e.g. ISIC) and generated colour-swapped counterfactuals to rule out dataset bias. We then evaluated 40 OOD methods across 7 benchmarks and found significant performance drops for most methods when artefacts differed from the ROI. Our findings highlight an overlooked failure mode in OOD detection and provide guidance for more robust detectors. Code and annotations are available at: https://github.com/HarryAnthony/Invisible_Gorilla_Effect.

AI.tldr: The paper uncovers a systematic bias in OOD detection—detectors perform better when artefacts visually resemble a model’s ROI and worse when they do not—demonstrated across datasets, methods, and with counterfactual controls (the Invisible Gorilla Effect).
AI.motivation: OOD detectors are crucial because model reliability collapses on distribution shifts, yet performance varies widely by artefact type without clear causal explanations. Understanding which artefacts evade detection—and why—matters for safe deployment, especially in safety‑critical vision domains like medical imaging.
AI.method: Annotate artefact colors in 11,355 images across three public datasets (e.g., ISIC); generate color-swapped counterfactuals to control for dataset bias; evaluate 40 OOD methods over 7 benchmarks, focusing on near-OOD artefacts that are hard to detect; use AUROC as the main metric and analyze dependence on similarity between artefact color and model ROI (e.g., red lesion ROI).
AI.result: Detection performance increases when artefacts share visual similarity (e.g., color) with the ROI and drops when they do not. Example: for a skin lesion classifier with red ROI, the Mahalanobis score yields 31.5% higher AUROC for red-ink (similar) versus black-ink (dissimilar) annotations. Across 7 benchmarks, most of 40 methods show significant drops when artefacts differ from the ROI; counterfactual color swaps rule out dataset-specific biases.
AI.conclusion: There is an overlooked failure mode in OOD detection: sensitivity is biased by ROI similarity. Many current detectors are unreliable for dissimilar near-OOD artefacts. The authors release code and annotations and argue for building and evaluating detectors that decouple OOD cues from ROI features, include diverse artefacts, and use counterfactual stress tests to improve robustness.

title: SemanticNVS: Improving Semantic Scene Understanding in Generative Novel View Synthesis
summary: We present SemanticNVS, a camera-conditioned multi-view diffusion model for novel view synthesis (NVS), which improves generation quality and consistency by integrating pre-trained semantic feature extractors. Existing NVS methods perform well for views near the input view, however, they tend to generate semantically implausible and distorted images under long-range camera motion, revealing severe degradation. We speculate that this degradation is due to current models failing to fully understand their conditioning or intermediate generated scene content. Here, we propose to integrate pre-trained semantic feature extractors to incorporate stronger scene semantics as conditioning to achieve high-quality generation even at distant viewpoints. We investigate two different strategies, (1) warped semantic features and (2) an alternating scheme of understanding and generation at each denoising step. Experimental results on multiple datasets demonstrate the clear qualitative and quantitative (4.69%-15.26% in FID) improvement over state-of-the-art alternatives.

AI.tldr: SemanticNVS is a camera-conditioned multi-view diffusion model for novel view synthesis that injects pre-trained semantic features into the generation process, yielding more consistent, semantically plausible images under large viewpoint changes and improving FID by 4.69%–15.26% over prior methods.
AI.motivation: Conventional NVS models work near the input view but break down under long-range camera motion, producing semantically implausible, distorted outputs—likely due to weak understanding of conditioning signals and intermediate scene content. Stronger semantic priors are needed to maintain coherence at distant viewpoints.
AI.method: Integrate pre-trained semantic feature extractors as conditioning within a diffusion-based, camera-conditioned multi-view NVS model. Two strategies are explored: (1) warping semantic features to target views using camera geometry to guide synthesis; (2) alternating, at each denoising step, between semantic understanding and image generation to iteratively inject semantic guidance.
AI.result: Across multiple datasets, the approach delivers clear qualitative gains and quantitative improvements, reporting 4.69%–15.26% FID reductions versus state-of-the-art baselines, with more stable, less distorted outputs for large viewpoint shifts.
AI.conclusion: Harnessing strong pre-trained semantic features within diffusion-based NVS stabilizes long-range view synthesis, improving both semantic fidelity and visual quality. The proposed conditioning schemes generalize across datasets and set a new performance bar for distant-view generation.

title: Do Large Language Models Understand Data Visualization Principles?
summary: Data visualization principles, derived from decades of research in design and perception, ensure proper visual communication. While prior work has shown that large language models (LLMs) can generate charts or flag misleading figures, it remains unclear whether they and their vision-language counterparts (VLMs) can reason about and enforce visualization principles directly. Constraint based systems encode these principles as logical rules for precise automated checks, but translating them into formal specifications demands expert knowledge. This motivates leveraging LLMs and VLMs as principle checkers that can reason about visual design directly, bypassing the need for symbolic rule specification. In this paper, we present the first systematic evaluation of both LLMs and VLMs on their ability to reason about visualization principles, using hard verification ground truth derived from Answer Set Programming (ASP). We compiled a set of visualization principles expressed as natural-language statements and generated a controlled dataset of approximately 2,000 Vega-Lite specifications annotated with explicit principle violations, complemented by over 300 real-world Vega-Lite charts. We evaluated both checking and fixing tasks, assessing how well models detect principle violations and correct flawed chart specifications. Our work highlights both the promise of large (vision-)language models as flexible validators and editors of visualization designs and the persistent gap with symbolic solvers on more nuanced aspects of visual perception. They also reveal an interesting asymmetry: frontier models tend to be more effective at correcting violations than at detecting them reliably.

AI.tldr: They benchmark LLMs and VLMs on enforcing visualization principles using ASP-derived ground truth over ~2k synthetic and 300 real Vega-Lite charts, finding models promising—especially at fixing violations—but still less reliable than symbolic solvers at detecting nuanced issues.
AI.motivation: Constraint-based checkers ensure visualization principles but require expert-crafted formal rules; it is unclear if LLMs/VLMs can directly reason about and enforce these principles without symbolic specifications.
AI.method: Translate visualization principles into natural language; generate a controlled dataset of ~2,000 Vega-Lite specs with explicit violations plus >300 real-world charts; derive hard verification ground truth via Answer Set Programming; evaluate models on two tasks—detecting violations and fixing flawed specs—comparing LLMs/VLMs to symbolic solvers.
AI.result: LLMs/VLMs function as flexible validators and editors but underperform symbolic solvers on nuanced perceptual principles; frontier models exhibit a marked asymmetry, being better at correcting violations than reliably detecting them.
AI.conclusion: Large (vision-)language models show promise for checking and editing visualization designs without formal rule encoding, yet they cannot fully replace symbolic methods; hybrid workflows and further research are needed, particularly to improve reliable detection of subtle principle violations.

title: Do Large Language Models Understand Data Visualization Rules?
summary: Data visualization rules-derived from decades of research in design and perception-ensure trustworthy chart communication. While prior work has shown that large language models (LLMs) can generate charts or flag misleading figures, it remains unclear whether they can reason about and enforce visualization rules directly. Constraint-based systems such as Draco encode these rules as logical constraints for precise automated checks, but maintaining symbolic encodings requires expert effort, motivating the use of LLMs as flexible rule validators. In this paper, we present the first systematic evaluation of LLMs against visualization rules using hard-verification ground truth derived from Answer Set Programming (ASP). We translated a subset of Draco's constraints into natural-language statements and generated a controlled dataset of 2,000 Vega-Lite specifications annotated with explicit rule violations. LLMs were evaluated on both accuracy in detecting violations and prompt adherence, which measures whether outputs follow the required structured format. Results show that frontier models achieve high adherence (Gemma 3 4B / 27B: 100%, GPT-oss 20B: 98%) and reliably detect common violations (F1 up to 0.82),yet performance drops for subtler perceptual rules (F1 < 0.15 for some categories) and for outputs generated from technical ASP formulations.Translating constraints into natural language improved performance by up to 150% for smaller models. These findings demonstrate the potential of LLMs as flexible, language-driven validators while highlighting their current limitations compared to symbolic solvers.

AI.tldr: First systematic test of LLMs as validators of data-visualization rules shows they follow structured prompts well and can catch common rule violations, but they struggle with subtle perceptual constraints and technical ASP formulations; natural-language rule translations help, especially for small models.
AI.motivation: Symbolic, constraint-based systems (e.g., Draco) accurately enforce visualization rules but are costly to author and maintain. It is unclear whether LLMs can directly reason about and enforce these rules, motivating an evaluation of LLMs as flexible, language-driven rule validators.
AI.method: Translate a subset of Draco’s ASP-encoded constraints into natural language; create a controlled dataset of 2,000 Vega-Lite specs with explicit rule violations; evaluate multiple LLMs on (1) violation detection accuracy (F1) and (2) prompt adherence (structured output compliance); compare performance on NL-translated vs technical ASP-formulated constraints.
AI.result: Frontier models exhibit near-perfect prompt adherence (Gemma 3 4B/27B: 100%; GPT-oss 20B: 98%). They reliably detect common violations (F1 up to 0.82) but perform poorly on subtler perceptual rules (some categories F1 < 0.15) and when judging from technical ASP formulations. Translating constraints into natural language boosts performance, by up to 150% for smaller models.
AI.conclusion: LLMs show promise as flexible validators for visualization rules but are not yet substitutes for symbolic solvers on nuanced perceptual constraints. Natural-language formulations substantially aid performance, suggesting value in hybrid pipelines and improved reasoning for subtle, perception-driven rules.

title: Flow3r: Factored Flow Prediction for Scalable Visual Geometry Learning
summary: Current feed-forward 3D/4D reconstruction systems rely on dense geometry and pose supervision -- expensive to obtain at scale and particularly scarce for dynamic real-world scenes. We present Flow3r, a framework that augments visual geometry learning with dense 2D correspondences (`flow') as supervision, enabling scalable training from unlabeled monocular videos. Our key insight is that the flow prediction module should be factored: predicting flow between two images using geometry latents from one and pose latents from the other. This factorization directly guides the learning of both scene geometry and camera motion, and naturally extends to dynamic scenes. In controlled experiments, we show that factored flow prediction outperforms alternative designs and that performance scales consistently with unlabeled data. Integrating factored flow into existing visual geometry architectures and training with ${\sim}800$K unlabeled videos, Flow3r achieves state-of-the-art results across eight benchmarks spanning static and dynamic scenes, with its largest gains on in-the-wild dynamic videos where labeled data is most scarce.

AI.tldr: Flow3r replaces costly dense geometry/pose supervision with dense 2D flow correspondences and a factored flow predictor that disentangles geometry and pose, enabling large-scale training from unlabeled monocular videos and achieving SOTA on 8 static/dynamic benchmarks, with biggest gains on in-the-wild dynamic scenes.
AI.motivation: Dense 3D geometry and camera pose labels are expensive and scarce, especially for dynamic real-world scenes, limiting scalability of current feed-forward 3D/4D reconstruction systems. There is a need for supervision that is abundant and cheap while still guiding geometry and motion learning.
AI.method: Introduce a factored flow supervision: predict optical flow between two frames using geometry latents from one frame and pose latents from the other. This encourages disentanglement of scene geometry and camera motion and naturally handles dynamics. Integrate this factorization into existing visual-geometry networks and train at scale on ~800K unlabeled monocular videos using dense 2D correspondences as the main supervision signal.
AI.result: In controlled ablations, factored flow outperforms alternative designs and exhibits positive data scaling with more unlabeled videos. When integrated into prior architectures and trained on ~800K videos, Flow3r sets new SOTA across eight benchmarks covering static and dynamic scenes, with the largest improvements on in-the-wild dynamic video datasets where labels are scarce.
AI.conclusion: Factoring flow prediction into geometry and pose latents provides an effective, scalable supervision for 3D/4D reconstruction from unlabeled monocular videos, generalizing well to dynamic scenes and yielding SOTA performance. This establishes dense 2D correspondences plus large-scale unlabeled data as a powerful recipe for visual geometry learning.

title: tttLRM: Test-Time Training for Long Context and Autoregressive 3D Reconstruction
comment: Accepted by CVPR 2026. Project Page: https://cwchenwang.github.io/tttLRM
summary: We propose tttLRM, a novel large 3D reconstruction model that leverages a Test-Time Training (TTT) layer to enable long-context, autoregressive 3D reconstruction with linear computational complexity, further scaling the model's capability. Our framework efficiently compresses multiple image observations into the fast weights of the TTT layer, forming an implicit 3D representation in the latent space that can be decoded into various explicit formats, such as Gaussian Splats (GS) for downstream applications. The online learning variant of our model supports progressive 3D reconstruction and refinement from streaming observations. We demonstrate that pretraining on novel view synthesis tasks effectively transfers to explicit 3D modeling, resulting in improved reconstruction quality and faster convergence. Extensive experiments show that our method achieves superior performance in feedforward 3D Gaussian reconstruction compared to state-of-the-art approaches on both objects and scenes.

AI.tldr: tttLRM is a large 3D reconstruction model that uses a test-time training (TTT) layer to compress multi-view inputs into fast weights, enabling long-context, autoregressive, and efficient (linear-time) 3D reconstruction that can be decoded into Gaussian Splats; it outperforms prior feedforward Gaussian reconstruction methods on objects and scenes and benefits from pretraining on novel view synthesis.
AI.motivation: Current 3D reconstruction methods struggle to scale to long input sequences, handle streaming observations efficiently, and bridge pretraining on view synthesis to explicit 3D outputs. Many require heavy optimization, quadratic cost with context length, or lack online refinement. A more scalable, efficient, and transferable approach is needed.
AI.method: Introduce a TTT layer with fast weights that incrementally compress multiple image observations into an implicit latent 3D representation. The model runs autoregressively with linear computational complexity in context length and can decode the latent into explicit representations, notably 3D Gaussian Splatting. An online variant supports progressive reconstruction from streaming inputs. The model is pretrained on novel view synthesis to transfer to explicit 3D modeling.
AI.result: Experiments show superior feedforward 3D Gaussian reconstruction vs. state-of-the-art across both object- and scene-level benchmarks, along with faster convergence and improved quality from NVS pretraining; the online variant progressively refines reconstructions from streams.
AI.conclusion: A TTT-enabled large reconstruction framework scales 3D modeling to long contexts and streaming inputs while remaining efficient, and effectively transfers NVS pretraining to explicit 3D (e.g., Gaussian Splats). This yields better accuracy and convergence than prior feedforward approaches and offers a practical path for progressive, real-time 3D reconstruction.

title: Mobile-O: Unified Multimodal Understanding and Generation on Mobile Device
summary: Unified multimodal models can both understand and generate visual content within a single architecture. Existing models, however, remain data-hungry and too heavy for deployment on edge devices. We present Mobile-O, a compact vision-language-diffusion model that brings unified multimodal intelligence to a mobile device. Its core module, the Mobile Conditioning Projector (MCP), fuses vision-language features with a diffusion generator using depthwise-separable convolutions and layerwise alignment. This design enables efficient cross-modal conditioning with minimal computational cost. Trained on only a few million samples and post-trained in a novel quadruplet format (generation prompt, image, question, answer), Mobile-O jointly enhances both visual understanding and generation capabilities. Despite its efficiency, Mobile-O attains competitive or superior performance compared to other unified models, achieving 74% on GenEval and outperforming Show-O and JanusFlow by 5% and 11%, while running 6x and 11x faster, respectively. For visual understanding, Mobile-O surpasses them by 15.3% and 5.1% averaged across seven benchmarks. Running in only ~3s per 512x512 image on an iPhone, Mobile-O establishes the first practical framework for real-time unified multimodal understanding and generation on edge devices. We hope Mobile-O will ease future research in real-time unified multimodal intelligence running entirely on-device with no cloud dependency. Our code, models, datasets, and mobile application are publicly available at https://amshaker.github.io/Mobile-O/

AI.tldr: Mobile-O is a compact unified vision–language–diffusion model that introduces a Mobile Conditioning Projector to efficiently fuse modalities, enabling near–real-time on-device image understanding and generation with competitive accuracy using only a few million training samples.
AI.motivation: Unified multimodal models are typically data-hungry and computationally heavy, making them impractical for edge/mobile deployment. There is a need for a small, efficient architecture that jointly supports visual understanding and generation entirely on-device.
AI.method: Proposes the Mobile Conditioning Projector (MCP) that fuses vision–language features with a diffusion generator via depthwise-separable convolutions and layerwise alignment for low-cost cross-modal conditioning. Training uses a modest-scale dataset and a novel quadruplet post-training format (generation prompt, image, question, answer) to jointly improve understanding and generation.
AI.result: Mobile-O attains 74% on GenEval and outperforms Show-O and JanusFlow by 5% and 11% while running 6× and 11× faster, respectively. For visual understanding, it surpasses them by 15.3% and 5.1% on average across seven benchmarks. On an iPhone, it generates a 512×512 image in about 3 seconds.
AI.conclusion: Mobile-O demonstrates practical, real-time, unified multimodal understanding and generation on edge devices without cloud dependency, and releases code, models, datasets, and a mobile app to facilitate further research.
